wine.name: Barons de Rothschild, Haut-Médoc, Kosher
wine.review: The Rothschild family is renowned for its impeccable production of elegant red Bordeaux wines. This Kosher bottle is full of dark, juicy cassis fruit on the palate, with a note of fresh tobacco on the finish and solid, approachable tannins.

wine.name: Tavel "Roc-Epine," Dom. Lafond
wine.review: Tavel is a tiny rosé appellation in the southern Rhône Valley. This dry bottling is like a mixed bowl of cherries on the palate, with a subtle note of watermelon and refreshing acidity that make it go well with lots of foods.

wine.name: Ramon Cardova Rioja Kosher
wine.review: This Rioja is very easy to drink with a touch of earthiness and a great tannic structure. Enjoy tonight with your favorite lamb dish.

wine.name: Mâcon-Pierreclos "Chavigne", Guffens-Heynen
wine.review: From a parcel of Chardonnay composed of 80 year old vines as well as some newly-planted ones, the "Chavigne" cuvée is Guffens-Heynen's top wine made partly from free-run and first press juice.

wine.name: Ch. Moulin de Tricot, Haut Médoc
wine.review: Dark berried on the palate with a hint of tobacco. Full-bodied and drinking well today. Best with rich foods or cheeses.

wine.name: Nebbiolo, Produttori del Barbaresco
wine.review: Nebbiolo this good, at this price, is unheard of. Lively earthy berry fruit floats atop fine tannins and great acidity. This Cantina's wines holds up to the producer's excellent reputation.

wine.name: Argyle Pinot Noir, Willamette Valley
wine.review: Rich and fruity Pinot Noir is the focus at this winery from the Willamette Valley in Oregon. Medium-bodied, soft berry fruit and simply great varietal character keeps us coming back for more.

wine.name: Alvear Pedro Ximenez de Añada
wine.review: A rich, viscous Sherry filled with aromas of orange marmalade, toasted almonds, and fine acidity. It shows good sweetness that is nicely balanced.

wine.name: Alvear Fino en Rama
wine.review: Crisp and clean in the mouth with fruit-driven top notes and a core of earthy, nutty aromas. Classic Fino.

wine.name: Alvear Asuncion Oloroso
wine.review: Deep and rich, this amber off-dry Oloroso, made from Pedro Ximenez grapes, is complex and well-executed. Nuts, prunes, caramel, and a hint of chocolate dance on the nose and palate, while the finish is long and smooth.

wine.name: Chianti Classico, Fattoria di Rodano
wine.review: A traditional Chianti Classico with earthy, red cherries and hints of tobacco. Medium-bodied with ample fruit on the palate and excellent structure.

wine.name: Laurent-Perrier Brut
wine.review: Chardonnay, is the dominant grape variety and its proportion is unusually high for a non-vintage champagne blend, being double the average. The blend is made of wines from more than 55 crus or villages and between 10 and 20% of reserve wines are used. Aged on its lees for approximately 3 years and only a very light dosage is used to preserve its balance and natural freshness.

wine.name: Laurent-Perrier, Grand Siècle Cuvée
wine.review: Grand Siècle is a blend of pinot noir and chardonnay, with the latter being slightly dominant. The grapes are supplied by twelve of the most prestigious crus or villages, all of them Grands Crus classified at 100%, such as Ambonnay, Verzenay, Mailly, Avize, Cramant, Chouilly and Le Mesnil-sur-Oger. Within the vineyards of these crus, only the very best plots are selected, as are the finest musts from the pressings. The blended wine is then aged for 6 to 8 years.

wine.name: Laurent-Perrier Brut Cuvée, Rosé
wine.review: A dry rosé Champagne that's incredibly versatile and can be drunk as an apéritif or throughout your meal. It goes incredibly well with countless foods, all the way from roast pork to bouillabaisse.

wine.name: Sagrantino "Collepiano", Caprai
wine.review: This modern Sagrantino is made with plenty of new oak aging and fully-extracted fruit that's aimed to please those who crave this style.

wine.name: Rosso di Montalcino, La Palazzetta
wine.review: La Palazzetta consistently produces extraordinary Tuscan red wines. Made from organically farmed grapes and aged in large Slavonian oak casks, this bottle shows all of Sangiovese's pure, tangy berry character.

wine.name: Villa Maria Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: A great example of New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc with typical ripe tropical-citrus fruit, zippy acidity and smoky, peppery flavors. Enjoy this with well-seasoned chicken, pork or fish dishes, especially if they're a little spicy.

wine.name: Crozes-Hermitage, Graillot
wine.review: Alain Graillot has 20 hectares in the Crozes-Hermitage. He has become one of the most sought after producers of the area, producing wines that are pure and balanced from the Syrah grape. Very small productions.

wine.name: St.-Joseph, Graillot
wine.review: Alain Graillot, one of the top producers in the northern Rhone appellation of Crozes-Hermitage, also produces a minuscule amount of Saint-Joseph from a 1 ½-acre plot of 20-year-old Syrah vines planted in decomposed granite soils. Fermentation takes place in concrete, and the wine is aged for 12 months in 1- to 6-year-old barrels. This has the explosive, vivid, deep, and peppery fruit that characterizes Alain’s wines, but with the unique charm and freshness of a Saint-Joseph.

wine.name: Sagrantino Montefalco "25 Year", Caprai
wine.review: This the Caprai estate's pride and joy. A slick, ultra-modern red wine made from the indigenous Sagrantino grape. Oak-aged to add spice and vanilla on the palate. This full-bodied red wine is full of black fruits - further enhanced by the spectacularly warm vintage.

wine.name: Kanonkop Pinotage, Stellenbosch
wine.review: Pinotage, a cross of Cinsaut and Pinot Noir, thrives in the Stellenbosch region of South Africa. Kanonkop has long been recognized as producing the benchmark for this varietal. Richly fruited with mouth-coating notes of red and black berries in a medium bodied style, this wine has good structure for ageing and avoids the astringency so commonly found with this particular grape variety.

wine.name: Hosmer Dry Riesling, Cayuga Lake
wine.review: This tasty Riesling comes from Hosmer, one of the finest Finger Lakes wineries. This is a dry white wine that boasts all the juicy peach fruit and acidity that we love in this regal grape. In the more marginal climes of upstate New York, this white variety does very well.

wine.name: Hosmer Cabernet Franc
wine.review: The Finger Lakes wine region in upstate New York is home to some fine reds. This Cabernet Franc is a delicious example: full of dark berried fruits - blackberries and blueberries - it finishes fresh and lightly tannic. Works well with aged cheeses and grilled meats.

wine.name: Moët Brut Rosé
wine.review: If you're looking for a stylish rosé Champagne that will look just right at your next party, you've found your match.

wine.name: Veuve Clicquot, La Grande Dame
wine.review: The top cuvée from Veuve Clicquot; rich, complex and flavorful, but very, very elegant. This is what great Champagne is all about! 64% Pinot Noir grapes, 36% Chardonnay grapes.

wine.name: Vouvray Brut, Dom. des Aubuisières
wine.review: Aubuisières has captured Chenin Blanc's richer side in this intensely ripe rendition. A sparkling wine that's full of tropical fruit and custard flavors, yet quite dry with a minerally finish due to Chenin's high natural acidity. Match with rich shellfish or poultry.

wine.name: Apremont, Pierre Boniface
wine.review: This is one of those incredibly fruit-forward dry whites that seem almost too good to be true. Produced in a tiny sub-region called Apremont in the easternmost part of France known as the Savoie, it is fresh, easy-drinking, and always a crowd favorite when lightly chilled.

wine.name: Solo Reggiano, Medici Ermete
wine.review: A delicious dry frizzante made of Lambrusco. Redolent of blackberry with a hint of earth and ripe tannins, it excels with pizza, salami, or any hearty Italian fare.

wine.name: Erbaluce "Cariola," Ferrando
wine.review: The "Cariola" is a medium-bodied, fragrant, still white wine from Caluso in northern Piedmont. Made from Erbaluce, an indigenous white grape variety, this has ripe, white floral aromas that lead to a very lovely mineral finish.

wine.name: Pinot Grigio, Bruno Verdi
wine.review: An amazingly fruit-driven Pinot Grigio boasting dense stone fruit, silky rich texture and minerals on the palate. Gives Pinot Grigio a new meaning and that's because it comes from the Oltrepo Pavese region of Lombardia.

wine.name: Schneider Cabernet Franc "Le Breton"
wine.review: Schneider's excellent Cabernet Franc shows distinct varietal character, filling the palate with fresh raspberry and redcurrant aromas. Made in a lighter style, it is meant to be consumed young. Tonight, for example - tonight would be great.

wine.name: Wyatt Chardonnay
wine.review: A very nicely balanced wine: perfectly ripe tropical fruit flavors, with just a hint of oak at the fringes, are buoyed by clean, fresh, perfect acidity. Choose this wine if you need something to set the mood for a light dinner.

wine.name: Wyatt Pinot Noir
wine.review: A wonderfully lush, fruit-driven Pinot Noir, full and round on the palate and finishing well. It drinks well on its own and is easy to match with meat, chicken, and even some fish dishes.

wine.name: Seresin, Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: A very good example of New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc, with more complexity, and greater length than the norm. Hand-harvesting, careful selection, and blending in 8% of Semillon makes the difference

wine.name: Rosso di Montalcino, Mastrojanni
wine.review: Mastrojanni's wines are elegant in style and show the true character of traditional Tuscan wines. This Sangiovese shows violets, tobacco, and red cherry fruit on the palate with a distinct clay mineral note on the finish.

wine.name: Heitz Grignolino, Napa
wine.review: A color like few others, this new-world Grignolino is a beautiful coppery pink. Dry and crisp, the fruit characteristics sing with orange blossoms, raspberries and strawberries and light floral notes.

wine.name: Cuvée Granit VdP, Dom. de la Pepière
wine.review: A light and refreshing red wine with purity of fruit, strawberry and currant, accents of spice and fine minerality.

wine.name: Cour-Cheverny "Cuvée Renaissance", Cazin
wine.review: Late harvest Romorantin, off-dry with delicate raw honey, floral and linden notes, and great vibrant acidity that carries the flavors through a long finish.

wine.name: Chablis "Dom. Ste. Claire," JM Brocard
wine.review: This Chardonnay is delicious and crisp in its youth. The Brocard estate is dedicated to creating classic Chablis from prime sites. Although this is their introductory Chablis, it's a true representation of the high quality this estate pursues.

wine.name: Tokaji "Mandolas", Oremus
wine.review: A crisp, dry Furmint. Floral aromas, green apple, spice and a hint of smoke. Great structure will allow this wine to transform into something great with sufficient age but drink it today when you’re looking for an aromatic, refreshing white wine.

wine.name: Heitz Cellar Cabernet Sauvignon, Bella Oaks
wine.review: Bella Oaks Vineyard is a prestigious sliver of 18 lush acres in the heart of the distinguished Rutherford growing district. Positioned on the west side of the valley where the soil is wonderfully rich and well-drained, the vines revel in the sun's rays all day long resulting in plump berries that ripen a bit earlier in the season. This Cabernet has the most finesse of all the Heitz single vineyard Cabernets.

wine.name: Ch. Ste. Michelle Dry Riesling
wine.review: Finally available in the east coast for the first time. Crisp, dry and refreshing with an ellegant finish. Pair with Asian dishers or shrimp.

wine.name: Dragonstone Riesling, Leitz
wine.review: Ripe aromas of stone fruits abound with good acidity and a nice finish. Try this as an apéritif or simply to cleanse your palate any time. No matter what the vintage, Leitz always expresses it.

wine.name: Torrontes "Crios," Susana Balbo
wine.review: Exotic, aromatic, rich, complex, and deep, this wine shows a surprising side of Torrontés. Beautiful floral notes are accompanied by honeysuckle, citrus and apple aromas, and are followed up by impressive balance and great length. This white goes perfectly with rich, saucy seafood dishes.

wine.name: Côtes du Rhône, Dom. des Bacchantes
wine.review: This is a delicious Syrah-based red blend, with some Mourvèdre and Grenache as well. It comes from chalky, clay-based soils and boasts dark, spicy fruit on the palate. A real bargain if you're looking for high-quality Côtes du Rhône with character. Organic, too.

wine.name: Ch. de Bonhoste, Bordeaux Blanc
wine.review: Light, crisp, and clean, showing an impressive balance of fruit flavor. This is a great white for sipping with any light cuisine; it goes especially well with fish.

wine.name: Nero Bufaleffi, Gulfi
wine.review: This is made from the Sicilian red grape Nero d'Avola. It comes from a limestone-based vineyard around Pachino in the Val di Noto region of Sicily. This is a full-bodied, chocolatey red wine with a complex mix of black berries, vanilla, and mineral-driven tannins. It is always a favorite wine at the dinner table. This unfiltered bottling should be decanted to aerate the wine and separate the sediment.

wine.name: Kim Crawford Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: This white shows lush tropical fruit aromas with key lime and a touch of green bell pepper. The round fruit is evenly balanced with good acidity on the palate to keep everything fresh.

wine.name: Bianchetta Ü Pastine, Bisson
wine.review: A dry white wine from the rare Bianchetta grape variety, this absolutely bursts with vibrant white peach flavors and firm mineral character. Born near the sea, it naturally pairs well with foods from the sea.

wine.name: Cape Mentelle Cabernet/Merlot
wine.review: An elegant blend from the Margaret River in Western Australia. Dark fruit plays off of winter spice undertones on the nose, leading to a rich and varied palate impression; most salient are chocolate, cassis, and spice box flavors. Well structured, with a lively touch of tannins and an impressive finish.

wine.name: Mt. Difficulty Pinot Noir
wine.review: Medium bodied and fruit-forward, this New World Pinot Noir is a delight to drink. Find raspberries and blackberries on the palate with notes of savoury dried herb and white pepper. The tannins are smooth and silky on the finish.

wine.name: Chablis "Les Serres", Dom. Oudin
wine.review: The “Les Serres” parcel of land is full of chalk soils and minerals, which end up defining this Chardonnay. It’s very steely and youthful on the palate, with citrus fruits and honey. This wine is vinified and fermented in tanks without the use of any sulfites; it’s also completely unoaked.

wine.name: Montefalco Rosso "Pipparello", Paolo Bea
wine.review: Aromas of red and black currants, plums and dark chocolate. Inviting earthy tannins and finely balanced acidity. Decant and enjoy today or hold another 10 years plus if you're patient.

wine.name: Ribolla Gialla, Dorigo
wine.review: A white wine from the fascinating wine region of Friuli, made from the Ribolla Gialla grape. Floral and exotic, with good acidity to liven the senses, this is delicious with seafood, chicken, and other delicate dishes.

wine.name: New York Malmsey Madeira, Barbeito
wine.review: Recreating the style of Malmsey Madeira that was all the rage in New York, oh, about two hundred years ago. This is part of a special historic series newly developed by The Rare Wine Company. Nutty aromas: almonds, hazelnuts and exemplary acidity.

wine.name: Boston Bual Special Reserve, Barbeito
wine.review: This is the complex and elegant style of Madeira relished among Bostonians in the early days of the Republic. It's moderate in sweetness with great tangy flavor. This is part of a historic series newly developed by The Rare Wine Company.

wine.name: Barolo "Villero", Brovia
wine.review: The Villero is a heavier, denser Barolo from Brovia that is nicely nuanced. It has a fine minerality, along with delicate aromas of roses, red berries, and hazelnuts. All in all a very impressive Nebbiolo.

wine.name: Corbières "Fontanilles", Dom. des Deux Anes
wine.review: This Corbières is dark, rich and smoky, with fine tannins giving it excellent structure and an impressive presence on the palate. It is aged in tank only - no oak barrels. Biodynamic.

wine.name: Petite Arvine, Les Cretes
wine.review: From northwest Italy comes this Petite Arvine. Honeyed notes with aromas of fennel and lemon. A fine streak of mineral and acidity give this wine freshness and longevity.

wine.name: Derthona Timorasso, Vignetti Massa
wine.review: An unoaked white wine made of the rare local Timorasso grape variety. Walter Massa is one of the few winemakers who grow this indigenous white. Pure white flowers on the nose, with notes of lilacs and yellow plums. Dry on the palate with lithe minerals and a slightly spicy, clean, white-peppercorn character. This white is a bit like a Pinot Bianco married to a Chardonnay from the Côte de Beaune.

wine.name: Chianti Classico, Castello di Cacchiano
wine.review: The Castello di Cacchiano produces some of the best Chianti Classico made in a traditional style. This is quite elegant, a wine that favors finesse over power, and which will work very nicely with red meats off the grill.

wine.name: McManis Family Syrah, River Junction
wine.review: Soft and fleshy, with ripe tannins, complex flavors of blackberry and cherry, and just a touch of cedar and smoke. This red screams for black pepper-crusted pork loin.

wine.name: Hamilton Russell Pinot Noir
wine.review: Hamilton Russell Vineyards concentrates on only two grape varieties - Chardonnay and Pinot Noir - because they believe these are best suited for the terroir of Walker Bay, South Africa. It's ruby in color, with aromas of cherries and warm “winter” spices like vanilla and cinnamon.

wine.name: Ridge Three Valleys, Sonoma County
wine.review: Ridge's Three Valleys bottling is a field blend, consisting mainly of Zinfandel. It's a hearty, full-bodied red wine, dense with black fruit and chocolatey tannins.

wine.name: Layla Pinot Noir, Kosher
wine.review: This is a very llight styled Pinot that would work well with poultry or even fish.

wine.name: Excelsior Chardonnay
wine.review: A medium-bodied Chardonnay with a pale golden color, fruity aromas, and floral honey notes to round out the apple and lemon-lime flavors. With its creamy texture, this would be perfect with a dish like shrimp étouffée.

wine.name: Vino Nobile di Montelpulciano, Bindella
wine.review: CO. A lovely combination of plum aromas, leather, tobacco and a bit of earth. This red spends just a bit of time in oak adding a modern touch yet preserving the aromas of the grapes we cherish. Enjoy with rich fare. Will benefit from air.

wine.name: Erbaluce Spumante "Cuvée del Fondatore", Ferrando
wine.review: Everybody should be drinking Erbaluce these days. We offer many but here we have the dry, sparkling version. Yellow apples, acacia and brioche aromas with a mineral edge and lively acidity.

wine.name: Trittenheimer Apotheke Riesling Kabinett, Clüsserath
wine.review: Racy with a distinct green apple note alongside white peach aromas. Most notable on this Riesling is the mineral backbone that comes from the slatey soils of the Saar region of Germany. This wine will keep for many years to come.

wine.name: Trittenheim Apotheke Riesling Spätlese, Clüsserath
wine.review: A bit of botrytis adds richness and complexity without diminishing the clarity, nor covering the minerality in the least. The mineral seems to carry the fruit.

wine.name: Meddersheim Rheingrafen "Quarzit" Riesling, Hexamer
wine.review: QbA from a parcel on quartzite, this is big-boned stony mineral wine, forward and overt.

wine.name: Kim Crawford Pinot Noir
wine.review: Flavors of cherry and wild strawberry, silky tannins, and a light kiss of oak all hang in perfect balance here, and the finish lingers. Another in a string of tremendous efforts from one of the most talented Pinot Noir producers in New Zealand.

wine.name: Castelnau de Suduiraut, Sauternes
wine.review: The second wine of Château Suduiraut, one of the best producers of this beautiful dessert wine.

wine.name: Château-Grillet
wine.review: Château Grillet is much like a Condrieu, but an appellation unto itself, Château Grillet is one of the finest and most sought after Viognier wines in the world.

wine.name: Shooting Star Blue Franc
wine.review: Great color, medium body, dense, rich velvety fruit. It is delicious and ready for enjoyment.

wine.name: Grüner Veltliner "Hefeabzug", Nikolaihof
wine.review: B. Hefeabzug means aged on the lees. This is Grüner Veltliner as Muscadet - with crisp, salty minerality, just with bigger bones, and more spice.

wine.name: Banrock Station Shiraz Bag in Box
"Butterfly" Estate Riesling HT, Zilliken
wine.review: You can't go wrong with this whimsical Riesling from producer Zilliken. It's off-dry, fruity on the palate with citrus and fresh peach fruit aromas. This is from the sub-region of the Mosel called the "Saar". In our books, Zilliken makes the finest Saar wines around. You won't be disappointed any of the wines in their entire lineup.

wine.name: Saumur Brut, Cousin-Leduc
wine.review: B. A sparkling blend of Chenin Blanc and Chardonnay coming from just outside of the Layon. A delicious, dry white wine with warm apple fruit aromas, yellow plums, a touch of smoke and a delicate bead to finish. Drink with a light chill. Organic.

wine.name: Vin de Table Nature "Chapeau Melon", Dom. de la Sénéchalière
wine.review: From the Nantes region of the Loire comes this white wine made from the Melon de Bourgogne variety. Had this juice been held for another half year at the winery, it would be a Muscadet, for Marc Pesnot chooses to hold his Muscadet for at least 18 months before release. This is a novelty, basically Muscadet before it's deemed Muscadet by the producer. It's fresh, just out of the cellar with aromas of ripe lemons and vivid minerality thanks to the schist soils. Decant and enjoy. Unfiltered.

wine.name: Côtes-du-Rhône "Sagesse", Gramenon
wine.review: Gramenon is located in the northern reaches of the southern Rhône. The vineyards are planted to old vines and Michelle Aubry-Laurent owns some of the best vineyard sights in the region. This 100% Grenache, aged partially in oak, is rich, meaty, and balanced.

wine.name: Anjou Rouge "Les Copines Aussi", Sablonettes
wine.review: A light and fruity red wine made from the Gamay grape by a natural winemaker. It's light-bodied with red cherry and currant fruit on the palate.

wine.name: Moscato, Gatti
wine.review: If you're dining at home solo why not pop this half bottle open for dessert? Luscious, lightly sweet, lightly sparkling with notes of acacia and honey. If you're feeling altruistic this bottle could be shared two ways...

wine.name: Sammarco, Castello dei Rampolla
wine.review: Aromas of tobacco leaves, blackcurrants and cherries dominate the palate. A full-bodied red with solid tannic structure to carry this wine through the ages.

wine.name: Spumante, Giacosa
wine.review: A rich, toasty white sparkling wine from a producer whose wines speak for themselves. Aromas of freshly baked brioche, rhubarb and strawberries rounded off by a lengthy finish.

wine.name: Gravonia Rioja Blanco, Lopez de Heredia
wine.review: This is the newly released vintage of Lopez de Heredia's "young" white wine. In the flush of youth, it is ready to drink, but of course shows the complexity of the slow, gentle aging process this house is famous for.

wine.name: Guy Larmandier, Grand Cru Cramant, Blanc de Blancs
wine.review: Endlessly satisfying, with great finesse, excellent balance, and complex notes of minerals, white flowers, honey, citrus, and apple in a sublime composition.

wine.name: Dom Pérignon "Oenothèque"
wine.review: This is the latest release of Oenothèque. It is a youthful Champagne, light in color, rich and honeyed on the nose. Honeyed lemon on the palate, with toasted brioche, leads to intense, cyrstalline minerality.

wine.name: Barbeito Malvazia Madeira
wine.review: This vintage bottling of Malvazia, also known as Malmsey, offers seemless notes of thyme, toasted almonds, lemon and lime aromas. The acidity, fruit and sweetness are finely tuned with perfect balance.

wine.name: Sincerely Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: Crisp and fresh, with aromas of white flowers, white currants, and lime. This is delicious as an apéritif, but even better with seafood or a grilled chicken salad.

wine.name: Henri Billiot "Cuvée Laetitia" Brut
wine.review: A solera-style blend that was started in the year Laetitia was born. A wine of great pride for Henri, his best selection, his one Chardonnay-based wine.

wine.name: Cabernet Franc Ice Wine, Inniskillin
wine.review: Consider this a rare opportunity to try Cabernet Franc as an ice wine. This is rich and complex with concentrated aromas of eucalyptus, strawberries, cranberries, spices and herbs. Taste fine winemaking from our neighbors to the north.

wine.name: Oracle Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: Lately we're finding that South African wine is nearly unbeatable when you're looking for value and top quality at all levels. Drink this crisp white as an apéritif wine to whet your appetite, or enjoy it throughout a seafood dinner. It's unoaked, refreshing on the palate, and driven by citrus fruit flavors.

wine.name: Steenberg Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: Made from a Loire Valley Sauvignon Blanc clone, this South African white tastes of tropical fruit and citrus, and it has slight grassy notes. Dry and crisp with loads of minerality and a long finish, Steenberg's fresh white wine is great with shrimp cocktail.

wine.name: Valpolicella, Le Ragose
wine.review: A deeply colored wine of voluptuous aromatics, like freshly macerated black cherries, violets, and red peppercorns. With focused fruit and mouthwatering acidity, this is a perfect accompaniment to your next rich meal.

wine.name: Aglianico del Taburno, Ocone
wine.review: (B) Ocone's commitment to biodynamic viticulture shows in this fine bottle of Aglianico. Along with firm tannins, the aromas of rhubarb and ripe cherries make this a bottle of red wine for the ages. Decant today or hold for another decade plus.

wine.name: Bourgeuil "Nuits d'Ivresse", Breton
wine.review: An assemblage from his best parcels, this is Pierre's most ambitious wine. Always striving for absolute purity of fruit in this wine. He has achieved a stunning result.

wine.name: Peju Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Chocolate and fleeting eucalyptus aromas show up on this brilliant Napa Cabernet. Dark stone fruits and spice flavors on the palate lead to a well-structured finish. This is an outstanding red wine that could age beautifully for years.

wine.name: Recanati Chardonnay, Galilee
wine.review: Terrific varietal expression of Chardonnay, with just the right balance of great fruit flavors, fine acidity.

wine.name: Tio Pepe Kosher Sherry
wine.review: Shows notes of green apples, almonds, and freshly baked bread, with a slight saline quality and a long, dry, reassuring finish.

wine.name: Estancia Pinot Grigio
wine.review: Medium-bodied and crisp, with flavors of pear and yellow fruit and the faintest suggestion of white pepper on the finish. California has proven itself to be a perfect home for Pinot Grigio – like so many other grapes – and started to turn out incredible examples like this one.

wine.name: Chassagne-Montrachet Blanc, "La Bergerie", Jean-Marc Morey
wine.review: This is Jean-Marc Morey's basic village Chassagne-Montrachet. This Chardonnay is full of white apple fruit character with raw honey and mineral on the finish. Excellent finesse from a traditional producer whose wines thrive with years of age.

wine.name: Herzog Late Harvest Chenin Blanc
wine.review: Delightfully fresh with vibrant fruit flavors, lively acidity, and just enough sweetness to freshen up the palate. This is great as an aperitif, as an accompaniment to richer dishes, or on its own after dinner.

wine.name: Monastrell, Castillo del Barón
wine.review: This Monastrell comes from the high-altitude vineyards of Yecla, a region in southeastern Spain. Low yields create a richly concentrated and well-structured red wine. Notes of mocha, plum, and black cherry burst from the glass.

wine.name: Falanghina del Taburno, Ocone
wine.review: Falanghina is one of Italy's most ancient varieties. We were excited when we discovered this biodynamically farmed dry, crisp white wine from Campania. Floral notes balance flavors of peach and orange peel, along with a great minerality derived from Campania's volcanic soil.

wine.name: Castle Rock Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: A bold Cabernet Sauvignon with great plushness on the palate, minty, herbal notes on the nose, and a luxurious mouthfeel. Made in the Alexander Valley, this is a satisfying and pleasing example of classic California winemaking.

wine.name: Morgon "Côte du Py", Foillard
wine.review: Coming from Morgon's famous hillside vineyard of the Côte du Py, widely considered to produce superior wines, this Morgon possesses sweet black fruit notes while an ethereal body keeps it light and silky on the palate. Jean Foillard produces beautiful, delicate wine year after year.

wine.name: Ch. Gruaud Larose, St. Julien
wine.review: This is a great Bordeaux showing intense, smoky, mineral-laced blackcurrant fruit on the nose, with real depth of aroma. The palate is rich, tannic and full of concentration of primary fruits. There's great potential here for the cellar.

wine.name: Clos des Lambrays GC, Dom. des Lambrays
wine.review: This vintage is the most true to terroir, and with the best long-term aging, will flourish. The value is incomparable among Grand Cru red Burgundy. On the palate, it's showing earth and game notes. One of those Pinot Noirs that makes traditional palates weep with joy.

wine.name: Chevalier-Montrachet, Pillot
wine.review: Burgundian Chardonnay for the ages. Rich, floral, with cream and citrus on the palate. Exuberant at the moment but will flourish with time.

wine.name: Pouilly-Fumé "Pur Sang", Dagueneau
wine.review: The wines of Dider Dagueneau are unrivalled in the world of Sauvignon Blanc. Sadly, this is Didier's last vintage. Due to his choice to age in old oak, Dagueneau's wines take on a creaminess as well as an ability to age that is unusual for the region. The "Pur Sang" is as beautiful as the "Silex" but with less emphasis on smoky minerality.

wine.name: Chiroubles, C. Pacalet
wine.review: A wine of character with distinct terroir. It has an earthy edge, but it’s the fruit that shines here: ripe raspberries, orange rind, cherry, and a touch of musk. Very fresh and very pretty, yet maintaining a mien of rusticity, the wine is produced organically, with no sulfur added.

wine.name: Arneis, Funtanin
wine.review: A light-bodied and dry white wine with aromas of pears, melon, almonds and honey. Made from the Arneis grape variety, this comes from Piedmont in northwest Italy. Excellent with seafood dishes like fish soup.

wine.name: Nero d'Avola, Case Ibidini, Valle dell'Acate
wine.review: This delicious red wine is made from Nero d’Avola grapes grown in the Ragusa region of southeastern Sicily. Aromas of fresh raspberries lead to a hint of cocoa on the finish. This is a clean, easy-drinking red to enjoy every day.

wine.name: Ch. Kefraya, La Dame Blanche
wine.review: A Lebanese white wine that's fruity with aromas of peaches and dried apricots. Dry yet fruit forward. Works wonders with Lebanese cuisine: sautéed dandelion greens, tabouli, hummus, olives and hard cheeses.

wine.name: Pinot Noir, Puffeney
wine.review: Jacques Puffeney makes this Pinot Noir on a tiny plot of land in the Arbois. On the palate you'll find brilliant dark cherry and rhubarb fruit, followed by a subtle mineral finish with a bit of clove. All Pinot Noir character is perfectly preserved.

wine.name: Vin Jaune, Puffeney
wine.review: This gem of a wine is made from the Savagnin grape variety. The atypical aging process adds a delightful intentionally oxidized character to this dry white. Rich aromas of hazelnuts, walnuts and preserved lemons. Enjoy with Comté today or, hold for decades.

wine.name: Pouilly-Fumé "Porcheronnes", Deschamps
wine.review: Sauvignon Blanc from the Loire Valley with mineral driven chalky character along with notes of pineapple and grapefruits. Dry and refreshing with a lovely floral character on the finish.

wine.name: St.-Aubin Rouge "Argillers", Prudhon
wine.review: Gerard Prudhon's winery in the tiny village of St.-Aubin continues to produce outstanding wines at modest prices. This Pinot Noir is none other than elegant with delightful raspberries and minerals. Enjoy the benefits from this value-driven appellation.

wine.name: Ch. Belregard "Tellus Vinea"
wine.review: An everyday red wine from Château Belregard. Medium-bodied with upfront earthy fruit, red cherries and currants. Delicious and drinking well today.

wine.name: Carricante/Carjcanti, Gulfi
wine.review: Carricante, a white variety native to Mount Etna, also thrives in the Monte Iblei area of southeastern Sicily. Though truly a wine of finesse, this has a strong and robust structure, with notes of grapefruit, almonds, and chalky minerality on the palate. Decant and enjoy this today or hold it for up to a decade. From a Practicing Organic winemaker.

wine.name: Valpolicella, Trabucchi
wine.review: This Valpolicella has excellent character with complexities rarely found at such a reasonable price. Aromas of violets, thyme and clove along with blackberry fruit make this a red wine well worth trying alongside aged cheeses, salami and more.

wine.name: L. Aubry Fils Rosé Brut
wine.review: A subtle Rosé with a beautiful bronze hue. Great on the palate with fresh acidity and all around cherry aromas, white, yellow and red cherries. Drink just with a light chill.

wine.name: Amarone, Corte Sant'Alda
wine.review: This Amarone hits the spot when you're in the mood for a rich red wine. Dry yet very giving on the palate, with aromas of blackberries, fresh prunes and dark chocolate, it is a surefire crowd-pleaser.

wine.name: Clos du Tue Boeuf Blanc, "Le Buisson Pouilleux"
wine.review: Old vines Sauvignon Blanc. Ripe and earthy on the palate with aromas of yellow plums, currants and a touch of menthol. Drink with a light chill.

wine.name: Vilmart "Grand Cellier d'Or" Brut
wine.review: (B) This vintage Champagne is based on Chardonnay. It's partially fermented in foudre and barrique and exudes a richness unlike many other Champagnes. A gorgeous wine with irises, peaches and apples on the palate. It's a rich Champagne and is always food friendly.

wine.name: Chablis, Dampt
wine.review: A steely Chablis with firm citrus fruit character and a mineral driven backbone that keeps you coming back for more.

wine.name: Chartogne-Taillet "Cuvée St. Anne"
wine.review: Using older wines as a base, the Chartogne-Taillet is integrated and silky, reminiscent of older champagnes. Notes of shitake mushroom, butter, and brioche fill the nose, while crisp green apple awakens the palate. This champagne is made mostly with Pinot Noir.

wine.name: Bandol, Dom. la Souffrene
wine.review: A rich red wine made from a blend of Mourvèdre, Cinsault and Carignan. Aromas of blackberries, black cherries and a note of cedar.

wine.name: Echeverria Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: From the Curico Valley of Chile comes this rich Cabernet Sauvignon. Pretty blackberry and red cherry fruits greet the nose, and there is a touch of mint on the finish.

wine.name: Muscadet "Cuvée Classique", Guy Bossard
wine.review: This Muscadet from Guy Bossard has all the telltale signs of honest winemaking. It's a mineral-driven white with distinct citrus fruit and fresh white flowers. Organic since 1975. Fully Biodynamic as of 1996.

wine.name: Sancerre, S. Laloue
wine.review: A firm, dry and minerally Sauvignon Blanc from Sancerre. Treat yourself to this delicious half bottle anytime.

wine.name: Outis (Nessuno), Biondi
wine.review: A beautiful red wine from Mount Etna in Sicily, made from a blend of the native Nerello Mascalese and Nerello Cappuccio grape varieties. On the palate you'll find fascinating, delicate notes of tobacco, red currants, red pepper, and anise.

wine.name: Fidenzio, Podere San Luigi
wine.review: A formidable Cabernet Sauvignon-based red coming from the area of Fidenzio in Tuscany. Delicate aromas of cassis, anise seed and lavender. A fresh red with clean, elegant, honest aromas.

wine.name: Pian del Ciampolo, Montevertine
wine.review: Montevertine's Pian del Ciampolo bottling is made for earlier drinking. This is a delightfully lithe and light style of Sangiovese, with fresh red cherry fruit aromas, notes of red currants and anise. With its perfectly lively fruit, balanced out by earthy tannins, this is what Sangiovese should always taste like.

wine.name: Amaroo Shiraz
wine.review: With blackberry fruit and a spicy finish, this Shiraz will go with everything from a summer barbecue to lighter fare. It's friendly enough to please a crowd, yet complex enough to reward repeated tastings; try it alongside a few different cuisines to see how it changes with food.

wine.name: Huia Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: Gooseberry, tropical fruit, and lime notes abound in this textbook New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc. A classic wine calls for a classic pairing, so try it with shellfish for a phenomenal experience.

wine.name: Ballentine Napa Zinfandel
wine.review: We were very excited when we found this Zinfandel. This winery takes care to find a true expression of the grape variety, using careful practices in both the cellar and the vineyard. Richly textured fruit and good balance abound in this wonderfully priced California Zin. Well done!

wine.name: Tenuta Beltrame, Tocai Friulano
wine.review: This northern Italian white is clean and fresh on the palate, with aromas of honey, freshly cut grass and a touch of eucalyptus. It's a bottle you can enjoy every day with light meats and seafood dishes.

wine.name: Ribolla Gialla, La Castellada
wine.review: La Castellada works in the vineyard and the cellar with organic practices. This Ribolla Gialla is earthy with aromas of yellow fruit, yellow plums, grapefruit & mocha. A dry white wine with complex earthy notes and even a touch of herbs. Do not overchill.

wine.name: Charleston Sercial Madeira, The Rare Wine Company
wine.review: Charleston Sercial celebrates the refined, delicate Madeiras that the 18th- and 19th-century Charlestonians prized. Like any great Sercial, this miraculously balances power and delicacy. With its nutty, tangy flavors, it is not only a wonderful apéritif, it's also great with many foods.

wine.name: Txakolina, Ameztoi
wine.review: Drinking this Basque wine is a lot easier than saying the names of the grapes in it: Hondarribi Zurri and Hondarribi Beltza. Dry and light-bodied with mineral-driven fruit and aromas of grapefruit and lemon, it is a perfect wine for seafood.

wine.name: Agrapart, Blanc de Blancs Brut
wine.review: Today, brothers Fabrice and Pascal Agrapart continue to run their family winery that has exisited in the town of Avize for over a 100 years. Most of their Chardonnay vines are over 40 years old. This Champagne is dry and mineral driven with fruit of apples, ripe lemons and white tea on the palate. Drinks very well today and always a partner for seafood cuisine.

wine.name: Camille Savès Carte Blanche Brut 1er Cru
wine.review: Based on Pinot Noir with the remainder being Chardonnay. Aromas of smoke and strawberries dominate the palate of the rich Champagne from the village of Bouzy. Just delicious and a fine companion throughout a meal.

wine.name: "Agamium" Colline Novaresi, Cantalupo
wine.review: The wonders of Nebbiolo from such a thoughtful producer as Cantalupo keep us coming back for more. This bottle is full of dusty roses and cherries. Decant and enjoy today or feel free to hold for a few years.

wine.name: Dolcetto d'Alba, Cascina Morassino
wine.review: This bottle of Dolcetto is just right when you're craving a red with upfront fruit, black cherries and blackberries and a touch of dried thyme. Delcious and satisfying and even better with food.

wine.name: Côtes-du-Rhône Syrah, D'Andezon
wine.review: The organic farm of D'Andezon is blanketed with large, round stones like those in found in Chateauneuf du Pape. This 100% Syrah from old vines is dense, meaty, and bursting with dark, lush, berry fruit.

wine.name: Picpoul de Pinet "Gaujal de St. Bon," Gaujal
wine.review: An exciting and unusual white wine made in southwest France from the Picpoul Blanc grape. Light and dry, this has lemony aromas, raw honey flavors on the palate, and even a nice little kick of mineral on the finish. The Mediterranean climate of this appellation gives its wines plenty of acidity, and this one goes well with a huge range of foods. It's tasty on its own, too.

wine.name: Powers Syrah, Washington
wine.review: Washington states cooler climates have proven to be ideal for Syrah and this wine is no exception. Bursting with crisp fruit and classic notes of blackberry, blueberry, smoke, and pepper. This a rich, mouthfilling Syrah that has a gentle structure that allows it to be very food flexible and is sure to make it a real crowd pleaser.

wine.name: Artazu Artazuri Garnacha
wine.review: This is 100% Garnacha from the northernmost reaches of Spain. Spiciness prevails on the first sip, while dark fruit flavors and velvet tannins round out the finish. A great value from the up-and-coming region of Navarra.

wine.name: Sangiovese di Romagna, Poderi dal Nespoli
wine.review: This red wine is made from the Sangiovese grape grown in the hills of Romagna in the northern part of Italy. Dense with cherry fruit, black and red, with a touch of clay mineral on the finish. A pure wine that's simply delicious today.

wine.name: Melville Estate Chardonnay
wine.review: Melville is owned by father and son Ron and Chad Melville, with Greg Brewer as their winemaker. After owning several vineyards in Napa, Ron Melville came to Santa Rita and never looked back. The microclimate of the Santa Rita Hills appellation, which is characterized by cool temperatures, prominent coastal winds, and foggy mornings, is well suited to growing the grapes of Burgundy. This Chardonnay offers aromas of toast, white peaches, and grapefruit. It is refreshingly bright and carries a lengthy finish.

wine.name: Grignolino, Cascina Tavijn
wine.review: Grignolino is a rare red Italian grape, and it's simply a fun wine to drink with food. This bottle has loads of red cherry fruit to it. It's dry and pale red in color and works wonders with antipasti.

wine.name: Melville Pinot Noir Estate
wine.review: This estate, located in the Santa Rita Hills area of California, has a cool maritime climate that is perfect for growing pinot noir. Black cherry and dark plum flavors surround notes of earth and spice, while the luscious and velvety texture fills your mouth.

wine.name: Quinta do Infantado, White Port
wine.review: White port is a more rare type of this fortified wine. In fact, the color is more amber than white. This one i sstill showing lots of nut-driven character that reminds us of a lighter-style Madeira. The fruit is fresh as well, and full of citrus and almonds. This is on the dry side, but still has a touch of residual sugar.

wine.name: Auratus, Alvarinho-Trajadura
wine.review: A blend of Alvarinho and Trajadura, Auratus is a Portuguese white that goes beyond your traditional Vinho Verde. Very clean and fresh, this has notes of honey and ripe apples, with vivid acidity and mineral notes.

wine.name: Torremuga Muga
wine.review: Made from the local varieties of Tempranillo, Graciano, and Mazuelo, the Torremuga is one of Muga's most powerful reds. This wine shows elegance and finesse, with notes of roasted coffee bean, dark chocolate, and dried fruit. Muga remains one of the oldest family run estates in Rioja.

wine.name: Prosecco "Bellenda" Brut
wine.review: This is a dry bubbly from the north of Italy. It has such pretty character with white floral aromas and a touch of chalky minerality on the finish. You'll be hooked before you know it.

wine.name: Cannonau di Sardegna "Le Bombarde"
wine.review: Cannonau is the grape variety known as Grenache in other parts of the world. “Le Bombarde” is a rich red wine from Sardinia that is overflowing with fruit character: plums, red berries, and prunes. It’s rich and delightful and it beautifully sets off all sorts of decadent, meaty cuisines.

wine.name: Recioto, Trabucchi
wine.review: A dessert wine that's red, a touch sweet and still has all the complexities of a fine rich red wine. Aromas of violets, fresh thyme, delicious blackberries and pepper. Wow is what you'll say on this fine selection. Your drinking self-discipline will be challenged.

wine.name: Nieddera Rosso, Contini
wine.review: This beautiful red wine from the island of Sardinia is smooth and rich. Notes of violets, black cherries, orange peel, and mocha blend together perfectly. This vintage is especially ripe and gives the wine an extra dose of richness.

wine.name: Lieb Cellars Pinot Blanc
wine.review: Located on the North Fork of Long Island, Lieb Cellars is a family run winery making limited production wine. This Pinot Blanc is their signature wine. Made with only first press or free-run juice and fermented in stainless steel, this white wine displays notes of white peaches, tangerine and pear surrounding a mineral core. This wine is excellent with shellfish and is a great Chardonnay alternative.

wine.name: Sileni Pinot Noir
wine.review: This Pinot spends a bit of time in wood - this is noticeable on the palate in the form of round vanilla flavors. It also has loads of red cherry fruit aromas with a touch of dill. A solid red wine that represents the fruit-forward style of New World Pinot Noir so well.

wine.name: Ch. Noaillac, Médoc
wine.review: Notes of red currant and cassis with a touch of rosemary on the finish. The firm fruit structure makes this a great candidate for roasts or aged cheeses.

wine.name: Clairette de Die "Cuvée Impériale," Jaillance
wine.review: This off-dry sparkling white wine has terrific quince and wild honey aromas. For those seeking a sparkler with a hint of sweetness, this is great for toasts or with dessert. From southern France and based on the Clairette grape variety.

wine.name: Benziger Cabernet Sauvignon, Sonoma
wine.review: Aromas of dark fruit and rich earth leads to a smooth rich wine that would go well with stews and other hearty meats.

wine.name: "Aragosta" Vermentino di Sardegna, Santa Maria La Palma
wine.review: A light-bodied, dry, easy-drinking wine with aromas of fresh lemons and limes. It comes from the island of Sardinia, and naturally goes very well with seafood (as the label would suggest).

wine.name: Estate Riesling Feinherb, Karthäuserhof
wine.review: "Feinherb" is a some what loosely defined style of off-dry German wine that is at once refreshing and approachable. This estate is the pre-eminent estate in the Rüwer region of Germany.

wine.name: Echeverria Unwooded Chardonnay
wine.review: A Chardonnay unlike any other in the New World. This is a hand-crafted wine without any trace of oak influence. Aromas of tropical fruits and pears intermingle with mouth-watering acidity, while the wine retains a lovely round feel on the palate.

wine.name: Vouvray Sec, Vincent Raimbault
wine.review: A dry and honeyed white wine with citrus aromas waiting to quench your thirst.

wine.name: Temento, Tement
wine.review: This light, aromatic white wine is a blend of Welschriesling and Sauvignon Blanc from the limestone hills of Austria. Welschriesling (no relation to Riesling) adds beautiful citrus and floral notes to this wine as a hint of clove spice peeks through. Perfect as an apéritif, or paired with green salads and asparagus.

wine.name: Grüner Veltliner "Wogenrain", Soellner
wine.review: This Grüner Veltliner is made from old vines just north of the Danube. An amazing food wine, this wine is dry, has great balance, and displays a bouquet of yellow grapefruit and lime. You'll note the stoney minerals on the finish.

wine.name: Hautes-Côtes de Beaune Rouge, Rollin
wine.review: From a great producer in Burgundy, this Bourgogne Rouge shows delicious notes of fresh, red raspberries surrounding a mineral backbone. Rollin is a family-run estate, producing wines with outstanding character at a good value. This particular Pinot Noir is a beautiful match for pan-roasted salmon with morel sauce.

wine.name: St. Aubin Blanc "Le Ban," Prudhon
wine.review: Prudhon makes top rate red and white Burgundy. This Chardonnay is all about apple and floral fruit with persistent mineral on the finish. The village of St. Aubin has lots of hidden gems that offer value and elegance.

wine.name: St. Aubin Rouge "Frionnes" 1er Cru, Prudhon
wine.review: You can't go wrong with this red beauty from the little-known village of St. Aubin. Prudhon offers value in Pinot Noir. This vintage shows dark cherry fruit, spice and a note of raspberry on the finish.

wine.name: Manta Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: A light, easy-drinking white wine made even brighter by fresh melon and lemon zest flavors. This is a purely refreshing wine that is a hit at parties, so consider picking up a case.

wine.name: Muscat Sec, Mas las Cabes, Dom. Gardies
wine.review: While the Muscat grape is often vinified in a sweet style, Languedoc winemakers excel at making dry versions like this one. Put just a light chill on this bottle and appreciate all it has to offer: we especially liked its delicate bouquet of white flowers, fresh limes, and white pepper.

wine.name: Egly-Ouriet "Vignes de Vrigny" Brut
wine.review: This Champagne is made entirely from Pinot Meunier. It has a toasty, brioche quality to it and ample red berry fruit. Dry, delicate and drinking just right today.

wine.name: Konigsbacher Idig Riesling Trocken, A. Christmann
wine.review: One of the most highly sought after Pfalz estates is finally here. Christmann's top vines of the Idig vineyard are among his best. This Riesling has aromas of apricots, white peaches and a note of pear. This is a complex and elegant wine that you can cellar for decades to come. The 2002 vintage was very giving though so you can enjoy this gem today as well.

wine.name: Fendant du Valais "Les Murettes", Gilliard
wine.review: A dry white from the Valais region of Switzerland. Made from the Chasselas grape. Aromas of yellow fruit, yellow plums and cherries. Perfect for Raclette or Fondue.

wine.name: Viré-Clessé, Dom. de Roally
wine.review: Chardonnay from the Mâcon is hardly ever made from estate-grown grapes. Here's a rich version that's full and round in the mouth with yellow apple fruit and fresh almonds on the finish.

wine.name: Grignolino "Poggeto", La Casaccia
wine.review: This tasty red wine from Piedmont is made from the Grignolino grape, and comes from 50-year-old vines. The pale cherry-red color is captivating. The palate boasts the freshest imaginable red berry flavors, with hints of white peppercorn. This red has such pristine fruit and great mineral-laced acidity that you'll be aching for more before you know it.

wine.name: Côte de Brouilly, C. Pacalet
wine.review: This Côte de Brouilly, one of the 10 "Crus" of Beaujolais, is so beautifully concentrated and generous in fruit. Enjoy the forward raspberry and dark cherry fruit today or feel free to cellar this for a few years. Unfiltered. Organic.

wine.name: Riesling "Katzenthal," Binner
wine.review: This unfiltered Riesling is unexpectedly full in body. It shows the classic peach-and-apricot fruit profile of the best examples of this varietal, but there's a good dose of citrus in there as well. Organic.

wine.name: Barbera d'Asti "Baby Barb", Cantine La Mondianese
wine.review: This young fresh Barbera is one of 3 that Cantina Sant'Agata makes. We chose this one cause it tastes like it's fresh off the farm with upfront cherry and red berry fruit. This does not see any oak aging. A wine to drink today.

wine.name: Piazzolla Malbec, Mendoza
wine.review: When we think of Argentina, the red Malbec grape usually comes to mind. This version is unoaked, allowing you to appreciate all of the wonderful flavors of Malbec grown in the Mendoza region. This wine is packed with rich, dark, jammy berry fruit.

wine.name: Piazzolla Bonarda, Mendoza
wine.review: The red Bonarda grape is widely grown in Argentina. This tasty example from Piazzolla is a hearty wine, free of oak, that is full of mulberry fruit aromas with a touch of graphite and thyme on the finish. It goes very well with grilled meats, especially steak.

wine.name: Gavi di Gavi, La Merlina
wine.review: Another great white wine from Piedmont. Dry and a touch reticent upon opening, this flourishes after a few minutes in the glass with notes of raw honey, fresh lemons, and rusty minerality.

wine.name: Gevrey-Chambertin "Coeur de Roy", Dugat-Py
wine.review: An impressive, old vines (50-95 years) bottling from the formidable estate of Dugat-Py. Firm with cherries, cassis, violets and just a slight note of cedar. A wine to decant before enjoying. Showing incredibly today.

wine.name: Anjou "Pur Breton," Cousin-Leduc
wine.review: "Breton" is the local name for Cabernet Franc, and this one is a complex rendition, full of pomegranate fruit with a touch of leather and spice. Bacchus wholeheartedly approves, and so do we! Don't miss out on this juicy Loire Valley red.

wine.name: Lambrusco "Concerto", Medici Ermete
wine.review: Lightly sparkling with aromas of cassis, black pepper and black cherries. Dry with just the right amount of sparkle and even tannin to lend itself to meat or cheese antipasti.

wine.name: Ribolla Gialla "Anfora", Gravner
wine.review: This white wine is fermented on the skins for much longer than usual, and then aged in amphorae. There's a near copper tint to the mostly golden hue. On the palate are endlessly changing aromas - ripe pears, white pepper, even melon.

wine.name: Brunello di Montalcino, Castel Giocondo Frescobaldi
wine.review: Silky smooth tannins make this well constructed, complex and well balanced Sangiovese ready to drink now but will improve for years to come.

wine.name: Blaterle Tafelwein, Mayr-Nusser
wine.review: This white wine from the Alto Adige of Italy is dry with mineral driven acidity. Aromas of pith, white flowers and lemongrass and fresh mint leaf. The grape variety is the ever-rare Blaterle.

wine.name: Lagrein Riserva, Mayr-Nusser
wine.review: Coming from one of our favorite small producers, this is full of dark berries, leather, smoke, and earth. This wine has exuberant dark-berried fruit character, an elegant texture, and a note of powder on the finish.

wine.name: Prosecco Brut, Col Vetoraz
wine.review: A dry sparkling wine made from the Prosecco grape variety. This white is all about pears, white flowers, citrus and peaches. Excellent toasty fruit on the palate.

wine.name: Rosso del Soprano, Palari
wine.review: The fruit on this great red is a combination of delicate red berries, iron, powder, and sweet spice. This comes from northeastern Sicily, in the province of Messina - grown at 1400 feet above sea level. Made from a wild blend of indigenous grape varieties.

wine.name: Abbots Red Table, Owen Roe
wine.review: From a devoted winemaker and from great vineyards in the Pacific Northwest, this red will bring you much pleasure. A tasty blend made of Syrah, Pinot Noir, Zin and perhaps more. Beautiful and packed with fleshy black fruit character. A good dose of tannins make this a wine to stand up to a variety of hearty meals. Hold for a few years or drink up today.

wine.name: Zaca Mesa Viognier
wine.review: This estate-bottled Viognier from Santa Barbara has aromas of honeysuckle and mandarin orange. Deliciously dry on the palate with apricot, mineral, and peach notes. With limited intervention, this Rhône Ranger has created a great Viognier.

wine.name: Pelaverga, Vigna di Terre Rosse
wine.review: This is a beautiful, bright crimson-colored wine made from the rare Pelaverga grape. It is shy upon opening, but within a couple of hours begins to show fresh cranberry fruit with vivid aromas of flowers, spice, clay, and powder. Delicately textured with a subtle iron minerality on the finish. Just another humble yet amazing Piedmontese wine, well worthy of a patient taster's attention. This comes from the Saluzzo area (southwest of Turin), which is known as the original home of Pelaverga.

wine.name: Taittinger Brut Vintage
wine.review: This vintage offering shows good ripeness and a lush mouthfeel typical of fine vintage Champagne.

wine.name: Crossroads Chardonnay "Destination Series", Hawke's Bay
wine.review: This New Zealand Chardonnay sees a light dose of new oak aging. It's a beautiful expression of fresh apples, white flowers and vanilla. Rich and round on the palate with refreshing acidity to stand up to heartier fare.

wine.name: Corbières "Premier Pas", Dom. des Deux Anes
wine.review: Premier Pas means "first step" in French - and this was indeed the first wine produced by a talented husband-and-wife team after they'd moved to the Corbières region in Languedoc-Roussillon. A natural, completely organic wine with no sulfites added, this shows ripe blackberry fruit with underlying herbal layers and cocoa notes. It's medium-bodied and great for any time of year.

wine.name: Juliénas, Dom. du Clos du Fief, Michel Tête
wine.review: This red wine is made from the Gamay grape variety. On the nose you'll find hints of black pepper, followed by ample fresh cherry fruit on the palate.

wine.name: Water Wheel "Memsie"
wine.review: A solid red wine from the Victoria region of eastern Australia. Rich with blackberry and blueberry fruit character. A touch of mint and pepper adds richness to this structured red wine. A blend of Shiraz, Cabernet and Malbec.

wine.name: Fitou "La Grangette," Clos des Camuzeilles
wine.review: This cuvée is produced from a single hectare of 70-year-old Carignan vines and 35-year-old Grenache. The color is deep, rich purple. Aromas of cassis, cedar, coffee, blackberry and blueberry notes intermingle in beautiful complexity. Well-integrated tannins give this red excellent aging potential, or you could enjoy it now after a quick decanting.

wine.name: Corbières "L'Enclos," Dom. des Deux Ânes
wine.review: Another great endeavor from this husband-and-wife team in the Corbières area of Languedoc. Aged both in tank and in old barrels, this structured red wine comes from a warm vintage, giving it powerful flavors of black fruit, nutmeg, and dried fig.

wine.name: Doc's Draft Hard Apple Cider
wine.review: Hand crafted cider from Hudson Valley apples. Moderately effervescent with a taste of fresh orchard picked apples. The palate suggests a hint of sweetness but the finish is on the dry style.

wine.name: Doc's Draft Framboise Hard Apple Cider
Ch. Moulin de Lagnet, St.-Émilion
wine.review: (PO) The right bank region of Bordeaux, is known for its elegant Merlot-based wines. The clay soil allows for the Merlot grapes to ripen fully in the cooler of the Bordeaux regions. This medium bodied red is soft with red plum fruit character and medium tannins.

wine.name: Olssens Pinot Noir "Jackson Berry"
wine.review: The wines from Olssens of Bannockburn are always sophisticated and elegant. Their flagship wine is this intense Pinot Noir, which shows floral fruit with plum and black cherry nuances. It is drinking very well today, but could easily be held for years to come.

wine.name: Huia Pinot Noir, Marlborough
wine.review: Huia Vineyards was established by Winemakers Claire and Mike Allan, who were drawn to Marlborough by the intense fruit flavours in the wines. This Pinot is lush with focused red raspberry fruit.

wine.name: Ch. Cadillac Lesgourgues
wine.review: A delicious red Bordeaux full of cassis and black cherry fruit. With its solid tannins, this wine has enough backbone to stand up to the richest of beef dishes.

wine.name: Ch. Le Bonnat Rouge, Graves
wine.review: Fresh and clean on the palate with aromas of red cherries and currants.

wine.name: Ata Rangi Pinot Noir, Martinborough
wine.review: This delicious red wine comes from the region of Martinborough, at the southern tip of the North Island of New Zealand. The producers of this Pinot Noir were highly concerned with preserving varietal typicity, and the wine exhibits beautiful redcurrant and red cherry fruit flavors.

wine.name: J. Schram, Schramsberg
wine.review: Dedicated to the founder of Schramsberg, their J. Schram was first made in 1987. Using only the top 5 to 7% of their grapes, only 1500 cases are made. This is a blend of 75% Chardonnay & 25% PN that sees some barrel fermentation. The result is showing evolution yet with a lush, toasty palate with notes of quince, green apples & pineapple.

wine.name: Au Bon Climat "Isabelle Morgan" Pinot Noir
wine.review: Isabelle Morgan is a blend of the best barrels from the best vineyard sites of Au Bon Climat. This is serious wine, with flavors of fig, spice, and pomegranate surrounding an earthiness at its core. A very structured and concentrated pinot that can be drunk over the next decade.

wine.name: Zobing Heilig Riesling, Bründlmayer
wine.review: On this parcel, Bründlmayer uses a special "Y"-shaped vine training method that allows grapes and leaves alike to soak up every available bit of sunlight. Mineral flavors and invigorating green aromas of aloe and lime abound.

wine.name: Lacryma Christi Rosso, Mastroberardino
wine.review: Legend says that the tears of Christ fell onto the vineyard site after seeing the beauty of the area. Well, we can't say that you'll have a similar reaction to this wine but we can guarantee that it's a red wine worth tasting. Made from the indigenous red Piedirosso grape variety and borne on volcanic soil at very high altitude vineyards. Rich with fleshy dark berry fruit. Bright fruit character and a solid tannic backbone that lends itself to rich, italian fare.

wine.name: Tokaji Aszú 5 Puttonyos "Red Label", Royal Tokaji
wine.review: Nearly every discussion of the prestigious wines of Hungary includes Tokaji, the country's famed dessert wine. This is a stunningly well priced bottle full of apricots and peaches on the palate. It's sweet, but it has bright acidity to balance out its richness. Give it a light chill and enjoy it with Stilton, nuts, and salty fare - or just be a purist and enjoy it for everything it is on its own.

wine.name: Lagrein "Porphyr," Terlan
wine.review: Deep black fruits with bold flavors of plums and blackberries on the attack. The mid-palate shows the mellow character that barrel aging has imparted to the wine, giving it well-integrated notes of vanilla and espresso cream. While it is already drinking quite well, this benchmark Lagrein is sure to improve with additional time in the cellar.

wine.name: Pinot Bianco, Terlan
wine.review: This northern Italian white is made from the Pinot Bianco grape variety. It's different than the average Italian Pinot Bianco in that it is very mineral driven and dry, with a notable amount of fruit and acidity. Beautiful honey, white grapefruit and pollen on the palate.

wine.name: Leyda Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: Viña Leyda aims to express the true colors of Sauvignon Blanc in this white. Full of fresh floral and honey aromas with a note of mint on the finish. Very approachable and ripe on the palate and a great match with poultry or richer fish dishes.

wine.name: Morey-St.-Denis "Clos Solon" VV, Fourrier
wine.review: From a very old-school Burgundy producer who is rigorous in his pursuit of excellence. A wine that will do very well in the cellar and is best kept there for several years at least.

wine.name: "L'Effraie" Coteaux-du-Loir, Dom. de Bellivière
wine.review: Chenin Blanc from Bellivière is not to be missed this season. This white is honeyed and filled with yellow stone fruit extract that will keep you coming back for more.

wine.name: Tishbi Pinot Noir, Kosher
wine.review: Notes of strawberries and cherries are subtle yet profound here, and a bit of coffee and chocolate come from five months of aging in French oak. This has a velvety texture, perfect balance, and a soft finish.

wine.name: Vinho Verde, Fâmega
wine.review: This dry, spritzy wine is refreshingly light-bodied and shows a just-off-the-boat freshness on the palate. Floral aromas and lively ripeness make this a wine to remember. If you haven't yet discovered what a wonderfully easy-drinking wine Vinho Verde can be, this is the perfect introduction.

wine.name: Porca de Murça, Douro
wine.review: Made from a blend of indigenous Port grapes in the Douro Valley. This is a still red wine with very forward cherry fruit aromas and a soft backbone of earthy tannins. Drinks very well with hearty, meat-based dishes.

wine.name: Cardeal Reserva, Touriga Nacional, Dão
wine.review: Made from Touriga Nacional, this fresh red wine shows firm dark fruit, warm spices, and a gentle touch of fresh tobacco on the finish. It has a great tannic structure that allows it to hold up to big, meaty dishes.

wine.name: Burge Family Garnacha, Barossa Valley
wine.review: A full-bodied red wine with dark berries - blackberries, currants and blueberries - with a touch of mint and spice on the finish. Moderate tannins help to balance out the fruit character. Made from mostly 80-year-old vines that have been dry farmed. 80 years ago, Garnacha wasn't as popular as the "port-like" red wines of those days. Burge didn't follow trends, however, and the estate has those ancient Garnacha vines to this day. Today, Rick Burge propagates his vineyard from old-vine cuttings.

wine.name: Ch. Valcombe Rouge, Côtes du Ventoux
wine.review: A dry red wine that's full of cherries, strawberries and a touch of spice. A perfect wine to keep in the fridge for those unexpected guests.

wine.name: Valtellina, Sandro Fay
wine.review: This red is made from the Nebbiolo grape in the northeastern corner of northern Italy's Lombardia region. It's a delight to drink, especially if you've had your eye out for good value in Nebbiolo - which is all too rare! This wine is a great example of what this regal grape can do: pale garnet in color, it boasts an elegant and lithe texture. The nose shows subtle aromas of violets, red berries, and earth, and there is a touch of melon flavor on the palate. Do what the Italians do and enjoy this wine with rich food.

wine.name: Big House Pink
wine.review: This is their newest addition and it is the perfect summer wine. A light, refreshing rosé filled with berry fruit, cinnamon, and floral notes while finishing dry on the palate.

wine.name: Silver Thread Riesling, Finger Lakes
wine.review: This will impress any Riesling fan. It most resembles wines from the Mosel Valley and has the lip smacking mineral appeal that balances the delicate stone fruit aromas. Off-dry, meaning it has just the slightest hint of sweetness. Drink chilled and enjoy as an aperitif wine or with anything spicy.

wine.name: Silver Thread Pinot Noir
wine.review: Winemaker Richard Figiel started his tiny, 10 acre vineyard in the early 1980s in the Finger Lakes region of upstate New York. This is a lighter-bodied Pinot Noir that's full of incredible character: sanguine, red berried and delicate. This could fool many-a-palate blind to be a classic Bourgogne Rouge.

wine.name: Burgess Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: This is a library selection from Burgess Vineyards. In great vintages, Burgess holds back a portion of wine to release later on. This 1993 Cabernet is at its prime right now, showing cedar, chocolate, and pepper notes. Decant this wine to discover endless layers of flavor; this is sure to delight.

wine.name: Estate Riesling Trocken, Sybille Kuntz
wine.review: In spite of our utmost adoration of Riesling in its not-dry versions, every now and then we crave a juicy dry version. Sybille Kuntz is an absolute expert on this style of Riesling and expresses it perfectly in this bottle. Very precise on the palate with peaches and white floral-driven fruits.

wine.name: Wolffer, Cabernet Franc
wine.review: Cabernet Franc, known to flourish in the Loire Valley, also thrives on Long Island. Enjoy this bottle's spicy, black fruit and relish its relative ease in contrast to many of its Loire Valley brethren.

wine.name: Taittinger "Comtes de Champagne", Blanc de Blancs Brut
wine.review: The "Comtes" is made from the first press ("la Cuvée') of Chardonnay grapes. Five percent of the wine is aged in new wood before being blended and bottle aged.

wine.name: Salmon Run Riesling
wine.review: From New York's Finger Lakes region, this fragrant white wine has a persistent, flinty white peach flavor and a dry finish. An ideal party sipper that goes with many hors d'oeuvres.

wine.name: Don Miguel Gascon Malbec
wine.review: One of our more exciting recent finds, this incredibly lush, purple-hued red wine from Argentina is so ripe and round that it is nearly impossible not to gulp it down. A great wine for peppery steaks and chops, or rich Mediterranean fare.

wine.name: Golan Sion Creek Red
wine.review: From the Galil region of Israel, this easy-drinking red is a blend of Sangiovese, Syrah, Gamay Noir, Pinot Noir and Napa Gamay.

wine.name: Fleurie, Dom. des Grands Fers
wine.review: A fantastic Cru Beaujolais from a phenomenal vintage, with lots of black fruit aromas and violets. It's just slightly tannic, and while this is a red wine to drink today, it certainly has enough structure to hold up to rich meat dishes.

wine.name: Lugana "San Benedetto", Zenato
wine.review: A soft white wine that's full of white plums, raw honey and exotic fruits like pineapple on the palate. It's a dry wine, but it shows plenty of upfront fruit, making it great either before a meal or with a variety of foods.

wine.name: Muscadet "Expression de Gneiss", Dom. de l'Ecu
wine.review: Guy Bossard is a well-respected grower in the Nantais region. He classifies some of his Muscadets by the soil that they grow on. This is a stony white wine with floral fruit character and great mineral structure (imparted by the gneiss soils this wine is named after). It is a natural match for seafood of any kind.

wine.name: Columella, Sadie Family, Swartland
wine.review: A red that's based on Syrah with a bit of Mourvèdre and comes from the Swartland subregion of South Africa. Made in the name of those fantastic northern Rhône wines we love to drink. Velvety textured tannins, black spiced berries, licorice, butter. Wonderfully balanced with great acidity. A young wine that merits your attention. Age-worthy. Named after Columella, an astute Roman who wrote on agriculture in the 1st century. Estate-grown fruit. Organic.

wine.name: Porter Creek Chardonnay "George's Hill"
wine.review: This winery, named after one of the main tributaries to the Russian River, is run by a father and son. The vineyards are farmed organically and the winemaking practices are Burgundian in style. This Chardonnay took us completely by surprise when we first tasted it: great Old World-style minerality complements notes of pear, lime, and brulée.

wine.name: Porteño, Mendoza
wine.review: With its ruby red color and aromas of black cherries and plums, this Argentine red is simply one of the best wines to come out of Mendoza in years. The tannins are silky-smooth and work perfectly with grilled meats or hard, aged cheeses.

wine.name: Vin de Savoie "Abymes," Dom. Labbé
wine.review: A clean, dry white made from the Jacquère grape variety. With tangy, chalky minerals and floral fruit flavors, it is a natural match for shellfish.

wine.name: Oyster Bay Chardonnay, Marlborough
wine.review: An easy-drinking Chardonnay from New Zealand. Clean and fruit driven on the palate with yellow apple fruit aromas.

wine.name: Brouilly Vieilles Vignes, Lapalu
wine.review: On the palate this Gamay is showing the finesse and ease that the best Brouillys offer. With dark cherries, violets, and a wet, stony finish, this is just brilliant alongside sausages, ham, and country pâtés.

wine.name: Justin "Isosceles"
wine.review: Aromas of blackberry, black plum, leather, mocha, and cassis combine with light layers of caramel, vanilla and a touch of smoke resulting from the extended oak ageing.

wine.name: Frascati Superiore, Regillo
wine.review: A dry white from Lazio that's full of citrus aromas and stony minerality. An easy white to chill, open and quaff anytime. And, of course, don't forget the food.

wine.name: Gomersol "Magpie" Grenache
wine.review: It's a real treat to be able to taste this bottle, which has evolved delightfully over the past few years. There is meaty, richness and lots of red fruit on the nose, which carries through to the palate. An elegant style of wine for hot, arid Barossa Valley.

wine.name: Lambrusco "Bocciolo", Ermete
wine.review: This is a sparkling red wine made from Lambrusco grapes. It is deep crimson in color, lightly sparkling, and lightly sweet on the palate with red raspberry flavors. Put a light chill on this and watch it disappear, especially with salty antipasti.

wine.name: Beaujolais-Villages, Granger
wine.review: Fresh off the boat and drinking well today. Clean and fruit-driven and very distinctly Beaujolais with raspberry fruit aromas. Shows a fresh acidity that works so well with meat dishes.

wine.name: Chatom, Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: In the warm days and cool nights of the Sierra Foothills, these Cabernet Sauvignon grapes were able to attain perfect ripeness. The wine shows aromatic fruit and black pepper, with undertones of coffee and bittersweet chocolate.

wine.name: Heitz Cellar Chardonnay
wine.review: In operation since the early 1960s, Heitz Cellar remains a family-owned, family-operated winery. Heitz recently revamped the flavor profile of its Chardonnay by reducing the amount of new oak it sees, allowing the fruit's fresh acidity to shine through.

wine.name: Ch. Belingard, Bergerac
wine.review: Bergerac is a wine producing region located east of Bordeaux. Naturally wines are made with similar varieties as those found in Bordeaux. This red wine is based on Cabernet Sauvignon. It's meant to be an everyday red wine. Solid on the palate with clean blackcurrant fruit character. Just a delight with meat dishes.

wine.name: Barolo "Rocche", Brovia
wine.review: A very impressive wine marked by intensely ripe fruit, firm tannins, rich texture and approachability in it's youth due to the vintage. Rocche from Brovia never disappoints in the test of time.

wine.name: Barolo, Brovia
wine.review: A red wine blended from younger vines found within the four crus of the Brovia estate. This has smooth tannins on the palate, with a real woodsy/spicy character and red fruits. Always a compelling Nebbiolo from one of our favorite estates in Piedmont.

wine.name: Côtes-du-Rhône, Dom. Grès St. Vincent
wine.review: A scrumptious Côtes-du-Rhône with a solid backbone of velvety tannins with dark, juicy black berried fruit and black licorice on the palate. What a great wine to drink with pizza, burgers or anything grilled.

wine.name: Alvear PX Solera 1927
wine.review: From a solera that is now in its 8th decade, this elegant dessert sherry has a dark amber hue, with flavors of crème brûlée, marmalade, and toasted hazelnuts. Not nearly as syrupy as might be expected, it finishes long and clean. Wonderful when slightly chilled, either with rich desserts or on its own.

wine.name: Geyser Peak Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: The latest Sauvignon Blanc from Geyser Peak is deliciously crisp and packed with flavors of lime, gooseberry, and tropical fruit. Try it with anything from summer salads to sushi.

wine.name: Muscat de Rivesaltes, Clos des Camuzeilles
wine.review: A true terroir Muscat that changes with every year. This year, aromas of apricots and cream appeal to the nose while mandarin and vanilla appear on the palate. This is perfect as an apéritif or with creamy desserts. Made in the Roussillon region in southern France.

wine.name: Bogle Vineyards Phantom
wine.review: As everyone knows, "bogle" is synonymous with hobgoblin, bogeyman, and bugbear. The Bogle Phantom, despite having a somewhat redundant name, is a tight, focused blend, consisting mainly of Petite Sirah and old-vine Zinfandel, with a touch of Mourvèdre adding mystique.

wine.name: Taittinger Prélude
wine.review: This Champagne comes entirely from Grand Cru classified vineyards in Champagne. It's driven by floral fruit with some citrus vibrancy on the finish. A blend of equal parts Pinot Noir and Chardonnay. A wine to drink immediately.

wine.name: Larmandier-Bernier Premier Cru, Blanc de Blancs Brut
wine.review: Dry and mineral-driven on the palate with a earthy apple fruit aromas and precise red berries on the finish. Excellent with seafood fare. Drink lightly chilled.

wine.name: Yuzu Wine, Japan
wine.review: Yuzu fruit is a type of citrus fruit. It looks like a small grapefruit and can be either yellow or green and has aromas of mandarins. This is a sweet wine meant to be drunk with a light chill.

wine.name: Crémant d'Alsace, Albert Mann
wine.review: A Crémant is the name of a sparkling wine made in the traditional Champagne method outside of the region of Champagne in France. The Mann winery renders one of the best. Dry and citrus driven with yellow plum fruit. Give it a light chill and enjoy throughout your next meal. Organic.

wine.name: Prosecco, Frozza
wine.review: Prosecco isn't always a simple sparkling wine. This is a dry with complex citrus fruit, stony minerality, and white tea. Very young on the palate now, this can be enjoyed lightly chilled today or aged for a few years.

wine.name: Tablas Creek, Côtes de Tablas Rouge
wine.review: This is a blend of four estate grown grape varieties: Mourvèdre, Syrah, Grenache and a dash of Counoise. It's well-structured and very generous on the palate with dark berried fruit, raspberries and spice. Organic.

wine.name: Muscadet "Briords", Marc Ollivier
wine.review: Marc Ollivier's estate is comprised mostly of granite earth even though very little exists in the whole of the Nantais region. Briords is stony, mineral driven with floral and citrus fruit. Enjoy in its youth or amaze yourself with the ageability of top grower Muscadet. A natural match with oysters, cured salmon and most anything from the sea.

wine.name: Orvieto "Abbocato", Barbi
wine.review: Made from the white Grechetto grape and vinified into a very fruit forward, nearing off-dry wine. Fresh, easy with ripe fruit of yellow plums and honey.

wine.name: Cheverny Blanc, Dom. du Salvard
wine.review: This wine shows lovely Sauvignon Blanc character, offering refreshing notes of citrus and herbs on the nose. The palate delivers very lively acidity and ripe, white fleshed fruits. Tangy and well-mineraled on the finish.

wine.name: Gavi "White Label," La Scolca
wine.review: A lovely everyday white with a good dose of honey, lemons and fennel seed. Fresh and vibrant, this would slice right through fritto misto.

wine.name: The Chook Sparkling Shiraz
wine.review: A medium-bodied sparkling red wine made from Shiraz. Mixed, fresh dark berries on the palate with just the right touch of bubbles and tannin. Drinks well today and has just a bit of sweetness to enjoy as a before dinner drink. You can give it just a light chill before opening.

wine.name: St Francis Red, Sonoma County
