wine.review: Made from grapes sourced from the esteemed Sonoma Valley region, this is an extraordinary blend of Zinfandel, Grenache, Merlot, and Sangiovese. Spicy, dark fruit and lively tannins will awaken your palate as you match this up with grilled meats and barbecued fare.

wine.name: Byblos Sweet Bonarda
wine.review: A robust red with lots of dark berry notes on the palate. Jammy with a lingering finish, and without the juice-like flavors that some semi-sweet wines have.

wine.name: Lugana, Tenuta Roveglia
wine.review: Beautiful aromas of pears, yellow grapefruit and white flowers waft gently out of the glass. Made from the Trebbiano grape variety, this has bright, fresh acidity and the minerality to hold up to any seafood dish.

wine.name: Moro, Fattoria Montellori
wine.review: Think of this as a baby Super Tuscan. Yes, it's especially fruit driven but it has so much more depth with clay minerals, warm spices and even a black tea tannic finish. Drinking very well today.

wine.name: Marques de Gelida Cava
wine.review: This is an estate-bottled vintage cava with great acidity. Warm brioche and citrus flavors will fill your mouth, while the light bubbles seduce you.

wine.name: Greco di Tufo, Fratelli Urciuolo
wine.review: The region of Campania produces a range of excellent wines. This one, made from the Greco grape, delivers what we crave in a southern Italian white: fragrant quince, floral aromas, bright acidity, and a deep mineral finish. A must-try white wine.

wine.name: Condrieu "La Petite Côte", Cuilleron
wine.review: A dessert Condrieu made from Viognier. Nicely sweet, nicely balanced. Full of citrus fruit (grapefruit and mandarin) on the palate. Ever so slightly mineraled on the finish.

wine.name: Grillo "Parlante," Fondo Antico
wine.review: This white wine is pure fruit flavor on the palate - mostly pineapples and oranges - with a ripe and juicy appeal. Grillo is a white Sicilian grape variety best known for its robust contribution to Marsala (but don't worry: this bottle is completely dry).

wine.name: Verduno Pelaverga, Fratelli Alessandria
wine.review: A medium-bodied red wine from the northern Piedmontese area of Verduno. The rare Pelaverga grape is grown mostly in this region, where chalky soils predominate- and that terroir clearly shines through in the wine. Aromas of red berries, black tea, and that chalkiness work very well together here.

wine.name: Luzon Verde
wine.review: Coming from one of the oldest estates in the Jumilla area of southern Spain, Luzon Verde is an organic wine made up of 100% Monastrell (aka Mourvèdre). Spice notes and flavors of licorice, black fruit, and tobacco leaf burst forth from this dense, full-bodied red.

wine.name: Beaune 1er Cru "Le Clos des Mouches", F. Gaunoux
wine.review: Rich with red berry fruit character and a note of coffee grind. Beautiful texture, powerful yet lithe to the touch. A solid 1er Cru from a traditional producer worth exploring.

wine.name: Campo de Borja "Los Dos," Almira
wine.review: An excellent Spanish red from the Campo de Borja region, made from a blend of old-vine Garnacha and a bit of Syrah. Dark, fresh and – no surprise – deliciously "grapey" on the palate. Light, silky tannins make for a very pleasant finish. Try it with grilled fare for a failsafe pairing.

wine.name: Bianco, Cantina Zaccagnini
wine.review: A white blend from central Italy's Abruzzo region made from Riesling, Trebbiano, and Chardonnay. It shows aromas of yellow plums and flavors of soft honey fruit. Easy-drinking, unoaked, and a great alternative to California Chardonnay, this has a fresh acidity that makes it perfect with seafood dishes.

wine.name: Brampton Shiraz
wine.review: A solid Shiraz from South Africa. The Brampton wines from the Stellenbosch region are made in a style that boasts upfront fruit on the palate. This is unoaked and shows all the red, peppery fruit you've come to love in this versatile grape.

wine.name: Mas de Daumas Gassac VdP Rouge
wine.review: From the top estate from the Languedoc, this red is based on Cabernet Sauvignon with an assortment of indigenous red grapes blended in. Subtle aromas of bay leaf, mixed fresh berries, and violets lead to a finish that shows a pleasantly chalky mineral quality. Delicious and absolutely age-worthy, this is at its best when paired with rich foods, especially roasts.

wine.name: Mauritson Zinfandel, Dry Creek
wine.review: The Mauritsons have been growing grapes in Sonoma since the 1870s. Beginning with the 1998 vintage, the family (led by winemaker Clay Mauritson) has been making its own wine. The fruit for this Dry Creek Zinfandel comes from four different vineyard sites, creating a wine that is complex and well-balanced, with notes of dark chocolate and black plum.

wine.name: Stellenbosch "John X Merriman," Rustenberg
wine.review: A red blend made of Cabernet, Merlot and Cabernet Franc. Fruit driven but has the depth of a classic Bordeaux with tobacco and blackcurrants. Solid but integrated tannins that can hold up to hearty meat fare.

wine.name: Brunello di Montalcino "Pertimali", L. Sassetti
wine.review: One of Montalcino's finest estates, producing wines of stunning quality and age worthiness. Hold for a decade to experience Brunello at its best.

wine.name: House Wine Red, Magnificent Wine Co.
wine.review: Coming from the Blue Mountains of Walla Walla in Washington, this red blend delighted us as soon as we tried it. Made from Cabernet, Merlot, Syrah, and Cabernet Franc, the House Wine has brambly spice, licorice, and blackberries, with supple tannins and a velvet texture on the finish. The perfect red for grilled meats and strong cheeses.

wine.name: Côtes du Rhône "Cuvée de la Pierre Chaud", L'Anglore
wine.review: Made from Grenache by natural winemaker Eric Pfifferling. A prominent floral nose leads to freshly macerated mixed berries on the palate. This wine is made without the addition of sulphur, allowing it to retain a rare purity and cleanness of flavor. Delicious.

wine.name: FRV100 "Terres Dorées", Jean-Paul Brun
wine.review: A sparkling rosé that's vibrant and fresh on the palate. Aromas of raspberries and cherries, a hint of sweetness and low in alcohol. Made from the Gamay grape.

wine.name: Wehlen Sonnenuhr Riesling Kabinett, Dr. F. Weins-Prüm
wine.review: Full of slate minerals on the palate. This along with the honeysuckle and the citrus fruit make for a very appealing off dry Riesling.

wine.name: Riesling Kabinett "Jean-Baptiste", Gunderloch
wine.review: Fritz Hasselbach, owner of Weingut Gunderloch, is not only one of the premier producers of the Rheinhessen; he's also incredibly dedicated to making wines that show their terroir. Here, the red, iron-rich soils show through on the palate. This is off-dry, and full of peach and yellow plum flavors.

wine.name: Oberon Cabernet Sauvignon, Napa
wine.review: Formerly available only in restaurants, this Napa Cabernet is made by Michael Mondavi, with most of the fruit coming from the Stags Leap District. It shows rich, spicy cassis notes and a velvety finish. This is just the thing for grilled meats and roasts.

wine.name: Chalone Vineyard Chardonnay Monterey
wine.review: We're certain that you'll enjoy this Chardonnay. Its fresh appeal, touch of vanilla oak and bright apple and pear fruit character will please many palates. Chalone's wines are highly acclaimed and very well-made. This white is exemplary of their winemaking standards and offers a glance into their portfolio.

wine.name: Viña Bosconia Reserva, Lopez de Heredia
wine.review: Coming from the family-run and very traditional Lopez de Heredia estate, this wine has notes of strawberry, blood orange, pomegranate, coconut, and exotic spices. Viña Bosconia is produced from the juice of Tempranillo, Garnacha, Mazuelo, and Graciano, aged for three years in American oak barrels. The winery is one of the few in Rioja still owned by its founding family.

wine.name: The Observatory Syrah/Carignan
wine.review: Of the new estates of the Swartland region, the Observatory's wines are not to be missed. This bold red wine is rich yet remains elegant and most impressively expressive of spice, earth and dark currants on the palate. The tannins are fine, mineraled and give a solid backbone to the wine. The fruit is hand harvested, with low yields, and without the use of synthetic pesticides.

wine.name: Clos L'Ermita, Alvaro Palacios
wine.review: A rare bottling from superstar producer Alvaro Palacios, this wine is made almost entirely from old vine Garnacha grown at high elevations in soils composed mainly of schist. With undertones of truffle, dark chocolate, and pepper, this wine fills the palate with bright tannins. Decant and enjoy now, or hold as this wine will age with grace for years to come.

wine.name: Ürziger Würzgarten Riesling Kabinett, Mönchhof
wine.review: Legend has it that the wines from the Ürziger Würzgarten vineyard draw their spicy and herbaceous aromas from an adjacent herb garden. The Mönchhof estate has an undeniable talent for expressing ripe stone fruit and slate flavors in its luscious wines.

wine.name: Morgon VV, Daniel Bouland
wine.review: One of the 10 Crus of the Beaujolais region, Morgon is noted for producing wines with darker, more powerful fruit profiles than are typical of the Gamay grape. This one shows excellent character with a rustic, earthy edge that pairs well with the charcuterie (sausages, hams, country pâtés) so widely enjoyed in the wine's region of origin – not to mention here in NYC.

wine.name: Twomey Merlot, Napa
wine.review: Sourced from a single vineyard called the Soda Canyon Ranch, this small-production Merlot shows extraordinary complexity. Winemaker Daniel Baron learned winemaking in Bordeaux and has brought European techniques to Napa. Drink this bottle now or hold it for a few decades.

wine.name: Dominus, Napa
wine.review: Dominus Estate wines are made solely from grapes grown on the historic Napanook vineyard. This blend of Cabernet Sauvignon, Cabernet Franc, and Petit Verdot shows ripe fruit, balanced acidity, and lively tannins on the finish. Decant and enjoy today, or hold this bottle for 10 -15 years.

wine.name: Santenay "Les Champs Claude", J.M. Pillot
wine.review: Jean Marc Pillot makes a very red berried and fruit driven style of Pinot Noir. His reds are aged for between 12 and 15 months in oak, only 25% new in order to provide structure without overwhelming the inherent fruitiness of the wine with oak flavor.

wine.name: Barolo "Brunate," Vietti
wine.review: The Brunate bottling is always Vietti's most accessible, typically showing earthy fruit supported by rose petal aromatics and rich, slightly roasted berry fruits. This one is no exception, and 2001 just happened to be a phenomenal vintage in Barolo. While this is very enjoyable today, it has the concentration and balance to evolve for decades.

wine.name: Jelu Malbec
wine.review: We just can’t resist this Malbec: It’s a perfect example of how well this lovely red grape can do in Argentina. Made on a Practicing Organic estate in the Mendoza region, this full-bodied wine shows dark berry fruit and a spicy edge on the finish.

wine.name: Hobbs Viognier
wine.review: A sweet, luscious dessert wine that's packed with white fruits and flowers on the palate. An excellent choice after dinner with the cheese plate! Drink with a light chill.

wine.name: Chenin Blanc, Coriole Vineyards
wine.review: Chenin Blanc is Coriole's principal white wine and was first planted in McLaren Vale in 1977. Aromas of white pineapple and passionfruit dominate the palate. Highly aromatic with a juicy, tangy finish.

wine.name: Grechetto, Chiorri
wine.review: The Grechetto grape variety is at home in the region of Umbria, nestled right in the middle of Italy. This is an earthy white wine with aromas of raw honey, cannabis, and sage. It's dry on the palate, but rich in texture and aromas. Excellent with Farro or mushroom risotto.

wine.name: Bandit Pinot Grigio
wine.review: A 1-liter box from the people who bring you Three Thieves; they've made it their mission to give good wine back to the people. This is fresh, light white wine, in a convenient and eco-friendly container.

wine.name: Grüner Veltliner Berg Vogel, Bründlmayer
wine.review: Willi Bründlmayer pays remarkable attention to detail. His vineyards, located within wooded hills, are protected from the cold northerly winds. This gives his wines beautiful succulence while remaining structured. The Berg Vogelsang is a single vineyard.

wine.name: Foxglove Chardonnay, Edna Valley
wine.review: Foxglove is the brainchild of brilliant winemaker Bob Varner, who is renowned for the Varner wines he crafts with his brother. This Chardonnay is sourced from Edna Valley, a small wine region located close to the Pacific Ocean. The Valley's cool, foggy summers and clay-loam soils produce a well-balanced, mineral-driven, beautifully complex wine.

wine.name: Juan Gil, Jumilla Red
wine.review: Made of 100% Monastrell (a.k.a. Mourvèdre) in the Jumilla region of Spain, the fruit for this wine comes from old vines grown in chalky limestone. A rich, smoky, deep red, this wine pairs perfectly with slow-roasted meats.

wine.name: Corton Rouge "Les Bressandes", Chandon de Briailles
wine.review: (B) Corton is the respectable Grand Cru from the village of Aloxe-Corton in the Côte de Beaune of Burgundy. Winery, Chandon de Briaille, produces none other than traditional red Burgundy. A wine to age but showing it's prominent red raspberry fruit on the palate today. Tannins are prominent, for Pinot Noir, but still silken in texture and will integrate further with bottle age.

wine.name: Gevrey-Chambertin "Vieilles Vignes", Harmand-Geoffroy
wine.review: Earthy, cherry fruit character that's medium-bodied with lithe tannins on the finish. Forward today but always a wine to hold for a few years if you like a more evolved character.

wine.name: Sinskey Abraxas, Scintilla Sonoma Vineyard
wine.review: This Alsatian field blend is a first release from Robert Sinskey. This wine sparkles with life - as the name of the vineyard, "Scintilla," would suggest. Notes of citrus, honeysuckle, and sage won us over immediately. Delicious!

wine.name: Hedges Estate Red Mountain
wine.review: For those of you that are impressed with the wines of Bordeaux, take a sip of this Washington State red blend that easily compares. Fresh tobacco and dark berries on the nose and palate. Solid tannins give this wine a backbone that will aid in cellaring. Approachable today but can easily be held a few years. Based on Cab and Merlot with a touch of Syrah.

wine.name: Huia Gewurztraminer, Marlborough
wine.review: The Huia winery is a young winery that's been committed to quality since 1996. The Gewürztraminer comes from the Reed vineyard (in the upper Wairau Valley) and the Traminer-View vineyard of the lower Wairau Valley. Dry with aromas of spice, lychee, nutmeg and rose leaves. Hand harvested and fermented with indigenous yeasts in order to get full expression of terroir.

wine.name: Familia Mayol Bonarda
wine.review: Bonarda is one of the most popular and successful red grapes grown in Argentina. Familia Mayol makes their fantastic version in the Mendoza region, and the wine gives us everything we want in a full-bodied red: spice, lush black fruit (blueberries and blackberries), and medium grip from the tannins.

wine.name: A to Z Pinot Noir
wine.review: Affordable Pinot Noir from Oregon! Black cherries and red raspberries on the palate. Juicy with lush fruit and a great fresh finish. Light tannins and drinking well today.

wine.name: Montepulciano d'Abruzzo, Lillà
wine.review: Made from the Montepulciano grape, this hearty, everyday red wine is an easy crowd-pleaser with tasty aromas of oregano, black olives, blackberries, and fern. Solid varietal character comes from estate-owned vines located in the Colline Teramane zone of Abruzzo. Meat on the menu? Pair this wine with a lamb ragù served over pasta. If you're in the mood for a cheese plate, this goes hand in hand with Pecorino, the region’s famous sheep’s milk cheese.

wine.name: Trebbiano d'Abruzzo, Lillà
wine.review: A remarkable Trebbiano from Abruzzo, a coastal region nestled alongside the Adriatic Sea in central Italy. This bottling comes from middle-aged and old-vine plantings in the foothills of the Majella mountain range, one of the highest points of the Abruzzo appellation. Dry on the palate, the wine offers a harmonious balance of citrus fruits and minerals on the finish. As on the beaches of Abruzzo, this wine is best enjoyed with seafood: it goes hand in hand with fresh anchovies, octopus, and shellfish.

wine.name: Oberhäuser Brücke Riesling Auslese,Dönnhoff
wine.review: Is there anything more juicily, explicitly flavorful than a Dönnhoff Auslese? Possibly, but if so, I have yet to find it. When importer Thierry Theise writes "simply, like the most perfect Riesling that can ever be" he makes a valid point. Nothing drinkable is quite so breathtaking. But seriously, one of the nice aspects of this particular Auslese is that it isn't dessert level sweetness and has a refreshing, balanced, and above all deliciously ripe quality.

wine.name: Graham's Vintage Port
wine.review: The Graham's port house is probably one of the most recognizable names in the port world. Their style of port is ultra rich with confectioned aromas of freshly macerated black berries. The fruit, sugar and tannin levels are all elevated, and even more so in this vintage.

wine.name: Smith Woodhouse Vintage Port
wine.review: This vintage of port is more potent than what typically comes out of this house. It's due to the ultra warm conditions of the growing season and in port, this means that this bottle is even more unctuous than ever. The fruit is black, with peppercorns and assertive tannins.

wine.name: Ruchè, Cascina 'Tavijn
wine.review: A dry, floral-berried red wine. Ruchè is a rare red grape variety that has become a success ever since it hit the States.

wine.name: Freisa "Vivace" Monfiorenza, La Casaccia
wine.review: Made by a tiny husband-and-wife winery in Monferrato, this red is just lightly sparkling on the palate: This is how the Piedmontese prefer their Freisa. This wine is on the dry side, with lively black cherries and a tiny hit of spice.

wine.name: "KO" In Côt We Trust, Puzelat
wine.review: Another knockout wine from Thierry Puzelat. Made from Côt (Malbec). Coming from the Loire Valley, as opposed to the southwest of France, you may find this red more spiced yet lighter in body on the palate. Full of delicious red berried fruit character with notes of black pepper and chalky minerals on the finish.

wine.name: Excelsior Shiraz
wine.review: A juicy, tasty red from Robertson, South Africa. It shows loads of dark fruit on the palate with cassis and a touch of smoke on the finish. The tannins are eager to please - in fact, this wine just won't let you down in general. Friendly and approachable.

wine.name: R. Mondavi Cabernet Sauvignon Reserve
wine.review: In 1966, Robert Mondavi founded the Mondavi winery and has been making world-class wines since. This reserve Cabernet Sauvignon is made mostly from Cabernet with a hint of Merlot, Cabernet Franc, Petit Verdot and Malbec. Rich, supple mouth feel, cassis fruit, and lively tannins on the finish make this a remarkable wine.

wine.name: Sauvignon Blanc, Buitenverwachting
wine.review: We won't even attempt to sound the name out phonetically, but we will tell you its translation: "beyond expectation." We found that very apt when we tried this wine. Made partly from vine plantings that are over 80 years old, with some younger ones mixed in as well, it has notes of crisp fresh flowers, peppers and minerals. Still fresh and young, this will evolve wonderfully with a bit of bottle age. From Constantia, a cooler-climate ward of the coastal region of South Africa.

wine.name: AN/2 Anime Negra, Spanish Red
wine.review: Tried a Mallorcan wine lately? This small-production red comes from 50- to 100-year-old vines of the indigenous varieties Callet, Mantonegro, Fogoneu, and Monastrell; the fruit is hand-picked and fermented with native yeasts. With an intriguing nose of bougainvillea and jasmine, and a lush mouthfeel with dark chocolate, coffee, and black plum flavors, this is a must-try.

wine.name: Malbec, Familia Mayol
wine.review: Sweet tannins blend with oak to provide lots of complexity and a velvety texture on this tasty gem from Mendoza, Argentina. Excellent with grilled meats...even burgers!

wine.name: Clos de la Roche GC, H. Lignier
wine.review: It's a nice aspect of the Lignier estate that Romain Lignier, who took it over from Hubert, his father and founder of the estate, is, in many ways, more traditional than his father. He practices Pigéage in the old fashioned sense, by aiding maceration with their bare feet.

wine.name: Ch. Latour, Pauillac
wine.review: This vintage of Latour is showing marvelously today. It's full of tobacco, currants, smoke and ripe tannins on the finish.

wine.name: San Pio, Mastrojanni
wine.review: San Pio is a blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Sangiovese. Dark aromas - black cherries and berries - with herbs, leather and peppercorn. Moderate tannins and best enjoyed with rich meat-based meals such as roasts or stews.

wine.name: Ch. Kefraya, "Les Breteches"
wine.review: When you think of wines from Lebanon, Château Kefraya should always come to mind. This cuvée is a red blend of French varieties: Cabernet, Syrah, Mourvèdre, Carignan and Grenache.

wine.name: Ch. Deyrem Valentin "Cru Bourgeois", Margaux
wine.review: Fresh floral aromas with black fruit and a touch of fresh herbs. Rich and vinous with a rich texture and solid backbone of tannins that will resolve with time.

wine.name: Epesses "Clos du Boux" Grand Cru, Luc Massy
wine.review: From the village of Epesses in the Vaud region nestled alongside the north of Lake Geneva in the west of the Switzerland. Made from the Chasselas grape. Floral, honeyed, smokey and viscous and round on the palate. Aged in large oak barrels. A monopole.

wine.name: Brunello di Montalcino Riserva, Talenti
wine.review: A traditionalist in the land of leisure and experimentation also known as Tuscany. A rich red with dark fruit, firm acidity, and tannins that will allow this wine to age for decades. This reserva bottling spent a good 4 years in cask and subsequent bottle aging before release.

wine.name: Amarone, Quintarelli
wine.review: The most sought after wines from the Veneto. Giuseppe Quintarelli's wines are second to none and enjoyed by connoisseurs and novices alike. Only made in ideal years, this Amarone was held, as always practiced at this estate, and not released until deemed ready. Yet, you'll see the precise fruit can thoroughly evolve for much longer in the cellar.

wine.name: Recioto, Quintarelli
wine.review: From the artisinal and world renown producer whose wines we would love to devour from morning til night.

wine.name: Ca' del Merlo, Quintarelli
wine.review: This Valpolicella comes from a single vineyard known as Ca' del Merlo, named after the Merlo bird of the area. The depth of flavors put this hearty, dry red wine a level above most in its category. It's complex and powerful, yet full of finesse.

wine.name: Billecart-Salmon Brut Réserve
wine.review: A pale yellow Champagne with an elegant, persistent bead that glides down easily. This blend of Chardonnay, Pinot Noir and Pinot Meunier is dry and floral, with aromas of ripe pears.

wine.name: Billecart-Salmon Brut Rosé
wine.review: A fine, delicate bead is Billecart-Salmon's signature. A blend of the Pinots and Chardonnay. Dry with exquisite red berry character and a gorgeous texture. An ideal Champagne to enjoy as an apéritif with smoked salmon or sushi.

wine.name: Moscato d'Asti, Gianni Doglia
wine.review: Aromas of sage and powdered sugar on the palate of this delicate, lightly sparkling dessert wine. Could pass as a liquid breakfast in some people's books but works more appropriately alongside butter cookies or fresh berried fruit tarts. Drink chilled.

wine.name: Stephen Ross Pinot Noir, Central Coast
wine.review: Formerly the winemaker at the prestigious Edna Valley Vineyard, Stephen Ross started his own label in 1994, and has been making graceful and beautiful wines ever since. In creating his entry-level Pinot Noir, he has taken full advantage of the perfect Pinot-friendly climate in the Edna Valley. Full of fresh raspberry fruit with underlying notes of mocha and stones, this wine is mouth-watering!

wine.name: Sinksey Pinot Noir, Vandal Vineyard
wine.review: Robert Sinskey is a trailblazer on the winemaking front in northern California. All of his vineyards are farmed organically, and the Vandal Vineyard is no exception. Near the city limits of Napa, the Vandal vineyard produces deep lush Pinots that show wild, brambly fruit with mocha, clove, and spice undercurrents. Drink now, or hold on to this baby for 5 years.

wine.name: Côte-Rôtie Cuvée Classique, R. Rostaing
wine.review: Pure Syrah. The wine is matured in oak barriques with a very conservative use of new oak - no more than 10%. After 18 months' aging this hearty red was fined and bottled without filtration, rendering a more complex wine, made for the ages.

wine.name: Côte-Rôtie "La Landonne", R. Rostaing
wine.review: A single-vineyard offering from the heart of the famed slope that is Côte Rôtie, this bottling by the enlightened house of Rostaing maximizes the inherent quality of both the vineyard and this outstanding vintage. Built for cellaring, with exquisite structure and intelligent use of oak, this wine only hints at its future potential with a classic aromatic profile of roasted berries and black olives, with nuances of smoke, minerals, and flowers.

wine.name: Vouvray "Le Mont Sec", Huet
wine.review: Huet is the considered to be the master of Vouvray, creating wines that can age for decades. Le Mont is a hillside vineyard overlooking the Loire, creating a softer style wine. This Chenin Blanc shows notes exquisite aromas of honeysuckle flowers. The crisp acidity and minerality that contribute great structure to the wine. Drink with a light chill.

wine.name: Vouvray "Clos du Bourg" Sec, Huet
wine.review: The vineyard is a true "Clos" meaning walled vineyard dating back to the 7th century. The Vouvray has an outstanding expressive nose with floral and honey aromas that will captivate you, while underlying minerality will keep you intrigued.

wine.name: Mirassou Pinot Noir
wine.review: The Mirassou family started making wine in the late 1800s, earning them the distinction of being the oldest winemaking family in America. This Pinot Noir, coming from the cooler region of Monterey County, exhibits the Mirassous' expertise. Bright raspberry and red currant flavors explode on the palate, while underlying notes of spice, earth, and smoke create a lasting finish.

wine.name: Whitehaven Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: A lovely expression of Sauvignon Blanc, this bottling features the classic notes of gooseberry and cut grass on the nose but in a cool, ripe register that also hints at white cranberries with crisp citrus notes. In the mouth this is a textbook Marlborough Sauvignon Blanc, zippy with lovely citrus flavors supported by bright acidity in a medium-bodied style, finishing dry with a subtle mineral note that makes this is a natural match for lighter summer fare.

wine.name: Leopardi Brut Rosé Cava, Llopart
wine.review: This rosé Cava, a great alternative to Champagne, is a blend of Monastrell (aka Mourvedre) and Garnacha. Produced by the Llopart family, which has been producing wine in the Penedés region of Spain since the early 19th century, this Cava is packed with expressive red raspberry fruit and finishes with a spicy bite.

wine.name: Jelu Syrah
wine.review: The Jelu winery, located in the San Juan region of Argentina, is located at an elevation of 900 feet. "Jelu" means sun in the native language, and these grapes do in fact achieve maximum ripeness from all the hot Argentine sun they get. Blackberry fruit, pepper, and great underlying minerality make this a tasty and crowd-pleasing wine.

wine.name: St.-Chinian "Mas au Schiste", Rimbert
wine.review: St. Chinian is a village in the Languedoc-Roussillon known for their ripe, friendly character. This is a hearty red wine that's spiced with dark berry fruit.

wine.name: Côteaux du Languedoc "Promise", Fontedicto
wine.review: A blend of Grenache and Carignan. This estate is a mere 5 hectares in size and is a snapshot of how winemakers tended the land hundreds of years ago - using a horse to plow and simply pressing the grapes. Sounds simple doesn't it? It depends who you're asking...

wine.name: Grolleau "Le Cousin," Cousin-Leduc
wine.review: Looking for something new? Try Grolleau, the little-known Loire Valley grape that has produced this pale red wine redolent of wild berries and earth. It's just a bit gamey and sanguine on the palate, with great acidity and soft tannins that make it a perfect match for wild game birds.

wine.name: Gamay, Cousin-Leduc
wine.review: This Gamay has no sulfur added and is made from 37-year-old vines. The wine has a dark, pulpy character that makes it easy to drink on its own though food is, obviously ideal.

wine.name: Lambrusco "Pruno Nero," Cleto Chiarli
wine.review: This lightly sparkling, medium-bodied dry Lambrusco shows lots of bright red fruit on the palate and is almost alarmingly drinkable. This red is absolutely perfect for the summer: just put a chill on it and enjoy.

wine.name: Lambrusco "Vigneto Enrico Cialdini", Cleto Chiarli
wine.review: This artisanal lambrusco, making its debut in the U.S., comes to us from the Chiarli family in Emilia-Romagna, the oldest producer of Lambrusco in Italy. Made from single-vineyard Grasparossa grapes, this lambrusco has a bright blackberry and raspberry fruit. This sparkling red will dance on your tongue before finishing dry. Try it with your favorite pizza tonight.

wine.name: Chablis, Gilbert Picq
wine.review: With yields kept very low, this village level Chablis has the breeding of a premier cru. It is always flinty and minerally, with notes of green apple and grapefruit. This is classic Chablis at its best.

wine.name: Cabernet Franc, Craftsman
wine.review: Overlooking the Danube River, in the historic of Ászár-Neszmély, sits the Craftsman winery. This area has been a grape-growing region since the Romans planted vines here 2000 years ago. Great blackberry fruit, tannins, and a hint of tobacco on this 100% Cabernet Franc.

wine.name: L. Aubry Fils Brut
wine.review: In this wine Aubry makes a great case for Pinot Meunier, which is 60% of the blend, with the remainder equal parts Chardonnay and Pinot Noir. The wine is soft, rich, round, with light floral honey aromas, and dark notes of crackers, toasted bread and pepper. Just a delight to drink and very food-friendly.

wine.name: L. Aubry "Nombre d'Or - CVV" Brut
wine.review: Made from the ever-unique varieties in Champagne of Arbanne, Petit Meslier and Fromenteau. Lovely aromas of green tea, tarragon, lemon and nectarine - simply full of character. An brilliant Champagne from a devoted small producer.

wine.name: L. Aubry Sablé Rosé
wine.review: Sablé is a term that is only used at Aubry's estate in Champagne. It's a dry, lightly- pétillant rosé with aromas of hibiscus & strawberries.

wine.name: Jacquesson Brut Cuvée 733
wine.review: Perfection Brut is the classic Champagne blend - Pinot Noir, Meunier and Chardonnay, multi-vintage, multi-village. It is wonderfully complex, perfectly balanced, minimally dosed. It is a wine of elegance, structure and finesse.

wine.name: Henri Billiot Brut Réserve
wine.review: From a tiny estate in Ambonnay in the Montagne de Reims, this NV Brut is great wine. No dosage, no filtration, no malolactic fermentation, but Grand Cru fruit of the highest quality. The wine is bright and lively with lavish fruit flavors.

wine.name: Vilmart "Grand Cellier" 1er Cru, Brut
wine.review: Truly a luxury Champagne, even though a MV or "Multi-Vintage". It is made from free-run juice only. It is a barrel-fermented wine, rich and luscious, with aromas of orange blossom, mint, herbs and spice, with fullness and great depth of flavor. This is a favorite food wine for it's rich and giving. Age-worthy but drinks well today too. Biodynamic.

wine.name: Jean Milan "Carte Blanche", Blanc de Blancs Brut
wine.review: 100% Chardonnay from the village of Oger, in the heart of the Côtes des Blancs. It has floral and honeyed apple aromas, soft and elegant fruit on top of fine and firm stony minerality.

wine.name: Pierre Peters, Blanc de Blancs "Cuvée Réserve" Brut
wine.review: An intensely mineral Champagne. The chalky character comes from the chalky soils of Mesnil-sur-Oger. This is dry wine with great concentration of citrusy fruit and a touch of green tea. Great as an apéritif wine and a must have with seafood, especially shellfish.

wine.name: Cristalino Cava Brut
wine.review: This soft, fruit-forward Cava has a lovely nose of apples, toast, and cinnamon. The rich flavors of ripe apples and figs finish with a clean citrus note. Simple and fun, this is a great apéritif.

wine.name: Felton Road Pinot Noir, Central Otago
wine.review: A nose of plum, dark cherry and herbs with oriental spice. Ripeness drives the palate, no jamminess but a rich, dark compote of black fruit laced with raspberry and chocolate.

wine.name: Guy Larmandier Rosé 1er Cru, Brut
wine.review: Côtes des Blancs Chardonnay blended with 12% Pinot Noir to give the wine its pale rosé color. This is a wine of precision and purity, brisk and dry on the palate, with all the character and presence needed for the dinner table.

wine.name: Can Blau, Montsant
wine.review: The Montsant region, located on the periphery of the Priorat D.O., is considered by many to be baby Priorat. Can Blau is a traditional blend of Cariñena, Syrah, and Garnacha. Grown on slate hillsides, this wine is characterized by plush black fruit and underlying minerality.

wine.name: Iron Horse "Wedding Cuvée", Blanc de Noirs
Hebrart "Cuvée de Reserve" 1er Cru, Brut
wine.review: Full of cream, red apples and citrus fruits on the palate. Mostly Pinot Noir then Chardonnay. This Champagne is made from vineyards that are at least 32 years old. Older, healthy vines are highly prized for good reason - they add complexity.

wine.name: Pêche Impériale
wine.review: Natural peach aromas and flavors flow through this fresh and lively French sparkling wine. Produced in the Loire and made mostly from Chenin Blanc, it is an engagingly unique, off-dry sparkler.

wine.name: The William, Graham Beck
wine.review: A delicious and complex blend of Pinotage and Cabernet Sauvignon. This dark red shows lots of spicy oak and cassis on the nose and palate.

wine.name: Guy Larmandier, Cramant, Blanc de Blancs
wine.review: This is from Larmandier's 8-acre Grand Cru vineyard in Cramant, the epicenter of Chardonnay in Champagne. The wine is very dry, fresh and filigreed, with fine acidity that marries the mineral, fruit and toast flavors.

wine.name: Aglianico "Irpina", Mastroberardino
wine.review: Aglianico is the great red grape of southern Italy, and Mastroberardino makes some of the finest examples in existence. Deep purple, smoky, and dense, these wines have excellent potential to age. Try this with a slab of grilled meat: the smokiness of both the food and the wine will make for a compelling pairing.

wine.name: Quivira Zinfandel, Dry Creek
wine.review: Quivira is a small, organic, family-run estate in the heart of Sonoma in California. This Zinfandel is produced with fruit from several different vineyards throughout the Dry Creek Valley. It's a dry red wine with an abundance of red raspberry fruit with underlying layers of tobacco, cedar, and mocha.

wine.name: Barolo "S. Stefano di Perno", G. Mascarello
wine.review: Lovely light garnet color, with brambly aromas and raspberry fruit leading to a lengthy and smooth finish. This is an accomplished bottling that shows all the power and potential of this vintage.

wine.name: Westhofener Morstein Riesling TBA, Wittmann
wine.review: The Wittman winery is located in the Rheinhessen region and is a family estate of 25 hectares. This is a wine to cellar, a dessert wine that was made with miniscule yields. The Morstein vineyard site is highly esteemed - this bottle proves why: intense cantaloup, keylime and stone fruit dominate.

wine.name: Pernand-Vergelesses Blanc, Rollin
wine.review: Some of the most astounding white Burgundy these days comes from lesser-known villages such as this Chardonnay from Pernand-Vergelesses. You can find tremendous satisfaction in the bouquet itself: cream, leesy floral aromas and mineral. The palate is equally satisfying and clearly points in the direction that this can be held for years to come.

wine.name: Vina Robles Chardonnay, Monterey
wine.review: This winery was born of a dream in the mid-'90s by two Swiss entrepreneurs who fell in love with the Central Coast of California. The fruit for their Chardonnay was sourced from Monterey, a very cool microclimate. Aromas of apple and honeyed citrus lead to flavors of baking spices, tropical fruit, and a warm toasty finish. An oaky style of Chardonnay.

wine.name: Savennières "Cuvée Speciale, Ch. d'Épiré
wine.review: From a ripe vintage comes this rich Chenin Blanc redolent of lanolin, pollen, ripe pear and quince over a base of wet stones. The richness in the mouth is cut but the rapier like acidity and the fruit is contrasted nicely by the crisp mineral notes.

wine.name: Notios Red, Gaia
wine.review: Notios means "the southerner," and this easy-drinking red is indeed from southern Greece. It is made from the local Agiorgitiko variety, which in this case has yielded a soft, velvety wine with plum and cherry flavors.

wine.name: Dom. Ste. Michelle Brut
wine.review: This wine is smooth and dry, with nicely balanced fruit and yeast flavors. A very good buy in American sparkling wine.

wine.name: VdP Merlot, Dom. de la Patience
wine.review: Here we have a stellar example of high-quality Vin de Pays from a great producer. This fruit-forward Merlot from the Languedoc region shows assertive black cherry flavors and a smooth, velvety mouthfeel. It is made without the use of sulfites by a Natural winemaker.

wine.name: Gloria Ferrer Brut, Sonoma
wine.review: A relatively high proportion of Chardonnay in this blend gives the wine a nice delicacy and elegance. A touch of yeastiness blends well with the fruit. Always one of the best buys from California.

wine.name: Torrette, Grosjean Frères
wine.review: The Vallée d'Aoste region is a tiny winemaking region nestled high up in the Alps of northwest Italy. For such a small region, there are certainly a wealth of great wines coming from unheard of indigenous varieties. This light-bodied, dry red wine offers elegance, pure red fruits and lithe mineral.

wine.name: Mas de Gourgonnier, Baux de Provence
wine.review: This robust red blend is a crowd favorite that is drinking exceedingly well in its youth. Chock-full of dark berries with a touch of anise, this wine gets a little support from an approachable tannic structure.

wine.name: Castle Rock Petite Sirah, California
wine.review: A medium-bodied Petite Sirah featuring dark berry fruits and black pepper, gently supported by spicy oak. The typically aggressive tannins of Petite Sirah are incredibly well managed here, yielding a bright and smooth expression of this California variety.

wine.name: Terra Andina Merlot
wine.review: Full of plump plum fruits and a bit of spice, this Merlot is a great red wine to open up with friends (or even enemies - it's that good).

wine.name: Château Gaunoux Bourgogne Blanc, F. Gaunoux
wine.review: A great example of traditionally made Chardonnay from a 10 hectare estate. Beautiful upfront fruit aromas of crisp, green apples and pears. Dry with a voluptuous, silken texture and a solid backbone of acidity that makes this a very food friendly companion at the dinner table. If you love the village wines from Gaunoux, try this "baby" Gaunoux for a remarkable glimpse of what this winery has to offer.

wine.name: Montepulciano "Marina Cvetic", Masciarelli
wine.review: This is a dense red wine that's certainly not your typical Montepulciano. Think of it as a "Super Abruzzo" with all the richness and structure.

wine.name: Korbel Natural
wine.review: A very dry sparkler with pear and apple fruit flavors. A hint of ginger adds a nice spicy dimension to the finish.

wine.name: Segura Viudas Reserva Heredade
wine.review: Medium-bodied and smooth with aromas and flavors of toast, fruit and spice that linger on the long finish. A very special Cava.

wine.name: Malleolus de Sancho Martin, Emilio Moro
wine.review: Malleolus de Sancho Martin is a single-vineyard wine coming from Bodegas Emilio Moro, located in the region of Pesquera de Duero. The vines are planted in a limestone-clay and produce a velvet texture and lush blackberry fruit. Decant and enjoy now, or hold for 15 years.

wine.name: Lustau East India "Solera Reserva" Sherry
wine.review: Centuries ago, casks of solera Sherry were lashed to ships sailing for the Indies as ballast, and were then found to be extraordinarily smooth and complex, with nutty sweet flavors. This one is great with lighter desserts and cheeses or by itself as an after-dinner treat.

wine.name: Étoile Chardonnay, Dom. de Montbourgeau
wine.review: Your friends might not believe that this is Chardonnay: It's made in an oxidized style, so it's not for everyone - but the wine geek in your life will flip over this bottle.

wine.name: Dom. Triennes Viognier, Ste. Fleur
wine.review: A fresh, dry white wine with apricot and peach floral aromas and lovely minerals on the finish. This is a fruit-laden Viognier that you can enjoy tonight.

wine.name: Pinot Nero Riserva, St. Michael-Eppan
wine.review: It took a long time to find a Pinot Nero that's varietally correct and affordable from northern Italy. This comes from the Alto Adige region from a respectable cooperative in Appiano. What we love is the delicate texture and the playful red fruit character on the palate. A bargain in our eyes!

wine.name: Moscato d'Asti, G.D. Vajra
wine.review: Dessert wines like this are dangerously easy to ingest at any hour. We especially enjoy the sage fruit character and the acidity balancing out the sweetness on the finish. Lightly sparkling, light in alcohol.

wine.name: Valpolicella Classico "Solane", Santi
wine.review: Rich and smooth with a good concentration of ripe plummy fruit. Dry and a bit earthy this is the wine for your next rich Italian meal or try it with roasted pork and rosemary sage stuffing. Very well balanced.

wine.name: Mumm Napa Brut Prestige
wine.review: Plenty of complex fruit flavors blend nicely with a touch of yeast and toasty oak. The lovely finish adds touches of anise and earth.

wine.name: Billecart-Salmon Brut Rosé
wine.review: A fine, delicate bead is Billecart-Salmon's signature. A blend of the Pinots and Chardonnay. Dry with exquisite red berry character and a gorgeous texture. An ideal Champagne to enjoy as an apéritif with smoked salmon or sushi.

wine.name: Krug, Multi-Vintage Brut
wine.review: The richest Champagne style produced today. Barrel fermentation and plenty of Pinot Noir give this the power that lovers of full bodied Champagne crave!

wine.name: Krug, Multi-Vintage Brut
wine.review: A brilliantly made wine of great finesse and power. This is the blending art raised to its highest level.

wine.name: Muscadet VV "Pierre de la Grange," Luneau-Papin
wine.review: Pierre Luneau-Papin's estate, also known as Pierre de la Grange, is situated in the heart of Muscadet country and has been in existence since the early 18th century. His wines are meticulously produced, from the hand-harvested old vines to his exceedingly careful cellar work. Clean, crisp wines with underlying intense minerality are the result. This is one of those rare Muscadets that will age beautifully.

wine.name: Riesling "Gobelsburger", Schloss Gobelsburg
wine.review: With notes of green tea, verbena, pear, lime-blossom, and wisteria, this is an absolute masterpiece from the Schloss Gobelsburg estate. A gorgeous, structured, and focused Riesling.

wine.name: Estival, Viñedo de los Vientos
wine.review: We highly doubt you would guess where this wine came from if you tasted it blind. You'd certainly note its clean, unoaked New World style. This is a dry white blend that’s highly aromatic and fresh, with floral and apple fruit. It’s also delicious.

wine.name: Tannat, Viñedo de los Vientos
wine.review: We're no etymologists, but we think it would be fair to say that the red Tannat grape got its name from the tannins in its skins. Yes, the tannins in this wine are firm - but boy, are they good with anything meat-based, especially if it's grilled. So go ahead: lug the barbecue out to your fire escape and enjoy.

wine.name: Fixin Blanc, Hubert Lignier
wine.review: Get ready for some mouthwatering Chardonnay. This is full of minerals, full of lively acidity and of course the floral, honeyed fruit.

wine.name: Hourglass Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Coming from winemaker Bob Foley, this small production Cabernet shows his characteristic winemaking style of ripe dark fruit concentration, sweet round tannic structure and a long velvety finish. A powerhouse of a wine. The name comes from the hourglass shape of the vineyard located in the narrowest part of Napa.

wine.name: Schioppettino, Girolamo Dorigo
wine.review: What's this? Why, Schioppettino, of course. One of the many great grapes indigenous to Friuli, Schiopettino makes medium-bodied red wines with floral notes and rustic acidity. Pair this with gamey foods or hard cheeses.

wine.name: Luzon, Jumilla
wine.review: Coming from a tiny winery in the southeastern part of Spain, this full-throttled red is mostly Mourvèdre with a tiny bit of Syrah. Spicy black plum, red currants, and licorice fill the palate, and it finishes with a warm vanilla toastiness. A great introduction to Spanish reds.

wine.name: Fumin "Vigna Merletta", Grosjean Frères
wine.review: Fumin is a rather obscure red variety grown in the alpine region of Val d'Aosta, in the northernmost part of Italy. This red is lively, yet delicate, with focused red berry fruits and notes of rose petals.

wine.name: Farnum Hill Extra Dry Apple Cider
wine.review: This cider blew our staff away with it serious earthy palate and intense focus. Very wine like in nature, the Extra Dry would make for some very fun food pairings. Pick up a bottle and let the experimentation begin.

wine.name: Santenay "Grand Clos Rousseau", Jean-Marc Morey
wine.review: A gamey Pinot Noir from the lesser-known village of Santenay. Lithe, earthy with aromas of red currants. A sanguine touch on the finish makes this an ideal match with venision or any rarely prepared meat dishes.

wine.name: Schramsberg, Blanc de Noirs
wine.review: Bright and lovely, this vivacious bubbly can barely contain the berry and candied citrus aromas that soar up from the glass. The exuberant bouquet is perfect preparation for the decadent palate impression, oozing stone fruits and subtle notes of vanilla and cream.

wine.name: Kumeu River Chardonnay
wine.review: This Chardonnay balances flavor intensity with subtle winemaking to produce an elegant wine that we found reminiscent of a nice Burgundy. Its rich core of apple fruit gives way to gently assertive notes of vanilla, tropical flowers and earth. This wine has a track record of aging exceptionally well and remains one of New Zealand’s finest whites, year in and year out.

wine.name: VdP de Vaucluse, Dom. de Fenouillet
wine.review: This tasty red wine is from the southern borders of the Rhône Valley, more specifically known as the Vaucluse. This based on the Marcelan grape (a cross between Grenache and Cabernet Sauvignon), with Merlot and Alicante Bouschet. Naturally, there's a bit of spice on the palate and lots of mixed dark fruit.

wine.name: WH Smith Pinot Noir, Sonoma Coast
wine.review: Strawberry, cola, and pomegranate flavors burst on the palate of this Sonoma Coast Pinot Noir. Toasty vanilla mingles with a well-balanced acidity to create a complex, elegant Pinot with a velvety-smooth texture.

wine.name: A to Z Chardonnay
wine.review: It's quite the success story: This Chardonnay came about through a partnership of the two families that founded A to Z in 2001 - and A to Z is now the fastest-growing winery in the Willamette Valley. Fermented and aged mainly in stainless steel, this white wine has a bright, crisp character.

wine.name: Saar Rausch Riesling Auslese, Zilliken
wine.review: Wines from the 1993 vintage were very good coming from the Mosel's top producers. Zilliken thrived and produced a clean, exquisitely ripened Riesling. The minerality and general austerity of Riesling from the Saar tributary are exemplary in this bottle. Take a drink for yourself.

wine.name: Vrucara, Feudo Montoni
wine.review: A hearty, medium-bodied red wine from central Sicily that shows aromas of blueberries, fresh rosemary, fern, and olives, with excellent minerality on the finish. This is clean, unadulterated Nero d'Avola that can easily be held for years to come.

wine.name: Nero d'Avola, Feudo Montoni
wine.review: A Sicilian Nero d'Avola that shows pure red-berried fruit, fresh acidity, and a touch of mineral on the finish. This red could easily be held for years, but it needn't be; if you're drinking it today, it will be excellent after a quick decanting.

wine.name: Argyle Brut
wine.review: Apples and asian pear aromas with ovely fruit on the palate and just the right amount of bubbles. Drink with a light chill as an apéritif wine if you like it on the more fruit forward side.

wine.name: Moscato d'Asti "Sori' Gramella", Tintero
wine.review: We think it's a good thing to drink Moscato d'Asti alongside a nice brunch on the weekend even if it's really a dessert wine. It's never too early to enjoy the wonders of this low alcohol sparkling wine that's taking our customers by surprise.

wine.name: Ch. Curé Bon la Madeleine, St.-Émilion
wine.review: A powerful wine made mostly from Merlot from a small domaine located just across the street from Ausone. Just delightful with earthy notes of plum and berries and a hint of anise. Drinking well today.

wine.name: Avinyó Cava Brut Reserve
wine.review: Produced in the Penedès region north of Barcelona, Spain, this Cava is a great sparkling alternative. It's a blend of the traditional grapes used for Cava: Parellada, Xarel-lo, and Macabeo. Made in méthode champenoise with no dosage - meaning it's bone dry.

wine.name: BV Private Reserve Cab. George De Latour
Adelaida Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Adelaida winery, founded in 1981, is located on the west side of Paso Robles, an area known for its limestone and calcareous shale. This is a rustic Cabernet, full of brambly fruit, lively tannins, and a great texture. A must try.

wine.name: Clos Mimi Syrah, Shell Creek Vineyard
Marcassin Chardonnay, Hudson Vineyard, E Block
Donnas Rouge, Vallée d'Aoste
wine.review: This is a true Alpine wine that sings of its place of origin. These steep hills and mountains are ideal for grazing herds, also for the production of light bodied red wines. A blend of Nebbiolo and Freisa, this bottle gives delicious brambly notes on the nose, as well as dark, fleshy black berries and cherries. Imagine the elegance of a Barbaresco combined with the light, airiness of a Pinot Noir. The tannins are very approachable and the wine makes a perfect accompaniment to many of the local cheeses from Vallé d'Aoste.

wine.name: Sancerre, Dom. La Croix St.-Laurent
wine.review: This is solid Sancerre that makes for a great everyday white wine. Produced at a small estate from 30-year-old Sauvignon Blanc vines, this wine is left in contact with the lees until bottling. With excellent ripeness of white fruit and fresh white flowers, this Sancerre represents a leaner style that’s approachable today.

wine.name: Georges Gardet "Cuvée Saint Flavy" Brut
wine.review: This family's vineyards are spread over 7 hectares of Premier Cru areas of Chigny les Roses, Ludes and Rilly la Montagne. A Champagne with ripe red strawberries on the palate. Great round mousse and fruit-forwardness.

wine.name: Veramonte Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: Casablanca Valley in Chile is the premier place to grow Sauvignon Blanc that ripens to perfection with rich fruit flavors complemented by lively acidity. Refreshing, light, crisp with citrus flavors makes it perfect for any occasion.

wine.name: Saumur Brut Rose, Vieux Pressoir
wine.review: Rosé wine is always a pleasure to drink whether it be zero or a hundred degrees outside. Add to that the bubbles and you'll see why it's especially refreshing on the palate. This is a dry, sparkling pink wine that's bursting with red fruit aromas on the palate.

wine.name: French Rabbit Pinot Noir Tetra Pak
Ch. Ste Michelle "Eroica" Riesling
wine.review: In collaboration with the famed Dr. Loosen estate of Germany's Mosel region, Ch. Ste Michelle has created this wine in the image of the best Old World Rieslings. This has bright raciness, seamlessly woven in with ripe peach flavors and citrusy accents.

wine.name: Valpolicella Ca' Fiui, Corte Sant'Alda
wine.review: From one of our favorite Amarone producers comes this stellar ''baby'' Amarone known simply as Valpolicella. A spicey red wine with fleshy dark berries, cherry wood and a note of cedar. Medium-bodied and mineraled on the finish and ideal with rich fare.

wine.name: Ruca Malen, Yauquén
wine.review: A full-bodied red blend made from Cabernet Sauvignon and Malbec. Spends 10 months in barrel adding complexities of cedars and vanilla. Full of black candied aromas, pure dark chocolate and mineral on the finish.

wine.name: Vinupetra Rosso IGT, I Vigneri di Salvo Foti
wine.review: Leave it to the expert, Salvo Foti, to get his hands on old vines of red indigenous varieties planted on the volcanic Mount Etna. Foti is Sicily's most learned winemaker, and his passion and meticulous nature shine through in this unadulterated red. Decant and enjoy this today or hold it for years to come.

wine.name: Oliver Caldwell Cabernet Sauvignon, Aida Vineyard
wine.review: A solid Cabernet Sauvignon from the St. Helena area of Napa. Decant now and drink, or hold for several more years.

wine.name: Tom Eddy Cabernet Sauvignon,
wine.review: From legendary winemaker Tom Eddy, this Cabernet shows a floral nose, with notes of violet, rose, and white pepper. A great wine from a sleeper vintage.

wine.name: Beaune 1er Cru "Toussaints", Lucien Jacob
wine.review: An estate that came to evolve in its modern form in the late 60's when Pinot Noir became their focus. Before, their emphasis was growing cassis and framboise. These days they've mastered each of these specialties to perfection. This wine is fairly structured with concentrated mixed berry aromas.

wine.name: Ex Libris Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: A very nicely ripened Cabernet from the Columbia Valley. Full of red and blackcurrant berries on the palate. Fresh and very approachable yet still has a nice backbone of tannins.

wine.name: Anjou Blanc, Ch. Soucherie
wine.review: From a producer known for exquisite Savennières comes this introductory-level Chenin Blanc. Notes of fresh peach, honeydew, and white flower are balanced by a crisp acidity.

wine.name: Chianti Classico Riserva, Monsanto
wine.review: Winemaker Laura Bianchi makes an old world style Chianti Classico that is full on the palate and has lots of black fruit flavors.

wine.name: Red Knot Cabernet Sauvignon, McClaren Vale
wine.review: This Cabernet Sauvignon from South Australia shows ripe cassis fruit and a velvet texture. Bright acidity and lively tannins round out the finish.

wine.name: Essencia, Royal Tokaji
wine.review: The Royal Tokaji winery was started in 1990. This is the rarest of wines in the world. So thick and concentrated, it took well over 6 months just to ferment. Comes with a crystal sipping spoon that will serve 33 lucky mouths. This is the best vintage out since the fabulous '93's.

wine.name: Bramaterra, Sella
wine.review: The Sella winery has been family-owned since the early 1700s. Bramaterra (the name of both the wine and the vineyard) is a red blend: mostly old-vine Nebbiolo, with Vespolina and Croatina as well. Exotic, dark-berried, spicy fruit, with notes of rose petals, quinine and aniseed.

wine.name: Lessona, Sella
wine.review: The Lessona appellation boasts just one producer: Sella. This northern Piedmontese red wine is based on Nebbiolo and Vespolina. The nose evolves by the minute, filled with violets, warm spices, strawberry compote, mint, and sanguine minerals. Approachable today but can be held for years.

wine.name: Blanc de Blancs 1er Cru, Voirin-Jumel
wine.review: This Champagne is made in a fresh and friendly style, highlighting notes of bright orchard fruits accented by a light yeastiness and a slight minerality on the finish. This full-bodied wine should ideally be served with food (think white meat and cream sauces – even chicken pot pie), though it is a pleasure to enjoy all on its own. No doubt this NV will flourish with age yet is drinking wonderfully today.

wine.name: "Mailly" Brut Nature, Raymond Boulard
wine.review: This Champagne is classified as a "Brut Nature," a designation given only to the driest of sparkling wines. This winery has been meticulously tending their vines since the late 17th century. This is no pedestrian wine; rather, it shows great complexity, with lots of earthy iron minerals and floral, berry-driven character.

wine.name: Grand Cru Cramant Brut, Voirin-Jumel
wine.review: An intense golden Champagne based on Chardonnay and a terrific value in Grand Cru, vintage bubbly. The nose offers notes of earth, honey, raw mushroom, nuts, and mineral. The bead is fine and somewhat mellowed by time. Dry and complex.

wine.name: Grand Cru "555", Voirin Jumel
wine.review: There are only two occasions when I drink Champagne, and these are: when I have game for dinner and when I haven't.

wine.name: Petraea MMV Brut, Raymond Boulard
wine.review: Petraea is an unusual wine made in a “perpetual cuvée” (a term that Boulard prefers to “solera”), begun in 1997. The name Petraea refers to the type of oak that the barrels used for this wine are made from, and the final blend contains about 60 percent pinot noir, with the remainder equally divided between chardonnay and meunier. It’s neither filtered nor fined.

wine.name: Brut Rosé de Saignée, Boulard
wine.review: "What contemptible scoundrel stole the cork from my lunch?" W.C. Fields

wine.name: Barbaresco "Boito," Rizzi
wine.review: Rizzi's Grand Cru vineyard "Boito" consists mostly of old Nebbiolo vines planted on chalk-based soils. The wine shows great structure, full of violets and rose petals on the palate - the quintessential attributes of traditionally crafted Barbaresco.

wine.name: Corton-Charlemagne Grand Cru, Dom. Chevalier
wine.review: Top producers with vineyards in prime locations turned out fantastic white Burgundy even in this capricious vintage.

wine.name: Roussanne VdP, Cuilleron
wine.review: Roussanne is one of the handful of white grape varieties used in the Rhône Valley to make their aromatic whites. Typically, it's blended, here it's what makes up this beautiful wine. Dry, aromas of fresh bay leaf, white flowers, raw honey and more. Viscous in texture and drinking very well today.

wine.name: Syrah, Dom. Monte de Luz
wine.review: This is an unoaked Syrah that comes from the pictoresque Majoma mountain region. These young vines are planted in schist-based soil at a 500 feet above sea level. This elevation allows for cooler temperatures that in turn preserve acidity on the palate.

wine.name: Tannat, Dom. Monte de Luz
wine.review: Tannat is a hearty grape that's home in Madiran, France but has been planted in Uruguay for decades. This wine is opaque and full of blacker than black berried fruits on the palate. Still has a freshness to it and will work wonders with grilled burgers or steak.

wine.name: Côte-Rôtie, "Côte Blond," Rostaing
wine.review: This is one of the top cuvées from René Rostaing, considered one of the best producers in the Northern Rhône. Rostaing started out in 1971 with only 0.47 hectares in the Côte-Rôtie vineyards and now has over 6 hectares. This wine is shows smoky black plum notes and lush tannins.

wine.name: Côte-Rôtie, "Cuvée Classique", Rostaing
wine.review: This entry-level cuvée comes from René Rostaing, one of the masters of the northern Rhône. The Cuvée Classique is a blend of grapes from different vineyards in the Côte-Rôtie, and it shows dark blueberry, tobacco, and brambly tannins.

wine.name: Côte-Rôtie, "La Landonne," Rostaing
wine.review: La Landonne is considered the top cuvée from René Rostaing. The grapes are sourced from three vineyard sites in La Landonne, including old vines. Smoky and sultry, this wine can be drunk young, yet will explode with flavor if aged 10-20 years.

wine.name: Muscat de Rivesaltes, Groupement des Producteurs
wine.review: This Vin Doux Naturel from the Rousillon region of France.

wine.name: Vinho Verde, Provam
wine.review: This tasty white comes from the area of Monção in the Vinho Verde region of northern Portugal. It’s dry on the palate, offering firm minerals and notes of tarragon and green apples. A natural match for anything seafood-based, this is also quite refreshing all by itself.

wine.name: Wisdom & Warter Amontillado Sherry
wine.review: The Wisdom & Warter firm was began in 1854 by two Englishmen, and continues today to make high-quality Sherries. This Amontillado is medium-dry, with notes of hazelnut and mocha. Aging has given this Sherry a special elegance.

wine.name: Wisdom & Warter Cream Sherry
wine.review: The firm of Wisdom & Warter was started over 150 years ago in Jerez. This Cream Sherry was produced from the blending of Oloroso and Pedro Ximenez sherry, producing a sherry that is light, with a good amount of sweetness. This is a perfect sherry as an aperitif, after dinner, or on the rocks to refresh.

wine.name: Bogle Pinot Noir
wine.review: This is the first time that Bogle has made this limited edition Pinot Noir. Flavors of red raspberries and toasty vanilla oak make this the perfect barbecue wine.

wine.name: Punto Final Malbec Reserva
wine.review: This rich red is aged in French oak for 16 months and then in bottle for a further 6 months. It is deep violet-red in color, with a nose that reveals a combination of red fruits and toasty notes from the oak. On the palate it is a complex and structured wine with a long finish.

wine.name: Krug, Rosé Multi-Vintage
wine.review: A blend based on Pinot Noir with Chardonnay and Pinot Meunier. Delectable berried and spiced fruit on the palate. Aged in oak cask, a full-bodied Champagne that evolves by the minute in the glass.

wine.name: Sassicaia
wine.review: Coming from a cooler vintage this Sassicaia exhibits classic notes of Cabernet in it's herbaceous nose which features green herbs as well as crisp cassis fruit. Lean and focused in the mouth with a rich savory, earthy core.

wine.name: Sassicaia
wine.review: A legend in the making. 1997 was a benchmark vintage in Tuscany and Sassicaia took full advantage of the warmth of the growing seaon to produce this flamboyant wine redolent of warm berries and savory baking spices. Decadent in the mouth with a soft structure and a plush mouthfeel.

wine.name: Barolo "Cannubi Boschis", Sandrone
wine.review: Luciano Sandrone led the modernist movement in Barolo but has moderated his approach in recent years. His move from small barriques to larger tonneaux is obvious in the less noticable oak impact his recent vintages exhibit. This approach lets the fruit take center stage and yields plush and pure wines.

wine.name: Rombauer Vineyard Chardonnay
wine.review: Full-bodied yet showing impeccable balance, Rombauer's Chardonnay has fresh honey and citrus notes that keep you coming back for more. It's extremely versatile and goes well with a huge range of foods.

wine.name: Chianti Classico "Le Trame", Le Boncie
wine.review: One of our latest additions to the Chianti Classico bin. It should really fall under the sub-section of "Supremely Elegant Chianti Classico" but we realize that this will confuse some. What's most straightforward about this is the pristine red fruit on the palate that's both lithe yet focused at the same time.

wine.name: Klausner Laitacher, Eisacktaler, Garlider
wine.review: From steep, mountainside vineyards in northern Italy comes this brilliant red comprised mostly of Schiava with a touch of Lagrein. The varied soils of clay, iron, quartz, and granite lend a distinctly mineral component to the wine. Delicate and almost Burgundian in style, it offers notes of red berries, wild flowers, and white pepper. Aged in large (used) tonneaux.

wine.name: Spigau Crociata "Terredamare," Le Rocche del Gatto
wine.review: Fear not this bold, earthy, dry white wine that is near amber in color. Made from Pigato, it has precise floral aromas, fresh pear fruits, and great acidity. Drink it cool, but don't overchill.

wine.name: Lambrusco di Sorbara Red, Zucchi
wine.review: A frizzante that's dry with firm acidity and aromas of fresh raspberries and violets. This is quite different from the inky, dark Lambrusco most people are used to. The fruit is redder and the texture far more delicate. The name "Lambrusco" actually refers to a large family of grapes, much like Moscato or Pinot. This Lambrusco di Sorbara will evolve for years to come.

wine.name: Chardonnay, Terlan
wine.review: Just released, this wine had been stored in stainless steel on it's lees for a decade of ageing under ideal conditions. Thus this wine has evolved marvelously with laurel leaf, mirabelle and white flowers on the palate. Dry, minerally and still very fresh and with a roundness from ageing that rivals fine Burgundy.

wine.name: Madiran, Pierre Laplace
wine.review: Madirans are generally rich and chunky and full of black fruit. This one certainly leans that way, but it is fresher and much more lively on the palate than the typical high-tannin Madiran (no doubt owing to its 20% each of Cabernet Franc and Cabernet Sauvignon).

wine.name: Santa Sara, J.P. Vinhos
wine.review: Santa Sara is part of the new breed of juicy, friendly wines from the Alentejo region, and it's quite a popular bottle around here. Made from Tempranillo and indigenous Portuguese red grapes, it is packed with bright fruit and sturdy tannins.

wine.name: Ch. Le Pavillon de Boyrein Rouge, Graves
wine.review: This is an unusual red Graves in that it's made with 40% Merlot - pretty high for an area with more Cabernet under vine. This makes it incredibly approachable with round, red fruit on the front palate. It's still structured and has a subtle-but-present stony mineral finish. Will drink well for years to come.

wine.name: Ch. L'Hermitage Bordeaux Rouge, St.-Émilion
wine.review: A dense, silky red wine from 45 year old vines. Round texture on the palate with precise red and black fruit.

wine.name: Norton Ridge Cabernet Sauvignon, Napa
wine.review: With notes of mocha and cassis, this has all of the characteristics that make reds from California, and Cabernet Sauvignon in particular, such a treat. Decant this wine for a great experience.

wine.name: Côtes de Provence "Escapade", Comptoirs de Magdala
wine.review: Antoine Pouponneau, winemaker of Tour du Bon Bandol, has created this brilliant Côtes de Provence. It's full of bright red fruit and balanced acidity.

wine.name: Paranga Red, Kir Yianni
wine.review: Located in the Macedonia region of Northern Greece, the Kir Yianni estate produces quality wines, marrying indigenous and international varieties. The Paranga is a blend of the local Xinomavro grape with Merlot and Syrah, creating a wine with notes of cinnamon, red fruit, and a peppery finish.

wine.name: Gewurztraminer VT "Rangen de Thann", Schoffit
wine.review: A luscious late harvest from the esteemed vineyard site of Rangen de Thann. This is spicy on the palate, nicely sweet with aromas of lychee and candied ginger.

wine.name: Vin Santo, Villa Sant'Anna
wine.review: Traditional, real-deal, Vin Santo is a rarity today. Made only in stellar vintages and left up to nature as to whether the wine will turn out. The grapes are fermented then put into tiny casks where they sit for 7 years before opening it up. This is the kind of precarious behavior that gets the palate going. Pure apricots, rustic and lithe texture that will make you teary.

wine.name: Falerio Bianco "Telusiano," Rio Maggio
wine.review: From the Marches region of central Italy comes this beautiful white blend of Trebbiano and Pecorino (it's not just a cheese). The wine has aromas of white tea, lilac pollen, and white flowers. Unoaked, delicate and dry, it has a beautiful silken texture on the palate.

wine.name: De Wetshof Estate "Lesca" Chardonnay
wine.review: A delicious white wine that is lightly oaked for 3 months; the wood shows up on the palate as a fresh undertone of vanilla bean. With its abundant floral apple fruit, you'd never mistake this for anything but a great Chardonnay. It's drinking well today but could certainly hold for a few years to come.

wine.name: Fleur de California Petite Sirah, North Coast
wine.review: This is the perfect cool-weather wine. Packed with flavors of pepper, vanilla, and black fruit, this red has a smooth texture and bright acidity. Great with game.

wine.name: Tannat "Alcyone", Viñedo de los Vientos
wine.review: Uruguay is surprising us these days with their vast realm of reds, whites, and even dessert wines such as this one. Made from the Tannat grape, a variety that renders reds with very decent tannins, this is fortified lightly with grappa and tastes almost like a sweet Italian bitter.

wine.name: Vin Santo, Fèlsina
wine.review: This dessert wine comes from the Chianti Classico zone of Tuscany. I'ts made by first air-drying the grapes for 7 months. Then there's fermentation in small casks for 7 years. The result is this nutty, sultan raisined, peach dessert wine that's sweet but balanced with meyer lemon acidity.

wine.name: MJZZU Blau & Blau, Jermann
wine.review: Rumor has it that this wine was named after the sound that dogs make, a version of "bow wow" or to Jermann "Blau & Blau". A play on words that also ties in the grape used: Blaufränkisch, Blauburgunder. Full of blackberries, blueberries & cedar on the palate. Fleshy texture & slight minerals on the finish.

wine.name: Esszencia, Királyudvar
wine.review: Esszencia is the quintessence of Tokaj. This is made from the juice that runs free from the botrytized aszú berries. One of the rarest wines made in the world. So concentrated that the fermentation is lengthy and rarely achieves even 5%.

wine.name: Vin Santo "Orlando", Querciabella
wine.review: Full of hazelnuts and almonds on the palate. Great profile of spice and apricots. Sweet with exquisite balance. Made in honor of a beloved grandson named Orlando.

wine.name: Vouvray "Le Mont" Moëlleux, Huet
wine.review: Le Mont is one of the 3 main vineyards. This elegant and sweet on the palate but supreme expressive in fruit with honeydew and pears. Ends with a lightly stony mineraled finish.

wine.name: Vouvray "Cuvée Constance", Huet
wine.review: Made in honor of Gaston Huet's wife. Only been made maybe a half dozen times to date. Made from a laborious selection of botrytized grapes coming from all 3 of Huet's vineyard sites. Highly prized and highly collectible.

wine.name: Sterling Vintner's Collection Pinot Noir
wine.review: With bright raspberry fruit and toasty notes of vanilla and spice, this is the perfect easy-going Pinot to keep you warm on those cool nights.

wine.name: Brunello di Montalcino, La Palazzetta
wine.review: Flavio Fanti, owner of the family estate La Palazzetta, represents one of Montalcino's elite sources of limited-production Brunello, a full-bodied red wine that comes in many shapes and sizes. His ten acres of Sangiovese Grosso in picturesque Castelnuovo dell'Abate is home to several of the zone's finest parcels.

wine.name: Sagrantino Passitio, Milziade Antano
wine.review: There's nothing like a tannic red dessert wine to get the papillae going. This is made from dried, tannin-driven Sagrantino grapes. They're harvested late, pressed and aged in oak for months before bottling. Sweet but incredibly complex with leather, plums, pepper, vanilla and more.

wine.name: Riesling "Unplugged," Tesch
wine.review: This Kabinett Trocken comes from several vineyard sites in the Nahe that have been in the family since the 1700s. It shows very focused and concentrated fruit on the palate, yet is thoroughly dry and full of minerals. Look for juicy notes of Meyer lemon (and then try and put your glass down).

wine.name: St. Remigiusberg Riesling, Tesch
wine.review: A spicy Riesling that shows the volcanic soil from the vineyards. Excellent white pepper and lively floral and apricot fruit on the palate. Dry yet voluptuous texture and very concentrated in fruit. This is a Spätlese from the Nahe.

wine.name: L'Extravagant de Doisy Daëne, Sauternes
wine.review: This is a wine with intense concentration. A 2nd classified Growth; L'Extravagant de Doisy Daëne began making this powerful Sauternes in 1990, pushing Sauvignon Blanc to its utmost ripeness. Flavors of clove, spice, honeysuckle abound.

wine.name: Jurançon "Gourmandise", Clos Cancaillaü
wine.review: This late-harvest dessert wine comes from Southwest France. Notes of honey melon, pear, and fig come forth in the nose and palate. Try with your favorite southern French cheese.

wine.name: Ürziger Würzgarten Riesling Eiswein, Christoffel
wine.review: From the tiny Christoffel estate in the Mosel, this is a complex Eiswein with huge aging potential.

wine.name: Haardter Bürgergarten Riesling Auslese, Müller-Catoir
wine.review: Despite the high level of sugar in this Auslese, the balancing acidity shines through clearly, giving this wine tart notes of lemon. Perfect botrytis, perfect structure.

wine.name: Moët Nectar Impérial
wine.review: The Demi-Sec style is for lovers of sweet Champagne. This Moët is great with light desserts or for after dinner sipping on its own.

wine.name: Ruchottes-Chambertin Grand Cru, Dominique Laurent
wine.review: Dominque Laurent contracts grapes from a myriad of reputable growers and takes great lengths to control the barrique that's used to ferment and age the wines. This sees 200% new oak. Smoky on the nose with aromas of leather and dark currants and cherries. Rich and ripe character that will cellar for many years to come.

wine.name: B.R. Cohn Cabernet Sauvignon "Olive Hill"
wine.review: These Cabernet vines rest above thermal hot springs creating a naturally frost-free environment during the growing season. The soil is a combination of well-draining loam and gravel soils - something imperative to great grape growing.

wine.name: Saarburger Rausch Riesling Spätlese, Zilliken
wine.review: Zilliken makes some of the best wines in the Mosel-Saar-Ruwer. More specifically, they come from the sub-region of the Saar, noted as more delicate and restrained in wine character. The wines are fermented and aged in German oak casks. The wines are dusty and crystalline in their youth, and evolve elegantly with age.

wine.name: Stielweg Riesling Trocken "Old Vines, Künstler
wine.review: The soil of the Hochheim vineyard is made up of loamy loess and gravel. This was picked at a Spätlese level of ripeness but vinified into a dry Riesling. Stunning concentration from 50 year old vines.

wine.name: Pinot Noir "Tradition", Künstler
wine.review: The Künstler estate was started in the 1960s. It is now not only one of the best wineries in the Rheingau; it outranks most others in Germany as well. This is one of the only estates in the country to export a red wine. Künstler Pinot Noir is aged in large, neutral oak, creating a wine that is light on the palate, with nuances of red raspberry and cherry and an earthy finish.

wine.name: Barnett Cabernet Sauvignon, Rattlesnake Hill
wine.review: Rattlesnake Hill is a small rocky knoll located at 2000 feet on Spring Mountain. Because the vines are so high up, they receive 3 more hours of sunlight a day, plus cooler evening temperatures. This creates an amazingly balanced wine, with bright acidity and great concentration.

wine.name: Prosecco Brut, Scu Dò
wine.review: Prosecco has long been our favorite alternative to Champagne, and this delicious bottle is a perfect reminder of why. Light, dry, subtly citrusy and endlessly drinkable, Scu Dò comes to us from a collection of small independent growers in Northern Italy's Valdobbiadene, a sub-region of the Veneto. We think it’s some of the best bubbly on the market: perfect for sipping, savoring, or toasting.

wine.name: Robola, Gentilini
wine.review: Located on the island of Cephalonia in the Ionian Sea, the Gentilini winery has been making wines since the early 1980s. Robola is a native variety from this region, creating a white that is fresh and light, with citrus, floral, and almond notes. A great mineral finish, too!

wine.name: Werewolf Merlot, Romania
wine.review: Romanian Merlot made by men who resemble werewolves. Full of plums and dark fruit. Excellent with raw meat, we won't suggest what kind...

wine.name: Châteauneuf-du-Pape, Charvin
wine.review: Dried fruit, spice, and lively tannins on the finish, this is a Châteauneuf with power and structure. Traditional in style, this wine is drinking well now, or can age for 5-10 years.

wine.name: Mâcon-Villages, Dom. Sainte Barbe
wine.review: Southern Burgundy whites can be incredible values. This is a serious Chardonnay from an esteemed winery that has been practicing Biodynamic viticulture for decades. Precise and clean, this wine has floral aromas and mixed apples on the palate. The concentration is amazing - and no wonder; the fruit is grown on 45-year-old vines.

wine.name: Quarts de Chaumes "Les Varennes", Jo Pithon
wine.review: Quarts de Chaume is the name of a tiny sub-region within the confines of another sub-region of the Loire called Coteaux du Layon. This dessert wine is only made when the grapes have been affected by noble rot. This is viscous, honeyed with apricots and baked brown sugar on the palate.

wine.name: Amarone "Mithas", Corte Sant'Alda
wine.review: Aged in French oak for 6 years before releasing. The oak is surprisingly judicious and blends well with the precise red berry fruit. This is a wine to enjoy at all stages: upon release or with decades of age.

wine.name: Freixenet Brut Nature
wine.review: This driest style of Cava features rich fruit and spice flavors and a soft texture. Good as an apéritif or as a refreshing accompaniment to spicy food.

wine.name: Chandon Rosé
wine.review: Soft, slightly dry, fruit forward style.

wine.name: Piper-Heidsieck Brut
wine.review: A clean, slightly toasty Champagne with intricate bead and nice, fresh doughy and vanilla flavors.

wine.name: Châteauneuf-du-Pape "Le Parvis," Ferraton
wine.review: Mostly Grenache, with Syrah and Mourvèdre as well. This powerful red wine is made in an earthy style with aromas of leather, game, spice, and dried cranberries. Old vines add considerable richness, and distinct minerality shows up on the finish. Drinking well today.

wine.name: Richard Hamilton "Daisy's" Viognier
wine.review: This Viognier is aged for a short period of time in oak, which adds a touch of body and complexity.
