The wood never obscures the fruit in this dry white wine, however, and it remains very clean and pure on the palate. With aromas of pineapple, white flowers and mixed peaches, this is an elegant apéritif wine, or an excellent match for light meat dishes and seafood.

wine.name: Amarone, Trabucchi
wine.review: This staff favorite hails from the eastern part of the Valpolicella sub-region. Made from some well-loved grapes indigenous to the area (Corvina, Corvinone, Molinara, Rondinella) as well as some not-so-common ones (Croatina, Dindarella, Forsellina, Oseleta, and Rossignola), this is a dry, voluptuous, concentrated red wine with flavors of dark berries and currants.

wine.name: Oculus, Mission Hill Family Estate
wine.review: Oculus is the Mission Hill family estate's signature Bordeaux-inspired red wine. Lush with dark blackberries, wild raspberries, cedar, truffle and chocolate on the finish. Decant in its youth.

wine.name: Gruet Brut
wine.review: A transplanted family from Champagne chose the micro-climates of New Mexico for the richness of the grapes that the area produced. The result is a fine sparkler combining very ripe fruit and a nice round texture.

wine.name: Côte-Rôtie, Ch. de Mont Lys
wine.review: There's nothing more inviting than a beautiful red wine that's a mix of flowers, black pepper and warm spices like nutmeg and clove. This sounds exotic but it's ironically very restrained and subtle and sublimely balanced with the dark berry fruit.

wine.name: Pitch Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Lots of dark berry fruit here - cassis and cherries - and subtle dried herbs. Medium-bodied with mocha, cola, and vanilla notes, this finishes with a good tannic structure, making it great with rich, hearty fare. We tasted it with grilled flank steak and it made a marvelous match.

wine.name: Sobon Estate Zinfandel, Hillside
wine.review: This delicious Zinfandel is produced from old vines in Amador County. Flavors of cocoa and blackberries ooze from the glass, making this sturdy and bold wine an absolute joy with hard cheeses or a grilled steak.

wine.name: Prosecco Rustico, Nino Franco
wine.review: Prosecco is an indigenous grape of Italy grown in the Veneto region. Nino Franco’s Prosecco is absolutely gorgeous with aromas of pear, apple and white peach. While delicate, the body is round and the bubbles soothing.

wine.name: Barolo Riserva "Vignolo", Cavallotto
wine.review: The Vignolo vineyard offers up a more delicate expression of Nebbiolo but in a powerful vintage such as 1989 it exhibits unusual depth and complesity. Maturing more quickly than the San Giuseppe this is very approachable now and exhibits classic dried floral and forest floor aromas with a structured mouthfeel that features spicy notes of sandlewood and dried citrus peel.

wine.name: Croft Vintage Port
wine.review: The Croft Ports as of late have gone through a sort of renaissance. This vintage will no doubt impress. Full of dark berries and licorice. Very silken in texture with a rich, fruit-driven character that will last decades.

wine.name: Pinot Grigio, Elena Walch
wine.review: Elena Walch makes some very respectable wines, not the least of whichi is her lovely Pinot Grigio. This is fresh, round in texture, and full of floral and yellow plum fruits on the palate. Dry and delicious.

wine.name: Terra Sparkling Malbec, Viniterra
wine.review: Sparkling red wine, anyone? This is a refreshing, fruit-forward, bubbly Malbec from Agrelo, located in Argentina’s Luján de Cuyo. It is full of mixed dark berries – blueberries, blackberries, and currants – with a hint of velvety tannins. A touch of black pepper spice, great bubbles, and a hint of earthiness make this a sparkler for all occasions. It is lovely by itself as an apéritif, and it makes a great addition to any meal: Try it with everything from hors d'oeuvres to roast pork.

wine.name: Refosco, Dorigo
wine.review: The Refosco grape is a regional specialty that makes deep, fleshy, dark red wines. This one is full-bodied with abundant black fruit. Fresh with a touch of spice and vanilla, this is an excellent choice if your tastes veer towards the New World winemaking style and you want to explore the wines of Northern Italy.

wine.name: Iron Horse Classic Vintage Brut
wine.review: This is a blend of 70% Pinot Noir with the rest made from Chardonnay.

wine.name: Bouvet Brut
wine.review: A sparkling wine from the Saumur district of the Loire Valley. Made with a portion of Chenin Blanc which imparts a wonderful bouquet.

wine.name: Ruinart, Rosé
wine.review: From the oldest Champagne house in the world comes this elegant, well balanced sparkler. Rose petal in color, the intense nose leads to a fresh, fruity and very smooth finish.

wine.name: Ruinart, Blanc de Blancs
wine.review: From the oldest Champagne house in the world comes this blend of 100% Premier Cru Chardonnay from different years. The golden yellow color leads to a toasty nose and slight mineral notes on the palate.

wine.name: 40ème Rugissants, Estezargues
wine.review: From the Estezargues growers of the Rhône Valley. This is Syrah-based, so it's full of luscious dark berries and pepper. Give this a whirl in a decanter and watch it open up.

wine.name: Rosso di Montalcino, Argiano
wine.review: Full of spicy tannins, dark berried fruit and a forward fruit that will appeal to New World and Old World palates alike. This vintage shows incredible ripeness and delicacy all at once.

wine.name: Cuvée Blanc, Ch. Musar
wine.review: Made from old vines (60 years average) Obaideh - an indigenous white grape variety that's related to Chardonnay. This is grown in a very mountainous terrain, facing the sea at 3,500 feet above sea level. Very floral with pine and yellow plums on the palate. Reminiscent of French Roussanne.

wine.name: Barolo "Monfortino," G. Conterno
wine.review: Monfortino is considered by many to be the pinnacle of the Barolo pyramid. Carrying on a grand tradition begun almost 90 years ago this remains a monument to traditional winemaking. Rich with deep, spicy fruit this Barolo has incredible structure ensuring a life that will be measured in decades yet is bursting with enough fruit to conceal all that power. A wine for the cellar.

wine.name: Larmandier-Bernier "Rosé de Saignée" Premier Cru Brut
wine.review: Hands down, one of the finest producers of Champagne in our books. This isn't your shake-it-and-pop-off-the-cork Champagnes, rather, without sounding snobby cause we hate that, it's a thinking wine. Let's clarify, this is a sparkler that truly evolves in aromas and structure as you caress it over the course of an evening.

wine.name: Mâcon-Charnay "Franclieu", Jean Manciat
wine.review: One of those Chardonnays that simply refreshes the palate with all the bright quince fruits and mineral. Makes you wonder how you would survive if wine didn't exist.

wine.name: Freixenet Cordon Negro
wine.review: Here's the benchmark for top value sparkling wine. Clean, fruity and well-balanced, this wine adds a refreshing and festive note to any occasion.

wine.name: Chianti Classico, Querciabella
wine.review: When we find a great Chianti Classico producer like this one, it's cause for celebration. This food-friendly red wine shows dark fruit, powder, licorice, and solid tannins. It's all wrapped up in a surprisingly approachable package, but the bottle shows all the signs of ageworthiness.

wine.name: Freixenet Carta Nevada
wine.review: Another delicious value-priced Cuvée from Freixenet. This one has a touch of mineral to complement the central flavors of apple and honey.

wine.name: Vieilles Vignes Brut, Dom. Bruno Gobillard
wine.review: This comes from a selection of Gobilliard's best grapes that are well over 50 years old. What this adds is concentration to this delectable sparkler. This is concentrated with intense floral and yellow fruits. Dry yet very approachable if you like a rich-styled Champagne.

wine.name: La d-18, Olivier Pithon
wine.review: A white blend from the Catalanes area near the Spanish border. Made mostly from Grenache Blanc, this rich Vin de Pays has been aged in large (used) wooden vats for 16 months, giving it a great leesy complexity. Full of pears and quince on the palate.

wine.name: Savennières "Jalousie", Dom. du Closel
wine.review: You'll certainly feel a bit jealous of anyone drinking a glass of this if you're empty-handed. This is stellar Chenin Blanc, dry, with aromas of pear skin and honeysuckle. Best enjoyed just slightly chilled.

wine.name: Chénas, C. Pacalet
wine.review: The northern part of Beaujolais is divided into ten "Crus," the smallest of which is known as Chénas. Christophe Pacalet's Chénas bottling, made from Gamay, is a touch gamey, with pure aromas of freshly crushed mixed berries. This is a wine that cries out for food.

wine.name: Gaillac "Le Duras", Plageoles
wine.review: Dark in color with equally dark fruit on the palate (blueberries and ripe blackberries). Made from the Duras grape variety, this wine shows ripe fresh fruit all around. No new oak was used here, so you can count on a full expression of Gaillac terroir. This hearty red benefits from air: give it a whirl in a decanter, pitcher, or glass and you'll notice the change immediately.

wine.name: Mercurey "La Plante Chassey", Derain
wine.review: Everything you could want in Pinot Noir from Burgundy. This is drinking brilliantly today and smells exactly like raspberries and cherries. There's an incredible freshness and bright acidity to balance. Lithe, honest and delicate texture. You won't be disappointed.

wine.name: Vermentino "Costamolino" Argiolas
wine.review: Made from 100% Vermentino grown in the Costamolino vineyard, located 625 feet above sea level. The grapes are harvested in September and vinified in temperature-controlled, stainless steel tanks. Costamolino is straw yellow in color with green highlights and an intense yet delicate bouquet that displays distinct varietal characteristics. On the palate it is delicate and pleasantly refreshing.

wine.name: Salice Salentino, Taurino
wine.review: Made from the Negroamaro grape in the region of Apulia, in Southern Italy, this delicious wine represents great value. Black fruit flavors combine with a slight herbal edge and finishes with firm tannins.

wine.name: Pigato "Le Russeghine", Francesco Bruna
wine.review: Pigato, another one of the thousands of local grape varieties of Italy. This one is from the Mediterranean region of Liguria. This is a dry, white wine that's unoaked and full of fresh yellow fruit aromas, minerals and mouthwatering acidity. Excellent with seafood fare.

wine.name: Joël Falmet "Tradition" Brut
wine.review: A dry white sparkling wine that wonderfully shows aromas of red berries and toasted brioche. The minerals are more earthy and red. Based mainly on Pinot Noir and Pinot Meunier. Just delicious throughout a meal. Don't overchill.

wine.name: Prosecco "Bellenda" Extra Dry Kosher
wine.review: This is a dry white bubbly from the north of Italy. With white floral aromas and a touch of chalky minerality on the finish, it has such pretty character that you'll be hooked before you know it.

wine.name: Barkan Classic Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: This soft round wine exhibits classic notes of cassis, cigar box and dried herbs. Exhibits fine balance and is ready to drink on it's own or as a fine match for hearty dishes and robust cheeses.

wine.name: Barkan Classic Petite Syrah
wine.review: This lighter-styled Petite Syrah is a fantastic value. It features bright plum and berry flavors as well as classic aromas of black pepper and forest floor. Mevushal.

wine.name: Ribolla Gialla, Movia
wine.review: This unfiltered white is made in Slovenia, from Ribolla Gialla fruit grown both in Italy and in Slovenia. Plump with quince, pears, and honey, this is a dry wine that drinks well today, but we're certain it will benefit from a few years of aging.

wine.name: Cour-Cheverny, François Cazin
wine.review: This is the regular bottling from François Cazin, a light, floral, delicate white made from the rare Romorantin grape. Beautiful notes of honeysuckle and quince.

wine.name: Saxon Brown Pinot Noir, Parmalee Hill
wine.review: While this is a very big wine, it carries itself with considerable grace, retaining great balance and admirable grip across the mid-palate with a great depth of red berry fruits, and accents of clove, earth, and licorice.

wine.name: Griottes-Chambertin, Dom. Fourrier
wine.review: A very successful year only adds more magic when the vines are in the hands of the Fourrier Domaine.

wine.name: Barolo Riserva, G. Borgogno
wine.review: The phrase iron fist in a velvet glove is abused when it comes to wine but in this case it is so fitting. The core of fruit from this exceptional vintage has remained vibrant as the structure has melted away leaving a voluptuous wine of exceptional depth.

wine.name: Barolo Riserva, G. Borgogno
wine.review: Now fully mature, this bottling is showing all it has to offer: a caressing texture and classic Nebbiolo notes of tar, roses, earth, and warm red fruits on the nose. This is a rare chance to sample classic Barolo from an excellent vintage at peak.

wine.name: Txakolina, Xarmant
wine.review: "Xarmant" means charming in Basque, and that’s a very apt way of describing this wine (but really, it had us at “Txakolina”). From the tiny D.O. of Txakoli de Alava, this is an extremely light and refreshing white wine, showing the perfect amount of mouthwatering acidity and crisp, green apple fruit.

wine.name: Barolo, Giacomo Conterno
wine.review: Coming from a powerful vintage, this wine has not lost a step with the passage of time. Still strapping if a touch less elegant than other vintages this wine continues to exhibit exceptional depth in a rugged, traditional style.

wine.name: Barolo, G. Conterno
wine.review: Fully mature and offering a classic aged nebbiolo character resplendent with aromatics of faded dried flowers, orange peel, and balsamic notes this is a wine of contemplation, quiet and dignified with fillagree grace and delicate elegance.

wine.name: Billecart-Salmon Demi-Sec
wine.review: Everything you love from this house and more. This is a nicely off dry Champagne with all the floral, honey character you can crave. An excellent apéritif sparkler.

wine.name: Prosecco Brut, Col Vetoraz
wine.review: A dry sparkling wine made from the Prosecco grape variety. This white is all about pears, white flowers, citrus and peaches. Excellent toasty fruit on the palate.

wine.name: Torrontés "Plata," La Rioja
wine.review: This brilliant white wine is crafted in northern Argentina’s La Rioja region. The Torrontés grape, a distant cousin of Muscat, produces distinctively aromatic wines, and we think they are some of the best bottles to come out of Argentina lately. The “Plata” is dry on the palate, with notes of mixed white flowers, yellow plums, and even some white peppercorn on the finish. Overall, it has a remarkably fresh character, enabling it to complement lighter dishes without overwhelming them. It’s fresh and surprising each and every time you open a bottle.

wine.name: Fleur de California Pinot Noir, Carneros
wine.review: The Fleur de California winery was begun in 1972 by a couple with a great love of Burgundy, and they have gone on to produce Pinot Noirs that remind us just why we love this grape. This bottle has cranberry and cherry aromas, warm earthy notes of nutmeg and forest floor, and a beautifully soft mouthfeel.

wine.name: Wiemer Semi-Dry Riesling, Finger Lakes
wine.review: Hermann Wiemer moved to New York from Germany's Mosel region in 1968. This Finger Lakes Riesling, made in the traditional German Spätlese style, clearly shows his roots. Notes of baked apples and tangerine fill the palate.

wine.name: Pol Roger, Winston Churchill Cuvée
wine.review: Winston Churchill's favorite Champagne house honors his memory with this spectacular, full bodied cuvée.

wine.name: Pinot Noir "Cuvée M", Laurent Barth
wine.review: In the right hands, the red Pinot Noir grape can even thrive in Alsace. Only a minute amount of "Cuvée M" is produced, but we managed to get our hands on some. Full of currants, lithe tannins, and all-around approachable fruit character.

wine.name: Vouvray "Cuvée Constance", Huet
wine.review: Made in honor of Gaston Huet's wife. Only been made maybe a half dozen times to date. Produced from a laborious selection of botrytized grapes coming from all 3 of Huet's vineyard sites. Highly prized and highly collectible.

wine.name: Tokaji Aszú 5 Puttonyos, Imperial Domain of Hétszolo
wine.review: An elegant bouquet of honeyed apricots, plums, peaches, oranges and hazelnut. Aptly put by Louis XIV "...king of wines and the wine of kings". We may not live in a monarch but drinking this sure makes us feel regal.

wine.name: Le Colombier de Château Brown, Pessac-Léognan
wine.review: This medium-bodied red Bordeaux blend is the second wine from Château Brown. It boasts a round, friendly texture with up-front cassis fruit and a note of spicebox.

wine.name: Weinert "Carrascal" White
wine.review: There's an exotic edge to this white that makes it not quite typical for a Mendoza wine; this could be due to the influence of the European winemaker. In any case, the culture clash has produced an endearing Sauvignon Blanc, full of pears, juicy acidity, and a touch of vanilla bean. A great wine for white meat dishes.

wine.name: Ausbruch, "On the Wings of Dawn," Heidi Schröck
wine.review: From passionate winemaker Heidi Schröck comes this impressive (and impressively named) bottle of wine. This is an Ausbruch - a traditional Austrian dessert wine that is fairly rare these days. Ms. Schröck's version is made from a blend of different grapes, and explodes with flavors of maple, candied lemons, and brown sugar.

wine.name: Martini & Rossi Asti
wine.review: Light and fruity, this famous Italian sweet bubbly is produced by the giant Vermouth and sparkling wine firm Martini & Rossi. Made from aromatic Moscato Bianco grapes grown near the Piedmont town of Asti, it's perfect with fruit at the end of a meal.

wine.name: Duché de Longueville "Muscadet de Dieppe"
wine.review: Muscadet de Dieppe is one of Normandy's classic apple varieties for cider. Here, we have an off-dry version with fine apple aromas.

wine.name: Quintessa Rutherford
wine.review: With layers of complexity, and perfumed with floral and black fruit notes, this meritage blend is not to be missed. A delicate vintage accented with opulence.

wine.name: Dom Perignon
wine.review: A classic, this wine is meant for aging but very good now. Perfect for any celebration, really. Very elegant with toast and earth on the nose and deep fruit flavor. 55% Chardonnay grapes, 45% Pinot Noir grapes.

wine.name: Bartenura Prosecco, Kosher
wine.review: A delightful sparkling wine from the Veneto. With creamy, dry flavors, it's the perfect companion for fish dishes.

wine.name: Barolo "Pie Franco", Cappellano
wine.review: Teobaldo Cappellano makes this Barolo using ungrafted vines, "Franc de Pied" in French or "Pie Franco" in Italian, resulting in a wine of amazing profundity. He doesn't submitt his wines to a wine guide or buy into any system of valuation, so his Baroli "Pie Franco" are virtually unknown and possessed of unique and impressive character.

wine.name: Barolo "Pie Franco", Cappellano
wine.review: Teobaldo Cappellano makes this Barolo using ungrafted vines, "Franc de Pied" in French or "Pie Franco" in Italian, resulting in a wine of amazing profundity. He doesn't submitt his wines to a wine guide or buy into any system of valuation, so his Baroli "Pie Franco" are virtually unknown and possessed of unique and impressive character.

wine.name: Mumm Cordon Rouge Brut
wine.review: This wine is toasty and rich, with lots of malt, butter and strawberry flavors and a fresh backbone of acidity.

wine.name: Perrier-Jouët Grand Brut
wine.review: An elegant, fruity style. This wine has clean citric and toasty aromas and is light in body. This is 45% Chardonnay, 40% Pinot Noir, and 15% Pinot Meunier.

wine.name: Perrier-Jouët Grand Brut
wine.review: An elegant, fruity style. This wine has clean citric and toasty aromas and is light in body.

wine.name: Jelu Pinot Noir
wine.review: The Patagonia region of Argentina is known for its world-class outdoor adventures. Little do most people know, however, that it also has the perfect climate for growing the capricious Pinot Noir grape. Jelu Pinot Noir is a hearty red wine, medium-bodied with wild raspberries and black cherries on the palate, and it will be just delicious tonight with a hearty meat dish.

wine.name: Perrier-Jouët Fleur de Champagne
wine.review: The tête de cuvée from Perrier-Jouët. Medium-bodied and complex, Fleur de Champagne is enjoyed by lovers of great Champagne for its beautiful flower-painted bottle, as much as its smooth, sophisticated taste. It is 50% Chardonnay and 50% Pinot Noir.

wine.name: Merlot "Sassi Grossi", Ticino, Gialdi
wine.review: A hearty Merlot from Switzerland, a land that does more on the oenological front than just Fendant for raclette. This is a serious red. Serious in the sense that it comes from older vines, well over 40 years, and is aged in French barrique - 35% of which are new. Taste what collectors love.

wine.name: Viré-Clessé, Trenel
wine.review: Viré-Clessé is a relatively new white wine appellation ('98) in the Mâconnais. It was basically created for ''more serious'' white wines in this sub-region of southern Burgundy. This has depth, in part because of the bit of wood age (not new) this sees.

wine.name: Nicolas Feuillatte, Brut Réserve
wine.review: This rich, invigorating non-vintage Champagne includes toasty, apple aromas packaged in a dry sparkling wine.

wine.name: Nicolas Feuillatte Brut Rosé
wine.review: A dry rosé that's full of ripe strawberry and cherry fruit aromas.

wine.name: Gruet, Blanc de Noirs
wine.review: Full of rich, creamy red fruit flavor, this delicious Blanc de Noirs is made at a small, modern winery in New Mexico established during the 1980s by the sons of the Champagne house Gruet. A top-value sparkler.

wine.name: Quinta do Crasto, Douro
wine.review: This red wine speaks of Portugal. It's plush with dark fruits, and espresso foam. Very rich and full of lively character on the palate. A great match for meat fare.

wine.name: Rasteau "Tradition," Cave de Rasteau
wine.review: Produced by the tiny Cave de Rasteau, this Côtes du Rhône Village wine is made of Grenache, Syrah, and Mourvédre. With notes of black cherry, licorice, and plum, it is very approachable, yet maintains a serious structure and great acidity.

wine.name: Pol Roger Brut
wine.review: This is top-notch Champagne, mostly Chardonnay, in a clean and fresh style with fine mousse. At the price it is one of the best.

wine.name: Côtes de Duras Blanc, Ch. Haut Lavigne
wine.review: This light, refreshing white wine, a blend of Sauvignon Blanc and Sémillon, comes from the tiny AOC of Côtes de Duras, located directly northeast of Bordeaux. Quince notes, a honeyed nose, and a leesy, mineral-driven palate make this the perfect apéritif wine.

wine.name: Psagot Edom Red
wine.review: A Bordeaux blend of Cabernet and Merlot aged in French and American oak. A full bodied wine with spicy vanilla notes that will hold up to the heartiest stew or robust pasta dishes.

wine.name: Kadesh Barnea Gilad Red
wine.review: A meritage blend of Petite Verdot, Merlot and Shiraz aged in American Oak Barrels. Quite a big, powerful glass of wine.

wine.name: Roederer Estate Brut
wine.review: A rich and toasty sparkler from the famous Champagne maker who was the first to stake a claim in Anderson Valley as the best site in California for Champagne-style wines.

wine.name: Terra Noble Gran Reserva Carmenère
wine.review: The Carmenère grape came to Chile via Bordeaux in the late nineteenth century, and lately it's been more at home in South America than France. The red wines made from this grape can range from refreshing and easy-drinking to full-bodied and dense. This is one of the brawnier ones, with rich, dark fruit and a touch of spiciness from oak aging.

wine.name: Pinot Grigio, Cantine del Borgo Reale, Kosher
wine.review: This is one of those mouthwatering white wines that's dry yet full of fresh white fruits. From the Venezie in northern Italy. Mevushal too!

wine.name: Teperberg Family Estate "Meritage"
wine.review: This hearty Kosher red wine comes from the Judean Hills of Israel and was inspired by the noble wines of Bordeaux. "Meritage" is wine lingo meaning that the grapes used are those that are traditionally used in Bordeaux.

wine.name: Taittinger Brut, La Française
wine.review: The high proportion of Chardonnay is used in the blend gives this wine a crispness that is uncommon in non-vintage Champagnes. La Française sets the standard for lightness and delicacy among the Champagne houses.

wine.name: Orvieto Classico, La Carraia
wine.review: Orvieto is not only the name of this white wine but also the name of a stunning medieval city in the region of Orvieto, home to the grandiose city of Rome. This is a crisp, dry wine that's a natural match with anything seafood.

wine.name: Belle Vallée Pinot Noir
wine.review: While many wineries in Oregon are quite specific as to where their grapes come from, Belle Vallée strives for continuity of quality, year in and year out. You can count on getting a wine with consistently juicy red fruit, made in a fresh, appealing style.

wine.name: Cline Viognier
wine.review: A delightfully crisp wine that is bursting with tropical fruits and spices. It’s brilliant as an apéritif, but its freshness will also brighten up just about any meal you can think of.

wine.name: Taittinger Rosé Cuvée Prestige
wine.review: A wonderful rosé cuvée with nice berry-like Pinot Noir flavors and generous toastiness. From a winery known for its delicate, intricate style.

wine.name: New Harbor Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: Lots of grapefruit and honeysuckle on the nose. Well balanced with bright, crisp acidity.

wine.name: Billecart-Salmon "Nicolas François" Brut
wine.review: The "Nicolas François" was created to honor the founder of this wonderful Champagne house that was started in 1818. A blend of Grand Cru vineyard fruit from the Côte des Blancs and Montagne de Reims.

wine.name: Billecart-Salmon "Cuvée Elisabeth Salmon" Rosé, Brut
wine.review: This rosé was first made in 1988 to honor Elisabeth Salmon, one of the founders of this highly-respected Champagne houses. It's made from equal parts Pinot Noir and Chardonnay.

wine.name: Billecart-Salmon "Grande Cuvée" Brut
wine.review: This was just disgorged in October of 2006. This is Champagne that's aged to perfection. Full of complexity from the extended aging on the lees. A blend of Pinot Noir and Chardonnay.

wine.name: Quinta Sardonia, Sardon de Duero
wine.review: This biodynamic property, located on the outskirts of the Ribera del Duero region, is a project from famed winemaker Peter Sissek. The property is planted with both Tinto Fino (Tempranillo) and Bordeaux varietals, creating a lively blend with bright fruit and an immense elegance.

wine.name: Richter Estate Riesling
wine.review: This estate riesling was technically harvested at a ripeness level of a Spätlese. On the palate you can feel that richness in the texture. Very fruit forward with a floral nature and white pepper to finish.

wine.name: Graacher Himmelreich Riesling Spätlese, Richter
wine.review: This vintage in Germany shines especially well with the Spätlese ripeness level. As was the tradition centuries ago, this Riesling was aged in large foudre, the traditional German, large oak cask. It's rare that Rieslings be aged with indigenous yeasts but that is a result of meticulous care in the vineyards during the year. Full of yellow fruits with palpable sweetness but perfectly balanced with the mineral.

wine.name: Purple Mountain Pinot Noir
wine.review: This California Pinot Noir is fresh and clean on the palate, with notes of lush cherry and red raspberry. Balanced acidity and a medium body makes this a very drinkable wine; this is simply a great expression of the Pinot Noir grape.

wine.name: Agioritiko "Red Stag", Dom. Spiropoulos
wine.review: This very approachable and very drinkable red is made from the indigenous Agiorgitiko grape. Notes of red currants and black pepper are followed up by soft tannins and a long finish. Try this with light fare for an amazing pairing. Practicing Organic.

wine.name: Mantinia, Dom. Spiropoulos
wine.review: This dry white is produced from the indigenous Moschofilero grape, grown at an altitude of 650 meters. Similar in style to Muscat, this has a floral bouquet and citrus flavors on the palate. Clean and crisp.

wine.name: Estate Red, Domaine Mercouri
wine.review: The Mercouri Estate has been operating since the late 1800s and imported the first Refosco vines from Italy's Friuli region during that time. Since then, Refosco has flourished in Greece. This wine is deep and complex, with black fruit, layers of spice, and herbal notes. It could easily age for another five to ten years, but it is simply stunning right now.

wine.name: Harvey's Orange
wine.review: Adding a citrusy zest to one of the worlds best known cream sherries.

wine.name: Veuve Clicquot Brut
wine.review: The big, full-bodied, non-vintage Champagne in a half-bottle. Cheers!

wine.name: Veuve Clicquot Brut
wine.review: Try this Champagne blind against a sample of the other brands we stock and see for yourself what you prefer. A dry Champagne with brioche and baked apple aromas.

wine.name: Veuve Clicquot Brut
wine.review: The classic big, full-bodied, non-vintage Champagne. Cheers!

wine.name: Sonoma Cutrer Sonoma Coast Chardonnay
wine.review: Using grapes from their renowned "Cutrer" and "Vine Hill" vineyards, Sonoma Cutrer has added a stunning new Chardonnay to their esteemed family of wines. Well-balanced with a citrusy nose and slightly oaky flavors, this is the perfect wine for grilled fish.

wine.name: Roederer Brut Premier
wine.review: Terrific richness in a brut, non-vintage Champagne. From the house that makes the world-famous "Cristal."

wine.name: Pinot Grigio, Boira
wine.review: This is an easy-drinking white wine that keeps your palate refreshed with citrus fruit. It's made organically in the Veneto region of northern Italy.

wine.name: Sancerre "Mélodie," Gaudry
wine.review: Take a sip of Gaudry's brilliant Sancerre and you'll immediately taste the impact that 50-year-old vines can have on a wine. This is well concentrated, showing white fruit, fresh citrus, and floral aromas. Quite simply a gorgeous bottle of wine, and an excellent example of what old vines can do in the right hands.

wine.name: Monte das Ânforas, Herdade das Ânforas
wine.review: This hearty red wine comes from southern Portugal's Alentejo region. Based on the Aragónez grape (a.k.a. Tempranillo), with some Trincadeira and Alfrocheiro blended in, it is full of mixed black berry flavors. Unoaked and showing incredible fruit concentration, this is drinking terrifically well today.

wine.name: Schramsberg, Brut Rosé
wine.review: From the first press of Pinot Noir grapes (the second is labeled Blanc de Noirs) in an elegant, refreshing style. Very opulent.

wine.name: Prosecco di Valdobbiadene, Mionetto
wine.review: The Mionetto family has exemplified the spirit of Prosecco since 1887. As is the custom, their flagship wine, Prosecco di Valdobbiadene, is produced with half the carbonation of Champagne, rendering it softer and more enjoyable with food.

wine.name: Faugères, La Croix Belle
wine.review: Wines from Faugères are always blends of local varieties; this one is based on Grenache, with Syrah, Mourvèdre and Carignan filling out the rest of the blend. Completely unoaked, this fresh, pure red wine is meant to be enjoyed in its youth.

wine.name: Schramsberg, Blanc de Blancs
wine.review: One of the finest sparkling wines made in the United States. With its inviting, open-knit quality, its citrus and tropical fruit aromas, and its subtle framework of vanilla and toasty spice notes, this is simply irresistible.

wine.name: Ramey Chardonnay, Russian River
wine.review: David Ramey believes in showing off the differences in terroir for his wines, and because of this, each Chardonnay from different sights is vinified the same. The Russian River is a cooler climate, resulting in a Chardonnay with a fresh acidity, with notes of honeysuckle and citrus.

wine.name: Retsina, Gaia
wine.review: Not your yiayia's Retsina. Gaia has produced an exquisite version of this traditional wine by seeping “tea bags” of pine resin in the must, which creates subtle aromas of mint and eucalyptus. A must-try with salty foods!

wine.name: Pinot Blanc "Cuvée George", Ginglinger
wine.review: A lush, golden Pinot blanc that is full of white flower aromas and peach flavors. This complex and fruit-driven white wine is great with shellfish or white meats.

wine.name: Barolo "Le Rocche del Falletto" Riserva, Giacosa
wine.review: The Riserva wine is produced only in the best vintages. Aged in old oak barrels for 30 months before bottling and then aging another 3 years in the bottle before finally releasing for sale. Perfumed on the palate with mulberry, licorice and violets.

wine.name: Prosecco, Zardetto
wine.review: A delicious, very popular easy-drinking sparkler from the Veneto region of Italy. This wine has pleasing citrus fruit with a touch of toast on the nose and a clean pear fruit finish.

wine.name: Bollinger Grande Année Brut
wine.review: One of the finest vintage Champagnes now available. A rich, big-flavored, extremely dry style. This wine will continue to gain complexity.

wine.name: Freixenet Carta Nevada Semi-Secco
wine.review: If you like your sparklers a little sweet, you really should try this one. It's rich and well balanced and another example of why Spanish sparkling wine is such a good value.

wine.name: Menetou-Salon Rouge, Gilbert
wine.review: From the Menetou-Salon appellation, located just west of Sancerre, comes a Pinot Noir that is full of pretty, floral, and supple red berry fruit. There's a cool kiss of mineral on the finish, giving this a fuller feel on the palate.

wine.name: Delta Vineyards, Pinot Noir
wine.review: We can't get enough of this New Zealand Pinot Noir. It's like drinking a glass of pure heaven with all the freshly crushed raspberry fruits. This is a light-bodied, dry red wine that's just amazing alone but works wonderfully with meat dishes as well.

wine.name: Piper Sonoma, Blanc de Blanc
wine.review: Here's a sparkler that has the perfect amounts of green apple flavors with a crisp and delicate finish.

wine.name: Rocco Rosso, Dolcetto di Ovada, Cascina Il Rocco
wine.review: This winery is located in the ancient town of Castelletto d'Orba in Piedmont. The wine is made from the red Dolcetto grape and is the epitome of a ''soft'' red. The tannins are silky and the fruit is dark: it's just a little bit too easy to finish this bottle all by yourself.

wine.name: Adesso, Cagnina di Romagna
wine.review: This delicious Italian red is only lightly sweet and not nearly at the level of a dessert wine. Made in the Romagna area of the Emilia-Romagna region of Northern Italy, it is full of fleshy red berries with just the kiss of sweetness our customers crave sometimes.

wine.name: Barefoot Chardonnay
wine.review: Pure quaffing wine, in a carefree style and a convenient magnum bottle.

wine.name: Bereich Johannisberg Riesling, Kreusch
wine.review: Showing ripe fruit, this slightly sweet Riesling with notes of white flower and honeysuckle is great with many types of food.

wine.name: Bacaro, Pinot Grigio Rosé
wine.review: Pinot Grigio is known for making white wine, but if you let the juice sit with the skins long enough, it will take on that very rosé color. This Venetian wine is all too friendly in its fruit-forwardness and once you’ve experienced its gentle touch of sweetness, you'll have a hard time saying no.

wine.name: Stringtown, Pinot Noir
wine.review: This luscious Pinot Noir comes from various plots of prime vineyards located throughout the beautiful Willamette Valley in Oregon. This red wine is full of raspberry and cherry fruit on the palate.

wine.name: Barolo "Cannubi", Burlotto
wine.review: The Cannubi vineyard gives a more structured Barolo. This red wine from the Burlotto estate is solid in structure yet retains a delicate texture. This wine was made for the ages. Will hold for decades.

wine.name: Anjou Blanc, Château de Passavant
wine.review: This is a dry white wine made from the Chenin Blanc grape. Full of honey, citrus and white flowers. Fantastic with meaty, seafood dishes like halibut.

wine.name: Dunn Cabernet Sauvignon, Howell Mountain
wine.review: A hearty, full-bodied red wine from the Dunn winery. A wine to cherish in its youth.

wine.name: King Estate "Signature Collection" Pinot Gris
wine.review: A dry Pinot Gris (a.k.a. Pinot Grigio) that's full of flowers and citrus fruit on the palate. This is surprisingly rich, both in body and texture.

wine.name: Cecchini, Pinot Grigio
wine.review: Pinot Grigio should always have a fresh, lively quality to it...just like this one does. It has vibrant white fruits, juicy citrus, and fresh flowers on the palate. A delight to drink alone or alongside light fare; seafood is a natural match.

wine.name: Primitivo di Manduria, Koiné
wine.review: We don't want to scare you away but truth be told, this wine has a je ne sais quoi sort of funk to it. It's a little smoky, spicy, berried and leathery but it most definitely has a raw meat (gamey to be precise) element. Excellent with earthy foods, mushrooms, smoked meats, grilled lamb and the like.

wine.name: Beaune Rouge "Aux Coucherias," Voillot
wine.review: This vineyard (a mere quarter hectare) has only been in Voillot's hands for 5 years. It's located in one of the highest vineyards in Beaune. This vintage is the best result so far for it's well-balanced with ample fruit, tannin and refreshing acidity.

wine.name: Paul Hobbs Cabernet Sauvignon, Cross Barn
wine.review: This is the second label of the Paul Hobbs Winery. Rich cassis flavors, toasty vanilla undertones, and notes of roasted coffee beans and licorice all blend together to create a well-balanced and highly intriguing Napa Cab.

wine.name: Chono Reserva Carménère
wine.review: This is a hearty, dark red wine made from the Carmenère grape variety. It's aged in oak for a short period of time to give it just a little spice on the palate. An excellent choice for anything barbecued or meat-based.

wine.name: Juve y Camps Brut, Reserva Familia
wine.review: The noblest of Spanish Cava. A decidedly fresh, clean wine with perfect bead. Supremely elegant.

wine.name: A to Z "Night & Day" Red
wine.review: A hearty Oregon red that is 100% barrel-fermented for 18 months. This is an unusual blend of grape varieties from Bordeaux, Spain and the Rhône. Beautifully aromatic, with succulent flavors of plums, currants, boysenberries and cocoa. A powerful, fruit-forward wine, this is excellent when you're in the mood for something different.

wine.name: Rosso di Montalcino, Uccelliera
wine.review: This estate is located in the southern part of the Montalcino DOCG and was formerly part of the Ciacci Piccolomini's holdings. The wines are big and bold, though far from opaque, and filled with dark cherry fruit.

wine.name: Regaleali Bianco, Tasca d'Almerita Sicily
wine.review: This dry white wine from Sicily is made from the indigenous Inzolia, Catarratto, and Grecanico grapes. With citrus fruits and mineral on the finish, this is a delightful everyday white to enjoy with seafood or any other simple, light fare.

wine.name: Montepulciano d'Abruzzo, Valle Reale
wine.review: This is made from the Montepulciano grape variety (not to be mistaken with the village of Montepulciano in Tuscany). This is a hearty, red wine with aromas of mixed black berries and rosemary.

wine.name: Dom. Carneros, Brut
wine.review: Produced by Taittinger, this is an excellent value in California sparkling wine. It has an impressive complexity with aromas of yeast, apples, vanilla and spice, and a smooth finish.

wine.name: Barolo "Bussia Soprana", Pianpolvere
wine.review: This first vintage Pianpolvere from Rocche di Manzoni shows the breed of this fine site. A deep and rich wine with caressing notes of oak adding contour to the intensely spiced and deeply fruited core that will require some time in the cellar to show at peak.

wine.name: St. Aubin Blanc "Combes", Philippe Colin
wine.review: Saint Aubin is one of the smaller, and lesser-known, winemaking villages in Burgundy where both Chardonnay and Pinot Noir are grown. This Chardonnay is full of white, fleshy fruits with honey on the finish.

wine.name: Pommery, Brut
wine.review: The historic Reims-based Pommery house, purchased by Moët-Hennessy in 1991, produces this fresh and well-balanced non-vintage Champagne. It is full-flavored with a complex, yeasty character.

wine.name: Nuits-St.-Georges Blanc "Perrières", Henri Gouges
wine.review: A wine that's made for the cellar. Rare and from a great producer and vintage that's for the ages.

wine.name: Ployez-Jacquemart Brut
wine.review: This tiny estate produces truly elegant and intellectually satisfying Champagnes. With 1.8 hectares of 40-year-old vine Pinot Noir and Grand Cru Chardonnay, the fruit they begin with is impeccable. The wines age for 5 years on the fine lees, giving it a creamy midpalate and toasty foam.

wine.name: The Prisoner, Orin Swift
wine.review: The Prisoner is here! A Napa blend of Zinfandel, Cabernet Sauvignon, Petite Sirah, Charbono, and Grenache, this wine is rich and lush, with layers of dark chocolate, cassis, roasted coffee bean, and black pepper.

wine.name: Andrew Will Red Blend, Champoux Vineyard
wine.review: The Champoux Vineyard, planted in 1972, is five miles from the Columbia River. Here, the cooling breezes of the Columbia River Gorge never cease, creating the perfect conditions for ripening grapes. Right now, this wine is showing many layers of intense flavors - notes of licorice, blackberry, and tobacco - but it will continue to evolve and be expressive for many years to come.

wine.name: "Dreams", Jermann
wine.review: Jermann is one of just a handful of Friulian winemakers that has impacted the winemaking world in Northern Italy. This is thoroughly modern white wine that's been aged in barrique for nearly a year. Very floral fruit with apples and citrus on the palate.

wine.name: Martin Códax Rioja, "Ergo"
wine.review: Martin Códax has created this easy-drinking, fruit forward wine from Rioja. Made from 100% Tempranillo, this wine is the perfect match from everything from summer pasta salads to burgers.

wine.name: Trebbiano d'Abruzzo, Emidio Pepe
wine.review: This beautiful white wine is foot trodden in wooden tubs in order to avoid the contact between the iron presses and the acids of the fruit. The result is a white wine that's slightly golden hued, well-balanced and complex, with hints of nuts and yellow fruits.

wine.name: Brunello di Montalcino, Collosorbo
wine.review: Tenuta di Collosorbo belongs to one of the original estates of Montalcino, Tenuta di Sesta, owned by the Ciacci family for almost 200 years. The estate is located in the southern zone of Montalcino, a special terroir for growing Sangiovese.

wine.name: Rosso di Toscana "I Piaggioni," Mocali
wine.review: This lighter style of Rosso is perfectly suited to casual summer fare and is a great introduction to both the modern style popular in Montalcino and the character of the Sangiovese grape.

wine.name: Gran Sarao Brut Cava
wine.review: This is a delicious and refreshing Cava made mostly from the local Xarel-lo grape in northeastern Spain's Penedès region. Light touches of citrus and sage flit across on the palate; this is pure pleasure in bubbly form.

wine.name: "Runrig", Torbreck
wine.review: The grapes for this wine are sourced from 7 prime vineyards in the Barossa Valley. This is only made in stellar years and only 220 cases total were even produced. Aged in 60% new wood for 2 years before release and finished with around 3% viognier just as is done in the Côte-Rôtie. Full of heavenly chocolate and berries on the palate.

wine.name: "L'Alba," Jean-Louis Tribouley
wine.review: When you eat a hamburger, you want it to taste like a hamburger, right? Well, this may sound silly, but with food you never give it a second thought: food typically tastes like "what it's supposed to taste like." Well, the winemaker at this estate is aiming for the exact same end result. He wants all his wines to taste of the grapes they're made of. Believe it or not, this is a rarity today.

wine.name: "Marceau" Blanc, Jean-Louis Tribouley
wine.review: Sometimes we like to write clever things to compel you to taste wines. Sure, occasionally it helps some - but other times all we need to do is present what we've been trained to find: all the bits and pieces of aromas and flavors that all come together to make a great wine. In the case of the "Marceau," we'd simply like to say that it is ideal for anyone who is craving a fruit-driven, ripe, dry, rock-solid white.

wine.name: Minervois "La Mère Grand", Le Loup Blanc
wine.review: Wow! This is concentrated and luscious, sp you'll love it if you're the type who likes full-bodied reds. This is made from old-vine (we're talking older than your grandmother!) Carignan, Grenache, and Syrah. The color is intense (nearly black) and the tannins perfectly ripe.

wine.name: Don Nicanor, Chardonnay-Viognier
wine.review: This white wine comes from Mendoza, Argentina, high up in the mountains where the climate is cooler - meaning that the wines turn out fresher. A blend of Chardonnay and Viognier, this is full of white fruit and vanilla bean flavors from oak aging.

wine.name: Kalterersee Auslese, Caldaro Pfarrhof
wine.review: This is a red wine made from the local Schiava grape variety. It is grown high up in the mountainous area of the Alto Adige (Südtirol) of Northern Italy. This region is, in fact, heavily Germanic - explaining the appearance of the term "Auslese" (German for "to select out"), which refers to the meticulous grape selection during harvest. A great aperitif wine, and perfect with cheese plates.

wine.name: Roessler Pinot Noir, La Brisa
wine.review: This Sonoma Coast appellation Pinot Noir comes from Roessler Cellars, who are known for their brilliantly hand-crafted wines. Dark fruit and earth on the nose open up to cherry and cola flavors on the palate. The breeze ("La Brisa") of the Sonoma Coast gives this wine an amazing freshness.

wine.name: Tintilia, d'Uva
wine.review: Even if you're Italian, this label needs explanation. Tintilia is the name of the grape variety (yes, it's rare) and d'Uva is the name of the winery. This is a red wine from the Molise wine region of Central Italy (rare to see wines from here too). The wine is dark red and full of equally dark-berried fruits. Very approachable on the palate yet still full of body. Ideal with food without a doubt.

wine.name: Dominio de Atauta "Valdegatiles", Ribera del Duero
wine.review: Aged in French barrels for 16 months, you’ll find intense concentration, characteristics of black plums, dark chocolate, and vanilla spice.

wine.name: Tinto da Anfora, Herdade das Anforas
wine.review: Made from a blend of red grapes in southern Portugal's Alentejo region, this is aged in oak for 12 months. Loaded with dark berry fruit, it is a purely tasty, unfussy wine that is easy to drink and easy to love.

wine.name: Lioco Chardonnay, Sonoma County
wine.review: Lioco has created this Chardonnay from a blend of different sources, with all fruit grown in dried creek beds throughout the Russian River. The wine is left in contact with the lees for six months, it does not see any oak, and it is bottled unfined and unfiltered. Fresh citrus notes play against a creamy mouthfeel.

wine.name: Klinker Brick, Old Vine Zinfandel
wine.review: This hearty, full-bodied red comes from Zinfandel vines that are well over 50 years old. Aromas of dark fruit contrast with fresh herbal notes; this also shows intense concentration, packed with berry flavors set off by spicy oak.

wine.name: Cuatro Pasos, Bierzo
wine.review: Coming from 80-year-old vines grown on the hillsides of Bierzo in northeastern Spain, this wine sees only two months of oak and possesses many layers of flavor and complexity. We tasted black plum and cherry notes, hints of tobacco, and a touch of bittersweet chocolate.

wine.name: Passopisciaro Rosso
wine.review: This rare red wine is made from vines that are planted on Mount Etna, the active volcano in Sicily. Naturally, the mineral content is distinctive, the fruit dark and luscious. This is a full-bodied, ripe red wine that can age in the cellar for years to come.

wine.name: Krug, Vintage Champagne
wine.review: From the top house in Champagne comes this rich, full wine. Delicate bubble and notes of brioche and hazelnut create a pristine Champagne. Enjoy now or hold for 10-15 years.

wine.name: Vezzo, Pinot Grigio
wine.review: This is no run-of-the-mill Italian white. We get excited about finds like this because undiscovered wines of this caliber are all too rare. The Vezzo is a lovely dry Friulian wine with ripe, luscious, mixed citrus flavors. It is appealing enough to please any palate, yet complex enough to reward repeated tastings. Try it with a few different dishes and you'll see what we mean.

wine.name: Delacroix, Brut
wine.review: This is exactly what bubbly should be: fun, friendly, and festive enough for a special occasion. This new bottling has just arrived and it's better than ever! An exceptionally tasty dry French sparkler, the Delacroix bottling will please just about any palate; enjoy it as an apéritif or marvel at how it sets off your most luxurious lobster dish. Many of our customers are buying this wine by the case, and wisely so: we think everyone should have a bottle of bubbly chilling in the fridge at all times, ready to be popped whenever the situation calls for it. Which turns out to be quite often.

wine.name: Segura Viudas, Brut
wine.review: A crisp, clean Cava with nuances of toasty nuttiness. Owned by Freixenet, Segura Viudas maintains its distinctive style.

wine.name: Alloro Pinot Noir
wine.review: Especially coming from such a young winery, this is an impressively advanced bottle of Pinot Noir. Its distinct aroma of musk makes it unlike any Oregon wine we've ever had. This is full of mixed red berry flavors and reminds us of a great Burgundy.

wine.name: Belle Pente, Pinot Noir
wine.review: This Pinot Noir comes from the Willamette Valley of Oregon. This wine shows gamey fruit - berries and spicy flowers. Unfiltered and distinctly natural on the palate with a tremendous amount of character for a wine coming from the New World.

wine.name: Tamar Ridge "Devil's Corner" Pinot Noir
wine.review: How often do you see a Pinot Noir from Tasmania? This bottle represents an opportunity that may not come around again for a while. It is an easy-to-drink red, full of soft, spicy berry fruit flavors.

wine.name: Ca' del Bosco "Cuvée Prestige", Franciacorta Brut
wine.review: Carefully selected grapes and intense care have been used in order to produce this Franciacorta - a sparkling wine denomination from northern Italy. The result is a fresher, more fragrant product with a wide range of aromas. It also has a firm structure, rich attractive mousse and persistence.

wine.name: Côte du Ventoux, Delas
wine.review: This is a fresh, youthful wine that allows its fruit flavors of plums and black cherries to take center stage, as the juice never sees any wood. Coming from the base of Mount Ventoux, east of the Rhône River, it is 80% Grenache and 20% Syrah. Drink this with a slight chill to experience a perfectly approachable and delicious wine.

wine.name: Coenobium, Bianco
wine.review: Nuns probably aren't the first people who come to mind when you think of winemaking, but this white was indeed made by a group of nuns in Italy's Lazio region. They did a phenomenal job, too: this unique, dry white wine is full of pears, quince, cinnamon, and mineral flavors. Put just a light chill on it and enjoy.

wine.name: Côte-Rôtie "Bassenon", Cuilleron
wine.review: The Cuilleron family domaine, located in the town of Chavanay, was founded several generations ago. The Bassenon vines are located in the southern part of the Côte-Rôtie. This wine boasts structure, finesse and a touch of fruit-forward modernity. This wine can be held for decades but is certainly made in a style that makes it accessible upon release. Give it a whirl in the decanter and enjoy tonight.

wine.name: Nuits-St.-Georges 1er, "Les Pruliers", D. Duband
wine.review: David Duband is a young vigneron working with enviable holdings in Nuits-St.-Georges, Gevrey-Chambertin, and Vosne-Romanee. He is of the new generation of winemakers revitalizing family vines.

wine.name: Chono Riesling
wine.review: This Riesling is full of citrus fruits - limes and meyer lemons especially - and is incredibly firm with acidity. While Riesling is not at all common in this part of the world, this white wine is well worth the try. Quite a bit fuller in body than the European expression.

wine.name: Vacqueyras, Dom. de Montvac
wine.review: The Montvac Domaine, located in the village of Vacqueyras in the Rhône Valley, has been passed down from mother to daughter for four generations. A blend of Grenache, Syrah, and Mourvédre, this Vacqueras doesn't see any wood and is packed with black fruit, spice and chewy tannins.

wine.name: Remelluri Blanco, Rioja
wine.review: This small production white from Rioja is a blend including Viognier, Chardonnay, Roussanne, and Marsanne. These vines are grown at a high altitude on clay soils and aged in French barrel for 1 year, creating a wine with a luscious mouth feel and a striking minerality.

wine.name: Ferrari Brut, Metodo Classico
wine.review: This sparkling wine is produced according to the regulations of the metodo classico Trento D.O.C, a process akin to that used by the finest Champagne houses. This is 100% Chardonnay and aged on the lees for a minimum of 2 years. A sparkling wine of incredible delicacy, floral fruit and finesse.

wine.name: Pic Saint-Loup "Les Tonillières," Mas Foulaquier
wine.review: This Pic Saint-Loup comes from southern France's Coteaux du Languedoc region. It’s a full-bodied, unoaked, dry red blend that bursts with mixed dark fruit aromas.

wine.name: Cerdon de Bugey, Raphaël Bartucci
wine.review: The gorgeous color of this wine is enough reason for us to celebrate any occasion with this bottle. This comes from a tiny parcel of land in the Savoie called Bugey. It's based on Gamay, Poulsard, and Chardonnay. There's a nice dose of sugar on the palate and it is packed with strawberries, wild raspberries, and clay minerals. Drink chilled.

wine.name: Ch. d'Yquem, Sauternes
wine.review: Classic notes of almond shells, coconut, and honeysuckle show how young this vintage really is. There is a huge prresence in the mouth with thick, rich apricot flavors, great structure with spicy notes coming from both the botrytis and wood. The finish is fresh and full of yellow fruits that just linger. Quite young and in tact to hold for decades to come.

wine.name: "Kallisto" White Blend, Dom. Mercouri
wine.review: This crisp, dry white blend comes from the beautiful Mercouri Estate located on the Iionian Sea in Greece. Here, many Italian varietals flourish including Ribolla Gialla- the Kallisto is a blend of Ribolla and Assyritiko. Clean and fresh, with a lemon-lime zestiness.

wine.name: Ch. La Mission Haut-Brion, Pessac-Léognan
wine.review: This vintage of La Mission has beautiful material and is finely structured on the palate. The bouquet is full of ripe fruits, licorice and silken tannins and is certainly an accessible wine. If you don't find yourself in Bordeaux often but are aiming for instant gratification, you've found your wine.

wine.name: Graham's Vintage Port
wine.review: One of the great pleasures in life, is drinking aged port. This comes from one of the best houses in the Douro and is just coming around.

wine.name: Chianti Classico, Val delle Corti
wine.review: This Chianti Classico has abundant flavors of wild red berries, almonds, anise, and violets, all grounded by mineral-laden tannins. The concentration is amazing. This is a wine of immense purity, made in the most traditional of styles and created to celebrate Sangiovese in all its glory.

wine.name: Chianti Classico Riserva, Val delle Corti
wine.review: The aromas on this Sangiovese are full of dark fruits, licorice and mixed berries with a palate of elegance and balance. This was aged in bottle for six months before release. While young and accessible, it certainly can be held for years to come.

wine.name: Pinot Noir "Cuvée A", Anne Amie
wine.review: Cuvée A is a classic Oregon Pinot Noir. The bouquet is filled with aromas of spices, fresh black raspberries, and hints of toast. On the palate, you'll find cranberries and ripe black cherries, with accents of sage and cinnamon. The finish is lively and long, with a clean freshness that invites another sip. Excellent with seafood, such as salmon or halibut.

wine.name: Domaine Gauby Blanc, Vieilles Vignes
wine.review: This white wine comes from the Catalanes region of southern France near the border of Spain. This is a serious white wine that's made from older vines of Macabeo, Grenache Blanc and Gris. Full of concentrated honey, white flowers and minerals on the palate. Don't overchill this wine and you'll be able to appreciate the aromas better.

wine.name: Amarone, Roccolo Grassi
wine.review: This is a more modern style of Amarone but it still shows the finesse you only see at the best estates. Think of this as a concentrated, full-bodied, dry red wine that still retains a good elegance yet has a distinct streak of spice from the oak aging.

wine.name: Costa d'Amalfi "Tramonti," San Francesco
wine.review: A unique bottling from the village of Tramonti on the Amalfi coast. Vines in this area have long been known for producing lean, nervy, well-mineraled white wines from a blend of indigenous varieties. This beautiful dry white is based on Falanghina, Pepella and Biancazita, and sings with aromas of citrus fruits, herbs, and stony minerals.

wine.name: Ch. Moulin de la Roquille "Cuvée l'Espérance"
wine.review: The Côtes de Francs region of Bordeaux is a fantastic area to grow Cabernet Franc, which makes up one third of this red blend. It shows up marvelously on the palate; the fruit is nothing but rich cassis and blueberries.

wine.name: Le Colombier de Château Brown Blanc, Pessac-Léognan
wine.review: An excellent white Bordeaux that's creamy in texture on the palate and boasts everything from quince and honey fruit to fresh vanilla bean. One of the top, white Bordeaux on the market!

wine.name: Le Haut-Médoc de Giscours, Haut-Médoc
wine.review: This is a second wine from Giscours and is drinking better than ever today. It's full of character, spices, dark tobacco and berries. Perfect with a roast or any fare that's "earthy" in style.

wine.name: MacMurray Ranch Pinot Gris
wine.review: Coming from California's Sonoma Coast, MacMurray ranch has created a delicious Pinot Gris that is fruit-forward with notes of fig and white peach and a lingering finish. Pair this with scallops or lobster tonight.

wine.name: Georges Gardet Rosé Brut
wine.review: This is a very elegant style of Champagne that offers wild cherry, spice and earth notes on the palate. There's good concentration of fruit and structure that makes it a fine match for any number of poultry or pork dishes.

wine.name: Bourgogne Rouge, La Burgette
wine.review: The great wine region of Burgundy actually has one of the least varied ranges of vine varieties. This red is made from the habit-forming Pinot Noir, and it is full of freshly crushed raspberries and cherries on the palate. It makes a wonderful match for roast chicken, duck, and cured meats.

wine.name: Bourgogne Blanc, La Burgette
wine.review: This Chardonnay is dry yet fruity, fascinating on its own yet lovely with food, and full of plush yellow fruit flavors like plum, Meyer lemon, and Golden Delicious apples. In fact, “Golden Delicious” would be a perfect nickname for this wine.

wine.name: Chablis, Billaud-Simon
wine.review: This is a beautiful example in the classic Chablis style. The fruit is abundant yet there's a discreet but very present mineral structure that's most notable on the finish. Full of freshness, fruit and finesse. A fine match with lobster dishes, trout or even a cheese ravioli.

wine.name: Sauternes, Le Tertre du Lys
wine.review: This is an amazing Sauternes that shows great depth and complex fruits of white flowers, apricots, acacia and raw honey. Young Sauternes is amazing, sweet, fresh with vibrant fruits that make an imcomparable match with blue cheese and salted, roasted almonds.

wine.name: Arcadian Chardonnay, Sleepy Hollow Young Vines
wine.review: Joe Davis is a master of California winemaking. He studied in Burgundy, adopting many Old World techniques, and later brought them to his efforts in Santa Barbara, California. This Chardonnay will remind you of a white Burgundy, but it shows more exuberant notes of citrus, white flowers, and stony minerals on the finish. A sophisticated California Chardonnay.

wine.name: Pie de Palo, Viognier
wine.review: This dry, unoaked white wine is full of delicate aromas of ripe pineapple and citrus fruits. It's a versatile wine that makes a fascinating companion to simple poultry or seafood dishes.

wine.name: Vacqueyras Blanc, Dom. de Montvac
wine.review: Vacqueyras Blanc is a rare find. Made from Roussanne, Clairette and Bourboulenc, this white wine shows a rich, creamy mouthfeel and underlying toasty notes. Domaine de Montvac has been handed down from mother to daughter for 4 generations. These vines are 30 years old and grown in chalky clay soils, giving this wine an alluring minerality.

wine.name: Elizabeth Spencer Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: This alluring Sauvignon Blanc comes from the winemaking team of Elizabeth Pressler and Spencer Graham. Thirty-year-old vines and extended lees contact give it a rich mouthfeel, with grapefruit and white flower aromas bursting from the glass.

wine.name: Álvaro Castro Tinto, Dão
wine.review: This is an intensely fragrant, full-bodied red wine from the Dão region of Portugal. Alvaro Castro is a meticulous winemaker whose overarching goal is to ensure that varietal typicity shows in his finished wines. This bottle is full of dark, compote-like black fruits that are accessible in spite of their intensity. Of course, this would be a great match for grilled skirt steak and the like.

wine.name: Millesimé Brut, Jacques Lassaigne
wine.review: This comes from the village of Montgueux in Champagne. This comes from 35 year old Chardonnay vines. On the palate, there's the expected chalk-driven minerals that you get from soils of a limestone and chalk composition. Incredibly youthful yellow fruits and flowers. Delicious as an apéritif to whet the appetite.

wine.name: Pignoletto White Sparkling, Zucchi
wine.review: Pignoletto is a white grape variety native to the Appenine hills surrounding the city of Bologna. If you feel like you're in a Prosecco rut, try this on for size: full of white fruit and floral aromas, the Pignoletto is dry, sparkling, and dangerously drinkable.

wine.name: Opus One, Napa
wine.review: Opus One is a joint venture between Mondavi and Rothschild created to express the balance between traditional and modern techniques. The vineyards of Opus One are meticulously tended and the wines are allowed to express the character of the vintage and the terroir. Sultry tannins, balanced acidity, black fruit and spices all combine together to create a memorable experience.

wine.name: Eberle Syrah, Steinbeck
wine.review: Coming from the Steinbeck vineyard, this Syrah is very Rhône-like, with notes of blackberry and dark cherry. Very structured, with underlying notes of toasty vanilla oak and silky tannins. The flavors will linger on your palate.

wine.name: Lambrusco di Sorbara Rosato, Zucchi
wine.review: Yes, we were surprised too to find a rosé-version of Lambrusco. It's made from a different clone of Lambrusco, Sorbara, that renders a lighter color of red. Dry on the palate that show's off a mix of red berries.

wine.name: Saumur Brut, Dom. du Vieux Pressoir
wine.review: This sparkling wine from the Saumur region of the Loire Valley is made in the traditional champagne method and is aged 15 months sur lie. 30% of the blend is Chardonnay, creating a wine that has gorgeous brioche notes with a complimentary citrus character.

wine.name: Savia Viva, Cava Brut
wine.review: Very clean and very pretty, this Cava is laced with soft aromas of fresh lime zest and goes perfectly with spicy foods. This floored us when we first tasted it – and then we found out it was organic, too.

wine.name: Ch. Haut-Bailly, Pessac-Léognan
wine.review: The clay-based soils that the vines grow on at this estate greatly enhanced the moisture levels during this very hot season. This is bursting with dark plums, cassis and minerals on the palate.

wine.name: Ch. La Conseillante, Pomerol
wine.review: This right-bank Bordeaux is Merlot based and shows plenty of minerals and blackcurrant fruit on the palate. There's a great amount of spice on the finish that makes this a fine match with any type of roast.

wine.name: Pommard "Jarollières", La Pousse d'Or
wine.review: This Pommard has a spicy bouquet highlighted by well-integrated oak and subtle berry flavours. Lovely, soft, balanced.

wine.name: Puligny-Montrachet "Clos Le Cailleret", La Pousse d'Or
wine.review: Elegant mineral overtones with toasty hints of marzipan, tropical fruit, amber, and white flowers.

wine.name: Grande Reserve Brut, Lallier
wine.review: The Lallier family has been established in Ay for over 5 generations. This Champagne is rich in fruit - strawberries and apples - and incredibly accessible at the same time.

wine.name: Rosé Brut, Lallier
wine.review: The Lallier winery is located in the heart of the village of Ay in the Champagne region. This wine is all Pinot Noir, aged for 40 months on the lees and disgorged just 5 months before shipping to New York.

wine.name: Pol Roger, Rosé Brut
wine.review: This is an exuberant rosé Champagne that's fruit forward and full of tasty red fruits and spice on the palate. An easy sparkler to enjoy before a meal.

wine.name: Cerasuolo di Vittoria "Pithos", COS
wine.review: The Cerasuolo di Vittoria area is located in central Sicily. This delightful red was both vinified and aged in clay amphorae - an ancient practice that still works wonderfully - as this wine ably shows. The smooth, pleasant palate impression is of raspberry, mandarin, and minerals.

wine.name: Pol Roger Brut
wine.review: The Brut Vintage Champagne from Pol Roger is one of their greatest wines. It is a blend of 40% Chardonnay and 60% Pinot Noir. Full of berries, citrus and light spices.

wine.name: Pol Roger, Blanc de Chardonnay
wine.review: This vintage Champagne is a Blanc de Blancs - a white wine made entirely from Chardonnay. It's full of toast, acacia and honey on the palate and is certainly a wine of elegance.

wine.name: Willakenzie Pinot Noir, Willamette Valley
wine.review: The Willakenzie winery is named after the soil in which the vines are planted, and it is known for its Burgundian-style Pinot Noirs. Red and black fruit flavors, with bright acidity and hints of baking spices, are all in attendance here, and floral aromas waft from the glass. Overall, this is a delicious Oregon Pinot Noir from the Willamette Valley.

wine.name: Giacomo Sangiovese Toscana
wine.review: This Tuscan red exhibits earty tones and is a great food companion.

wine.name: Alicante, Ch. Ollieux Romanis
wine.review: This is a hearty, viscous, opaque, tannic, all-around intriguing red wine. Made entirely from Alicante (sometimes known as Alicante Bouschet) it is nearly black in color, packed with darker-than-dark fruits, and bursting at the seams with flavor.

wine.name: Ischia Bianco, Casa d'Ambra
wine.review: From the volcanic island of Ischia comes this explosive white wine. Dry, fresh, and bursting with yellow flowers and lime fruit, this is simply perfect with herbed fish dishes.

wine.name: Bergström "de Lancellotti" Pinot Noir
wine.review: De Lancellotti was the founder of the Bergström winery. This Pinot comes from a mere 6 acre plot of land with sedimentary soils of old ocean beaches. This is a rich Pinot Noir, full of coffee, dark chocolate, nutmeg, berries and game aromas. A powerful wine that's silken in texture and just brilliant on the palate. Aged in large, oak casks - none of which were new.

wine.name: Aspasie, Blanc de Blancs Brut
wine.review: There's nothing more luxurious than a great glass of Champagne. This is made entirely from Chardonnay and is full of smoky aromas with yellow fruits and chalk-mineral on the finish. It's a dry Champagne but all-around accessible. A superb sparkler that will work as an apéritif.

wine.name: Ariston Fils, Brut Millesimé
wine.review: This vintage Champagne is packed with character and has a more earthy side of aromas. Full of white flowers, oregano, raw honey and minerals. Drinking brilliantly today and truly succulent on the palate.

wine.name: Ariston, Brut Rosé
wine.review: This rosé has a nice copper hue to it and is just bursting with red berries and spice on the palate. This is mostly made from Pinot Noir and Pinot Meunier but also has 15% of a local variety called Brouillet Rouge - clearly named after the village of Brouillet where this Champagne comes from.

wine.name: Phelps Cabernet Sauvignon, Backus Vineyard
wine.review: Phelps produced the first Backus back in1977 from a steeply terraced hillside vineyard with red-brick soil. The wine is packed with flavors of cassis, smoke, and red current. Always outstanding.

wine.name: Châteauneuf-du-Pape "Cuvée Classique", Monpertuis
wine.review: This bottle of "Cuvée Classique" comes from a 10-hectare plot. Based on Grenache, Mourvèdre, and Syrah, it gets remarkable concentration and balance from 40-year-old vines.

wine.name: Forster Stift Rieslaner Beerenauslese, Von Buhl
wine.review: Rieslaner is made from crossing two other varieties: Riesling and Silvaner. You'll find peaches and lots of opulent citrus fruits with a sweetness balanced by acidity and light minerals.

wine.name: Iphöfer Kronsberg Riesling Spätlese Trocken, Wirsching
wine.review: You can't go wrong with the German wines from the Wirsching estate. This is truly a bottle that will make you drool with happiness.

wine.name: Nackenheim Rothenberg Riesling, Gunderloch
wine.review: Fritz Hasselbach, winemaker at the Gunderloch estate, puts forth great efforts in all his wines - namely the most popular bottlings such as this Riesling that was harvested technically as an Auslese but was vinified into a dry wine.

wine.name: Wild Oaks Cabernet Sauvignon, St. Francis
wine.review: St. Francis Winery has created this Wild Oaks Cabernet Sauvignon from a blend of mountainside vineyards thought Sonoma County. With underlying minerality that gives this wine immense structure and notes of dark berries, this Cabernet remains approachable.

wine.name: Wild Oaks Old Vine Zinfandel, St. Francis
wine.review: Most of the grapes for this Zinfandel come from a volcanic ridge high about Sonoma Valley. The wine shows intense, juicy berry flavors and a balanced acidity. Underlying notes of baking spices and a toasted vanilla round out the palate.

wine.name: Gewürztraminer Spätlese, Pfeffingen
wine.review: If you like the variety but are occasionally put off by exuberant Gewürztraminer armonatics, this delicate, reticent style will be perfect. Unmistakably floral yet reserved and pretty, this slightly sweet wine is an excellent choice for exotic, highly spiced south east Asian fare.

wine.name: Côte-Rôtie Brune et Blonde, E. Guigal
wine.review: Coming from a muscular vintage this has matured wonderfully with rich fruit balanced by classic beefy, mineral notes and a long, slightly peppery finish

wine.name: Laurel Glen Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Lush and velvety with rich, deep dark cherry fruit that caresses the palate. At peak and likely to hold there for years to come.

wine.name: Bacio Divino
wine.review: Coming from a small, family-owned winery in Napa.

wine.name: Beringer Merlot, Bancroft Ranch
wine.review: From Cali

wine.name: Cornerstone Cellars Cabernet Sauvignon, Beatty Ranch
wine.review: From Cali

wine.name: Swanson Syrah
wine.review: From Cali

wine.name: Bâtard-Montrachet Blanc Grand Cru, Pierre Morey
wine.review: Pierre Morey is one of the most talented winemakers in Burgundy. This Grand Cru is a wine for the cellar. On release, it boasts honey, mineral, smoke and yellow fruits.

wine.name: Monthélie Rouge, Pierre Morey
wine.review: The village of Monthélie produces mostly Pinot Noir and is located in the Côte de Beaune sub-region of Burgundy. Wines from Monthélie are wines to drink younger. This will be best enjoyed in the next years to come.

wine.name: Ch. Branaire-Ducru, St.-Julien
wine.review: Very restrained and showing the classic qualities of the vintage with it's medium weight and taut structure offering up youthful notes of expresso, leather, and mineral that serve to complement the cool cassis fruit.

wine.name: Ch. Pavie, St.-Émilion
wine.review: Very deep on the palate with rich red fruits and a good lashing of toasty oak offering spicy contrast. Excellent balance and an elegance on the palate belie the wines inherent weight and is sure to please all Bordeaux aficionados.

wine.name: Ch.Pavie-Decesse, St.-Émilion
wine.review: An unusual St. Emilion with it's 90% Merlot this is flamboyant yet structured with great depth of kirsh fruit that will unfold with time in the bottle. The nose today remains very expressive with wonderful fruit, floral, and soil tones.

wine.name: Ch. Bellevue-Mondotte, St.-Émilion
wine.review: Dense and chewy creme de cassis flavors coat the palate with this extracted, jammy styled St. Emilion. Rich with oaken spice to contrast to the dark fruits, this offers compelling drinking already yet will evolve well for decades.

wine.name: Ch. Cos d'Estournel, St.-Estèphe
wine.review: Very young and very firm with typically hard tannins and driving acidity that is amply balanced by very fresh and bright black currant fruit. Lots of toasty nuances and a bit of pencil lead and cigar ash add some supporting notes.

wine.name: Beaune Grèves "Vigne de l'Enfant Jésus", Bouchard Père et Fils
wine.review: This is one of the gems from Bouchard Père & Fils, sole owner of almost 4 hectares of this very well-regarded red Premier Cru from the village of Beaune.

wine.name: Beaune Rouge "Clos de la Mousse", Bouchard Père et Fils
wine.review: Full of cherries, licorice and cherrywood. Ripe and driven by fruit and lithe tannins. Drinking well today.

wine.name: Mauritson Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: This Sauvignon Blanc is a blend of grapes from three vineyard sites in the Dry Creek Valley. Aromas of dried peach and freshly cut hay waft from the glass. Ripe fruit is balanced by a bright acidity, with flavors of grapefruit and honeysuckle coming forth on the palate.

wine.name: Larmandier-Bernier "Terre de Vertus"
wine.review: This Champagne is dosage-free and is therefore bone-dry on the palate. A Champagne of this caliber can be held for many years to come. Quite young today, mineral-driven and perfect, if that's how you like your Larmandier-Bernier.

wine.name: Riesling Icewine Reserve, Mission Hill
wine.review: This is an ice wine from one of the great Canadian wineries located in British Columbia, Mission Hill. Making Riesling is always a gamble. You leave your perfectly ripened grapes in the vineyard only to wait until the first freeze of the winter comes to quickly whisk the fruit away to press.

wine.name: Giacchè Rosso Lazio, Casale Cento Corvi
wine.review: This comes from central Italy from vines not so far away from the gorgeous city of Rome. This is made from the once-though-extinct Giacchè grape variety. It's a fantastic red wine that's full-bodied and full of of darker-than-dark berries. Aged in large (not new) wood barrels.

wine.name: Prosecco "Cartizze Superiore," Col Vetoraz
wine.review: The Cartizze area is located in the heart of the Valdobiaddene. Col Vetoraz has set out to define a genuine and pure style of Prosecco, and this sparkler is pure silk on the palate, with aromas of white flowers and yellow fruit flavors. An easy wine to drink before, during and after a meal.

wine.name: Vampire Pinot Noir
wine.review: Halloween.

wine.name: Barolo Riserva "Granbussia", Aldo Conterno
wine.review: The Granbussia Riserva is only made in the finest of years from Nebbiolo coming from the 3 vineyards: Romirasco, Cicala and Colonnello.

wine.name: Roger Pouillon & Fils "Cuvée de Réserve," Brut
wine.review: Smoky and full of toasty brioche and melon, this is made mostly from Pinot Noir but has some Chardonnay as well. A great Champagne that could easily substitute for a meal.

wine.name: Roger Pouillon & Fils, Rosé Brut
wine.review: We can't get enough of rosé Champagne and this bottle will show you exactly why. This is liquid berry. It's dry, yet packed with roses, cherries and lithe minerals on the finish. Very generous on the palate and dangerously easy to drink from morning to night.

wine.name: Clos de la Plante Martin Blanc, Joguet
wine.review: This comes from one of our favorite red wine producers in the Loire, Joguet. This is in fact a new wine made from the white Chenin Blanc grape variety. It's dry, full of concentrated honeys and white flowers and yellow plums. Just a delight to drink with a light chill throughout a meal.

wine.name: Nuits-St.-Georges "Les Murgers", Dom. Bertagna
wine.review: This Premier Cru Pinot Noir from the vineyard, Les Murgers, is aged in 30% new wood. It's dominated by dark cherries and spice on the palate and retains a real elegance.

wine.name: Corton Rouge "Les Grandes Lolières" Grand Cru, Dom. Bertagna
wine.review: This great Pinot Noir was aged in barrel for nearly 2 years. Upon release full of intense fruit and mineral character. Clearly a wine to decant and drink immediately or to cellar for decades.

wine.name: Savia Viva Blanco "Clásico"
wine.review: Pure white wine goodness. This is one of our proudest discoveries: a still, dry, fruit-driven, delicious white made from grapes that are most often used to make Cava. Full of delightful quince fruit and intriguing minerals on the palate, this is a great apéritif, and a savvy match for seafood dishes.

wine.name: Savia Viva Tinto "Familia"
wine.review: This beautifully made red wine reminds us of a juicy Bordeaux from the Médoc: after resting in oak barrels for eight months, the juice (Merlot and both of the Cabernets) emerges full of dark red berry fruit flavors and spice accents. Great with roasts, braises, and company.

wine.name: Piedirosso "Campi Flegrei," La Sibilla
wine.review: This is an unoaked red wine from the Southern Italian region of Campania. Made from the indigenous Piedirosso grape variety, this still, dry wine is driven by wildflower and raspberry flavors. A great companion for grilled meats.

wine.name: Vineyard 29 "Cru" Cabernet Sauvignon
