wine.review: Vineyard 29 is located in the heart of Cabernet Sauvignon country. "Cru" is made from six vineyards that are specifically selected. The nose is packed with notes of coffee bean and chocolate, while in the mouth, flavors of cassis and black cherry bust with underlying silky tannins.

wine.name: Ayana, Pinot Noir
wine.review: This Pinot Noir comes from some great sites in California. Ayana has created a very approachable and enjoyable Pinot Noir here, with bright cherry fruit and velvet-laden tannins.

wine.name: Stephen Ross Chardonnay
wine.review: The Stephen Ross winery produces small quantity wines in the Edna Valley. This Chardonnay is aromatic and fruit forward, rich on the palate with good acidity, and finishes with a hint of oak and tropical fruit flavors.

wine.name: Qta. de Sta. Eufemia "Garrafeira", Douro
wine.review: This wine is produced in the Douro using traditional grapes normally used to make port. Toasted notes of vanilla and coffee burst from the glass while velvety tannins and red berry flavors linger on the finish.

wine.name: Qta. de Sta. Eufemia "Viseu de Carvalho" Grande Escolha, Douro
wine.review: Aged in French oak barrels, this red wine comes from a traditional port making house in the Douro. Toasted notes of hazelnut, vanilla and coffee bean characterize this red.

wine.name: Churchill's Vintage Port
wine.review: Firm concentration of dark cherry berries with dark chocolate, dark spices and all around rich concentration.

wine.name: Hartwell Cabernet Sauvignon, Sunshine Vineyard
wine.review: from cali

wine.name: Bourgogne Rouge "Les Barrigards", Cornu
wine.review: Cornu's basic Burgundy captures the essence of Chorey with its spice and nervosity. Lip-smacking acidity makes this wine an ideal partner for simply roasted bird or grilled sausage.

wine.name: Châteauneuf-du-Pape VV, Dom. de la Millière
wine.review: This full-bodied red wine comes from the southern Rhône, and it happens to be a superlative value in traditional Châteauneuf-du-Pape. Full of dark plum flavors and black pepper spice with an unbelievable velvet texture. Winemaker Michel Arnaud is of the 5th generation of Arnauds to work on the domaine.

wine.name: Mâcon-Cruzilles "Les Perrières", Dom. Guillot Broux
wine.review: This Chardonnay is concentrated with yellow fruits and flowers. Incredibly fresh and vibrant on the palate with a hint of vanilla bean and mineral on the finish.

wine.name: Bibich Riserva
wine.review: Located in the town of Skradin, this is made from a blend of local red varieties: Babich, Lasin and Plavina. Aged in American oak for 12 months, there’s a generous amount of mixed berry fruit aromas that are somewhat reminiscent of a medium-bodied Syrah.

wine.name: Bibich, Mantra Grenache
wine.review: The Bibich winery purchased these vineyards in the early '90s. They have since managed to cultivate this great Grenache which has vines that are 60 years old. The aromas are driven by plums and red cherries. Aged in oak for 12 months.

wine.name: Bibich "Sangreal" MMIV, Shiraz
wine.review: If you were to taste this wine blind, there's a very likely chance you'd mistake it for a Côte-Rôtie. It's very generous with fruits - cherries, plums and pepper too - with chocolate-like tannins on the finish. We're certain that you'll be pleased with the outcome.

wine.name: Corton-Charlemagne, Dom. Simon Bize et Fils
wine.review: The Bize family originate from the Savoie, only moving to Burgundy in the early 9th Century. While most of their holdings are in Savigny, they also have some formidable Corton-Charlemagne too.

wine.name: Messorio, Le Macchiole
wine.review: Year in and out this bottle of Messorio is about consistent beauty in Merlot. Le Macchiole is one of the handful of estates making quality-focused wines in Bolgheri.

wine.name: Scrio, Le Macchiole
wine.review: Production of this rare Syrah wine is miniscule. We are, therefore, pleased to offer you this voluptuous red wine.

wine.name: Clarendon Hills "Kangarilla" Grenache
wine.review: The wines from Clarendon Hills are among the least commercial you'll find in Australia. Here it's about quality rather than quantity. All the vines are dry-farmed, there's no filtration and add to that very old vines. The results are beautiful, rich and an expression of mineral that speaks of the land.

wine.name: Clarendon Hills "Piggot Range" Syrah
wine.review: We were blown away by this Syrah. It speaks wonders on the palate. Very full of lush, mixed dark fruits like blackberries and black plums and even some fresh peppermint leaf. The minerals are distinguised and add a great deal of complexity to this wine that will remind you of a ripe, northern Rhône red. Clearly a wine that can age for well over a decade.

wine.name: Channing Daughters, Rosso Fresco
wine.review: The wine has a translucent light red color with purple overtones. It is dry, medium-bodied, balanced, and juicy, showing plum, black cherry, black raspberry, Asian spices, a touch of smoke, and a slight meaty/gamey note.

wine.name: Laurent-Perrier Vintage Brut
wine.review: Laurent-Perrier has elected to be highly selective by only producing a vintage in the very best years. This vintage is an exceptional and rare wine.

wine.name: Caymus Cabernet Sauvignon, Napa Valley
wine.review: The core of this wine is a silky and amiably rich, textured base, with a pure Napa Valley Cabernet focus. Flavors of cocoa, currant and sweet tobacco. This rich and chalky wine drinks well now and should endure for a decade or more.

wine.name: Millbrook, Tocai Friuliano
wine.review: This is an off-dry white wine from the Hudson Valley region of New York. The grape has its origins in northern Italy and found its way to New York State decades ago. Full of yellow fruits and white pepper on the palate, this is slightly sweet and a great match for spicy foods.

wine.name: Millbrook "Proprietor's Special Reserve" Cabernet Franc
wine.review: This Cabernet Franc reminds us more of Bordeaux than anything. It's perhaps a bit more fruit-driven but in a great way. A rich, lively red wine with berries and black plum fruit on the palate.

wine.name: Powers Merlot, Washington
wine.review: Who says Merlot is dead? We don't - and this unoaked bottle from Washington State just proves our point. It's full of ripe plums and all-around beautiful dark fruits.

wine.name: Blanc de Noirs "Inflorescence", Bouchard
wine.review: Only 750 cases were made of this beautiful Champagne. Made entirely from Pinot Noir and very much a "meal" of a wine. Drink with just the slightest chill.

wine.name: Fronton Classic, Bouissel
wine.review: Qu'est-ce que c'est, you ask? Good question. It's a wine from just outside of the city of Toulouse, made in a hearty, rustic fashion, mostly from the Negrette grape (which is pretty common in that part of Gascony). This is full of black, earth-driven fruit with rosemary and violets.

wine.name: Marleo, Salustri
wine.review: This is everyday Sangiovese from the relatively new Montecucco DOC. The fruit is prominent, ripe, and full of dark cherries and mixed spices. An excellent match for any number of comforting, hearty dishes - from pizza to grilled steaks.

wine.name: Barbeito Verdelho Madeira 1981
wine.review: This Madeira just has a slight sweetness to it. It spent 20 years maturing in cask before being bottled. Where were you in 1981?

wine.name: Grotte Rosso, Salustri
wine.review: Grotte Rosso is aged in oak for 18 months. The fruit is intense, black and full of anise seed, almonds and minerals. A great wine if you're looking for a bold, oaked and fruit-driven red wine. Great with grilled steaks.

wine.name: Henriot Rosé Brut
wine.review: The Henriot Champagne house has been making great bubbly for years. This is a great rosé Champagne for everyday consumption. Full of lively berries and bubbles.

wine.name: Salina Bianco, Hauner
wine.review: A dry Sicilian white wine that's full of soft yellow fruits, laurel leaf, and honey. Made from a blend of Catarratto and Inzolia, two indigenous white grapes that thrive on the mostly volcanic soils of the island.

wine.name: Salina Rosso, Hauner
wine.review: The wines from the Hauner estate, on the Lipari Islands, always express the terroir of their volcanic soils. This blend of Nerello Mascalese and Nero d'Avola is dark, mineraled, and very much like an earthy but fruit-driven Dolcetto. It's great with grilled meats.

wine.name: Riesling Kabinett, Baron K
wine.review: Full of ripe red currants and pink grapefruit on the palate. Voluptuous on the palate and off-dry meaning it is not bone dry.

wine.name: Mas Doix Priorat
wine.review: Mas Doix has created their flagship Priorat from old-vine Garnacha, Carignan, and Merlot grown in intense Llicorella (slate) soils. This soil is extremely high in minerals, which lends to the age-ability of this wine. Dense, rich black fruit, with notes of tobacco and herb.

wine.name: Brut Pétillant, Huet
wine.review: Sparkling Chenin Blanc that's was aged on the lees for an extended period of time adding a palpable amount of aromatic complexity. Dry, honeyed and full of minerals.

wine.name: Ch. Léoville-Las-Cases, St.-Julien
wine.review: The vineyards of Léoville-Las-Cases lie in the northernmost corner of the St Julien appellation. Based mostly on Cabernet Sauvignon, it gives a solid backbone of tannins.

wine.name: Betts & Scholl Syrah
wine.review: Richard Betts and Dennis Scholl created their label in with a goal of making elegant, complex, and balanced wines in partnership with winemakers from all over the world. For this wine, they teamed up with Lewis Cellars in Napa to make a seductive Syrah, with black fruit and silky tannins.

wine.name: Philipponnat "Clos des Goisses" Brut
wine.review: The Clos des Goisses from Philipponnat is an exceptional vineyard set in Mareuil sur Aÿ. This is made of Pinot Noir and the Chardonnay. This champagne is a perfect expression of these lands: intense with fruit, complexity of minerals and wonderful length and freshness on the finish.

wine.name: Saxon Brown Pinot Noir, Durrell Hayfield
wine.review: Fewer than 100 cases of this were produced. Jeff Gaffner of Saxon Brown was lucky enough to get his hands on fruit from the famous Hayfield Block of the Durell vineyard. Cherry, cola, and raspberry aromas burst from the glass. Enjoy it now or lay it down to age beautifully for years to come.

wine.name: Vouvray "Le Haut Lieu" Sec, Huet
wine.review: Just recently released, this dry Vouvray is as fresh as they come. Honey, apricots, and mineral abound on the palate. Balanced and showing impressive finesse, this will settle in bottle nicely for years.

wine.name: Vouvray "Le Haut Lieu" Sec, Huet
wine.review: A dry Vouvray that's as fresh as they come since it has just recently been released. Great with honey and apricots and mineral on the palate. Full of balance and finesse that will settle in bottle nicely for years to come.

wine.name: Vouvray "Le Haut Lieu" Moëlleux, Huet
wine.review: This is one of the two greatest vintages of the century from the Huet estate, let alone from any estate in the world!

wine.name: Tokaji "Cuvée Ilona", Királyudvar
wine.review: The Királyudvar estate doesn't necessarily care to follow the stringent gov't regulations that dictate how many Puttonyos you can list on the bottle. This is technically a 6 Puttonyos except for the fact that it was not aged long enough in cask before bottling.

wine.name: Ch. Mouton-Rothschild, Pauillac
wine.review: An incredible endeavor from the Mouton-Rothschild estate. Everything you can imagine and more on the palate with dense spice, berries and finesse all at once.

wine.name: Ch. Haut-Brion, Pessac-Léognan
wine.review: Ch. Haut-Brion is the First Growth estate to be included in the 1855 Classification that exists outside of the Médoc. It's located in a sub-region of Graves, called Pessac-Léognan, located just a mile away from the town of Bordeaux. This is a great vintage of this decade. Still youthful. Decant.

wine.name: Ch. Cheval Blanc, St.-Émilion
wine.review: The Cheval-Blanc vineyards, and the property itself, border Pomerol. After fermentation the wine goes into oak, naturally 100% new, where it matures for 18 months before bottling. This is a fantastic vintage to drink. Youthful and can still be held for decades to come.

wine.name: Roessler Pinot Noir, Brosseau Vineyard
wine.review: The Brosseau Vineyard is located on a limestone bed in the Chalone AVA. Packed with mineral, this Pinot Noir shows mouth-watering acidity and ripe red berry flavors. Roessler is dedicated to the art of the Pinot Noir.

wine.name: Jacques Selosse "Initiale", Blanc de Blancs Grand Cru Brut
wine.review: The "Initiale" cuvée from Selosse is a Blanc de Blancs Champagne that's oozing with minerals on the palate. A dry, focused, intense Chardonnay that's brilliant today but has the substance to be held for years to come.

wine.name: Gruet Rosé Brut
wine.review: Gruet, our favorite New Mexico Sparkler, produces this rosé in limited quantity. Produced in the brut style with notes of cherry, raspberry, and strawberry on the palate and a bright, floral bouquet. Grab it while you can.

wine.name: Poggio dei Gorleri, Vigna Sorì
wine.review: This is a dry Italian white wine made from old-vine Vermentino grapes grown in the region of Liguria. It's a serious, unoaked wine, dense with floral fruit and lots of mineral. The concentration is superb and the texture silky. Drink with just a light chill and enjoy the wine's evolution in the glass. Ideal with seafood.

wine.name: Moss Wood "Ribbon Vale Vineyard" Blend
wine.review: The Moss Wood estate is in a league of its own out in Western Australia. They're located in the cooler climate of the Margaret River. This is a blend of 3 Bordeaux varieties Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Cabernet Franc.

wine.name: Barbera d'Asti "Montruc", Franco Martinetti
wine.review: Serious Barbera that's judiciously oak-aged. Full of dark plums, spice and mineral. Rich yet lithe in character and a wine that you can age for several years to come.

wine.name: Barolo "Brunate", Vietti
wine.review: One of the finest wines of the vintage showing ample fruit, spice and balsamic notes.

wine.name: Lewis Cellars Merlot
wine.review: from cali

wine.name: "Cuvée Speciale", Pascal Cotat
wine.review: This was a legendary year in the Loire and certainly one of the very few white wines from there that can still be aged for many years to come. This is an off-dry white wine.

wine.name: Meddersheimer Altenberg Riesling Spätlese, Hexamer
wine.review: The Hexamer estate is one of our favorites from the Nahe region. This is evolving marvelously thanks to the brilliant acidity of Riesling. Full of stone-fruits and minerals on the palate.

wine.name: Valpolicella, Dal Forno
wine.review: The Dal Forno estate makes delicious, modern wines from Veneto. This Valpolicella is heavily spiced, deeply fruit-driven and full of complexities will evolve for years.

wine.name: Grüner Veltliner "Im Weingebirge" Smaragd, Nikolaihof
wine.review: From one of Nikolaihof's top sites in the Wachau, this Grüner shows intense minerality and layers of flavors, including quince, honeysuckle, and white pepper.

wine.name: Dorsheimer Goldloch Riesling Spätlese, Schlossgut Diel
wine.review: One of the greatest estates on the lower Nahe, producing scintillating, terroir-driven Rieslings. This one is just entering its prime.

wine.name: Riesling Dürnstein Federspiel, Alzinger
wine.review: A dry Riesling packed with lime and kumquat fruit, notes of petrol and lots of minerals. Despite its power, this magnificent wine maintains a perfect balance among all its elements.

wine.name: Billecart-Salmon Brut Rosé
wine.review: A fine, delicate bead is Billecart-Salmon's signature. A blend of the Pinots and Chardonnay. Dry with exquisite red berry character and a gorgeous texture. An ideal Champagne to enjoy as an apéritif with smoked salmon or sushi.

wine.name: Ch. Clos de Sarpe, St. Émilion
wine.review: One of the richer wines from the right bank in St.-Émilion made from a blend of 85% Merlot and 15% Cabernet Franc. The grapes come from 65-year-old vines.

wine.name: Fleurie "Garants", Vissoux
wine.review: This is a rare cuvée from the Vissoux domaine. A gem of a Beaujolais with great minerality, red berries, and amazing freshness, this bottle could even be aged for a few years.

wine.name: Ch. La Vieille Cure, Fronsac
wine.review: This Fronsac estate has gone through some changes since the new owners took over in the mid-1980s: the glorious old vines are now processed by gleaming, updated facilities. The wine is full of dark fruits - blackberries and cherries - with spicy, assertive tannins.

wine.name: Kindzmarauli Semi-Sweet Kakheti, Teliani Valley
wine.review: Made from late harvest Saperavi grapes and grown in the Kakheti region of the republic of Georgia. Red in color, full of berries and sweetness.

wine.name: Masseto, Tenuta dell'Ornellaia
wine.review: The Masseto wine is made entirely from Merlot grapes from the very vineyards that also go into the wine, Ornellaia. This is the estates "second wine". Highly allocated with small production from a mere 7 hectares of vines.

wine.name: 100% Ptit Verre d'Eau, L'Homme Cheval, Leandre-Chevalier
wine.review: Léandre-Chevalier is second to none, and this is made entirely from pre-phylloxera Petite Verdot vines from the spectacular 2005 vintage.

wine.name: Nuits-St.-George "Perrières", Chevillon
wine.review: This is very stylish rich Pinot Noir that is very young but brooding with complex aromas driven by red berries and spice. Decant and enjoy in the flush of youth or hold for years to come.

wine.name: Ponzi "Tavola" Pinot Noir
wine.review: Full of milk chocolate, star anise and ripe raspberries on the palate. The tannins are soft and approachable. A great find from Oregon.

wine.name: Chassagne-Montrachet Blanc "Morgeot - Les Fairendes", Pillot
wine.review: Pillot's wines are made with an emphasis of expressing the terroir of the vineyard. This Chardonnay is full of plump yellow fruits, minerals and a touch of vanilla on the finish.

wine.name: Piper Heidsieck Viktor & Rolf Rose Sauva
wine.review: Limited Edition from Viktor & Rolf.

wine.name: Punkt Genau, Sparkling Grüner Veltliner
wine.review: Had a sparkling Grüner Veltliner lately? This refreshing sparkling wine is made in the heart of Austria's Weinviertal. With notes of green apple and hibiscus, this wine is delicious enough to convince any skeptics out there that you don't need a special occasion to drink sparkling wine these days.

wine.name: Moët Grand Vintage
wine.review: A new Champagne release from the Moët Champagne House. Surely to be another hit among Moët fans.

wine.name: l'Étoile de Rachelle, Merlot
wine.review: There's almost no other wine with the jubilant character and broad appeal of a friendly, fruit-driven Merlot. This one comes from the south of France, and it is simply everything you want in an everyday red wine: soft, velvety, and enticing, it's seductive and drinkable any night of the week. A Vin de Pays from the Aude in Languedoc.

wine.name: l'Étoile de Rachelle, Sauvignon Blanc
wine.appellation: Vin de Pays des Côtes de Gascogne

wine.name: Grüner Veltliner "Frauenweingarten" Federspiel, FX Pichler
wine.review: FX Pichler is considered to be one of the most preeminent winemakers in Austria. Making wine in the Wachau, his wines show immense complexity and luminescence. This Grüner is no exception.

wine.name: Vouvray Demi Sec "Clos Naudin"
wine.review: Mildly sweet with aromas of acacia and honey on the palate.

wine.name: Meursault "Perrières", Bitouzet-Prieur
wine.review: A complex white wine from a winemaker who is a staunch traditionalist in the cellar. This is full of raw honey, yellow apples, and quince fruit on the palate. The warm conditions of 2003 made this Meursault a bit fuller-bodied than most.

wine.name: Clos de Vougeot, Cathiard
wine.review: Sylvain Cathiard started working at his father`s Domaine in 1979. This wine was matured in oak casks (a good portion of which were new) for two years. Remarkably elegant, silky and concentrated just as you would expect from a finer bottling of Clos de Vougeot.

wine.name: Farnum Hill Semi-Dry Sparkling Cider
wine.review: A cider that has just a trace of sweetness. Aromatic notes dominate with apples, citrus and some tannin. A great alternative to white wine.

wine.name: Redfield, West County Cider
wine.review: This is a rosé-colored, hard cider that's sparkling and quite dry on the palate. It's amazingly addictive and tastes like none other than freshly picked, peak-season Macintosh apples.

wine.name: Morey-St.-Denis, Dom. Dujac
wine.review: The wines of Domaine Dujac are some of the most sought after Pinot Noirs in the world. The winery started in 1968 and soon thereafter began to be recognized as a top Burgundy estate.

wine.name: El Nido, Jumilla
wine.review: El Nido, a project with Australian Chris Ringland as head winemaker, is a bodacious blend coming from 60-year-old Monastrell vines and 25-year-old Cabernet Sauvignon vines. With its intense purple color and bold tannins, this wine captures the spirit of the Spanish South.

wine.name: Black Chook, Shiraz Viognier
wine.review: McLaren Vale has an unrivaled reputation in Australia, and indeed the world, for growing full-flavored Shiraz that is ripe yet balanced. This one makes use of a technique perfected in France's Côte-Rôtie: the winemakers add a little Viognier to the mix, creating a stunning and complex wine.

wine.name: Muscat de Beaumes-de-Venise, Dom. de Durban
wine.review: This dessert wine comes from one of the top producers in the southern Rhône. Honeyed and rich, this is truly bottled sunshine.

wine.name: Sherwood Pinot Noir
wine.review: Sherwood, based in Marlborough, New Zealand, has created this light, fruit-forward Pinot Noir. Notes of black plum and raspberry pop from the glass, accenting the underlying toasted vanilla flavors.

wine.name: Corton-Bressandes Rouge, Chandon de Briailles
wine.review: Although this bottle will evolve well for years to come, it shows a lovely, smoky elegance and delicate texture that is so characteristic of the Chandon de Briailles winery.

wine.name: Nackenheim Rothenberg Riesling Spätlese, Gunderloch
wine.review: The Rothenberg vineyard is Gunderloch's best site for Riesling that's vinified dry. You'll note a higher degree of alcohol due to the fact that there's no perceptible sugar on the palate. The texture is rich and full of red currants and white stone fruits.

wine.name: Shiraz "Old Bastard", Kaesler
wine.review: The name "Old Bastard" refers to the ancient (by aussie standards especially) age of the vines. This was made from a block of Shiraz vines that were planted in 1893. The result is a massive wine that's fuller than full-bodied and will impression anybody looking for bold.

wine.name: Ramsay Cabernet Sauvignon, North Coast
wine.review: Ramsay is Kent Rasmussen's side project. Made with fruit sourced from farmers throughout Napa Valley, this unique red shows notes of cassis, toasty vanilla, and hazelnuts.

wine.name: St. Joseph Rouge, Dom. du Tunnel
wine.review: Stephane Robert is a new producer in the small appellation of St. Joseph in the Northern Rhône. With only 2.5 hectares, he as managed to create a very approachable, clean, and well-structured Syrah. Notes of blueberry and blackberry, with a striking mineral backbone.

wine.name: Raventós Brut Cava "L'Hereu"
wine.review: This Cava, made from all-estate grown fruit, comes from Joseph Raventós. Made from the traditional grapes Xarel-lo, Paralleda, and Macabeo, this sparkling wine shows bright citrus notes along with a creamy, refreshing bead.

wine.name: Ch. Duhart-Milon, Pauillac
wine.review: The 4th Growth property Duhart-Milon covers some 71 hectares and offers up classic Pauillac notes of blackcurrants, licorice, earth, and smoke. The tannins are firm, the fruit dense.

wine.name: Chablis "Montée de Tonnerre", Raveneau
wine.review: Raveneau disciples believe you shouldn't touch the wine until it's at least a decade old. We agree on the one hand but understand impatience as well...

wine.name: Sablet, Dom. de Piaugier
wine.review: This Côtes du Rhône comes from the up-and-coming village of Sablet. Grown in sand, clay and silt, this Sablet is mostly Grenache with a bit of Syrah. Brambly, spicy black fruit, lively acidity, and velvet tannins.

wine.name: Nuits-St.-George, Dom. Leroy
wine.review: In 1988, the Noëllat Domaine was renamed Domaine Leroy. This new birth of sorts gave way to what some believe, today, as the best estate in the entire Côte d'Or. Amazingly concentrated and highly prized.

wine.name: Cassis Blanc, Dom. du Bagnol
wine.review: The sub-region of Cassis is located in Provence in the south of France. This is a sophisticated white wine made from Ugni Blanc, Clairette Blanc and Roussane. The aromas are driven by pears and quince. The minerals are subtle at first but grow on the palate. Drink with a light chill.

wine.name: Robert Foley Claret
wine.review: Coming from one of the top winemakers in Napa, Robert Foley has created a rich, concentrated Claret made from 90% Cabernet Sauvignon and 10 % Merlot. Showing ripe black cherries and youthful tannins now; hold for 10-15 years for an amazing experience.

wine.name: Saumur-Champigny "Amatéüs", Bobinet
wine.review: Absolutely delicious offering from winemaker Sebastien Bobinet who works the fields with a horse, having learned from Olivier Cousin. This wine is ripe with typical Cab Franc aromas and great minerals on the end. Try with herb sausage, peppers & onions; I promise you'll fall in love

wine.name: Terra di Lavoro, Galardi
wine.review: This beautiful red wine comes from the area of Sessa Aurunca, in northwestern Campania. An intense, full-bodied red wine made mostly from Aglianico and Piedirosso. This is a black, voluptuous wine that can age even longer in this large format bottle.

wine.name: Diamante, Rioja Blanco, Bodegas Franco-Espanola
wine.review: This semi-sweet white is made from Malvasia and Viura. Notes of orange peel and honeysuckle make it extremely drinkable.

wine.name: Saumur Rosé Sparkling "Corail", Louis de Grenelle
wine.review: A dry sparkling Cabernet Franc that’s well-structured and driven by red fruits on the palate with tannins on the finish. Great before dinner and incredibly food-friendly.

wine.name: Penner-Ash Viognier
wine.review: A wonderful dry white wine with subtle fruit and floral flavors: citrus and pear take center stage, but a subtle minerality is present as well. The wine is unoaked and aged on the lees for 5 months before bottling.

wine.name: Marc Hebrart "Selection" Brut
wine.review: Full of cream, red apples and citrus fruits on the palate. Mostly Pinot Noir then Chardonnay. This Champagne is made from vineyards that are at least 32 years old. Older, healthy vines are highly prized for good reason - they add complexity.

wine.name: Marc Hebrart, Rosé Brut
wine.review: Marc Hebrart Champagnes are new to the market and a real bargain if you're looking for quality Grower-Producer Champagne. This is delicately beaded, dry, full of saffron, raspberries and strawberries on the palate but in the most subtle fashion. Don't overchill. If you like real Champagne, you'll like this pink fizz.

wine.name: Pehu Simonet, Blanc de Blancs Brut
wine.review: The Chardonnay for this Champagne comes mostly from the village of Mesnil. The aromas are driven by apple fruit with pepper and tarragon adding a bit of intrigue. This is a bright, dry wine that's full of complex mineral touches.

wine.name: Avignon, Kaesler
wine.review: This savory red wine is medium-bodied by Australian standards. It spends 12 months in older oak, with the Grenache contributing soft fruit aromas, the Shiraz adding peppery spice, and the Mourvèdre giving a nice edge to the tannins.

wine.name: Riesling Reserva, Boxler
wine.review: Jean Boxler is, without a doubt, one of the most talented winemakers in Alsace. This Riesling is full of finesse, showing delicate floral fruit and stony minerality.

wine.name: Tokay Pinot Gris "Brand", Boxler
wine.review: For some odd reason, Pinot Gris is referred to as "Tokay Pinot Gris" in Alsace - much to the distress of Hungarians, who cherish an entirely different type of "Tokaji" wine. This dry white comes from the Brand vineyard site, a Grand Cru. It's quite rich, with aromas of red currants, spice, and peaches.

wine.name: Gewurztraminer "Brand", Boxler
wine.review: Leave it to the Alsatians when it comes to being masters of the Gewurztraminer grape. This highly aromatic variety is prized for its aromas of spice and lychee fruits. This is floral, dry and incredibly concentrated and age-worthy.

wine.name: Volnay, Armand
wine.review: This Pinot Noir comes from a tiny plot of vines that are planted on clay and limestone soil. The fruit is high-toned and red berry-driven with velvety-mineral tannins on the finish. If you've never tasted the Burgundies of Comte Armand, this is a great one to start with.

wine.name: Serras de Azeitão, Vinho Regional Terras do Sado
wine.review: This beautiful dry white wine is driven by floral fruits and spicy pear flavors. Unoaked and lightly mineral-driven on the finish, this is a fine choice if you're having seafood tonight. Made in the Terras do Sado region, just south of Lisbon in southern Portugal, this is a blend of indigenous white grapes and a little bit of Chardonnay.

wine.name: Santa Fé de Arraiolos, Vinho Regional Alentejano
wine.review: An excellent red if you're looking for something dark, rich, and dripping with black fruit flavors. This is a fresh and lightly tannic wine, and it shines with a huge range of meat-based cuisines.

wine.name: Mâcon-Chaintré Vieilles Vignes, Dom. Valette
wine.review: This comes from one of the many Mâcon villages in the south of Burgundy. Full of smoky, apple-driven fruit. Great texture and elegance on the palate. Give this Chardonnay a decanting to help enhance the yellow fruits.

wine.name: Beaujolais Blanc, Ch. du Chatelard
wine.review: No, your eyes aren't deceiving you: this is indeed a white Beaujolais. Chardonnay is by far in the minority when it comes to wine production in this region. This one is unoaked, ripe, and pleasantly round in texture. It has also gained incredible concentration from the impressive age of the vines. Give it a try tonight!

wine.name: "Les Mortiers" Coteaux-du-Loir Rouge, Le Briseau
wine.review: Made from the peppery Pinot d'Aunis grape variety, a red grape that thrives in the cool climate of the Coteaux du Loir. This dry red wine is packed with white and black pepper on the palate. The fruit is a bit wild and gamey, with intense flavors of wild red berry to match.

wine.name: Amayna, Sauvignon Blanc, Leyda Valley
wine.review: Leyda, a sub-region of San Antonio, is located in a valley between the Coastal Mountain Range and the Pacific Ocean, running parallel to Chile's Central Valley. This wine has lots of tropical fruit, dominated by white pineapple and white flowers. A dry, distinctively New World Sauvignon Blanc.

wine.name: Viña Alicia Petit Verdot "Cuarzo", Lujan de Cuyo
wine.review: Petit Verdot is one of those little-known grape varieties that originated in the Bordeaux region of France and made its way to the brilliant winemakers of South America, where it flourished. This exemplary bottling is rich, full-bodied, and spicy, with red currants and cherries on the palate.

wine.name: Amayna, Pinot Noir
wine.review: Pinot Noir in Chile has come a long way since it was first planted there, and we were extremely impressed with the Amayna bottling. Taste this wine blind and there can be no doubt that this is pure, delicious Pinot Noir (albeit a bit heftier in style than most). It's full of wild raspberries, dark cherries, and spice.

wine.name: Laurent-Perrier Brut
wine.review: Chardonnay, is the dominant grape variety and its proportion is unusually high for a non-vintage champagne blend, being double the average.

wine.name: "Neyen" Espiritu de Apalta, Colchagua
wine.review: Neyen means "spirit" in the native Mapudungun language. The Neyen vineyard was the first in Apalta (Colchagua valley); these Carmenère and Cabernet Sauvignon vines were planted in 1890. This red wine is a full-bodied and full of cassis and blackberry spiced fruit.

wine.name: De Lancellotti, Pinot Noir
wine.review: De Lancellotti Family Vineyards Pinot Noir is produced from estate-grown fruit from their 15-acre vineyard, nestled on top of a hill with exquisite exposure in the Chehalem Mountain AVA.

wine.name: Centennial, Reserve Pinot Noir
wine.review: There are few areas where Pinot Noir should be grown in Australia. One of the great climate ranges is in New South Wales. This has assertive fruits - raspberries and cherries and warm spices.

wine.name: Syan Reserve Shiraz
wine.review: Syan Reserve Shiraz

wine.name: Beaune 1er Cru "Cent Vignes", Jadot
wine.review: This wine from Louis Jadot is just starting to show secondary characteristics of blackberry and raspberry, with underlying earth notes.

wine.name: Zweigelt Classic, Iby
wine.review: Anton Iby only makes red wines. His Zweigelt Classic, made in Austria's Burgenland region, shows gorgeous red cherry fruit and soft tannins. As the name points out, this is a very traditional example of a great Zweigelt.

wine.name: Morey-St.-Denis Premier Cru "Les Loups", Dom. des Lambrays
wine.review: This cuvée, "Les Loups", is declassified "Clos des Lambrays" - the coveted Grand Cru of the Lambrays estate. It's declassified because the age of the vines is only from a replanted parcel from the 1980s. We'll toast to these "young" vines anytime!

wine.name: Charmes de Kirwan, Margaux
wine.review: This is Kirwan's second label, and it's just as appetizing as the first! You can't ask for a more generous palate than this, and it's no surprise that this Margaux comes from a formidable vintage like 2005. The fruit is berry-driven, the tannins assertive but accessible, and the spices from the oak aging just right.

wine.name: Barbaresco, De Forville
wine.review: The De Forville family emigrated to Piedmont from Belgium in 1848 and established themselves in the village of Barbaresco in 1860. This wine is very accessible, full of red berries (currants and cherries) and leathery tannins on the finish. It's packed with fruit and drinking extremely well today.

wine.name: Volnay "Les Grands Poisots", L. Boillot
wine.review: Louis Boillot is so much more than just the eager husband of truly A-list Chambolle producer, Ghislaine Bathod. His wines, though very different than Barthod's are beautifullly expressive of their terroir. The Volnay is dark, black-fruited, and peppery.

wine.name: Priorato, Clos de l'Obac
wine.review: Clos de L'Obac is produced from Grenache, Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah, Merlot, and Cariñena that is grown in the Llicorella (slate) of the steep hillsides of Priorat. This is an intense wine, showing black fruit, anise, and big tannins on the finish.

wine.name: Cabernet Franc, Monte de Luz
wine.review: We were nicely surprised by this Cabernet Franc. It's packed with dark ripe fruits. The tannins are accessible and give this everyday red wine an extra layer of complexity. Great with a burger.

wine.name: Zöld Veltelini, Craftsman
wine.review: Zöld Veltelini is Hungarian for Grüner Veltliner - the white grape usually associated with Austria. Full of yellow plums, yellow apples, and refreshing acidity, this multifaceted wine turns citrus-driven and dry on the finish.

wine.name: Pinot Blanc, Mittnacht
wine.review: Pale peach and pear flavors play against a hint of minerality on this white wine from Alsace. It finishes long, with a gentle kiss of sweetness. Biodynamic.

wine.name: Crozes-Hermitage, "La Guiraude", Graillot
wine.review: Coming from Alain Graillot, the Guiraude is a barrel selection from the 20 hectare plot in the Croze-Hermitage. Dark, brambly fruit, lively tannins, and black pepper finish. This is Croze-Hermitage at its best!

wine.name: Sky Vineyards Syrah, Mt. Veeder
wine.review: Sky Vineyards Syrah comes from organic, dry-farmed vineyards sitting on top of Mt. Veeder. Showing notes of blueberries and spice, with an amazing underlying minerality, this Syrah is very approachable and friendly.

wine.name: Whetstone Viognier, Catie's Corner
wine.review: This is organically farmed Viognier from the Russian River Valley that is aged in neutral French oak. With a creamy mouth feel and lively, fresh acidity, this is a perfect food wine. Flavors of stone fruit burst on the palate.

wine.name: Kurykta "Anton", Katunar
wine.review: From the Adriatic island of Krk comes this light/medium-bodied red that has intriguing aromas of balsamic and black, freshly picked cherries. A blend of Sansigot, Debejan and Syrah, it’s dry and easy drinking with the ripe fruit and soft tannins.

wine.name: "Les Trois Petits C" VdP Val de Cesse, Le Loup Blanc
wine.review: A wild blend of Tempranillo, Alicante, and Grenache that's aged in barrel for nearly two years before bottling. This comes from the Minervois of southern France, but since the atypical Tempranillo grape variety is in the blend, they cannot technically call it a Minervois. Instead, they've chosen "Trois Petits C," or the three little pigs. From a Practicing Organic winemaker.

wine.name: Ockfener Bockstein Riesling Kabinett, St. Urbans-hof
wine.review: Upon release this wine is truly showing incredible richness. The fruit is citrus driven with stone fruits. The acidity and mineral tang give this delicious Riesling incredible balance. It's off-dry (meaning not bone dry) on the palate and truly a mouthwatering white wine.

wine.name: Alate Cosecha Tempranillo kosher
wine.review: Flavors of tart cherry, light earth, and tobacco make this Tempranillo a great match with juicy poultry dishes.

wine.name: Côtes-du-Rhône Kosher, Louis Blanc
wine.review: A blend of Grenache, Syrah and Cinsault. The fruit is bright and full of powder and moderate tannins on the palate. Medium-bodied and drinking well today. Mevushal.

wine.name: Brachetto d'Acqui "Rebecca", Nuova Abbazia di Vallechiara
wine.review: A dessert wine that's just slightly sweet on the palate. The color is a show-stopping, luminescent cherry red. The fruit is all raspberries and mixed wild berries, and it finishes with a mineral edge. A bit of light carbonation only adds to this wine's appeal.

wine.name: Ch. Lafon-Rochet, St. Estèphe
wine.review: Since 1990, this estate's wines have benefited from improved viniculture techniques, such as destemming, and the addition of a higher proportion of Merlot to soften and round out the wine. You will find a little leather & tar on the nose, cassis and red currants on the palate and a touch of mint lingering on the finish.

wine.name: Ch. Giscours, Margaux
wine.review: Full of fine red fruits and firm, nut-like tannins. Quite youthful on the palate but certainly an ager and a Bordeaux that will age wonderfully.

wine.name: Katlav Wadi Katlav Blend
wine.review: A traditional left bank Bordeaux blend. Excellent complexity, deep and rich ripe fruit that transcends into a long velvety finish.

wine.name: Amarone "Punta di Villa", R. Mazzi
wine.review: Valpolicella, Italy

wine.name: Amarone "Montezovo", Zanoni
wine.review: A bright Amarone that's medium-bodied in style and much more accessible that the robust, brawny versions of the wine. Dark berries, spice with tannins that are very accessible in their youth.

wine.name: Auxey-Duresses Blanc "la Val" 1er Cru, Nerthus
wine.review: The village of Auxey-Duresses is relatively unknown and that's to all of our benefits! It's a source of great value in terms of Burgundy and shouldn't be overlooked.

wine.name: Bourgogne Chardonnay, Nerthus
wine.review: Not all Bourgogne Chardonnays are alike and we're forever grateful. This is a relatively new endeavor that's true to Burgundy in so many ways. Full of ripe honey, floral fruit and lithe minerals on the palate. A great wine to have with any seafood.

wine.name: Blanc de Morgex et de la Salle, Pavese
wine.review: A dry white wine from the highest vineyard site in Europe: Blanc de Morgex et de la Salle, which is just beneath Mont Blanc. The winemaker is Ermes Pavese, a youthful grower in the commune of La Ruine just outside of the town of Morgex, 1200 meters above sea level. This is made from the native grape, Prié Blanc. Subtle and elegant with persistent minerals.

wine.name: Gevrey-Chambertin 1er Cru "Cherbaudes", Fourrier
wine.review: Since taking the reins in 1994, Jean-Marie Fourrier has re-energized the Fourrier estate. The Cherbaudes vines are old, adding a meaty complexity that's well worth aging.

wine.name: La Posta Malbec, Pizzella Vineyard
wine.review: Don't be concerned if you find yourself inhaling deeply from your glass, over and over—it is just your nose's way of telling you that it wants its fair share! This is a medium-bodied and well-structured wine that is incredibly full of life and born to be enjoyed with food and friends.

wine.name: Sparkling Rosé of Malbec "CJR", Reginato Celestina
wine.review: If you're one of the many who are hooked on Terra Sparkling Malbec, maybe you'd like to try a rosé version of this Argentine specialty. This sparkling Malbec rosé is a rich cherry color and shows amazing cherry fruit. It's nice and bubbly with a bright, pretty, dry finish.

wine.name: Dolcetto d'Alba "Roussot", Rinaldi
wine.review: This dry red wine comes from the Roussot vineyard plot, and is full of really dark-berried fruits. A brilliant Dolcetto with a sophisticated earthy element and incredible minerality on the finish.

wine.name: Vinho Tinto Douro, Lavradores de Feitoria
wine.review: This red wine comes from a collection of growers dedicated to making some fantastic dry red wines in the Douro Valley. This is plush with fruit, dark berries and all-around approachability. A red wine to pair with any rich meal, whether it be burgers or a roast.

wine.name: Merlot, Radikon
wine.review: Stanko Radikon is a maverick in a land of mavericks. The town of Oslavia, on a relatively tiny stretch of hills north of the border town of Gorizia in the Isonzo zone of Friuli, is home to a number of talented and individualistic winemakers.

wine.name: Chambolle-Musigny "Le Village", Bertagna
wine.review: The wines of Chambolle are noted for their velverty texture and feminine elegance; Bertagna's is no exception. A year and a half of oak aging provides structure and the potential to age.

wine.name: Nuits-St.-Georges 1er Cru "les Murgers", Bertagna
wine.review: Employing 30% new oak, Bertagna straddles the fence between traditional and modern Burgundian viticulture. "Murgers" is reminiscent of small, red fruits with hints of minty oak that will mellow over time.

wine.name: Corton "Les Grandes Lolières" Grand Cru, Bertagna
wine.review: Spiciness accompanies redcurrant notes in this Grand Cru from Bertagna. The wine stays in mostly new French oak for 18 months, giving it structure and power. We suggest eight to ten years in the cellar, which is to say that it will take time for the new oak that permeates the wine in its youth to harmonize with rather than over whelm the wine's other flavors.

wine.name: Sylvaner "Kofererhof", Valle Isarco
wine.review: The Sylvaner grape is a little-known white variety that thrives in Alto-Adige of northern Italy. This wine is both fermented and aged in stainless steel. The nose is fruity with white flowers and yellow fruits. A frresh, dry, nicely structured wine.

wine.name: Riesling "Loibenberg" Smaragd, Alzinger
wine.review: Alzinger is one of the top producers in the Wachau, making pure and focused Rieslings. The Loibenberg bottling is packed with mineral, with notes of honeysuckle that evoke the first days of spring.

wine.name: Ribeira Sacra "Lacima", Dominio do Bibei
wine.review: Winemaker Sarah Pérez has created this remarkable red wine from steep slopes of old Mencía vines. Slate and clay soils give a strong mineral backbone to this well-balanced wine packed with red fruit and coffee bean notes.

wine.name: Pinot Grigio, Erste & Neue
wine.review: There's nothing like a crisp, dry Pinot Grigio to quench your thirst. This white is full of lovely floral aromas and citrus fruits, and it's easy to enjoy before, during and after a meal.

wine.name: Pommard "Noizons", Jean Garaudet
wine.review: Vines here, which range in age from 20 to 80 years, grow in terraced vineyards at 250 meters above sea level, and the soil is an iron-rich clayey chalk. This red shows superb concentration, combined with great elegance for the appellation.

wine.name: Châteauneuf du Pape Blanc, Dom. De Nalys
wine.review: White Châteauneuf is extremely rare, and rich yet balanced examples such as this one are even rarer. Full of peach and white flower with a pleasing viscosity that is the result of partial barrel fermentation.

wine.name: Saint-Romain Blanc, François d'Allaines
wine.review: There's nothing more fulfilling than finding a wine from Burgundy that's under the radar. This is a fantastic Chardonnay that shows clean smoky, white floral fruit, flinty minerals, and a citrus element on the finish. A fine partner with branzino, trout, or any number of other fresh fish dishes.

wine.name: Thimiopoulos "Uranos" Xinomavro, Naoussa
wine.review: Some say Xynomavro is the father of the Pinot Noir grape; others say it's related to Nebbiolo. What is for certain is that this Greek indigenous grape excels in the northern reaches of Macedonia. This example is spicy and crystalline, with black cherry notes. Delicious!

wine.name: Maremma Rosso "Querciola", Massa Vecchia
wine.review: Wines from the Massa Vecchia estate are unique and come from a tiny Tuscan estate that still plows their land with oxen. A red, earthy blend made from Alicante & Sangiovese. Decant, enjoy, repeat.

wine.name: Ch. Larrivaux, Haut-Médoc
wine.review: This vintage is filled with great quality wines and a wine like this offers greater value. More approachable too on the palate since it's based on the Merlot grape.

wine.name: Brunello di Montalcino, Mastrojanni
wine.review: The Mastrojanni estate is one of the top producers of Montalcino. Their focus is traditional and they've done an especially great job with this idiosyncratic vintage. Clearly more structured than typical. A full-bodied red wine with mixed dark fruits. Decant to enjoy today or drink several years down the road.

wine.name: Snoqualmie Syrah
wine.review: The Rhône Valley has clearly been a major source of inspiration for American winemakers recently. Syrah was first planted in Washington in the 1970s. This bottle is smoky with earthy aromas of leather and dark berries. Aged in oak (25% new) for less than a year.

wine.name: Bodega NQN, Malma Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Cabernet Sauvignon, like all the great grapes of Bordeaux, has been adopted by Argentinian winemakers, who are producing terrific, accessible, modern wines with it. The "Malma" bottling is no exception; big cassis fruit and eucalyptus are the show-stealers here.

wine.name: Don Nicanor, Malbec
wine.review: Malbec grown in Argentina always lends itself well to meat - especially grilled meats as they would enjoy in Argentina. This is a full-bodied red wine that's full of dark berried fruits and spices. Also works well with tangy, hard cheeses.

wine.name: Crémant de Bourgogne Blanc de Blancs, Parigot
wine.review: A Blanc de Blancs sparkling white wine made from the Burgundy white grapes: Chardonnay and Aligoté. The Chardonnay adds fruit and body, the Aligoté crisp acidity. This is quite a sparkler, dry and full of mineral-laced fruit.

wine.name: Godmé, Grand Cru Brut
wine.review: Godme Père et Fils is a small Champagne Grower Producer. They're located in the Montagne de Reims region and are one of the few family-owned and operated wineries. This is full of so many minerals you can nearly crunch on them! Concentrated and a real treat anytime.

wine.name: Miolo Pinot Noir, Reserva
wine.review: This Pinot Noir comes from the Vale Dos Vinhedos vineyards in the Rio Grande Del Sul. Lovely red berry notes on the nose, with earthy, toasted notes on the palate and a great long finish.

wine.name: St. Nicholas Commandaria, Etko
wine.review: This traditional dessert wine is made from dried grapes on the island of Cyrpus. Notes of caramel, mocha, and candied fruit waft from the glass. Commandaria is said to be one of the oldest wines still in production.

wine.name: Thierry Massin "Selection" Brut
wine.review: Thierry Massin is located in the Côtes de Bar, the new and upcoming growing region in the southern part of the region of Champagne. The limestone soils are perfect for Pinot Noir. This is an incredibly likable, mildly earthy wine that's full of ripe strawberries.

wine.name: Bourgogne Rouge, Dom. Jerome Chézeaux
wine.review: A vibrant Pinot Noir with notes of game, wild berry and fresh acidity. The tannic structure is surprising adding some solid weight to this great red wine.

wine.name: Craggy Range "Sophia" Gimblett Gravels
wine.review: Very Bordelais in style, with an additional dose of dark berried fruits on the palate. Elegant yet full-bodied and certainly a wine you can cellar for years.

wine.name: Cono Sur Pinot Noir, Vision
wine.review: We're always pleased to taste a Pinot Noir like this one from Cono: bright, fruity, and varietally correct in so many ways. Aromas of raspberries and cherries dominate the palate. The abundant fruit makes this as clear an expression of New World Pinot Noir as anything on our shelves.

wine.name: Chablis "Vaudesir" Grand Cru, Billaud-Simon
wine.review: If you haven't had Grand Cru Chablis, you're in for a treat. This is quite magical, pure, floral, mineral-driven and really young to tell you the truth. Decant and enjoy today or see how this Vaudesir can age for decades.

wine.name: Bello Family Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: A special project from David Abreu, this Cabernet is rich and sultry. Cassis, dark chocolate, and earthy, toasted caramel notes burst from this glass. This wine can be held for 10 -15 years, or decant and enjoy today.

wine.name: Solms "Amalie", Wijn de Caab
wine.review: A dry white blend of Viognier and Grenache Blanc. Fermented and aged for 6 months in French oak, this wine has developed rich, round fruit, with a good dose of yellow plums and fresh vanilla bean.

wine.name: Weilberg Riesling, Grosses Gewächs, Pfeffingen
wine.review: A dry yet very well-balanced Riesling with great aromas of ripe pink grapefruit and white flowers. Drink with just a light chill and enjoy alongside seafood. "Grosses Gewächs" is a certification for the absolute best vineyards sites in Germany.

wine.name: Pinot Blanc "Kalkgestein", Becker
wine.review: A Pinot Blanc that gives a good amount of red fruit character - especially pomegranite. Off-dry to dry with great texture and elegance on the palate.

wine.name: Heidsieck Monopole Rose
wine.review: This Champagne is clear and bright, the nose displays notes of red berry and wild strawberry. Vivacious and deliciously fruity on the palate.

wine.name: Green Lion Merlot, Napa Valley
wine.review: The Green Lion is Chris Ringland's new California project. Known for making award-winning wines in Australia, he's now decided to try his luck in California: so far, the results are quite promising. This Merlot packs a punch of perfectly ripe fruit and brambly spice.

wine.name: Hudson Vineyards Syrah
wine.review: This is the second vintage from Hudson Vineyards, collaboration between winemaker John Kongsgaard and vineyard owner, Lee Hudson. Miniscule amounts of this big, brawny Syrah are made.

wine.name: Hawkes Chardonnay
wine.review: This is a single-vineyard, unoaked Chardonnay from the Chalk Hill district. This rich white wine is left on the lees to develop a rich, concentrated mouthfeel. Delicious!

wine.name: Kenneth Volk Malvasia
wine.review: This Malvasia comes from Monterey. Because of its rarity, Kenneth Volk considers this one of his heirloom varieties. The wine shows great acidity, with bright floral notes along with hints of citrus and melon. Delicious!

wine.name: Ch. de Francs "Les Cerisiers", Côtes de Francs
wine.review: Perfumed and succulent with lovely berry and raspberry character. A medium-bodied wine with fine tannins and a sleek finish.

wine.name: Elizabeth Spencer Cab Sauvignon Special Cuvée
wine.review: Napa Valley Cabernet Sauvignon is a treat any time of year. This is incredibly generous in black currant and cherry fruits. Drinking well today.

wine.name: Ch. Rocher-Lideyre, Côtes de Castillon
wine.review: This estate restricts yields to make its delicious Merlot based Bordeaux as concentrated as possible. The wine is aged for a year before release adding spice notes to a red-berried frame. The tannins are silky but definitely present. A wine that can be drunk young or aged for a couple of years.

wine.name: Tishbi Sauvignon Blanc, Kosher
wine.review: This crisp dry white wine is made entirely from Sauvignon Blanc grapes grown in Zichron Yaakov and Kfar Tavor. It's rich in herbal aromas and fruity flavors.

wine.name: Muscat Sec, Dom de Blanes
wine.review: If you're into aromatic wines that are still dry, you've found your match. This is reminscent of lychees and white peppercorns. Delicious with a light chill with herbed branzino. Hand-harvesting is religiously enforced in the case of this estate's Muscat vines in order to attain maximum aromatics.

wine.name: Mapema, Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: Another fantastic easy-drinking white from Argentina, this Sauvignon Blanc is dry, fresh, floral, and free of any oak influence.

wine.name: Viña Cubillo Rioja, Lopez de Heredia
wine.review: Cubillo is Lopez’s answer to Rioja Crianza. Following the style of all their wines, this wine could be labeled a class above - as a Reserva - but they keep it a Crianza. It compares to most other Rioja wineries’ Reservas since the wine is aged for three years in oak, followed by another two to three years in bottle. The resulting wine is fruit-forward but with very developed, older-wine aromas of cherries and spices.

wine.name: Arneis, Correggia
wine.review: Arneis is frequently marked by its subtly expressive perfume, and this one is no exception. Arneis may be viewed as the Langhe's answer to Chardonnay, although the best are unoaked (this bottle, for example). Enjoy the vibrant orchard aromas of this well-made white wine.

wine.name: Barolo "Brunate" Vecchie Vigne, Marengo
wine.review: Marco Marengo is privileged to own parcels in the Brunate vineyard, one of the most highly touted in Barolo. He is a modernist who makes wines that are approachable young with lots of forward, dark cherry fruit and spicey oak. However, this incredibly concentrated old vine bottling should age elegantly over the next two decades. Marego is thought to be one of the top producers in La Morra.

wine.name: Mauro Red "Vendimia Seleccionada", Tudela de Duero
wine.review: A good amount of spice is apparent from the oak aging of this wine. Add to that the cassis, tobacco, blackberries and meat and you'll get an idea of what kind of rich, ruby-red wine this is.

wine.name: Pommard, Michel Gaunoux
wine.review: The Burgundy of the Michel Gaunoux estate are wines for the cellar. This bottle is a baby and just beginning its journey. If you drink today, decant for a good hour and eat with rack of lamb.

wine.name: Prosecco "Cuvée", Villa Sandi
wine.review: This "Cuvée" Prosecco is one of Villa Sandi's top bubblies. It's fruit-driven, not totally dry and just the type of sparkling wine that you could serve with any salty hors d'oeuvres.

wine.name: Barbera d'Asti "Quorum", Hastae
wine.review: The village of Asti has many winemakers behind this project and their sole mission is to raise funds to help preserve the culture of Asti whether it be a viticultural tradition or culinary. This is a full-bodied red, spicy with chocolate, dark cherries and leather. Cellar for years.

wine.name: Alfred Gratien Brut
wine.review: Champagnes from Alfred Gratien have a lengthy tradition and, disregarding the mass-produced ethos and fashions of modern times, still remain true to that tradition today. This vintage bottling is showing incredibly well and proves that great Champagnes are made for the cellar.

wine.name: Sancerre "Cuvée Edmond", Alphonse Mellot
wine.review: One of the top producers in the Loire Valley today. He makes wines that are profound and aged in large (old) wood barrels to oxygenate the juice. This is a controversial aspect to say the least. Especially to practice this with a Sauvignon Blanc. The outcome is remarkable.

wine.name: Fixin "Les Crais de Chêne", Dom. Collotte
wine.review: The village of Fixin is located in the Côte de Nuits. This Pinot Noir is accessible and showing plenty of appealing, youthful red-berried fruit character.

wine.name: Beaujolais-Villages VV, Ch. du Chatelard
wine.review: This old-vine Beaujolais shows bright red fruit with underlying notes of clay and limestone minerality. Flavors of wild blackberries and currants abound, with a hint of earth just beneath the surface. Bright, lively acidity makes this an excellent food wine.

wine.name: Crémant de Jura, Dom. de Montbourgeau
wine.review: Here is a delicious sparkler from the lovely (and ever sheltered from the dangers of spoofy modern winemaking) Jura mountains. From a top producer in Étoile, the wine ressembles a Champagne in that it is yeasty and full of mineral flavors and lip-smacking acidity.

wine.name: Mimus Pinot Noir, Dr. Heger
wine.review: from Germany

wine.name: Nahe Riesling "Monziger Halenberg" Spätlese, Schäfer-Fröhlich
wine.review: A plump Riesling with great balance and yellow stone fruit aromas: yellow plums, yellow peaches, and a touch of Meyer lemon. Finishes more off-dry than bone-dry. Drink chilled.

wine.name: Nuits-St.-Georges "Boudots", Jean Grivot
wine.review: There's nothing like great Pinot Noir from such a flattering vintage as 2006. This bottle is coming around nicely showing spice, mineral and red cherries. The texture is superb.

wine.name: Vosne-Romanée "Les Rouges" 1er Cru, Jean Grivot
wine.review: The Grivot family originally came from the Jura region in the north-east of France. They came to Burgundy at the end of the 18th century. Their approach to winemaking tends to prefer practices that show terroir. This wine is young still and will definitely evolve beautifully for years to come.

wine.name: Mazi-Chambertin "Cuvée A", Dominique Laurent
wine.review: A former pastry chef who turned to winemaking in the late 1980s. She always looks for concentration of fruit and bottles all wines without filtering - a common practice in Burgundy.

wine.name: Paumanok Vineyards "Tutthuls Lane" Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: A full-bodied, structured red wine that's full of cassis, blackberries, and spice. The type of wine to open up when you're having a great steak.

wine.name: Paumanok, Chenin Blanc
wine.review: A fresh, dry, unoaked Chenin Blanc that shows grapefruit, pineapple, melon, apple and guava. It makes an excellent companion to various white meat fish dishes, and especially shellfish.

wine.name: Morey-St.-Denis 1er Cru "Les Chaffots", Hubert Lignier
wine.review: This wine is young but is showing some lovely aromas. Rich in plums, cinnamon stick, spicy cherries and mineral. Just brilliant and a wine for those passionate about real Burgundy.

wine.name: Côte-Rôtie "Les Journaries", Levet
wine.review: The Journaries cuvée is made from grapes harvested in large part from the vineyard of “La Landonne”. The tannins are slightly more relaxed, the fruit somewhat more tame.

wine.name: Arbois Rouge Trousseau "Les Berangères", Puffeney
wine.review: Something special from the Arbois. Trousseau is unique to this area, and a source of great pride. The wine is deep and translucent in color, finely structured with complex aromas and flavors of berries and game.

wine.name: Arbois Rouge Poulsard, Puffeney
wine.review: Poulsard is a little-known red grape variety grown in the eastern part of France. Sometimes it's also referred to as "Ploussard." It resembles a Pinot Noir but is a touch more rustic on the palate.

wine.name: Channing Daughters, Pinot Grigio
wine.review: This is made mostly from Pinot Grigio, with a dose of Chardonnay for added body. It's a great white wine from Long Island, and it's a great argument for shopping locally.

wine.name: Channing Daughters, "Envelope"
wine.review: This white wine was fermented as though it were a red wine. Why do this? Why not? The result is an exotic, dry wine with a good dose of yellow color and spicy, aromatic fruits.

wine.name: The Grapes of Roth Merlot
wine.review: A full-bodied, rich, structured wine that's all about upfront fruit and bold structure.

wine.name: Shaw and Smith, "M3" Vineyard Chardonnay
wine.review: Shaw and Smith's overarching goal is to prove that Australia can grow grapes that are typically grown in cooler climates. This Chardonnay is impressive in every sense. Full of white floral fruits, it is reminiscent of a southern French white Burgundy, made with hand-picked fruit aged in neutral French oak.

wine.name: Priorat "Lo Givot", Celler del Pont
wine.review: With only 5 hectares, the Celler del Pont creates wine that is full of fruit yet maintains a complexity. They believe in low yields to obtain maximum concentration. This is a Priorat that can be enjoyed now, yet can age for many years to come.

wine.name: Billecart-Salmon "Nicolas François" Brut
wine.review: This half bottle is liquid gold to us. The concentration is superb and the extra years of bottle age have had a remarkable effect on this Champagne.

wine.name: Ch. de Seuil Blanc, Graves
wine.review: White wines from Graves are a treat year round. This one is based on Sémillon and Sauvignon Blanc, and is full of bright, refreshing white fruits on the palate.

wine.name: Pinot, "Cépage Pinot Noir" Blanc, Jean Pierre Dirler
wine.review: This is an extremely rare find: a white wine made from Pinot Noir grapes. By immediately separating the grape skins from the juice after crushing, Dirler prevents the finished wine from being imbued with the full red color of the skins. The result is this very dry, faintly copper-tinged wine, which has an earthy nose and a near-saline minerality that emerges with a bit of exposure to air. This bottle is an uncommon treat that is well worth seeking out.

wine.name: Corton "Perrières", Dubreuil Fontaine
wine.review: A Grand Cru Pinot Noir from a phenomenol vintage that belongs in the cellar. The fruit is red - full of raspberries and cherries, spicy minerals and a solid structure. A traditional estate that expresses full the terroir of the area.

wine.name: Bourgogne Pinot Noir, Joseph Voillot
wine.review: Joseph Voillot is well-known for his Pommard and Volnay wines however, this Pinot Noir is not to be missed. Full of raspberries, wild cherries and red peppercorns. Always an impressive Burgundy at the dinner table.

wine.name: Volnay "Vieilles Vignes", Joseph Voillot
wine.review: This fifth generation estate with property in Beaune and Pommard is rigorous when it comes to keeping yields low, hand harvesting, and sorting before the press. The estate is tradtional in that oak use is kept to a maximum of 30%. Each wine is a brilliant refection of vintage and terroir.

wine.name: Pommard "Vieilles Vignes", Joseph Voillot
wine.review: The iron-rich soils of Pommard give this Pinot Noir its gamey, earthy notes. Jean-Pierre Charlot, the current winemaker at this 5th generation estate is adamant about keeping use of new oak to under 30% with the result that the wines are extremely elegant. Age for the next up to five years for best results.

wine.name: Pernand-Vergelesses "Les Vergelesses" 1er Cru, Chandon de Briailles
wine.review: These wines are understated, particularly this 1er cru from the "Vergelesses" vineyard. Judicious oak use results in a pure cherry-ish red fruit character. There is a ripe suppleness to the palate that seems to transcend the problematic north and west facing slopes of Pernand-Vergelesses.

wine.name: Pernand-Vergelesses "Île des Vergelesses" Rouge, Chandon de Briaille
wine.review: The vine site, Îles des Vergelesses, has Premier Cru status. Winemaker, Claude de Nicolay, chooses to press the grapes with the stems on all wines above village status. This gives the depth and structure necessary for aging. This bottle can age a good 5-10 years, perhaps much longer.

wine.name: Volnay "Caillerets" 1er Cru, Chandon de Briailles
wine.review: Blackberry, cassis, violet, as well as a certain dustiness to the nose and palate make this a brooding and mysterious offering from Chandon de Briailles. Much richness and volume is contained here that will only develop elegantly over time.

wine.name: Corton "Maréchaudes" Grand Cru, Chandon de Briailles
wine.review: The Grand Crus of Corton are known to be closed in their youth but rewarding after a stint in the cellar. Extended macertion to extract tannins gives the wine superb structure. Ripeness and spice on the nose yield to a mouthful of practically sweet, dark fruit.

wine.name: Pernand "Île des Vergelesses" 1er Cru Blanc, Briaille
wine.review: Here is a discreet Chardonnay that shows an abundance of green apple fruit and white flowers from an estate that proves sometimes less is more through its light-handed use of new oak and understated style of winemaking.

wine.name: Oeil de Perdrix, Ch. d' Auvernier
wine.review: "Oeil de Perdrix" translates to "eye of the partridge" and is named after color of this rosé wine. This is a dry Pinot Noir vinified as a rosé. The fruit aromas are full of strawberries and yellow cherries. It's a subtle wine, dry with limestone-driven minerals and a supple texture.

wine.name: Pinot Gris, Ch. d'Auvernier
wine.review: This Pinot Gris comes from the Neuchâtel area of Switzerland. It's harvested a bit later than usual but still is in the direction of dry to off-dry on the palate. Exquisite, full of honey and white floral aromas.

wine.name: Dôle des Monts, Robert Gilliard
wine.review: Dôle is one of the few types of red wines coming out of Switzerland. This is mostly Pinot Noir and the rest Gamay. Full of game, iron-rich minerals and dark cherries on the palate. This would be a fantastic wine to drink alongside a roasted duck dish.

wine.name: Sassicaia
wine.review: Sassicaia is and always will be the first "Super Tuscan" to hit the market. Today, it lives up to its excellent reputation.

wine.name: Cornas "Cuvée des Coteaux", Michel
wine.review: Cornas is a sub-region of the northern Rhône Valley that can rival even the best appellations of this area. This is a complex, full-bodied, spicy red wine that's boasting currants, smoke, roasted nuts and strawberries. Graceful yet charmingly rustic.

wine.name: Mazi-Chambertin Grand Cru, Harmand-Geoffroy
wine.review: The most prestigious wine of the domaine is this Mazis Chambertin Grand Cru. This stellar Pinot Noir offers complex aromas of leather, game and red fruits. The type of red Burgundy that can be cellared for decades after release.

wine.name: Châteauneuf-du-Pape Blanc "Télégramme"
wine.review: A single vineyard dry, white wine that's incredibly rich with minerals, white flowers, anise and honey. Incredibly rich and coming from 20 year old vines from the Rhône Valley.

wine.name: Arbois Pupillin, Chardonnay "Le Blanc de la Rouge" A&P Bornard
wine.review: A pure, floral Chardonnay that's at once full of mineral, bone-dry, and ultra-concentrated. This comes from the Arbois in France's Jura region, which is located between Burgundy and Switzerland.

wine.name: Arbois Pupillin, Melon, "Le Rouge Queue" A&P Bornard
wine.review: The Melon grape variety is essentially Arboisian Chardonnay - a grape that's been cultivated here for centuries. This is a pure, dry white wine that's incredibly floral (think pollen) with fruit and minerals. The finish is mildly citrus with roasted chestnuts.

wine.name: Arbois Pupillin, Ploussard "la Chamade" A&P Bornard
wine.review: What would life be without tasting Ploussard? This unique red grape variety is peppery, with a touch of blood orange character. The tannins are firm and beg for rich, savory cuisines. Ploussard (a.k.a. Poulsard) is indigenous to the Jura region.

wine.name: Malvasia "Il Mio", Az. Agr. Camillo Donati
wine.review: The white Malvasia grape exists in many guises and hues. This is a more characterful, dry, earthy rendition that happens to be delicious before, during, and after a meal.

wine.name: Anjou Blanc, Mosse
wine.review: The Mosses make brilliant red and white wines. This is a dry, white wine made from the Chenin Blanc grape variety. It's full of texture, honey, apples and floral fruit. Drink with a light chill.

wine.name: Rouge Boire, Mosse
wine.review: A deeply fruity red wine made from old vines of Cabernet Sauvignon and young vines Cabernet Franc. A pretty red wine with ripe, cassis and plum aromas that comes from the Loire Valley of France. Unoaked, structured and ideal with rich, meaty fare.

wine.name: Bourgueil, "Nuits d'Ivresse", Breton
wine.review: An assemblage from his best parcels, this is Pierre's most ambitious wine. Always striving for absolute purity of fruit in this wine. He has achieved a stunning result.

wine.name: Anjou Blanc, "La Lune", Sansonnière
wine.review: Deep, rich, golden fruit with apricots, peaches, a bit of almond and coconut, very densely mineral. A wine of force and power, Bonnezeaux Sec, in fact.

wine.name: Ch. Majoureau "Cuvée Tradition", Bordeaux Superieur
wine.review: A generously fruited Bordeaux with lots of blackcurrant fruit. It's unoaked and made in a more international (meaning fruit-forward) style, to show off the ripe character of the Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon fruit.

wine.name: Dom. Serene "Côte Sud" Chardonnay
wine.review: Côte Sud is one of seven vineyards of Domaine Serene’s Evenstad Estate located atop the southernmost of the Dundee Hills of Oregon. The nose displays complex aromatics reminiscent of ripe citrus, quince, lemon custard, toast, clove, and anise.

wine.name: Biale "Black Chicken" Zinfandel
wine.review: The Biale family, immigrants from Northern Italy, began growing grapes in Napa in the 1930’s – Zinfandel only. This is a spicy, rich Zinfandel with lots of ripe, dark fruits on the palate.

wine.name: Hilberg "Variej", Pasquero
wine.review: An aromatic red wine made from a blend of Brachetto and Barbera. This tastes like freshly macerated raspberries, with a touch of geranium and red currant. Crisp and fresh on the palate, this is a great food wine that marries well with salami and other cured meats.

wine.name: Costières de Nîmes "Marginal", Terre des Chardons
wine.review: A delicious, concentrated red wine that's left unoaked in order to emphasize the character of the grapes. We couldn't be more pleased with the quality of this voluptuous wine. The flavors are very pure, with lots of dark fruits (currants, black cherries, blackberries) and floral spices on the finish. Feel free to decant this for half an hour before drinking.

wine.name: Rosso Conero, Villa Malacari
wine.review: The roots of wine production in Conero (located in the middle of the Marche) date back to the 10th century BC, during the Etruscan period. Compared to that, the Malacari family's 500 years in the region seems rather brief. The family produces wine from their 16 hectares of Montepulciano vineyards in the town of Offagna, known for its sandy and limestone soil. Made from the Montepulciano grape. Unoaked with terrific, fruit concentration.

wine.name: Bourgogne Rouge, Dom. Montanet-Thoden
wine.review: This Pinot Noir shows incredible fruit, but not the big and brawny sort. Delicate dark cherry flavors play off of clay minerals and black-tea tannins. This is the type of Burgundy that you can enjoy immediately or hold for a few years.

wine.name: Unico, Vega Sicilia
wine.review: Tempranillo, which comprises between 65% and 80% of "Unico" has a structure that seems to defy oxidation. Blended with a small portion of Cabernet, this Tempranillo gives intense black fruit and leather aromas. The texture is legendarily supple due to extensive oak aging. (10-25 years!)

wine.name: "Valbuena 5 Año," Vega Sicila
wine.review: "Valbuena" is a Tempranillo and Merlot blend that shows the feminine side of the Vega Sicilia. Somewhere between garnet and cherry in color, "Valbuena" gives red berries on the nose with softness and elegance on the palate. The Barbaresco to "Unico's" Barolo!

wine.name: Vin de Paille, Puffeney
wine.review: Vins de Paille, or "straw wines," take their name from the straw mats on which the grapes were traditionally dried before fermentation. Though most Jura producers have abandoned straw mats for boxes, the wines continue to be unctuously sweet with an impressive capacity to age.

wine.name: Coteaux du Layon, Moulin Touchais
wine.review: This sweet Chenin Blanc from the Loire is truly an exceptional find. Produced without botrytis, the wines of Moulin Touchais are thought to have the acidity necessary for them to be fresh after a hundred years in the cellar, which makes this 1971 practically a young wine!

wine.name: Coteaux du Layon, Moulin Touchais
wine.review: Decadent honeyed sweetness accompanies bright, green apple acidity in this elegantly balanced late-harvest Chenin Blanc. Possessed of compelling richness and texture, the wines of Moulin Touchais are all the more pure for their lack of botrytis.

wine.name: Eiswein, J & H Selbach
wine.review: from Germany

wine.name: Ürziger Würzgarten Riesling Auslese, Christoffel
wine.review: The Würzgarten vineyard is named after a large herb garden planted next to the vineyard, which is thought to impart an herby quality to the wines. Botrytis renders this red slate laden, late-harvest Riesling concentrated and complex with notes of star fruit, ripe peach, and spice.

wine.name: Riesling Sekt Brut, Biffar
wine.review: In climate, the Pfalz is ideally suited to the pruduction of dry wines and increasingly the region has been devoting itself to Sekts: traditional method sparklers. Imagine the lip-smacking acidity of Champagne but heralded by ripe peach and green apple aromas.

wine.name: Quivira Sauvignon Blanc, Fig Tree Vineyard
wine.review: A beautifully aromatic Sauvignon Blanc that shows aromas of grapefruit and key limes. This is a refreshing white wine with a very dry finish.

wine.name: Amarone Classico, Begali Lorenzo
wine.review: Amarone is always rich, some richer than others such as this bottling. Full of dark berries, violets and black tea tannins on the finish. Enjoy today with a good decanting or drink in several years to come.

wine.name: Barolo, Oddero
wine.review: This straight bottling of Oddero Barolo comes from their younger Nebbiolo vines. The fruit is nonetheless incredibly expressive, and surely has enough substance for a long cellaring.

wine.name: Barolo, Rocche di Castiglione, Oddero
wine.review: Despite that the Baroli of the Castiglione sub-region are known for their stern, age-worthiness, the Rocche vineyard with its sandy soils yields softer wines with enticing aromatics. Garnet in color and reminiscent of small red berries and licorice. South eastern expose; thirty months in French Oak Barrels followed by a year of bottle age before release.

wine.name: Barolo "Villero", Oddero
wine.review: Here is a wine for the cellar. Truly. After thirty months of aging in French oak, the wine spends a year aging in bottle before release. Cocoa and violets greet the nose while the palate is balanced and engaging if somewhat stern in its youth. Seriously, the wines of Castiglione are known to be a bit mean in their youth. Cellaring is strongly advised.

wine.name: Barolo, Elio Altare
wine.review: from Italy

wine.name: Pinot Grigio "ViV", Vivallis
wine.review: Northern Italy's Trentino region is a perfect place to make white wines. Its cool climate imparts a brisk freshness to many of the excellent wines produced here. Take this dry Pinot Grigio, for example: with ripe aromas of citrus fruits and lithe minerals, this is an outstanding everyday wine that you can sip before, during, and after a meal.

wine.name: Rosso di Montalcino, Talenti
wine.review: This "baby" Brunello is full of red fruit notes as well as a meaty, leathery quality that it perfect- not for any old pizza- but for the one you craft yourself in the privacy of your own kitchen (especially if you top it with lots of mushrooms, pepperoni, and roasted peppers.)

wine.name: Bourgogne Aligoté, De Moor
wine.review: In normal circumstances, Aligoté can be imagined as a leaner, meaner, more acidic, and less characterful version of Chardonnay. Not in the hands of Alice & Olivier De Moor, whose Aligoté becomes soft and luscious in large neutral oak barrels.

wine.name: Chablis "Rosette" De Moor
wine.review: "Rosette" is the name of the "lieu-dit" (a parcel of land that doesn't quite warrant cru status) that has become this estate's unofficial premier cru. The steepness of the Rosette parcel imparts vibrant acidity to this creamy, apple-fruited Chardonnay.

wine.name: Aloxe-Corton "Vieilles Vignes" Cornu
wine.review: A village wine from 45+ year old vines that is possessed of rosey hues and rustic tannins characteristic of Aloxe-Corton.

wine.name: Corton Grand Cru "Les Bressandes" Cornu
wine.review: Hailing from the only Grand Cru in the Côte de Beaune, this wine has complex and woodsy aromas of black raspberry and tart cherry. Sweet tannins make it approachable as a young wine but cellar for stunning results.

wine.name: Côte-de-Brouilly "Terres Dorées" Jean-Paul Brun
wine.review: Jean-Paul Brun refuses to use laboratory yeasts or add sugar to his wines - two practices that are very common in Beaujolais. His wines turn out light-bodied, juicy, and eminently quaffable: this one is brimming with red fruit.

wine.name: Côtes-Rôtie "La Landonne" Guigal
wine.review: In 1978, Marcel Guigal introduced the first vintage of "La Landonne," a small and propitiously located parcel in the Côte-Brune subregion of Côte-Rôtie. More structured and brooding than Guigal's famed "La Mouline," "La Landonne" is truly a wine for the ages.

wine.name: Côte-Rôtie "La Mouline" Guigal
wine.review: "La Mouline" is a well-situated vineyard site in the Côte-Blonde subregion of Côte-Rôtie, where vignerons were historically accustomed to blending a small portion of Viognier in with their Syrah to produce aromatic and luscious wines.

wine.name: Côte-Rôtie "La Turque" Guigal
wine.review: "La Turque" gives the aromatic beauty of "La Mouline" alongside the power of "La Landonne." Aged for 42 months in small, new oak casks, "La Turque" had astounding cellar potential.

wine.name: Pouilly-Fuissé "Les Ménétrières" Ferret
wine.review: "Les Ménétrières" was the favorite of Colette Ferret's father, who told her as a child that should tough times lie ahead, she could part with the other vineyards - but never with "Ménétrières." The wine is seductively feminine in texture with earthy, pine-y notes and lots of yellow fruit.

wine.name: Brunello di Montalcino, Talenti
wine.review: This estate was founded in the 1980s by Pierluigi Talenti from Emilia Romagna, who had long been in love with Tuscany. Today these 40 hectares produce some of the most traditional and profound wines of the region.

wine.name: Tio Soto Cream Sherry
wine.review: A medium-bodied, sweet style of sherry. This has pronounced caramel and apple flavors and a smooth, easy finish.

wine.name: Tio Soto Amontillado Sherry
wine.review: A finely crafted sherry from a reknown producer. This is dry and full-bodied, with rich, nutty flavors. A great tapas favorite.

wine.name: Tio Soto Fino Sherry
