wine.review: The de Soto family have been crafting traditional sherries for over 300 years and are still family owned today. Their fino is a classic example of the style: dry, crisp, and pale and a wonderful accompaniment to tapas.

wine.name: Aloxe-Corton "Les Valozières", Chandon de Briailles
wine.review: From the village of Aloxe-Corton at the northern tip of the Côtes de Beaune comes this earthy, gamey, red-berried offering. Though young vine fruit makes this bottling light and approachable in it's youth, the wine has enough structure to evolve in the celllar over the next few years.

wine.name: Pétillant "Moussamouettes" Mosse
wine.review: A blend of Grolleau, both Gris & Noir, and Gamay, this sparkler is the perfect choice for a summer apertif with fresh strawberry notes and an endearing fruitiness. Lively acidity and delicate foam dance across the palate. (Beware that with no filtration and very little sulfur, this bottle is cloudy.)

wine.name: Côtes-du-Rhône "From the Tank" Estezargues
wine.review: Ripe grapiness meets black cherry fruit in this exceptionally high quality bag-in-box. Candied fruit on the nose is followed by hints of smoke and annise on the palate. Equal to three bottles of wine!

wine.name: Wellies Sauvignon Blanc, Marlborough
wine.review: The Wairau Valley in Marlborough is the region that made New Zealand Sauvignon Blanc famous. The Wellies bottling is incredibly approachable, with a nose full of gooseberries, fresh herbs, and melon. An incredibly fresh, dry white wine to suit any number of occasions.

wine.name: Bodegas Real "Nazares" Tempranillo
wine.review: This red is made from Tempranillo, Spain's best-known grape variety. "Nazares" comes from younger grape vines and emphasizes a youthful fruit quality; the palate is full of fresh blueberry and cherry flavors. This is a dry, lighter style of Tempranillo that's great with appetizers like cured meats or Spanish omelettes. From the La Mancha region.

wine.name: Ch. Lynch-Bages, Pauillac
wine.review: Ch. Lynch-Bages continues to deliver quality in this spectacular 2005 vintage. This has a mildly smoky nose with dense tannins and currants. Great potential for the cellar.

wine.name: Delamotte, Brut Blanc de Blancs
wine.review: This sister Champagne to the renouned Salon has all that could be desired of a blanc de blanc: pear and white peach on the nose, delicate, chalky minerality... and above all purity.

wine.name: Fonseca Porto Vintage
wine.review: Special Order

wine.name: Pinot Gris, Clos des Rochers
wine.review: This Luxemburgian Pinot Gris has a weighty mouthfeel accompanied by intense white peach and ripe stone fruit notes. Clay and chalk interplay on the finish adding depth and complexity.

wine.name: Riesling, Clos des Rochers
wine.review: Lovely yellow and orange peaches coupled with hints of petrol and vibrant acidity make for a satisfying Riesling experience. With lemongrass notes on the finish, this would be a superb partner for Thai food.

wine.name: "Le Champ du Coq", Dom. La Croix Belle
wine.review: From a tiny region in the heart of the Languedoc called the Côtes de Thongue comes this satisfying Syrah and Grenache blend. Mediterranean warmth result in dense, sweet fruit on the nose and palate.

wine.name: Maury Vin Doux Naturel, Mas Karolina
wine.review: This fortified wine from Maury (in the Banyuls neighborhood of Roussillon) offers dark fruit on the nose and is decadently ruby port-like. Unique in that it's not oxidized, the wine finishes with flowers and a satisfying tang.

wine.name: Basilicata Bianco, Re Manfredi
wine.review: This slightly spritz-y Gewürztraminer blend makes a delightful apertif. Aromatic but not redolent of grandma's perfume as Gewürz can frequently be, the wine is sweet on the nose and palate with zippy acidity and a dry finish.

wine.name: Brut Rosé, Arunda Vivaldi
wine.review: Barely rosé in color, this "effervescent treasure from the mountains" offers a nose full of woodsy berries, earth, and brioche. Arunda does a traditional second fermentation in bottle to create a fine foam that tantalizes the palate.

wine.name: Taburno Greco, Fattoria La Rivolta
wine.review: The Greco variety (which is, unsurprisingly, of Greek origin) produces fleshy wines that are at times reminiscent of very good Viognier. Fresh citrus and white flower aromas pour from the glass, complementing a lithe and balanced palate.

wine.name: Mâcon-Verzé, Leflaive
wine.review: Vignerons in the Mâcon tend prefer to stainless steel vessels to oak ones for vinification and aging. The result is leaner, lither white Burgundies than are commonly made in the Côte Chalonnais. Here is a mouthful of green orchard fruit with lovely mineral notes.

wine.name: Prosecco, Bioldo
wine.review: Bioldo is a fragrant Prosecco that's more friendly than your typical sparkling wine. It's soft, floral with aromas of apples and powder. It's just the type of Prosecco that you can sip on before, during, and after a meal. Enjoy chilled with salted almonds, fresh anchovies, or even cured meats.

wine.name: Crémant d'Alsace Brut Reserve, Baur
wine.review: Tangy acidity and minerality balance the relatively high dossage in this offering from Alsace. With it's copper hue, creamy mousse, and ripe yellow fruit aromas, here is a perfect aperitif sparkler.

wine.name: Riesling "Clos de la Trielle" Baur
wine.review: From Baur's granite-rich monopole comes this delightfully complex bottle. Stone fruits so ripe they give the illusion of sweetness dance on the nose and palate, giving way to a fully dry wine with bright acidity and a tightly wound mineral finish.

wine.name: Taurasi "Radici", Mastroberardino
wine.review: The Mastroberardino family has been making wine in Campania for 300 years. The name "Radici" (roots) is a reference to their winemaking history. Dark berries, violet, and volcanic soil prevail in this structured and brooding bottle.

wine.name: Amarone, Alberino
wine.review: If you've never tried an Amarone, start here. Amarone is always a rich, concentrated red wine. This one is especially ripe in dark berried fruits, woody spices and all-around lushness. The fruit is so generous and the tannins full of chocolate. Amarone comes from the Veneto region of northern Italy. This particular bottle was made with an addition of intentionally dried grapes - a style known as recioto. The impact is phenomenal and in this case, gives the Amarone an extra ripe appeal on the finish.

wine.name: Prosecco, Mia
wine.review: At Astor we've been singing the praises of Prosecco for years - taste this one and you'll understand why. This is an incredibly refreshing, lightly sparkling wine that's full of citrus fruit with a delicate, dry finish.

wine.name: Nero d'Avola, Maravigna
wine.review: When you think of Sicily, think Nero d'Avola. This one is unoaked and made in a medium-rich style; more than anything, this red puts the focus on the fruit. Calling to mind spicy berries coated with a dusting of powder, this red is drinking very well today, and makes a great match for pepperoni pizza!

wine.name: Marzemino "dei Zirisi" Superiore, Vivallis
wine.review: The red Marzemino grape is cherished for its exuberant fruit-driven profile, which this wine offers along with intense body, chocolate tannins, and spice. Some of the Marzemino grapes were dried on straw mats until the January following the 2006 harvest. This added significantly to the depth of this red wine, making it taste like a cousin of Amarone. Excellent with hard, aged Italian cheeses.

wine.name: Fiano di Avellino, Mastroberardino
wine.review: This waxy-textured and mellow Campanian white has subtle aromas of pine nuts and yellow fruits like plums and apples. The wine is medium-bodied and balanced, yet maintains a roundness that makes it approachable without food.

wine.name: Quinta do Monte d'Oiro, Reserve
wine.review: This estate looks to the Rhône to set its standard. The wine (mostly Syrah with a touch of Viognier à la Côte-Rôtie) spends a year in 100% new French oak, giving it a cedar-y quality that will mellow over time. On the palate, the wine is pulpy and rife with dark fruit and thick tannins.

wine.name: Moscato Giallo "Vigna Giere", Vivallis
wine.review: The Moscato Giallo grape renders fantastically aromatic white wines. This one is off-dry and smells of yellow plums, citrus, and fresh white flowers. The texture is rich and the aromas are concentrated yet elegant. It is the perfect wine to enjoy before a meal (or with food if you're prepared for a touch of sweetness in your wine). This comes from a single vineyard, "Vigna Giere," in the Trentino sub-region of northern Italy. Enjoy the wine chilled, but don't overchill it: make sure you can appreciate all of the floral nuances.

wine.name: Ruchè di Castagnole Monferrato "Bric d'Bianc" Ferraris
wine.review: Italy has literally thousands of indigenous grape varieties. Ruchè is a specialty of the Piedmont region of northern Italy. This pale, ruby-colored Ruchè spends a few months in large, old botte - a traditional, large wooden cask - adding complexity to the aromas. This is a dry, red wine with assertive violets and red fruits, tangy acidity and prominent tannins making this wine ideal for rich foods.

wine.name: Touriga Nacional, Quinta do Vallado
wine.review: From vines planted in 1994, this is the first vintage Vallado felt was good enough to bottle as a single varietal wine. The wine spends 20 months in oak, 60% one year old French barriques and 40% new. With grippy tannins and cedar-y oak notes, here is an ideal wine for steak.

wine.name: Reserva, Quinta do Vallado
wine.review: The Quinta do Vallado is a 38 hectare estate that dates back to the early 18th Century. 26 of the estates 38 hectares are planted to 60 year old vines, which could account for the intensity and quality of the wines. Rich black fruit and new oak make this bottling reminiscent of a modern Bordeaux.

wine.name: Gigondas, Dom. Gour de Chaulé
wine.review: Mme Bonfils has crafted a stunning Gigondas with layers of dark fruits & deep meaty flavors. Smoky Syrah & powerful Grenache blend beautifully in this southern Rhône gem.

wine.name: Gran Reserva, Faustino I
wine.review: Rusty red in color with tobacco and dried red currant notes on the nose, this Rioja, at over a decade, shows a delightful amount of evolution. With some oak on the finish, this bottle deserves, even requires, a well-prepared London Broil.

wine.name: Reserva, Faustino V
wine.review: In this Reserva, Faustino has created a wine that is loyal to the flavors of traditional Rioja. A pretty, herbal bouquet gives way to a mouthful of red berries. On the finish, a burst of tangy acidity reminds us that true Rioja is made for food.

wine.name: Anthony Road Pinot Gris
wine.review: Ideal for lighter fare as this wine shows lemon and citrus character with a crisp and dry finish.

wine.name: Four Vines Naked Chardonnay
wine.review: This wine sees no oak, allowing the apple and citrus flavors to shine through. A California Chardonnay with good acidity can be hard to find, but this bottle from Santa Barbara is in a class all by itself. This is the quintessential food wine.

wine.name: Clayhouse Vineyards Adobe Red
wine.review: This five grape blend is full of ripe dark fruit, blueberry and cherry followed by some bold tannins.

wine.name: Ch Cordeillan-Bages, Pauillac
wine.review: If you are a lover of American Cabernet and are looking to expand your horizons to the old world, here is a wine to try. With aromas of cassis and tobacco and a lush, mouthfilling palate, this bottle is satisfying in its modernity.

wine.name: Anjou Blanc "Le P'tit Blanc", Sablonettes
wine.review: This unoaked, floral Chenin Blanc charmingly balances vibrancy and weight. A nose of yellow plums leads to ripe flavors on the palate, with very present and food-friendly acidity.

wine.name: Crémant d'Alsace, Extra Brut, Binner
wine.review: After a stint on the lees followed by a stint in the cellar, this Riesling based sparkler takes on a fabulous texture and mouthfeel. The mousse is extremely fine and the nose offers more earthy and floral notes than fruit.

wine.name: Melissa Rosso "Mutro'", Cantina Val di Neto
wine.review: This warm, southerly red from Calabria has remarkable freshness and vibrance. On the nose, the wine gives ripe strawberry notes with a distinctly herbal quality reminiscent tomato or oregano. With tangy tannins, and hints of chocolate on the finish, the bottle brings plenty of complexity to the table.

wine.name: Santorini, Hatzidakis
wine.review: The most interesting thing about the Assyrtiko that grows on Santorini, aside from the wines it produces, is that the vines are trained in spiral formations. This makes them resemble baskets, and protects the grapes against the island's incredible heat. Citrusy and made to accompany grilled octopus, this example is richer and riper than many Santorini whites, but its acidity and piercing minerality are pronounced enough to tame the wine's fullness.

wine.name: Ribeira Sacra, Viña do Burato, D. Ventura
wine.review: The "sacred banks" of the Sil and Miño rivers, just inland from Rías Baixas in Galicia, are so steep that they demand careful and laborious hand-harvesting. Ventura's old vines, along with his abhorrence of filtration and chemical yeasts, give this dark-fruited, pulpy wine its succulence. The wine is 100% Mencia, the grape of Bierzo, its neighboring DO. Unlike many of the jammier offerings of Bierzo, this Mencia has rusticity and fresh, punchy acidity reminiscent of a Cru Beaujolais.

wine.name: Clayhouse Petite Sirah
wine.review: This Petite Sirah comes from some of the oldest plantings in Paso Robles. The wine has good tannins, it's rich in dark fruit of black plums with spicy black pepper, brown sugar and vanilla.

wine.name: Felton Road, Chardonnay
wine.review: New Zealand's Felton Road winery is located in Bannockburn, Central Otago, the most southerly wine growing region in the world. Their Chardonnay is toasty and dry; on the palate it's full of apples, citrus, and hazelnut fruits.

wine.name: Ponzi, Pinot Gris
wine.review: A full-bodied, unoaked expression of Pinot Gris with round yellow plums, smoky aromas, and a floral finish. The texture is rich and can easily stand up to any number of fish or white meat dishes.

wine.name: Domaine Gauby Rouge, Vieilles Vignes
wine.review: There is perhaps no one in France more respected, indeed revered, than winemaker Gérard Gauby. This old vines red blend is dense in fruit and tannins but as of more recent vintages has taken on a good deal of finesse. Always a wine that can be aged. Decant.

wine.name: Dolç de Lobac, Late Harvest Priorat
wine.review: An incredibly rich, fortified dessert wine that's harvested late and is therefore sweet. The mouthfeel is viscous and certainly the type of dessert wine that you can pair up with churros con chocolate or if you prefer a salty counterpart, blue cheese.

wine.name: Agiorgitiko "Red on Black" Mitravelas
wine.review: Many Greek wines strike us as a tad out of the ordinary - and we love out of the ordinary! Fluffy, dark raspberry flavors carry through the nose to the palate, lending a pretty veneer to this meaty, earthy, medium-bodied red wine. This bottle will not disappoint.

wine.name: Enkidu "Odyssey" Syrah
wine.review: In this bottle, plush, dark fruit marries harmoniously with smokey cured meat aromas. The palate is unctuous and would be compliment a steak to perfection. Enkidu uses 30% new oak, ages for a year at least, and does partial whole cluster fermentation so there are plenty of grippy tannins here.

wine.name: Vin Doux Moscato, Samos
wine.review: This nectar-y Greek dessert wine is full of apricot and yellow plum character on the nose and palate. With intriguing chalky, limestone minerality and a healthy dose of sweetness and alcohol, it's an ideal after dinner sipper

wine.name: Meia Pipa, Vinho Regional Terras do Sado
wine.review: A Portuguese treat for lovers of big, plush Napa Valley reds. In this bottle you'll find plenty of voluptuous dark berry flavor and outstanding freshness - a characteristic that too often plays second fiddle to oak in modern wines.

wine.name: Petit Chablis, Billaud-Simon
wine.review: From a very traditional estate comes this luxurious yet well-structured Petit Chablis. On the nose, the wines gives pretty, floral aromas. Round in the mouth and full of citrus and green apple acidity, this bottle makes the perfect partner to oysters or white fish.

wine.name: Prosecco "Cartizze", Le Colture
wine.review: Cartizze, a subzone of Prosecco, produces the highest-quality sparkling wines in the region. This elegant bottle gives up gorgeous white flower and pear notes on the nose, with good acidity balancing its slight touch of sweetness.

wine.name: Manifesto, Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: The Suisun Valley east of Carneros is perfect for Sauvignon Blanc, which benefits enormously from the region's diurnal temperature difference. The wine has a slightly grassy and very aromatic nose, which gives way to a clean palate that is devoid of oak and has lots of bright, mouth-watering acidity.

wine.name: Piedirosso, Fattoria La Rivolta
wine.review: This remarkably fresh and tangy Piedirosso gets some of its structure from the addition of 15% Aglianico. When you take this bottle home, look forward to loads of brambly red berry fruit, granitic mineral notes, and food-friendly tannins.

wine.name: Maysara "Jamsheed" Pinot Noir
wine.review: This rather luscious Pinot Noir from McMinnville, Oregon is a great example of the fruit-forward style of American Pinot Noir that so many have grown to love. On the nose, the wine gives plenty of floral berry character. Though heavy on the jammy fruit, the palate is balanced and soft, and supple tannins round out the equation.

wine.name: Yellow and Blue Malbec
wine.review: Yellow and Blue make green... The grapes for this Mendozan Malbec are organically grown and the juice is unoaked and full of fresh, vibrant acidity. The nose is reminiscent of dark berries and the tannins are pleasingly present. The liter-size tetrapack is recyclable and lightweight, giving it a tiny carbon footprint. Take a tetra home tonight!

wine.name: Ch. Fantin, Bordeaux Supérieur
wine.review: The perfect Bordeaux for your steak frites tonight! The nose on this red has classic Cabernet notes of pure blackcurrant fruit that carry through to the palate. The wine is made in a very clean, very "Old World" style, making it a great choice for the table.

wine.name: Highfield Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: We found this Sauvignon Blanc to be a real treat. It's intense in all the ways: great acidity, lovely ripeness, and rich in both texture and minerality. Also, unlike so many of its New Zealand counterparts, the aromatics are restrained, showing pretty citrus and herbal notes.

wine.name: Highfield Pinot Noir
wine.review: We are as delighted with Highfield's Pinot Noir as we are with their Sauvignon Blanc, probably because both are full of Old World charm. The texture is streamlined - rather than viscous from excessive alcohol - and the wine has a Burgundian berried gaminess to it that we're smitten with. This is fantastic with duck.

wine.name: Vinho Espumante "Maria Gomes" Luis Pato
wine.review: This Portuguese sparkler is made from the obscure Maria Gomes grape by one of the country's top wine-makers, Luis Pato. White fleshy notes interplay with quince, jasmine, and yellow plum. Pato uses the Champagne method to create this lovely, dry bubbly.

wine.name: Vinho Espumante, Bruto Baga Rosé, Luis Pato
wine.review: Here is a very interesting specimen. This dry pink bubbly is pale watermelon in color with the deeply earthy nose of a Portuguese red wine. The wine is marked by strawberry aromas and red currant tanginess. It's mineral edge makes it a perfect wine for shelfish.

wine.name: Godello, Abad Dom Bueno
wine.review: We love this white grape for its dry, clean minerality, for its citus and pear-skin fruit flavors. We love Godello for its ability to call to mind a babbling mountain stream, and to make us hungry for freshly caught seafood. We love this particular Godello for its perfect ripeness and its fresh, unoaked appeal.

wine.name: Mesoneros de Castillo "Roble" Ribera
wine.review: This bottle is for the lover of modern Ribera. The fruit is pure blackberry with a hearty dose of tobacco and minty oak on the nose. In the glass it's nearly opaque and the finish shows some smoke and tannin; this is perfect for a slab of meat.

wine.name: Primitivo, Gioia del Colle
wine.review: This is hands down one of the best Primitivos we've tasted in quite some time. The wine has fresh berry and floral aromas and lacks the baked character of so many Primitivos. Best of all is the texture, silky smooth but giving way to a pleasantly tannic finish.

wine.name: Côtes-du-Rhône "Poignée de Raisins", Gramenon
wine.review: The wines of Domaine Gramenon accomplish a rare feat, that of being extremely ripe without being the slightest bit overblown or jammy. This bottling is aged in cement tank for purity of fruit and is bottled with minimal sulfur. The wine is gives lots of pretty Grenache fruit but with peppery hints of Syrah.

wine.name: Malvasia di Candia, Fiorano, Boncompagni Ludovisi
wine.review: The Fiorano estate belongs to Alberico Boncampagni Ludovisi, the prince of Venosa in Lazio. The wines are unique and both extremely rare and incredibly age-worthy. The prince, a self-made wine-maker, restricts yields and vinifies tradtionally. The wines are transcendental and magical in the sense that are thought to become fresher the older they get. Ludovisi planted Cabernet and Merlot and for his whites, Malvasia and Semillon.

wine.name: Malvasia di Candia, Fiorano, Boncompagni Ludovisi
wine.review: The Fiorano estate belongs to Alberico Boncampagni Ludovisi, the prince of Venosa in Lazio. The wines are unique and both extremely rare and incredibly age-worthy. The prince, a self-made wine-maker, restricts yields and vinifies tradtionally. The wines are transcendental and magical in the sense that are thought to become fresher the older they get. Ludovisi planted Cabernet and Merlot and for his whites, Malvasia and Semillon.

wine.name: Malvasia di Candia, Fiorano, Boncompagni Ludivisi
wine.review: The Fiorano estate belongs to Alberico Boncampagni Ludovisi, the prince of Venosa in Lazio. The wines are unique and both extremely rare and incredibly age-worthy. The prince, a self-made wine-maker, restricts yields and vinifies tradtionally. The wines are transcendental and magical in the sense that are thought to become fresher the older they get. Ludovisi planted Cabernet and Merlot and for his whites, Malvasia and Semillon.

wine.name: Quinta do Monte d'Oiro, Viognier "Madrigal"
wine.review: This is a brilliant bottle for the lover of rich, round Viognier from the Rhône. Hints of pear skin mingle with creamy oak nuances on the nose and palate. Despite its heft, the wine has solid acidity and would pair delightfully with roast chicken.

wine.name: Red by W, Kosher
wine.review: This light bodied, berried fruit red is brought to us by the Weinstock family. A blend of Gamay, Petite Syrah and Merlot makes this perfect for grilled meats and lamb.

wine.name: Parallel Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Phillipe Mellka is the heralded wine maker of Hundred Acres and now has created this beautiful Cabernet from Parallel. The soft tannins allow for immediate consumption.

wine.name: Brouilly, Ch. des Tours
wine.review: Chateau des Tours has been producing particularly fine wines of late. This vintage takes full advantage of their 40-year-old vines. Direct and full on the nose with classic notes of violets, black cherry, and moist earth. The slightly solid structure of the vintage supports crisp red berry flavors in the mouth, with a touch of fresh herbs. Lovely now but will improve with short-term aging.

wine.name: Dow's LBV Port
wine.review: An LBV (Late Bottled Vintage) Port is different than a vintage port that's bottled two years after harvest. Bottled anywhere from four to six years after harvest, LBVs have been aged longer in cask and are therefore more approachable upon release.

wine.name: Warre's Tawny Otima 20 Year Port
wine.review: Special Order

wine.name: Vendange Tardive Riesling "Kastelberg" Kreydenweiss
wine.review: Vendange Tardive ("late harvest") is a style of (usually) sweet, rich white wine made from extremely ripe grapes. The concentration of varietal character is extraordinary and the success of the wine relies upon a fine balance between sugar and acidity.

wine.name: Puligny-Montrachet 1er Cru "Clavoillons" Domaine Leflaive
wine.review: The Clavoillons vineyard is adjacent to Meursault and produces rich wines usually full of buttery oak character. Anne-Claude Leflaive is a scrupulous vigneron whose wines are a paradigm for Puligny. Drink now or hold for ten years.

wine.name: Puligny-Montrachet 1er Cru "Les Combettes" Domaine Leflaive
wine.review: If you're looking for a beautiful, breath-taking, and age-worthy white Burgundy, here is your wine. From a top vineyard sight and a benchmark producer comes this Puligny-Combettes.

wine.name: Carignan, Poudou
wine.review: In France, the red Carignan grape is typically used in blends. This is a rare monovarietal Carignan bottling, and it clearly expresses the classic profile of this ancient grape. The wine is unoaked, full-bodied, and dry, with aromas of dark berries and ripe, rustic tannins. This is a food wine that is meant to be drunk with meat - or any number of other rich foods.

wine.name: Minervois Blanc, La Tour Boisée
wine.review: La Tour Boisée is one of the great wineries of the Minervois. This dry white wine is full of floral aromas and apple flavors, making it an excellent wine to choose when you're having seafood.

wine.name: Minervois Rouge "Marielle et Frédérique," La Tour Boisée
wine.review: The Minervois is located in the west of the Languedoc region of southern France. This was a fantastic vintage, and this red wine is full of character and balance as a result. A blend based on Syrah and Cinsault, two of the region's primary grapes. Full of dark, ripe blackberry fruits, plums, and peppercorn. Unoaked.

wine.name: Crozes-Hermitage, Dom. Mucyn
wine.review: The Crozes-Hermitage appellation is located in the northern part of the Rhône Valley. At the Mucyn estate there's an abundance of granite on their vine slopes resulting is a rich, full-bodied red wine that isn't affected by new oak. The emphasis here is on the Syrah fruit: spice, smoke, dark berries, and licorice. Full of complexities that evolve in the glass.

wine.name: St. Joseph Blanc, Dom. Mucyn
wine.review: The Saint-Joseph sub-region of the Rhône Valley is best known for red wines, but the whites are proving to be just as sophisticated. Made entirely from the Roussanne grape variety, this dry, floral wine spends several months in barrel before further bottle aging. Aromas of acacia, apricots, and mixed flowers leap out on the nose.

wine.name: Les Quatre Tours "Classique" Red
wine.review: A hearty yet easy-drinking southern French red wine that's very easy to love. Full of dark cherries and black plums, this has just a moderate dose of tannins.

wine.name: Les Quatre Tours "Signature" Red
wine.review: A rich red wine from southern France. Based on Cabernet Sauvignon, this is unoaked yet quite structured, with ripe aromas of wild blackberry and cassis fruit. While this bottle is made just outside the city of Aix-en-Provence in southeastern France, it boasts a striking resemblance to a Cru Bourgeois from Bordeaux, with hearty, clean fruit and approachable, food-friendly tannins.

wine.name: Sauvignon Blanc, Dom. de la Rablais
wine.review: Undoubtedly, Sauvignon Blanc is one of the most likable French grapes there is. This white wine shows lots of floral aromas, citrus fruits, and a bright, dry finish.

wine.name: Jacques Chaput et Fils, Brut Tradition
wine.review: There's always good reason to open up a bottle of Champagne especially when it's this delicious. Based on Pinot Noir it gives rich berry aromas alongside brioche, quince and pears. Very approachable on the palate yet still finishes dry. Complete with a gift box!

wine.name: Jacques Chaput et Fils, Brut Rosé
wine.review: Rosé Champagne always makes a great statement in that its more rare than white Champagne. Jacques Chaput, both a graphic designer and a vigneron, crafts his from 100% Pinot Noir, with the result that there is an earthy element of terroir to the nose that compliments strawberry fruit on the palate. Dry and delightfully red berried.

wine.name: Sancerre, Dom. Buissonnes
wine.review: This white wine is from a family-run estate located in the village of Sury en Vaux. The wine rested on the lees until the April after the vintage. This vital process adds complexities that cannot be duplicated by other means. A great style of smoky Sancerre that's mineral-driven, floral, and bone dry on the finish, making it a marvelous match to fresh oysters.

wine.name: Nackenheimer Rothenberg Riesling Auslese, Gunderloch
wine.review: Gunderloch keeps yields extremely low to ensure maximum concentration in the wines. The estate practices reductive winemaking for a richer style of Riesling. The '97 is beginning to show stunning secondary fruit.

wine.name: Riesling "Laissez Faire", Becker
wine.review: This lightly sweet Riesling has an intriguing Pomegranate note to the nose that makes it both exotic and interesting. The flavors are mellow and ripe and while there is a touch of sweetness, the finish is delightfully dry.

wine.name: Valpolicella, Marion
wine.review: Although Marion's Amarone gets all the attention, you shouldn't shy away from the Valpolicella. Full of exuberant dark-berried fruits. Decant and enjoy today.

wine.name: Tensley Blanc
wine.review: This aromatic Rhône-style blend will be a hit with lovers of white Châteauneuf-du-Pape. With ripe stone fruits on the nose, this wine is as close to a bowl of peaches and cream as anything you'll find in a wine glass. Classic Viognier notes of apricot jam add to its complexity. The palate is round and mellow.

wine.name: Ayala Millésimé
wine.review: This is a very yeasty style of Champagne due to the six years it spends on the lees before being disgorged. A high percentage of Pinot Noir (80%) gives it interesting citrus notes. The palate is lean and focused.

wine.name: Ayala Rosé "Majeur"
wine.review: The Ayala Champagnes are light, elegant, and somewhat ethereal. The base is Chardonnay with the rest Pinot Noir and Meunier. The nose gives red berry notes and the palate shows a certain leanness and minerality.

wine.name: Ayala "Rich Majeur" Demi-Sec
wine.review: Here is a truly elegant Demi-Sec Champagne that is abounding with floral fruit, quince, and peach blossoms on the nose. Some residual sugar (30 grams) gives the wine a delightful softness and the balance is stunning.

wine.name: Pinoir de Soif, O. Lemasson
wine.review: Olivier Lemasson has a talent for producing light red wines that are simultaneously thirst quenching and complex. This Pinot Noir is pure red fruit in a glass complete with an earthy nose redolent of Loire Valley soil. Possessed of fantastic acidity that begs for food, the palate is lythe, the finish tangy and berried.

wine.name: Ch. Sainte-Marie, Bordeaux Supérieur
wine.review: Here is a reasonably priced Bordeaux that has all the cassis and dark fruit you'd expect from a much more expensive bottle. The finish has some tannin, from the hefty percentage of Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend. Perfect with steak or beef stew, and ready to drink tonight!

wine.name: Le Pergole Torte, Montevertine
wine.review: This is Montevertine's ultimate achievement. The estate parted ways with the Chianti DOCG in order to be able to make 100% Sangiovese, and here is the much-celebrated result. Aged for at least two years in barrel, the wine has the intensity of a classic Super Tuscan with a lighter feel on the palate and more finesse and elegance.

wine.name: Ch. Laurès, Entre-Deux-Mers
wine.review: Here is a crisp Semillon based white Bordeaux that, because the grapes are grown on Clay and limestone, offers plenty of oyster shell minerality on the finish. The wine is matured in old oak and the nose gives lots of soft, apricot fruit.

wine.name: Ch. les Hauts-Conseillants, Lalande de Pomerol
wine.review: This is a ripe, Merlot based Bordeaux that speaks of the clay and gravel on which the grapes are grown. Aged for 18 months in oak of which a third is new, this wine glances at modernity without fully embracing it.

wine.name: Cakebread Dancing Bear Cabernet
wine.review: This vintage from the Dancing Bear Ranch site produced grape clusters with small berries and intense concentrated flavors. Drink now with agrilled meats or lay down for years to come.

wine.name: "Adonis" La Grapperie
wine.review: Here at Astor we love to discover new wines made from Pineau D'Aunis. The combintation of black peppercorn spice and ripe, juicy fruit make this bottle real winner. Have it with food and/or make sure to decant to taste it at its best. This less than 5-hectare estate belongs to Renaud Guettier, who purchased his first parcel of vines in 2004. His vineyards are divided into 15 separate plots, each with a unique microclimate. He also plants Chenin, Grolleau, Gamay, and Côt.

wine.name: Côtes du Rhône "Comeyre", L'Anglore
wine.review: This wine is extremely lythe on the palate for the amount of dark fruit is shows on the nose. There is solid, food friendly acidity with excellent tannic structure. Made from all Carignan, this is a unique bottle that should improve with a few years.

wine.name: Côtes de Duras Rouge, Ch. Haut Lavigne
wine.review: This soft fruited Merlot blend from southwest France is, above all, accessible. It's dark berry character is simultaneously rich and balanced, its tannins, mellow. We can see this with a variety of foods, also on its own.

wine.name: Bishop's Peak, Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: This Cabernet is blended with just a touch of Cabernet Franc for spice and complexity. The wine sees 18 months in 20% new French and American oak. The wine's dark fruit is easygoing and food-friendly, its tannins approachable.

wine.name: Bergström "Dr. Bergström" Riesling
wine.review: Here is Bergström's first attempt at Riesling... and what a Riesling it is! The wine is delightfully aromatic with peachy, stone fruit notes and a mineral edge not always found in the domestic expressions of this grape. Off-dry with lovely floral fruit.

wine.name: Ridge Vineyards Chardonnay Santa Cruz
wine.review: While this Chardonnay definitely has plenty of rich California style, it shows truly impeccable balance along with supple-ness from lees aging. Expect apple and vanilla bean oak notes on the nose and palate.

wine.name: Châteauneuf-du-Pape "Vieilles Vignes" Clos St Jean
wine.review: This 40 hectare Châteauneuf producer boasts vines of over a hundred years! Since they made the move, several vintages ago, to estate bottling, the wines heave leapt in quality. Plush, and extracted with lots of licorice.

wine.name: Châteauneuf-du-Pape "Cuvée Girard" Usseglio
wine.review: Raymond Usseglio and his son, Stephane, own property on the famous Châteauneuf vineyard "Le Crau" and the depth imparted by this propitious parcel shows in the wines. Structured, brooding, with intense dark fruit.

wine.name: Riesling Scharzhofberger Trocken, Van Voxlem
wine.review: The off-dry Riesling has more citrus than stone fruit, showing great lemon meringue and orange flower notes. The estate fights against excessive alcohol levels in order to keep its wines vibrant and balanced.

wine.name: Salon Blanc de Blanc, Le Mesnil
wine.review: Simply one of the best and most well respected Champagnes of all time. The Le Mesnil vineyard is known for the bottle-age requiring Champagnes it yields. In their youth, they are overwhelmingly chalky but after a few years, they become absolutely devine.

wine.name: Chablis Grand Cru "Les Preuses" Faiveley
wine.review: This Granc Cru Chablis gives intense notes of apple, lemon, and pear on the nose. The vineyards, full of the limestone and fossilized oyster shell typical of Chablis, impart impressive minerality. Expect a certain balanced roundness on the palate.

wine.name: Beneventano Aglianico, De Falco
wine.review: In case you thought Aglianico couldn't go in a delicate, Burgundian direction, here is a bottle that will prove you wrong. There is lots of bright cherry fruit on the nose and palate with a rusty mineral finish. It may sound like a stretch but drink this with duck!

wine.name: Barbera d'Asti, La Fiammenga
wine.review: This very traditional bottle has all the qualities we love to see in a Barbera: great, tangy, food-friendly acidity, lively cherry fruit on the nose, and a burst of mouthwatering tannin on the finish.

wine.name: Blaufränkisch, Moric
wine.review: From a young estate (founded in 2001) comes this extraordinary example of Blaufränkisch. The nose offers pronounced graphite notes along with dark fruits and hints of chocolate. The estate's name "Moric" is of Hungarian origin and pronounced "Moritz."

wine.name: Blaufränkisch, Neckenmarkter, Moric
wine.review: With this wine, it is truly a challenge to decide which is more amazing, the nose or the palate. The nose gives intense dark berry and floral, violet notes. The palate is focused with well-integrated tannins that indicate great potential to age. Fortunately the only decision one needs to make is the decision to take a bottle home. The wine is aged for 18-20 months in oak but woodiness doesn't show on the nose or palate. Cellar or decant for best results.

wine.name: Chablis "Preuses", Dauvissat
wine.review: Jean Dauvissat produces outstanding Chablis, including this extremely rich, age-worthy label from Les Preuses, one of the seven Grand Cru vineyards. It will gain complexity over the next ten years, or enjoy soon with grilled fish.

wine.name: Franciacorta Brut, Ferghettina
wine.review: Franciacorta has been making sparkling wines using the Champagne method since 1570. This example has a fairly high dosage and shows appealing quince fruit on the nose. There is also an abundance of mineral on the finish from the stony soil of the region.

wine.name: Milcampos Tempranillo, Ribera del Duero
wine.review: This is a juicy and pulpy Tempranillo from Ribera that sees no oak at all and is remarkably fresh on the palate. There are coffee notes on the nose and delightful ripe tannins on the finish. Perfect with a well-prepared medium-rare steak and french fries.

wine.name: Cahors, Clos de Coutale
wine.review: If you're sick of drinking the same old Sangiovese or Primitivo with your pizza, this Malbec with a touch of Merlot makes a great alternative. It's perfectly rustic and earthy with great, food-friendly tannins and a dose of wild Mediterranean flavor.

wine.name: Dashe "l'Enfant Terrible", Zinfandel
wine.review: What puts this Zin in a class all its own, apart from its low alcohol and solid tannic structure, is that it is fermented using natural yeasts rather than commercial ones. This gives it all the character of its place of origin: the Alexander Valley. On the nose, it's full of sweet mixed red and black berries, but the palate is totally dry. A real treat from the Zin category.

wine.name: Riesling Spätlese "Kreuznacher Krotenpfuhl", Dönnhoff
wine.review: It's possible that Spätlese Rieslings are the estate's best. This example is ripe, tangy, and full of concetrated mineral, which takes the wine to a new level of beauty and complexity. In a word, pristine.

wine.name: Rivesaltes Rancio, Puig-Parahy
wine.review: The intentionally oxidative "Rancio" style dessert wine gives earthy tobacco notes as well as fig and plum jam. A luscious treat.

wine.name: Rivesaltes Rancio, Puig-Parahy
wine.review: Morello cherry notes prevail here along with definite hints of brandy. A perfect after dinner sipper from a family who has been making Rivesaltes in the Rousillon since the 15th Century!

wine.name: Riesling Ried Klaus Federspiel, Jamek
wine.review: A crisp. dry style of Riesling typical of Austria with great minerality and lots of food-friendly acidity.

wine.name: Rivesaltes Rancio, Puig-Parahy
wine.review: The nose on this bottle of Rivesaltes gives a complex array of dried fruit flavors from candied orange zest to stewed plum.The palate is dense and concentrated with lots of alcohol and brandy flavor, the finish, nutty and extremely long.

wine.name: Rivesaltes Rancio, Puig-Parahy
wine.review: Notes of Rum, dried grapes, and cocoa give way to a dense and concentrated palate.

wine.name: Rivesaltes Vin Doux Naturel, Puig-Parahy
wine.review: In another five years this Vin Doux will be a fully fledged Rancio. As it is, it's a young wine with astonishing potential to age into mahogany hued delciousness.

wine.name: Radog Pinot Noir
wine.review: This brambly, fruit-forward offering comes from Monterey, California. Full of raspberries on the nose and refreshingly not over-oaked, this Pinot is soft enough to drink alone, yet it can hold its own with food as well.

wine.name: Mckenzie-Mueller Malbec, Los Carneros
wine.review: It's time to broaden those Malbec horizons. The truth is that the grape can flourish outside Cahors and Argentina: Try one made in the warm, dry climate of Napa Valley. This Malbec, made by a husband-and-wife team who specialize in Pinot Noir, is dark and a touch jammy, showing fantastic ripeness.

wine.name: Barolo "San Lorenzo", Fatelli Alessandria
wine.review: The San Lorenzo vineyard in Verduno brings out the pretty, floral characteristics of the Nebbiolo grape. The vineyard faces south, yieding a ripe wine. The wine sees around 2 years in French oak and is very traditional in style. The Alessandria brothers make wines for the long haul and this is no exception. As is traditional in Barolo, the Nebbiolo is macerated on the skins for between two and three weeks to extract color and tannins. It is important to note that the San Lorenzo bottling from Fratelli Alessandria, while it is traditional, is less austere than the Monvigliero bottling.

wine.name: Barolo "Monvigliero", Fratelli Alessandria
wine.review: The Monvigliero vineyard is known for the austerity and age-worthiness of its wines. Fratelli Alessandria, simultaneously traditional and ambitious, capitalize beautifully on the power of this vineyard sight. Here is a bottle for cellaring or long decating, and food is a must.

wine.name: Herdade da Malhadinha Nova "Matilde"
wine.review: This blend of Alicante Bouchet, Aragonez, and Cabernet is abounding with dark fruit on the palate. The grapes are all hand-harvested and fermentation takes place in large, open topped containers with traditional foot maceration! Food is a must here, preferably meat. The wine offers some charry oak notes on the finish that are indicative of modern winemaking and scream our for food or else time in bottle.

wine.name: Riesling "Brand" VT, Zind-Humbrecht
wine.review: This beautifully rich late harvest Riesling comes from vines planted in the 1920's and 30's. According to locals, the vines must be at least 30 years old to reach the black mica sub soil that gives the wines from Brand their complexity. This is Auslese level sweetness with 70 grams or residual sugar so be prepared to indulge your sweet tooth.

wine.name: Verduzzo, Bressan
wine.review: This is a dry, floral white wine that has gorgeous aromas of quince and honeysuckle. Quite full on the palate, almost doesn't seem like a white wine. Great with seafood or mushroom dishes.

wine.name: Terrano, Edi Kante
wine.review: "Terrano," otherwise known as Refosco d'Istria, makes structured and engaging red wines that have plenty of tannin and minerality. Edi Kante's version sees three years is large Slovenian oak barrels before release, giving it spice and character while increasing the wine's potential to age.

wine.name: Pinotage, Graham Beck
wine.review: Pinotage is a unique South African hybrid of Cinsault and Pinot Noir that is medium-bodied and easy-drinking. Graham Beck's bottling is a wonderful introduction to the world of Pinotage - or a great way to continue your exploration if you're already familiar with this red grape.

wine.name: Chenin Blanc, Graham Beck
wine.review: Chenin Blanc, the most widely planted variety in South Africa, thrives in the hands of well-reputed winemaker, Graham Beck. Rich with lots of apple and herb notes on the nose, this bottle makes a great, unoaked alternative to Chardonnay.

wine.name: Black Opal Shiraz
wine.review: Aromas of blackberry, pepper and spice followed with rich plum flavors round out the palate of this very good value from the land of Oz.

wine.name: Barbera d'Alba, Produttori di Govone
wine.review: The Barbera grape makes deliciously likable red wines: They're full of bright, red-berried fruits, and they're lively and fresh on the palate. This one is unoaked, allowing the grape's full character to shine through. Enjoy this with cured meats, cheeses, and briny olives.

wine.name: Moscato d'Asti, Produttori di Govone
wine.review: A dessert wine that is full of floral fruit, spicy white pears and powdered sugar. Drink chilled and enjoy the sparkling nature of this nicely sweet Italian wine that's especially delicious with pound cake or brioche.

wine.name: Chablis "Montée de Tonnerre", Raveneau
wine.review: Among those in the know, Domaine Francois Raveneau is considered to be the best estate in Chablis. The wines are marked by their vibrant acidity, their wet stone character, and their hints of salty, marine mineral. This is a bottle with amazing potential to age.

wine.name: Barolo "Arborina", Altare
wine.review: The Arborina vineyard has perfect south facing exposure to the sun. This in conjunction with its old vines (50 years) makes for a truly winning Barolo. Though Altare is a modernist, his wines show well after time in the cellar. Dense, ripe, with classic Nebbiolo intensity.

wine.name: Barolo "Bricco Boschis", Cavallotto
wine.review: The Bricco Boschis vineyard is in the Barolo commune of Castiglione Falletto. Cavallotto's wines are more traditional than many: He practices long maceration and ages in large Slovenian oak, rather than the small barriques that are increasingly popular in Barolo.

wine.name: Paxton AAA, Shiraz Grenache
wine.review: This blend of 75% Shiraz and 25% Grenache is also grown biodynamically. Rich with spicy character, but not over the top thanks to the softening effect of the Grenache.

wine.name: Saint-Aubin "Les Pucelles", Morey-Blanc
wine.review: Morey-Blanc is Pierre Morey's négociant operation. The vines on this lieu-dit, "Les Pucelles" meaning "young ladies of noble birth," are 30-years old. The wine sees 17 months in oak, giving it a creamy texture with nutty hints on the nose and palate.

wine.name: Meursault, Morey
wine.review: The grapes that comprise Pierre Morey's village Meursault come from three parcels: Les Forges, Les Pellans, and Les Chaumes. These 20-year old vines produce wine of great beauty, giving lots of smoky lemon and lime notes on the nose. The wines sees 18 months on oak, giving it texture and nutty complexity.

wine.name: Bourgogne Rouge, Morey
wine.review: Pierre Morey's basic Bourgogne Rouge comes from 50-year old vines, resulting in a wines that is chalk full of complex berry fruit and earth notes. The wine sees 13 months on oak, as well as 3 in tank. This bottles is balanced and although it drinks well now, a year in the cellar wouldn't hurt.

wine.name: Échezeax, Forey
wine.review: When Régis Forey took over the estate from his father, Jean, he began to experiment with exotic new oak. Thankfully he has tempered his use of new barrique. This Échezeaux is a powerful wine with loads of dark, brooding fruit, concentration, and tannic structure perfect for the cellar.

wine.name: Jean Velut Brut à Montgueux
wine.review: Jean Velut sells a portion of his grapes to négiciants, which allows him to turn the rest of his juice into exquisite grower Champagne. In Montgueux, the soil is mostly calcareous, the perfect soil type for cultivating Chardonnay. A mere 15% Pinot Noir adds fruitness to this lean Champagne.

wine.name: Saint-Bris, Clotilde Davenne
wine.review: Clotilde Davenne was the head oenologist at Domaine Jean-Marc Brocard before she started her own 8-hectare estate. Her Sauvignon is a lean style, green, herbal and full of fossilized shellfish minerality. Drink this with oysters and tangy, fresh goat cheese.

wine.name: Gigondas, Dom. de Cabasse
wine.review: Here is a spicy and minerally Gigondas that will benefit from a few years in the cellar (or you can simply decant it before dinner). Dark fruits abound on the palate, and this shows lots of structure, tang, and tannin for a Grenache-based Rhône wine.

wine.name: Barolo "Cascina Francia", Giacomo Conterno
wine.review: Giacomo Conterno's wines are considered amongst the best in Barolo. The estate uses extremely traditional methods: long maceration on the skins to extract tannins, and aging in old oak barrels. The wines require time in the bottle to show their best.

wine.name: Barolo "Cascina Francia", Giacomo Conterno
wine.review: Giacomo Conterno's wines are considered amongst the best in Barolo. The estate uses extremely traditional methods: long maceration on the skins to extract tannins, and aging in old oak barrels. The wines require time in the bottle to show their best.

wine.name: Barolo "Monfortino", Giacomo Conterno
wine.review: "Monfortino" is the equivalent of Giacomo Conterno's Tête de Cuvée. It is the best grapes from the best sights and the oldest vines, vinified using traditional methods to create a wine for the ages.

wine.name: Kadesh Barnea Merlot
wine.review: Packed with cherry and mixed berry flavors. The perfect companion to a roased lanb or veal.

wine.name: Layla Malbec, Kosher
wine.review: If you're not sure if you want a Cabernet or Merlot you may want to try this Malbec. A hearty red that would pair nicely with beef dished or even a tuna steak.

wine.name: Layla Semi-Dry Sparkling Wine
wine.review: If you want a little sweetness in your sparkler but you don't want an Asti than try this. Pair with most desserts or open at any celebration.

wine.name: Ch. Haut Breton Larigaudière Kosher, Margaux
wine.review: A Kosher Bordeaux from the commune of Margaux. Based mostly on Cabernet Sauvignon and showing a good amount of cedar from the 12 months of oak-aging. Shows a great amount of cassis, spice and moderate tannins. Enjoy with a roast.

wine.name: R.L. Buller Tawny Port
wine.review: Golden raisin on the palate with a sweet finish. Serve with blue veined cheeses, figs or nuts.

wine.name: Ch.Ksara Blanc de Blanc
wine.review: This is a blend of Sauvignon Blancs, Semillon and Chardonnay that is elegant and subtle. Pairs well with delicate fresh fisf or shell fish.

wine.name: Nugan Riverina Shiraz
wine.review: Appealing aromas of plums, blueberries, pepper and spice. This is a powerful display of dark berry fruit with velvety tannins and a smooth finish.

wine.name: Cru d'Arche-Pugneau Sauternes
wine.review: This 13 hectare estate is adjacent to Château d'Yquem; its wines are more experimental and more reasonably priced than Yquem's. Here is a multi-vintage Sauternes made like a Solera method sherry with lots of dense botrytis and a silky texture.

wine.name: Umbria Bianco "Arboreus", Paolo Bea
wine.review: This brilliant white from the legendary Paolo Bea estate is made from a regional version of Trebbiano called "Spoletino." The wine spends four years on the lees, giving it a golden hue and fleshy complexity. Dry, full-bodied, and with striking minerality. Here the vines are trained high off the ground, a technique that was meant to leave room to plant other crops underneath. The wine takes his name from the Italian work for tree, "albero."

wine.name: Montefalco Rosso "San Valentino", Paolo Bea
wine.review: Often some Sagrantino is incorporated into Montefalco Rosso wines to lend structure and dark-fruited opulence to Sangiovese and Montepulciano. This example from Paolo Bea is packed with plum and black cherry notes also hints of vanilla from having spent time in wood. The San Valentino sight is quite high-altitude, ensuring that the wine has good balance. The wine spends four years in a combination of tank and large oak barrel while "finding its identity," according to Neal Rosenthal, and is bottled unfiltered.

wine.name: Ch. Haut-Batailley, Pauillac
wine.review: Perhaps the wines of Château Haut-Batailley live in the shadow of those of its older sibling, Château Batailley. These little brother wines, however, are graced with a certain finesse and elegance absent in the wines of the elder sibling. Violet, raspberry, cassis, and earth, especially after time in the bottle.

wine.name: Le Mission Haut-Brion, Pessac-Leognan
wine.review: La Mission is located in the northern most part of Graves where the soil is chalky, gravely, and perfect for planting both Cabernet and Merlot. The wines are, of course, possessed of remarkable ability to age and pronounced burliness in their youth, especially in such a stunning vintage.

wine.name: Ch. Palmer, Margaux
wine.review: Château Palmer is a fabulous example of a left bank Bordeaux that is both elegant and modern. The wine is redolent of dark fruits, backberry, cassis, and plum. Hints of milk chocolate and toasty oak on the palate give way to tannins that are firm and silky. A wine for the ages.

wine.name: Ch. Pavie, St. Émilion
wine.review: This modern Château has achieved true excellence in the 2005 vintage, crafting a wine of incredible density and depth. Brimful of blackberry, raspberry, spice, and incense character, here is a wine that has all the critics in a tizzy.

wine.name: "La Pépie" Rouge, Dom. de la Pépière
wine.review: This is a Cot from Marc Ollivier, best-known for his incredible Muscadets. This shows pure Malbec fruit in a balanced and clean format with low alcohol and nice acidity.

wine.name: Eliseo Silva Chardonnay
wine.review: Here is a lovely example of cool-climate Chardonnay from the New World. Lots of clean apple notes on the nose, along with pretty floral aromas. Round in texture on the palate, this shows clear evidence of partial malolactic fermentation; the wine is nonetheless impeccably balanced, with juicy acidity and the faintest touch of wood.

wine.name: Rock Point, Pinot Noir
wine.review: This Oregon Pinot Noir is particularly Burgundian, which is probably why we love it so much! The nose is full of brambly, dried red fruits that carry through to the palate. This wine is all about delicacy and finesse.

wine.name: Eliseo Silva Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: This Cabernet has all the ripe, brooding, dark fruit that you, passionate Cabernet lover, could want. The finish is full of licorice and sweet, mouth-coating tannins.

wine.name: Abadia la Arroyada Tinto Joven, Ribera del Duero
wine.review: This unique little Ribera marries the juiciness of Beaujolais with the dark fruit of traditional Ribera. It's quite fruit-forward and completely unoaked, making it nice to quaff on its own and brilliant with a simple platter of cheeses and charcuterie.

wine.name: Ch. Rouget, Pomerol
wine.review: This was a very successful vintage for Château Rouget. The wine shows a remarkable amount of ripeness on the nose, giving at once aromas of macerated red cherries and roasting meat. The palate is quite supple and the finish full of mouth-coating tannins that would make this bottle an apt match for your Sunday roast.

wine.name: Ch. La Tour Blanche, Sauternes
wine.review: This consistently fabulous Sauternes estate takes the utmost care in the vineyards and the cellar, restricting yields and sorting meticulously. Lesser grapes are declassified to the estate's second label and all that they produce sees the inside of a barrel for at least one year. A bottle to buy with confidence.

wine.name: Avinyó Cava Brut Rosado
wine.review: This full-bodied pink sparkler is reminiscent of cranberries and ripe cherries on the nose. Don't be fooled by its overtly fruity bouquet; the wine is dry and structured on the palate with fabulous acidity and hints of tannin that make it an excellent partner to salmon and tuna.

wine.name: Chinon Picasses, Raffault
wine.review: There's nothing more interesting than drinking great wine that's been aged. This bottle is showing very well considering it's a teen at the moment. Full of leather, spice and red berried fruits. Very approachable and lithe on the palate. Excellent with earth-driven foods or cheeses.

wine.name: Clendenon Family Vineyards, Petit Verdot
wine.review: This Bordeaux family has had ample success on the Bien Nacido vineyards they leased in 1994. Their Petit Verdot undergoes a long extraction and fermentation in open barrels followed by several years of oak aging. It is a generous and fruit driven wine with an elegant 13% alcohol.

wine.name: Clendenen Family Vineyards, Nebbiolo
wine.review: When you taste this exceedingly pretty Nebbiolo, you'll be surprised to find that it comes from California. From its rosy, earthy perfume to its beautifully extracted tannins, the wine reminds us of a Piedmontese Nebbiolo. The wine sees 48 months in barrel, so be prepared for hints of vanilla as well.

wine.name: Crémant de Bourgogne, Moissenet-Bonnard
wine.review: Here's a fabulous bottle of bubbly. It's priced reasonalby; it's great to drink; and you don't have to think too much about it. Mostly Pinot Noir with a touch of Chardonnay, this Crémant is full of almond flesh notes and yellow fruits with firm bubbles and a dry finish.

wine.name: Loriot, Blanc de Noirs Brut Réserve
wine.review: A unique bottle that of 100% Pinot Meunier Champagne that is enticingly ripe and earthy on the palate. Full of citrus, especially meyer lemon, this bubbly from Vallée de la Marne has loads of zesty bubbles that show no signs of waning after time in the glass. A real treat.

wine.name: Amarone "Crosara de le Strie", Coati Bruno
wine.review: Brother and sister team Enrico and Elena do a spectacular job with this irresistible, milk chocolate-y Amarone. The nose is full of dark fruits, the palate plush and fleshy. If you're feeling inspired, try this with braised venison for a decadent experience.

wine.name: Beaujolais-Villages "La Lutine", Dom. des Terres Vivantes
wine.review: This wine is an irresistibly lively pink-hued ruby red in the glass, a color that captures the spirit of the wine. On the nose and palate, the wine gives plenty of juicy Gamay fruit along with a healthy dose of granite mineral on the finish. The name "Lutine" means "little elfin girl" - which seems an apt image to associate with this light, joyous wine. The estate farms sustainably with no chemical pesticides, and uses only natural yeasts.

wine.name: Grüner Veltliner "Freiheit", Nigl
wine.review: From a top producer in Kremstal comes this delightfully steely and herbal white wine. Vibrant green notes and white pepper greet the nose making way for a well fruited, balanced, and food-friendly palate.

wine.name: Pernand-Vergelesses Blanc 1er Cru "Îles de Vergelesses", Chandon de Briailles
wine.review: Chandon de Briailles is one of our favorite Burgundy estates because of the care the propietors take in both the vineyard and the cellar, farming sustainably and eshewing chemicals and pesticides. The whites are noted for their impeccable balance and ability to age, in good vintages, for 5-10 years. This is marked by copious white flowers and green fruits on the nose and palate. The estate is extremely traditional; they use old oak and value acidity.

wine.name: Hewitt Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: This wine is quite elegant considering the rich, concentrated flavors of ripe currant, black cherry and plum. The finish will linger on your palate with hints of toffee and expresso.

wine.name: Casa Lapostolle "Clos Apalta"
wine.review: Here is an award-winning Bordeaux blend based on the Carmenère variety, which used to be widely planted in Bordeaux and now thrives in Chile. The wine is made from the estates oldest vines, the berries picked and de-stemmed by hand for the highest quality wine. Big and age-worthy.

wine.name: Riesling Spätlese "Meddersheimer Rheingrafenberg", Hexamer
wine.review: Quartz is to the Nahe what slate is to the Mosel. Enjoy this beautifully peachy, minerally, ripe bottle on its own or with spicy southeast Asian fare.

wine.name: Diel de Diel, Schlossgut Diel
wine.review: "Imagine if Bob Parker owned one of the 1st-Growth Bordeaux." -Terry Theise. Armin Diel is Germany's preeminent wine writer; his clout as a pundit is only surpassed by his skill as a vigneron. This is an oddball blend of Pinot Gris, Chardonnay, Riesling, and Pinot Blanc that sees some time in barrel.

wine.name: La Bohème Rouge, Auvergne
wine.review: The Auvergne is known more for its blue cheese than its red wine - but what wine it does produce is extremely interesting. This Gamay is beautifully gamey with lots of funk on the nose and mineral on the palate. Enjoy this bottle of dark-fruited deliciousness after a quick decanting.

wine.name: Pétillant Natural Demi-Sec "Festejar!", Le Bohème
wine.review: An ideal breakfast wine, this is bursting with fresh strawberry and cherry on the nose, and a touch of sweetness on the palate. Since it is disgorged before its fermentation finishes, the wine ends up delightfully bubbly; it's almost reminiscent of a Lambic beer. "Festejar," by the way, means "Faire la fête" or "to party" in Occitan.

wine.name: Clos Vougeot Grand Cru, Mugneret-Gibourg
wine.review: This estate, currently run by the two daughters of Georges Mugneret, is ultra-meticulous in the vineyard and the cellar, as well as ultra traditional. They own 14 hectares from which they produce barely 2,000 cases a year.

wine.name: Nuits-St-Georges 1er Cru "Chaignots", Mugneret-Gibourg
wine.review: This Nuits is full of earthy and brambly, black fruit character. The estate is quite traditional, macerating for 10 days on the skins before fermentation. The wine spends 18 months in barrel, of which only a small percent is new.

wine.name: Rouchottes-Chambertin Grand Cru, Mugneret-Gibourg
wine.review: The Rouchottes Grand Cru produces rich, velvety incarnations of Pinot Noir. This one shows black fruit on the nose, also truffle and vanilla. After 10 years in the cellar, watch it open up to reveal a complex meatiness. Decant.

wine.name: Vosne-Romanée, Mugneret-Gibourg
wine.review: A delightful village wine from Vosne-Romanée and a great estate. Mugneret-Gibourg is run by three women who work out of 500 year old cellar! If you have yet to experience old school Burgundy from the Côtes de Nuits, now is the time.

wine.name: Yellow and Blue Torrontés
wine.review: Here's a tasty way to be environmentally conscious: This floral-scented, lychee-flavored liter of white wine is crisp, clean, and makes a perfect apéritif. Its lightweight, recyclable packaging cuts down on its carbon footprint, and it even stays fresh in your fridge for days on end.

wine.name: Ornellaia
wine.review: A Super Tuscan based on Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot and Cabernet Franc. A full-bodied, hearty red wine that's impressive all around.

wine.name: Cakebread Zinfandel
wine.review: This Zinfandel from Cakebread is bursting with black fruit and peppery spice. On the nose, you'll get plum, blackberry, and cracked pepper. The palate is voluptuous and has enough structure for five years in the cellar. Drink this with pork barbeque.

wine.name: Nuits-St.-George 1er Cru "Les Pruliers", Gouges
wine.review: At the Gouges estate, Pierre manages the vineyards while Christian oversees the cellar. It's a division of labor that seems to work well for them. This estate produces some of the most elegant wines in the village. With 14.5 hectares of 35 year old vines, the Gouges brothers clearly live up to the reputation established by their father, Henri.

wine.name: Savigny-lès-Beaune 1er Cru "Narbantons", Mongeard-Mugneret
wine.review: A concentrated and age-worthy Pinot from 50 year old vines. The wine sees time in new barrel (35%) and has the structure to age but is also possessed of enough berry fruit to be approachable young.

wine.name: Gavi, Cà Adua
wine.review: There are some insipid bottles of Gavi out there, but this isn't one of them: the Cà Adua is the type of white wine we get excited about. The nose offers pure and precise aromas of yellow fruit, oregano, fresh herbs, and wet stones. On the palate the fruit is rich, satisfying, and intense. An absolute treat that we were delighted to find.

wine.name: Timorasso "Sassobraglia", Fontanassa, Val Borbera
wine.review: The Timorasso grape is a specialty of southern Piedmont. This one comes from the Valley of Borbera, which separates Piedmont from Liguria. The wine has lovely, bright acidity and delightful pear skin notes on the nose.

wine.name: Ghost Pines Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Louis M. Martini winery blends Cabernet Sauvignon from both Napa and Sonoma vineyards to create Ghost Pines. Dark berry fruit blends in with toasted vanilla flavors with firm tannins.

wine.name: Michael Mondavi Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Full of the intrepid spirit that makes this winemaking family such a paradigm for success.

wine.name: Beaujolais "l'Ancien" VV Terres Dorées, Brun
wine.review: Terres Dorées refers to the golden limestone in the area. Jean-Paul Brun, the Duke of Beaujolais, has won renown for the purity, delicacy and finesse of his wine.

wine.name: Sablet, Les Deux Anges
wine.review: This is a classic Côtes du Rhône in that it has an abundance of approachable dark fruit and warm spice. There is good structure here as well: a nice dose of Syrah is mixed in with the Grenache to impart complexity.

wine.name: Bourgogne Blanc, Clotilde Davenne
wine.review: Clotilde's wines are all complex and beguiling. This one has lots of texture on the palate that seems to indicate oak aging - yet the wine sees no wood! The nose in very citrusy, a flavor which, along with mineral, carries through to the palate and finish. Take our advice: decant this wine before you enjoy it.

wine.name: Crémant de Bourgogne "Extra Brut", Clotilde Davenne
wine.review: Delightfully dry and abundantly ripe, this Crémant offers beautiful white fruits and citrus on the nose. The palate and finish have a loveable, tangy quality. Like her other wines, this bubbly in extremely well made.

wine.name: Soave Classico "Montesei", Le Battistelle
wine.review: These Garganega grapes are grown in volcanic soil, which imparts a powdery, saline complexity to the wine. A very aromatic nose full of pears and white flowers complements tangy fruits and a long finish.

wine.name: Sauvignon Blanc, Balter
wine.review: This Sauvignon is more reserved on the nose than the typical Sancerre or New Zealand Sauv. Blanc with much less grass and grapefruit. The wine is focused, steely, and subtle with a fabulous flavor profile and excellent balance.

wine.name: Ladoix, Domaine Petitot
wine.review: The 2005 Burgundy vintage (along with talented growers, of course) produced ripe, sweet-fruited wines from less prestigious villages, at prices that normal humans could afford. This red wine is full of licorice, red fruit, and earth. Decant for best results.

wine.name: Frappato, FiaNobile
wine.review: It's hard to believe that a place as far south as Sicily produced such a delicate and light-bodied wine. With an abundance of ripe raspberry fruit on the nose and palate, this Burgundian wine has more tannin and mineral on the finish than your average Frappato.

wine.name: La Bohème Blanc, Marc Pesnot
wine.review: When Marc Pesnot refers to his young vines, he means they're "only" 30-50 years old! Needless to say, this young-vine cuvée is quite dense with ripe fruit, balanced out by bracing acidity and great minerality. The nose has seashell hints (typical of western Loire Valley soil) mingled with citrus notes. Truly a fresh and lovely offering.

wine.name: Ploussard "L'Uva Arbosiana", Dom. de la Tournelle
wine.review: A new producer from the Jura! This is made using carbonic maceration, which makes the wine irresistibly fruity, even though it's completely dry. Extremely light in color, it has full sauvage notes and fresh appeal.

wine.name: Pinot Noir, Les Chemins de Bassac
wine.review: This lithe and cheerful Pinot Noir hails from the Côtes de Thongue in the south of France. It is full of clean red fruit flavors like cherries and cranberries.

wine.name: Il Bosco, d'Alessandro
wine.review: Massimo d'Alessandro discovered that Syrah flourishes in Cortona in the 1980s. The hilly Il Bosco vineyard encourages low yields, resulting in a deep and concentrated wine. Il Bosco spend six months in new barrels and six months in used ones. Fruity and peppery with hints of oak-spice and a silky mouthfeel.

wine.name: Alma Rosa Pinot Noir, "Encantada Vineyard"
wine.review: Richard Sanford was the first person to plant vines in Santa Rita Hills and is legendary in California winemaking. The 100-acre Encantada vineyard is planted to seven different Pinot Noir clones. This relatively full-bodied Pinot has notes of cherry, cola, coffee, and pomegranate on the nose and rustic tannins on the finish.

wine.name: Côtes-du-Rhône Blanc "From the Tank", Estezargues
wine.review: A natural wine that is full of mellow, orchard flavors.

wine.name: Ch. Haut-Mayne, Graves
wine.review: Here is a big, plush example of red Graves. There is a healthy dose of gravelly mineral on the nose and finish; the wine really speaks of its terroir, which is a huge plus in our book! This has quite a bit of skin tannin and a touch of oak, so be sure to enjoy it with food.

wine.name: Ch. La Raze Beauvallet, Cru Bourgeois Médoc
wine.review: This excellent value in Cru Bourgeois combines an array of dark fruits on the nose with an array of red ones on the palate. The structure is pleasing and ripe yet maintains its essential Bordeaux flavors and textures.

wine.name: Ch. Moulin de Canhaut, Médoc
wine.review: A full-bodied and modern style of Bordeaux exhibiting some spicy, new wood notes and an abundance of ripe, dark fruit. Despite its modern leanings, all the flavors here are very well-integrated.

wine.name: Monte Volpe Primo Rosso
wine.review: This is a fascinating blend of grapes: Zinfandel, Sangiovese, Negroamaro, Carignan, and Nebbiolo. The wine shows lots of jammy fruit on the nose and offers quite a juicy mouthful.

wine.name: Quattro Mani, Exto Gredic Vineyard (toh-kai)
wine.review: From a vineyard that has been Biodynamic since 1820 (!) comes this remarkable Slovenian treat. Cloudy with a light golden straw color, this bottle is full of milky richness on the nose and palate, combined with green herbal notes that bring it all to life. An unusual, unforgettable, outstanding white wine.

wine.name: Primitivo, Soleto
wine.review: This is a modern style, unoaked Primitivo that is full of sweet fruit and has a very lush, pleasing texture. A perfect sipper if you're not planning to have food, this is also an appropriate bottle with classic Texas barbeque in sweet-spicy red sauce.

wine.name: Broadbent Madeira 10 Yr. Malmsey
wine.review: This dark, amber, coffee-scented Madeira will bring a smile to your face after a meal. With tangy dark fruits and plenty of woodsy character, it shows all the caramel complexity we like in these special fortified wines.

wine.name: Colheita Madeira, Broadbent
wine.review: Smooth with a nice, full texture and nutty finish. "Colheita," meaning "vintage" Ports and Madeiras are required to spend 7 and 5 years respectively in oak before release. This example is pefect as a dessert with Manchego and quince paste.

wine.name: Bourgogne Rouge "Clos des Vignes Maynes", Guillot
Ch. Haut Brisey, Médoc Cru Bourgeois
wine.review: Look out Cabernet lovers! Here is a big mouthful of dark, pulpy, voluptuous fruit. The tannins are ripe and indicative of a successful vintage and, while, the wine sees some wood, the nose and palate aren't oaky. Perfect both for left bank lovers and Napa Cab fans.

wine.name: "Z" Bordeaux Rouge
wine.review: This medium bodied and unoaked Bordeaux is deliciously quaffable. The nose is full of dark, earthy hints, and the palate resonantes with sweet, jammy flavors. The finish has complex, coffee notes. A thoroughly enjoyable, modern wine.

wine.name: La Chapelle d'Escurac, Médoc
wine.review: An elegant and old world style of Cabernet based Bordeaux which offers notes of cassis and graphite on the nose and palate. Full of complex, stony minerality.

wine.name: Castillo Real, Monastrell
wine.review: A meat and smokey Spanish offering with lots of dark fruit and a delightful rustic edge.

wine.name: Domaine Carneros Brut Rose
wine.review: 58 % Pinot Noir and 42% Chardonnay make up the blend of this outstanding rose that emphasizes fruity and floral characteristics.

wine.name: Artezin Zinfandel
wine.review: The perfect wine for your next barbeque or pasta party. Raspberry, pepper and just the right amount of spice.

wine.name: Copain Pinot Noir "Tous Ensemble" Anderson
wine.review: This wine is made by Wells Guthrie (yes, Woody's grand nephew!) There is plenty of brambly, spicy fruit and mineral here. Wells has spent time in France gathering inspiration from Burgundian vignerons and, as a result, he has lowered the alcohol content of his wines to ensure food-friendliness.

wine.name: Wyatt Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Imagine sticking your nose in a bag of dried cranberries. That's what this wine smells like. Ripe and berried and nutritious tasting with no perceptible oak. Cali Cab for those tired of the typical, brawny, cassis-laden profile of the typical Cali Cab.

wine.name: Copain Syrah, "Tous Ensemble" Mendocino County
wine.review: A dark and inky Syrah from a much-loved Sonoma producer. This bottle has pleasant hints of chalk amidst a mouthful of dark, ripe fruit. Though the wine may see the inside of a barrel, it is refreshingly free of oak flavors.

wine.name: Heida-Paien "Les Bernunes", Caloz
wine.review: If you thought Savagnin was only grown in the Jura, here is your chance to try a Swiss expression of the grape with totally different minerality. Pithy with rich citrus notes on the nose and palate.

wine.name: Ermitage de Vétroz "Les Ruinettes" Flétri, Serge Roh
wine.review: An entirely botritized Marsanne from the Valais region of Switzerland. This bottle shows balanced sweetness and longevity that will clearly benefit with years of aging. On the nose, you'll get notes of pineapple and yellow plums.

wine.name: Fié Gris, Dom. de l'Aujardière
wine.review: In the Nantais region of the western Loire Valley, winemaker Eric Chevalier has some rare plantings of the white Fié Gris grape variety. Some claim that Fié Gris is a parent to Sauvignon Blanc, while others believe that it's a mere Sauvignon Blanc mutation. Whatever the truth may be, you can taste the family resemblance. Full of ripe, fresh herbs, white flowers, and minerals on the palate, this dry white wine has a round texture and bright acidity, allowing it to marry well with nearly anything from the sea.

wine.name: Cerdon de Bugey, Demi-Sec, Lingot Martin
wine.review: A delightful off-dry sparkling rosé made from the local grapes Gamay and Poulsard. It's full of redcurrant and strawberry flavors, with a dusting of powdered sugar. Low in alcohol (8%), but high in palate-pleasing ripe fruits, this should be drunk lightly chilled as an apéritif.

wine.name: Szent Ilona Borhaz "Tardicio"
wine.review: This slightly oxidative blend of indigenous Hungarian varieties tastes of the minerally, volcanic soil that produced it. There is a lees-y weight and richness to the wine, coming partly from the winery's choice to age in neutral barrels.

wine.name: Barolo "Monprivato", G. Mascarello
wine.review: Traditional Barolo with a focus that's seldom matched by most producers in Piedmont. You'll find aromas of rose petals, red currants and red cherries. A structured and balanced red wine to withstand decades of age - especially in this large format.

wine.name: Barolo "Monprivato", G. Mascarello
wine.review: From a very traditional producer and a superb vintage comes this stunning Barolo. The 6 hectare Monprivato vineyard is widely considered to be the Piedmontese eqiuvalent of a Grand Cru. The impressive skill of fascinating winemaker, Mauro Mascarello, is demonstrated in this bottle.

wine.name: El Castro de Valtuille, Mencia Joven, Raul Perez
wine.review: Here is an interesting offering from Bierzo. The fruits are quite dark, ripe, and concentrated, yet there's a lithe, balanced tone to the palate that makes this bottle a real treat.

wine.name: Onyx Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: A dark and brambly Cabernet that effortlessly mingles Old and New world styles. The nose is full of jammy cassis notes, while the palate is quite structured. This wine sees 14 months in new French oak, which imparts subtle yet undeniable spicy notes.

wine.name: Minervois "Le Régal du Loup", Le Loup Blanc
wine.review: This producer is something of a Carignan specialist, with a reputation for brilliant and charming Carignan-based wines. This one is 50% Carignan, with the rest Grenache and Syrah. Compellingly full with red and dark berries with rich, nutritious tannins.

wine.name: Gewurztraminer, Binner
wine.review: The aromatics here are a bit reserved, making this a great starter Gewürztraminer. This has honeydew and floral undertones on the nose; the palate is dry, with the characteristic viscosity of Alsatian white wines.

wine.name: Chablis 1er Cru "Vaugiraut", Oudin
wine.review: This Chablis hails from less than one hectare of clay soil. With plenty of bracing acidity and tangy minerality, this is a wine that begs for seafood. A Chablis that can and will age gracefully for a couple of years.

wine.name: VdP de Mont Caume "La Chance", Comptoirs de Magdala
wine.review: This is a lively yet well-structured blend of Mourvèdre, Grenache, and Cinsault that is remarkably fresh for being from such a southerly locale. Full of ripe, sweet fruit and juicy acidity.

wine.name: "Amourvèdre", Vin de Table, Comptoirs de Magdala
wine.review: A stupendous Vin de Table from Antoine Pouponneau in Provence. Based on Mourvèdre, as the name might suggest.

wine.name: Morgon "Côte du Py", Foillard
wine.review: Truly a beautiful Cru Beaujolais full of incredibly expressive red fruit, sumac, and tart cherry. These aromas leap from the glass and are complimented by juicy, lip-smacking acidity. A wine that delights like a spring romp in the field.

wine.name: "Chut Derain", Vin Mousseaux Brut, Derain
wine.review: Extremely tasty Méthode Traditionelle sparkling Aligoté! This wine is loaded with waxy, floral fruit and quince on the nose. The palate is fully of zesty acidity and minerality. A bottle that cries out for oysters.

wine.name: Bourgogne Hautes-Côtes de Beaune Blanc, Montchovet
wine.review: A tasty white Burgundy with lots of yellow fruit and leesy richness on the palate. Didier Montchovet is a relatively new vigneron making wine around Pommard. He ferments in barrel, but the final product is not oaky.

wine.name: Bourgogne Grande Ordinaire, Montchovet
wine.review: This is Gamay-based Bourgogne from 50-year-old vines. Phillip the Bold couldn't possibly have gotten rid of all Burgundy Gamay in the 14th century. Expressive, with lots of wild raspberry on the nose and rustic, minerally tannins on the finish.

wine.name: Bourgogne Hautes-Côtes de Beaune Rouge, Montchovet
