wine.review: A lovely, soft, ripe-fruited Burgundy that is ready to serve tonight. Montchovet does a slow fermentation in barrel, followed by a year of barrel age. Still, the wine is far from oaky and primarily shows plush charm.

wine.name: St. Nicholas de Bourgeuil "Graviers", Dom. de Mortier
wine.review: This approachable Cabernet Franc is made by two young men who began their winemaking careers about a decade ago. The nose has some funk (characteristic of Bourgeuil), while the palate offers more softness. We recommend food.

wine.name: St. Aubin Rouge 1er Cru "Sur le Sentier du Clou", Prudhon
wine.review: The most substantial of the reds from the Prudhon, showing gamey notes and tannic elements. A great match for époisse.

wine.name: Ch. du Champ des Treilles Blanc, Sainte-Foy Bordeaux
wine.review: A leesy white Bordeaux from the westernmost part of the region. Vinified in large wood vats, this wine combines softness of texture with the characteristic acidity of Sauv. Blanc.

wine.name: Le Brin de Chèvre, Christian Venier
wine.review: A round, floral, apple-fruited, and absolutely delicious Chenin Blanc. The wine has brilliant, ripe density on the palate, with a streak of irresistible acid and mineral.

wine.name: Marques de Montemor, Vinho Regional Alentejano
wine.review: A dark, plush bottle full of lusty unoaked character and big fruits. An ideal choice if you're having burgers on the grill!

wine.name: Champs des Treilles Rouge "Le Petit Champ", Sainte-Foy Bordeaux
wine.review: A medium bodied, Merlot based offering full of clay and graphite notes. Very old world. Very delicious.

wine.name: "Fou du roi", Le Temps des Cerises
wine.review: This excellent VdT hails from the St. Chinian area of the northern Languedoc.The wine is loaded with super delightful dark fruits that please the palate with their Grenache-y easiness.

wine.name: Montepulciano d'Abruzzo, Arche'
wine.review: An quaffable mouthful of dark, unoaked fruit from central Italy. Perfect for every day drinking with or without food.

wine.name: Sangiovese Rubicone, Arche'
wine.review: An easy drinking Sangiovese with plenty of jammy fruit forward flavors. Quaffable and balanced with soft tannins.

wine.name: Dolcetto D'Alba, Burlotto
wine.review: This is a great Dolcetto of the dusty, mineral-laden, old school variety. Floral notes are complimented by dark, grapey fruit and a back-bone that is fairly tannic for Dolcetto. The finish offers limestone and chalk mineral character.

wine.name: Langhe Freisa, Burlotto
wine.review: Freisa, a specialty of the Langhe, produces remarkably berried and pure fruited wines. This example is dark and possessed of delicious wild raspberry notes. On the palate, you'll get some seed tannins, making the wine an especially apt food partner. This wine will play well with rich and fatty dishes.

wine.name: Galil Mountain Barbera
wine.review: Wonderful black and blue berries along with plum and chocolate. This wine needs to aerate for a while before serving

wine.name: Pommery Brut Royal Kosher Champagne
wine.review: Kosher Champagne at a reasonable price!

wine.name: Evans & Tate Margaret River Cabernet Sau
wine.review: A big, dark red from Down Under. Blackcurrant, plums, and chocolate explode on the palate, with the ripe fruit balanced out by nice smooth tannins.

wine.name: Zinfandel "Old Vine", Seghesio
wine.review: If you love the regular Sonoma Zin from Seghesio, it's time to try the old vine. The wine is dark, inky, and concentrated. Leathery notes mingle with plush fruits resulting in a complex, satisfying bottle.

wine.name: St. Laurent "Klassisch", Rosi Schuster
wine.review: A complex Austrian red showing peppercorn, cumin, and dark berry notes on the nose. St. Laurent is a relative of Pinot Noir, so expect a lighter style of wine marked by the great acidity that is a strength of cool-climate wines. Delicious, ripe, and unwooded.

wine.name: Volnay "Grands Poisots", Boillot
wine.review: Louis Boillot is so much more than just the eager husband of truly A-list Chambolle producer, Ghislaine Bathod. His wines, though very different than Barthod's are beautifullly expressive of their terroir. The Volnay is dark, black-fruited, and peppery.

wine.name: Gevrey-Chambertin, Boillot
wine.review: The 2006 vintage in Burgundy, while not offering the showiness and powerful structure of the 2005 vintage, offers wines with subtlety and purity, wines of classical beauty that showcase the loveliness of the Pinot variety.

wine.name: Bourgogne Rouge "Bons Batons", G. Barthod
wine.review: It's no wonder that Ghislaine Barthod's wines have so much finesse, she learned from her father, Gaston, who came from the Jura, where light-handed elegance is the order of the day. Simply the most refined Bourgogne ever.

wine.name: Gevrey-Chambertin "Aux Échezeaux", Fourrier
wine.review: Fourrier's wines are amongst the best in part because Jean-Marie only estate bottles wines from fruit of 30-plus year old vines. When young, the Gevrey typically shows some austerity in its tannins and minerality but will soften beautifully in the cellar.

wine.name: Ch. Dutruch Gand Poujeaux, Moulis-en-Médoc
wine.review: An interesting and fruit forward Bordeaux that offers classic dark berry and woodsy notes on the nose. The palate shows distinct hints of oak, enough wood, even, to hold this bottle for a couple of years. A blend of almost equal parts Cab and Merlot.

wine.name: Pallette Rosé, Château Simone
wine.review: This wine might be worth purchasing simply for its color, an eye-catching, neon pomegranate. The nose offers beautiful, complex dried fruit notes, while the palate is rich and intense with the structure of a red wine. A serious Rosé guaranteed to surprise and amaze... also to age.

wine.name: Muscadet, Dom. de la Pepière
wine.review: Great, refeshing Muscadet with vibrant minerality. Of course, this is perfect for oysters, but with its good round body, it's also great with light poultry or vegetable dishes. From a Practicing Organic estate.

wine.name: Monferrato Dolcetto "Nibio", Cascina degli Ulivi
wine.review: "Nibio" is an ancient name for Dolcetto and hearkens back to a time when the grape was widely planted around Gavi (those vineyards are now dedicated to the Cortese variety). This dark, earthy, and mineral-laden rendition of Dolcetto offers a fresh look at a grape known for its ebullient fruitiness. This 16-hectare estate is not only Biodynamic but also self-sustaining, in the sense that they raise everything from chickens to the yeasts they use in fermentation. Their wines are weirdly beautiful, compelling, and entirely worth experimenting with. The Dolcetto comes from the so-called "Terre Rosse": red, iron-rich soils that impart a distinctive mineral character to this wine.

wine.name: Côtes du Rhône, Parallèle 45, Jaboulet
wine.review: A standard-bearer in the Rhône, Jaboulet's "Parallèle 45" bottling is silky-smooth with smoky berry flavors. A good choice for hearty lamb shanks or duck dishes like cassoulet.

wine.name: Gamla White Riesling
wine.review: A touch of residual sugar makes this the ideal wine for those who want some sweetness but not too much.

wine.name: Gamla Chardonnay
wine.review: Citrus notes with a touch of oak makes this ideal for almost any chicken dish.

wine.name: Vinho Verde, Quinta Santa Maria
wine.review: A crisp and dry style of Vinho Verde that is richer and more complex than the average. Perfect with seafood.

wine.name: "Mosel St." Riesling, E. Clüsserath
wine.review: This refreshing and extremely well-priced Riesling offers pretty notes of peach, apple, and lime on the nose. The palate has a touch of sweetness, but the wine is fairly dry compared to most German Rieslings. A delightful find.

wine.name: Dom. des Sabines, Lalande de Pomerol
wine.review: This is an approachable yet complex example of right bank Bordeaux that offers a mouthful of both red and black fruits. Merlot based, the wine has characteristic notes of plum and spice.

wine.name: Ribera Sacra "Viña Caneiro", D. Ventura
wine.review: An elegant example of the Mencía grape that is reminiscent of a juicy cru Beaujolais. With grapey ease, lithe fruit, and great acidity, this cool-climate treat might change your perception of Spanish wines.

wine.name: Abando Crianza, Rioja
wine.review: Here is a traditional Rioja showing all the earthy, dried-spice character we have come to love in old-fashioned Rioja. This Crianza is a step away from the modern oak-driven style of Rioja that dominates the market nowadays. Perfect with beef.

wine.name: Atticus John Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: A blend of Cabernet with touches of Merlot and Petit Verdot for added fruitiness and complexity. There is a minty freshness on the nose that tells of some time in barrel. The fruit here is sourced from Rutherford and Stag's Leap, resulting a very high quality wine.

wine.name: St.-Romain Blanc "Les Perrières", Buisson
wine.review: A light-handed style of white Burgundy with emphasis on the pear and apple flavors of Chardonnay. This wine shows earth and mineral notes on the nose and palate, making it a great choice with lots of different dishes. Balanced and succulent.

wine.name: Rueda Verdejo "Casamaro", Garciarevalo
wine.review: A complex and exuberantly fruity white wine made from both young and extremely old Verdejo vines (145 years). On the nose, this offers an array of aromas - from peaches, to citrus, to tropical fruits - that carry through to the palate. Garciarevalo practices sustainable farming and makes this wine from 100% free-run juice, which is vinified in stainless steel to preserve its freshness. The wine has remarkable intensity, and stays crisp and clean on the finish: It’s an excellent choice for people who love Sauvignon Blanc.

wine.name: Zweigelt "Riedencuvée", Glatzer
wine.review: An elegant Austrian red that offers loads of violet, spice, and berry on the nose and palate. Hints of blackberry and herb interplay culminating in a lovely, minerally finish.

wine.name: Efron's Cave "Jerusalem White" Reserve Kosher
wine.review: Light and floral with nice acidity. This white would be even better with food.

wine.name: Shemesh Cabernet Sauvignon, Kosher
wine.review: This yummy Cab from the Negev would easily please those who usually reach for bottles from California. A rich, earthy nose, ripe fruit on the palate, and a soft tannic finish make this a great pairing for hearty fare.

wine.name: VdP du Mont-Caume, Jean Pierre Gaussen
wine.review: A structured and dark-fruited blend made mostly of Mourvèdre, hailing from Bandol in Provence. Gaussen uses more Grenache than is allowed under the Bandol AOC rules, so this is classified as a Vin de Pays.

wine.name: Kenwood Chardonnay
wine.review: A fresh and fruity California-style Chardonnay with just a touch of oak. Straightforward, crisp flavors make this a supremely crowd-pleasing white wine.

wine.name: Valdeorras Godello, A. Coroa
wine.review: This Godello truly puts all other Godellos to shame. From 5 unique parcels of mostly slate and granite soil, much care is taken in the farming and wine making at this small estate. The wine spends up to 5 months on the lees and is extra ripe and full of leesy honey and green apple notes.

wine.name: Zin 91 Old Vine Zinfandel
wine.review: At age 91, American wine pioneer Hubert Opici decided to produce an old-vine Zinfandel to commemorate his 75 years in the wine business. A bold and rich red wine, this is layered with black fruit and spice.

wine.name: Conquista, Malbec
wine.review: This red wine from Mendoza hits all the right notes. An aromatic cherry nose and big round tannins make this a great entry-level Malbec.

wine.name: Manyana, Bodegas San Valero
wine.review: This DO Tempranillo has a palate full of sweet fruit. A healthy dose of acidity and a solid tannic structure that make this a well balanced wine fit for quaffing or enjoying with food.

wine.name: Öko Pinot Grigio, Veneto
wine.review: This Pinot Grigio has a fresh nose and nice balance.

wine.name: ReLeaf, South Africa
wine.review: This South African red blends Cabernet Sauvignon, Merlot, and Shiraz for a good cause.

wine.name: Pommard 1er Cru "Jarollières", J.M. Boillot
wine.review: A delicious and robust Pinot full of red fruit notes and iron-y terroir.

wine.name: Chablis, Dom. Louis Michel et Fils
wine.review: A crispy style of Chablis showing lovely orchard fruits on the nose and mouth watering minerality on the palate.

wine.name: Muscadet, Estelle Sauvion
wine.review: A beautiful Muscadet for everyday drinking. More full-bodied in style, it is an excellent dry white wine to sip alongside shellfish or cured salmon dishes.

wine.name: Bonnes Mares, Dom. Bruno Clair
wine.review: The Grand Cru of Bonnes Mares lies partly in Morey-St.-Denis and partly in Chambolle-Musigny, with the result that the wines have the power and structure of Morey coupled with the prettiness of Chambolle.

wine.name: Maranges 1er Cru "La Fussière", Morey
wine.review: The wines of Maranges, especiallly in this particular vintage, have a lively zestiness that is charming at the table. This one can be held for several years on enjoyed on the spot.

wine.name: Marsannay Blanc, Dom. Bruno Clair
wine.review: A crisp, dry Chardonnay from the northern part of the Côte d'Or.

wine.name: Blagny "La Pièce sous le Bois", Matrot
wine.review: Blagny is nestled right up against Meursault, giving the wines of this village very interesting minerality. Light and laden with cherry fruit.

wine.name: Volnay-Santenots, Matrot
wine.review: A rich, thought-provoking, and complex red Burgundy from an esteemed village in the Côte de Nuits.

wine.name: Ch. La Rame, Bordeaux Blanc
wine.review: This is a crisp and clean white Bordeaux that has a lovely mouth-filling texture and pithy fruit character. As much as we adore the lean and mineraled Loire Valley take on Sauvignon Blanc, we also enjoy this rounder style, which is unique to Bordeaux.

wine.name: Jurançon Sec "Chant des Vignes", Dom. Cauhapé
wine.review: This exotic 100% Gros Manseng should be on your to drink list if you like stone fruit aromas, racy acidity, and crunchy minerality. An enchanting wine that is both round in the mouth and bright and nervy on the palate.

wine.name: Fronsac, Ch. du Fort Pontus
wine.review: A fresh and red fruited offering that dances on the palate, enlivened by a firm and minerally finish.

wine.name: Weinert Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Weinert is currently one of our favorite producers, mainly for their ability to intergrate Old World finesse into decidedly New World wines like this one. This Cabernet Sauvignon packs all the punch of a Napa Cab with great cassis fruit and soft vanilla oak flavors. There is something really special about the balance, too, and it elevates this bottle above the sea of great Cabs out there.

wine.name: Weinert Malbec
wine.review: A rich and sumptuous Malbec showing all the black fruit and spicy oak you could want in a full-bodied, Argentine wine. This fruit-forward offering will delight you on a cold night or with steaks on the grill.

wine.name: Volnay 1er Cru "Clos des Chenes", Gaunoux
wine.review: Neal Rosenthal describes these Burgundies as being wines that "whisper rather than shout." We think this is an excellent point and we love the wines because of this trait. Elegant and redolent of their terroir.

wine.name: Zweigelt, Dürnberg Falkensteiner Rieden
wine.review: Deliciously fruity and quaffable, this liter bottle is perfect for parties. This red wine is full of soft and approachable black fruits, with subtle tannins and a hint of zesty minerality on the finish.

wine.name: Grüner Veltliner, Dürnberg Falkensteiner Rieden
wine.review: A fresh, green, and zippy style of Grüner that opens up in the glass to reveal a host of complex apple and pear skin notes. There's a distinct sweet and powdery note to the nose that makes it a real crowd pleaser.

wine.name: Grüner Veltliner "Rabenstein", Dürnberg Falkensteiner Rieden
wine.review: A complex and yellow-fruited Grüner that shows lovely round character in the mouth. This is definitely a full and plush rendition of the grape that will delight you if you're not a fan of its more herbal and citric renditions.

wine.name: Bourgogne Aligoté, Marcillet
wine.review: The naturally high acidity of Aligoté is tamed in this version, which is softened by spending some time in old wood. This is a citrusy and fairly rich example of Burgundy's "other" white grape.

wine.name: Tishbi Cabernet Sauvignon, Kosher
wine.review: Lush ripe fruit on the nose and pallate make this is great addition to the holiday table.

wine.name: Chambolle-Musigny 1er Cru "Aux Combottes", Barthod
wine.review: Refined and elegant Pinot from a vintage that produced wines of thought-provoking complexity.

wine.name: Dürkheimer Spielberg Scheurebe Spätlese, Darting
wine.review: Scheurebe is a great variety to experiment with if you're looking for a fresh faced German. Full of succulent fruit and flowers on the nose and balanced sweetness on the palate.

wine.name: Kenwood, Red Table Wine
wine.review: A delicious, well balanced red wine with flavors of cherries and spices; medium-bodied with a fresh juicy character.

wine.name: You Are So Bubbly, Chaussard
wine.review: An extremely pretty and aromatic bubbly that is perfect for a spring afternoon. The nose sings out with white flowers, acacia honey, and succulent stone fruit notes. The palate seems ever so slightly off-dry, only because the fruit flavors are so ripe and juicy.

wine.name: Bourgogne Aligoté, Roulot
wine.review: Jean-Marc Roulot makes every drop of juice he touches turn to gold. The ethereal beauty behind his Aligoté is rooted in the marriage of ripeness and steely acidity and mineral. Generally an austere variety, Aligoté can have softer manifestations, of which this is one. Roulot is an ultra-traditionalist in the vineyard and cellar, using only 15% new oak as though to sand the angular edges of the wines.

wine.name: Brooklyn Oenology Chardonnay
wine.review: Burgundian Chardonnay by way of Brooklyn. Stainless steel fermentation, judicial use of malolactic and a brief stint in French Oak yield a wine that is subtle and balanced.

wine.name: Brooklyn Oenology Merlot
wine.review: Merlot sourced from the North Fork and vinified in Brooklyn. Classic notes of plum, coffee and chocolate present on the nose and palate. A firm tannic structure ensures this would stand up nicely to some red meat.

wine.name: Crozes-Hermitage "Chaubayou", Eric Rocher
wine.review: Make no mistake, this Crozes speaks of its terroir with an earthy nose full of black fruit, pepper, and characteristic barnyard aromas. For best results, decant over an hour or two and watch its aromas and flavors become increasingly expansive and approachable.

wine.name: Neyers Zinfandel "Pato Vineyard"
wine.review: A rich and chocolate-y Zin that shows great balance and enticing texture. The vines are 110-years old and produce fruit of complexity and concentration. Additionally, the grapes are left on the vine 30 days longer than the average harvest date in this vintage making for a superb finished product.

wine.name: Bianca di Casamatta, Bibi Graetz
wine.review: This is an ultra-approachable Vermentino adding pretty floral notes on the nose. It's fresh, vibrant white wine, perfect for summer weather.

wine.name: "Casamatta" Rosso, Bibi Graetz
wine.review: When we first tasted this delightful, unoaked Sangiovese, we found it ripe, earthy, and fruity in all the right places. Bibi Graetz has garnered much international acclaim, and we're beginning to understand why.

wine.name: Pecorino, Italo Pietrantonj
wine.review: From the oldest winery in Abruzzi comes this 100% Pecorino, fermented and aged in 1500-hectoliter old oak barrels (as oak barrels go, this is massive.) This unique, dry white wine offers coppery, citrusy, slightly oxidized notes on the nose and a concentrated, balanced palate. The slightly oxidized aromas are the result of the sheer difficulty of keeping such a large oak barrel topped up with wine. This is a great food wine that truly comes alive at the table.

wine.name: Montepulciano d'Abruzzo, Italo Pietrantonj
wine.review: This is great, rustic, and gulp-able Montepulciano from the oldest winery in Abruzzi. Lovely floral fruit on the nose mingles with the characteristic pencil and earth notes of the grape. The wine is unfined, unfiltered, and fermented in cement tanks. A fantastic wine and an excellent value.

wine.name: Montsant "Les Tallades", Els Guiamets
wine.review: The slate soil of Monstant gives this unoaked Syrah and Garnacha blend an enticing sleekness and cool, fresh minerality. The nose is powdery and sweet fruited but with a dark chocolate and ground coffee undertone. Juicy, dark fruits on the palate complement lithe structure.

wine.name: Black Box Pinot Grigio
wine.review: The newest addition to our best selling bag in box wine.

wine.name: Dolcetto d'Alba "Santo Stefano di Perno", G. Mascarello
wine.review: This is fantastic Dolcetto that balances approachability with the great structure of traditional wine-making. There is an intriguing geranium note to the nose that mingles deliciously with juicy, dark fruits.

wine.name: Mâcon-Villages "Sélection", Guillot-Broux
wine.review: Made in the town of "Chardonnay" (no we aren't kidding), this Mâcon should remind you very much of the original Guillot-Broux. Made by the same vigneron out of his neighbor's grapes, this wine is fresh and nutritious.

wine.name: "Montevertine", Montevertine
wine.review: For pure and unparalleled expression of the Sangiovese grape, look no further than Montevertine, an estate that gives new meaning to the word "Supertuscan." Aged 2 years in large barrels, this cuvée is almost all Sangiovese with a miniscule addition of Colorino. Concentrated and brooding in its youth, the wine will unfold spectacularly over time.

wine.name: Touraine Rosé Sparkling "Méthode Traditionelle", Sarl
wine.review: From the Côreau de Pizy comes this ever so slightly off dry pink sparkler made from the Pineau D'Aunis variety. Full of watermelon and strawberries on the nose and palate.

wine.name: Magerl, Sparkling Grüner Veltliner
wine.review: What?!? Sparkling Grüner Veltliner? Here is a dry and approachable bottle of bubbly with great herbal notes and ripe, citrus fruits. Extremely fresh on the nose and palate.

wine.name: Ch. Latour-Martillac, Pessac-Léognan
wine.review: A medium to full-bodied Bordeaux full of chocolate and dried herb notes on the nose and palate.

wine.name: Taburno Falanghina, Fatt. La Rivolta
wine.review: Falanghina is an ancient white grape variety; nowadays, it is found mostly in southern Italy’s Campania region. The volcanic soil there is ideal for this grape, adding a notable smoky mineral character. This wine shows powerful floral aromas, fresh acidity, and a clean finish.

wine.name: Riesling, Mittnacht
wine.review: This delightfully rich and expressive Riesling displays all the body and minerality that give Alsatian wines their charm. Made on a 20-hectare estate run by two conscientious brothers, this dense, balanced, and lively wine is full of petrol and ripe orchard fruits on the nose and palate.

wine.name: Dom Perignon 1999
wine.review: Dom Perignon is known for the delicacy of their house style. They use roughly half and half Pinot Noir and Chardonnay grapes, occassionally placing more emphasis on the flavors Chardonnay brings to the wine. The 1999 vintage Dom is full of floral apple and pear notes with with an underlying earthiness that speaks of the Pinot in the blend. The wine is light in style yet overwhelmingly sophisticated and complex.

wine.name: Shaw Vineyards Riesling
wine.review: This charming Riesling from Seneca Lake has lots to offer on the nose: classic petrol aromas mingling with juicy pineapple notes. The palate is dry with great, juicy, and mouth-watering acidity. A real treat.

wine.name: Zweigelt Rosé, Nigl
wine.review: Imagine a Loire Valley rosé but full of even more exuberant raspberry, cranberry, and tart cherry fruit on the nose. Though the aromatics reminded us of the Loire, we were delighted to find that the wine wasn't as astringent as some Loire examples can be. Refreshing and delicious.

wine.name: Grüner Veltliner "Steinsetz", Schloss Gobelsburg
wine.review: This Grüner is from a classic estate in Austria. Stony minerality and white pepper, along with a glycerine texture and nuances of white flowers make this a remarkable white wine.

wine.name: Chinon Blanc, Olek-Mery
wine.review: White Chinon is a rare treat. Made from 100% Chenin Blanc, the wines are dry and unctuous in the vein of Savennières. Since Olek-Mery passed away some years ago, the wines are made by Bernard and Mathieu Baudry, neighbors and reputed Chinon vignerons.

wine.name: Müller-Thurgau, Muri Gries
wine.review: Straw colored in the glass, this wine shows all the classic refreshing and floral aromas of Müller-Thurgau. The palate is light, elegant, and delicate. A perfect summer-time sipper or accompaniment to salads and other summer fare.

wine.name: Blanc Fumé de Pouilly "Silex" D. Dagueneau
wine.review: The "Silex" is perhaps Dagueneau's most prized wine, made from Sauvignon Blanc grown on silex soil. The wine is beautiful pure, earthy, round, and age-worthy. Last year Didier died in a plane crash. This is the last vintage he worked on.

wine.name: J. Wilkes Pinot Blanc, Bien Nacido Vineyard
wine.review: This wine spends 8 to 9 months on the lees, giving it creamy complexity and weight on the palate. The nose is full of fresh orchard fruit and pretty, powdery aromas, while the palate is balanced and elegant. A minuscule amount of this wine is made: just 360 cases!

wine.name: Casas del Mar Cava
wine.review: This whimsically labelled Cava is deliciously full of white flower notes on the nose. The palate is refreshing and clean with balanced acidity and soft, easy going bubbles. A crowd pleaser of fabulous quality for the price.

wine.name: BV Georges De Latour Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Another spectacular wine from one of the best Cabernet producers this country has seen.

wine.name: Pinot Noir "Petras", Carl Ehrhard
wine.review: This is a wonderfully soft yet characterful Pinot Noir. The wine spends 11 months in used oak barrels, with the result that there is plenty of supple texture to accompany it's sweet-fruited and floral nose.

wine.name: Loriot, Blanc de Noirs Brut, "Vieilles Vignes"
wine.review: Made from 100% Pinot Meunier grown in the clay soils of the Vallée de la Marne, this rich and vinuous Champagne boasts tremendous amounts of varietal character while beautifully expressing it's terroir. Loriot makes wine in the village of Festigny, a village that is historically known for Meunier based Champagnes. Clay soils give the wines a substantial quality in the mouth that is well complimented by lively acidity. The wine shows lots of apple, quince, and vanilla on the nose. It's young and tight at this stage of the game, and could stand to spend a few years in the cellar.

wine.name: LeDru, Blanc de Noirs Brut, "Cuvée du Gaulté"
wine.review: Made from 100% Grand Cru fruit from the village of Ambonnay, this is a true connoisseur's bubbly. "Cuvée du Gaulé" means "best of the best," which refers to Marie-Noelle LeDru's careful selection of grapes from her best parcels. LeDru has been making wine at this estate since 1984. She is a meticulous farmer who works with out herbicides and pesticides, and seeks to tend the land as naturally as possible. The wines spend an average of 3 years on the lees and are full of intense, chalky mineral notes.

wine.name: Kingston Family Vineyards Syrah, "Lucero"
wine.review: Is it a cliché yet to say that a new world wine has "Old World charm?" This wine held its own at an Old World-heavy tasting and we were extremely impressed. It is inky, full of dark fruit and peppery aromas; you might not mistake it for a Côte-Rôtie, but you will enjoy its unmistakable varietal character.

wine.name: Planeta Rose
wine.review: Made from 100% Syrah grapes by three cousins of the Planeta family. Another Sicilian treat!

wine.name: Vin de Vaucluse, Dom. de l'Ameillaud
wine.review: This wine is one of our best values from the Southern Rhône region. It is hard to believe that such a seductive, intense, full-bodied wine can be found at such a reasonable price. Appetizing aromas of blackberries and scrub brush.

wine.name: Getariako Txakolina, Arregi
wine.review: Here's a fantastic Txakoli. From the area around San Sebastian that produces "Getariako" Txakolia comes this bright, quince-fruited delight. The nose and palate offer an array of mouth-watering fruits that range from pear to citrus, as well as lovely ripe minerals.

wine.name: Bereziartua Dry Cider
wine.review: Look to have your mind boggled by this dry cider from Basque country in northeastern Spain. Made from native apple varieties that are crushed into an apple-sauce like mash before being pressed, this cider is bracing and cloudy from lack of filtration. A perfectly refreshing beverage that does wonders at the table.

wine.name: Riesling "Von Roten Schiefer", Clemens Busch
wine.review: A dry Riesling made from grapes grown on red slate. Clemens Busch is very much a winemaker who desires to express terroir in its purest form; he eschews the use of sulfur and doesn't fine or filter, with the result that his wines have beautiful richness and texture.

wine.name: Rüdesheimer Riesling, Carl Ehrhard
wine.review: For those of you out there who lament that "true Kabinetts" are no longer being made, here is your wine. This wine shows a mere touch of sweetness that is balanced by lots of juicy acidity. The nose offers peach notes as well as a bright and enticing green herbal and floral quality.

wine.name: Crémant d'Alsace, Domaine Agapé
wine.review: This is phenomenal sparkling wine. On the nose, it's full of floral orchard fruits like peach, pear, and apple. The palate is crisp but with a hint of dosage making it not excessively austere. Truly a heart-stealer.

wine.name: Arbois Chardonnay "Pamina", Dom. de l'Octavin
wine.review: The winemaker at this lovely new domaine in Arbois studied under Jacques Puffeney himself and the tutelage shows. Cloudy in the glass, this wine gives lots of apple fruit on the nose and cruchy, salty mineral on the palate.

wine.name: Vernaccia di San Gimignano, Fattoria il Palagio
wine.review: An earthy, lemon-y, and complex Vernaccia that has great ripeness on the palate. Approachable and a delicious choice at the table.

wine.name: Morellino di Scansano, Fattoria il Palagio
wine.review: Here is a wine that smells exactly like sumac, sweetly full of zingy fruit and refreshing acidity. The palate is quite fruit forward but balanced. A delicious and highly quaffable example of Sangiovese.

wine.name: Valpolicella, Az. Agr. Viviani Mazzano di Negrar
wine.review: This is a lighter style of Valpolicella that hearkens back to the days before new oak was used for these wines. Lythe, sprightly, and red-fruited, this is a delight... especially when lightly chilled.

wine.name: Chianti, Fattoria il Palagio
wine.review: A newly acquired Chianti that is full of clean red fruit and food-friendly tannins.

wine.name: Ch. Hauts de Pez, St.-Estèphe
wine.review: A dark and full-bodied Bordeaux from a glorious, ripe vintage. Full of cassis notes, black fruit, and robust, almost smoky tannins.

wine.name: Schiava "Elda", Mayr-Nusser
wine.review: A delicate and summery red wine from one of our favorite tiny producers whose estate is virtually inside the beautiful city of Bolzano. Smoky and redolent of cranberries, if this isn't the most delicious Schiava you've had, we'll be very surprised.

wine.name: Petite Arvine "Vigne Rovettaz", Grosjean Frères
wine.review: This is a wine that could well cause swooning. The nose is mellow, honeyed, and somewhat reminiscent of an Alsatian Pinot Gris. The palate is dense and a touch viscous with lots of ripe, almost waxy fruit, and exquisite balance. The wine changes as it's exposed to oxygen. Be ready for complexity.

wine.name: Paso de Piedra Cabernet, Viña Alicia
wine.review: A full-bodied, modern Cabernet Sauvignon full of ripe, dark fruit, and nuanced oak notes. The nose offers notes of currant, blackberry, and spice while the palate is savory and meaty.

wine.name: Lacrima di Morro d'Alba, Giusti
wine.review: An enthralling, violet-scented wonder from the Adriatic coast of Italy. This will knock your socks off with its plush texture and lithe, rompy palate. A must-try regional specialty.

wine.name: Bourgogne Pinot Noir, Joseph Faiveley
wine.review: A light, fresh, and delicate Pinot Noir that is abounding with bright, sour cherry and other red, pit fruit. The wine speaks clearly of its vintage and has a strong hint of tannin despite its pale color.

wine.name: Bourgogne Pinot Noir, Le Jardin de Charlotte
wine.review: Made from 20% Côte-de-Nuits fruit and 80% Côte-de-Beaune fruit, this plump and dark fruited delight is brambly and offers notes of dark, ripe cherry, and floral raspberry. A great value and very tasty wine.

wine.name: Régnié, Georges Descombes
wine.review: This wine is made by the 5th member of the legendary Morgon Gang of Four... it's his Régnié, which goes through a shorter raising process, making for a fruitier, young-drinking wine. Elegant, floral, and full of exuberant Gamay fruit, this is a bottle to chill down and drink on a warm summer evening.

wine.name: Estate Riesling Dry "Rocken", Ehrhard
wine.review: This dry Riesling is made from Spätlese level grapes, meaning that the nose is incredibly ripe and the palate full of mouth-watering, lime-y fruit. A very zingy example of dry Riesling, with just enough residual sugar to fend off austerity.

wine.name: VdT "Cuvée du Sommelier", Dom. de Boissan
wine.review: A light and extremely tasty young-vine Grenache that shows the skill of vigneron Christian Bonfils. Juicy and showing lots of tart cherry and sumac on the nose, this is sure to delight on its own as a summer quaffer or with lighter fare.

wine.name: Viognier, Ch. Massiac
wine.review: A fresh and lively example of Viognier that offers an array of both stone and tropical fruits on the nose. What surprised us about this delightful little bottle was its zippy acidity and engaging minerality, two traits that aren't exactly common in Viognier. Perfect for summer sipping.

wine.name: Ravines Pinot Noir, Finger Lakes
wine.review: This lively Pinot is full of cranberry notes on the nose and juicy fruit on the palate. With balanced acidity and little evidence of oak, this light-bodied wine makes a great choice for warm weather drinking.

wine.name: Ornellaia
wine.review: The legendary Super Tuscan.

wine.name: Ch. Tour de Pez, St.-Estèphe
wine.review: A full-bodied Bordeaux with lots of dense texture. The wine has a fairly heavy oak presence on the nose and palate, which is baked up by plenty of dark fruit.

wine.name: Ailes de Paloumey, Haut-Médoc
wine.review: A great, full-fruited Bordeaux that shows little oak influence on the nose or palate. Medium bodied and with good structure, this bottle has abundant dark berries.

wine.name: Wolffer "Big Apple" Apple Wine
wine.review: Made from aromatic apples such as Fuji, Braeburn, and Winesap, this crisp, dry, and incredibly refreshing apple wine is a perfect summer sipper. The winemaker at Wolffer suggests putting it on ice with a couple of mint leaves thrown in. Yum.

wine.name: Rosenblum Zinfandel "Maggie's Reserve", Sonoma
wine.review: Aromas of wild raspberry, blackberry and a touch vanilla come all wrapped up with subtle hints of cocoa and mint. The flavors are even more extracted and compelling than the aromas. A cornucopia of rich raspberry, blackberry and cherry with hints of clove and mint explode on the palate. The finish on this wine is so intense that it will make you wonder if life can get any better.

wine.name: Brouilly, Dom. Des Grandes Vignes
wine.review: Brouilly is among the lightest styles of Beaujolais when compared to the other crus. It's an everyday red wine that's dry, full of red cherries with a dusting of minerals.

wine.name: Blanquette de Limoux Brut, Esprit du Sud
wine.review: Blanquette de Limoux is a sparkling wine that some claim was even around before the production of Champagne. Either way, you'll enjoy this sparkler for all it has to offer: smoky and floral aromas, pearly bubbles - all with a dry finish.

wine.name: Esprit du Sud Rouge, Languedoc
wine.review: What does the spirit of the south of France taste like? It's a medium-bodied red wine, dense with dark fruits - but it also has an aspect of muskiness that will complement an array of grilled, meaty foods.

wine.name: Matelles, Merlot VdP d'Oc
wine.review: Sometimes Bordeaux is the only choice for your dinner, but at other times you want something more accessible, like this plush red wine from the south of France. It's full of classic Merlot characteristics: dark plums, refreshing acidity, and velvety texture.

wine.name: Gamay, Jacques Dépagneux
wine.review: A dry red wine that's technically classified as a Vin de Pays des Gaules - an area within Beaujolais. This is an everyday Gamay that's easy to love for so many reasons: for starters, the fruit, the freshness, and the accessibility.

wine.name: Saint-Amour, Dom. des Billards
wine.review: A light and easy-drinking Saint-Amour that is full of red fruit and savory, gamey notes. If you've never tried a wine from this northernmost Beaujolais Cru, now is the time.

wine.name: Wellies Pinot Noir, Marlborough
wine.review: You've loved the Wellies Sauvignon Blanc for years and now we've finally gotten our hands on some equally delicious Pinot Noir! A rare find indeed is this New Zealand Pinot Noir. It has finesse and cheery red cherries that will have you hooked in no time.

wine.name: Jurançon Moelleux "Symphonie de Novembre", Cauhapé
wine.review: One of the most exciting and succulent dessert wines to darken our doors in quite some time. The wine has a stunning nose full of sweet, buttery notes as well as savory decadence. The grapes are harvested in November for extra ripeness and concentration.

wine.name: Cour-Cheverny, Dom. de Montcy
wine.review: Cour-Cheverny is an appellation that was invented in order to protect the native Romorantin grape variety. This bottling is delicious and approachable, with stone fruit and raw honey aromas, bright acidity, and rocky minerality.

wine.name: Riesling, Jean Ginglinger
wine.review: A clean and racy Alsatian Riesling that has become one of our favorites for its streamlined texture and zippy acidity.

wine.name: Berdié Romagosa Cava, "Brut Rupestre"
wine.review: A clean and supple Cava with delicate, ripe fruit on the nose and palate.

wine.name: Chignin de Savoie, Dom. G. Berlioz
wine.review: Here's a remarkably fresh and zesty wine from eastern France, where they frequently specialize in such treasures. With plenty of citrusy and floral fruit on the nose and crunchy quartz-y mineral on the finish, this tangy treasure will be perfect with your next light, summer meal.

wine.name: Montepulciano d'Abruzzo, Emidio Pepe
wine.review: Emidio Pepe is the king of producers in Abruzzo. His Montepulciano offers and array of impossibly ripe, dark berries on the nose alongside stony minerality, garrigue-y flavors, and a healthy dose of gaminess. Decant for best results.

wine.name: Professor Black Sauvignon Blanc, Stellenbosch
wine.review: Here is a very old world style South African Sauvignon Blanc that is crisp, herbal, and may very well make you think of Sancerre.

wine.name: Corbières "Syrah Conference de Presse", Dom. Faillenc St.-Marie
wine.review: A velvety Corbières that is abounding with dark fruit as well as a hint of funk. This peppery Syrah has amazing depth and texture and will benefit from decanting.

wine.name: Sancerre, Hippolyte Reverdy
wine.review: This is Sancerre at its best, showing great ripeness on the nose as well as white fruit, citrus, and fresh, green herbs. On the palate, you'll get mouth-watering acidity, and a flinty mineral edge.

wine.name: Vouvray, Champalou
wine.review: This is technically a dry Vouvray, but it has a hint of incredibly pleasing sweetness. The nose offers classic notes of raw honey, apple, and quince that carry through to the palate. Here is an extremely elegant example of Chenin Blanc that will be at home on its own and also at the table.

wine.name: Château Musar Rouge
wine.review: The most meaningful wine to come out of Lebanon. Here's a full-bodied, unique Bordeaux blend that does wonders for a London Broil.

wine.name: Yellow and Blue Rosé
wine.review: A very pale, dry yet fruity Rosé based on Syrah and Monastrell. Great for pre-dinner and afternoon sipping and for lighter meals.

wine.name: Gentil, Hugel
wine.review: This dry wine is made from a blend of white grapes, and has a pleasing mix of spicy and floral characteristics. It is a great match for pâté or trout.

wine.name: Ribeira Sacra, Guímaro
wine.review: The slopes of Ribeira Sacra are remarkably steep, reminiscent of the slopes that ascend from the Mosel in Germany. This steepness lends beautiful acidity and freshness to the Mencía grown there. This wine is rompy with pure berry fruit notes and delicious peppery flavors.

wine.name: "Racines Métisses", Laurent Barth
wine.review: This is Laurent Barth's Edelzwicker-style blend, a field blend of Pinot Blanc, Sylvaner, Riesling, Pinot Gris, and Muscat. The wine is extremely fresh and aromatic with floral notes on the nose and a very slight touch of sweetness on the palate. Best of all, this wine improves open in the fridge over several days. Barth farms 3-hectares of vines very traditionally. The cuvée name: "Racines Métisses" means mixed races.

wine.name: Teatro, Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Though Argentina is best known for its Malbec, the appeal of the region's great Cabernet Sauvignon can't be denied. This unoaked red is full of fruit, with dark cassis, plums, and blackberries dominating the palate. It's the type of wine to enjoy alongside grilled steaks or burgers.

wine.name: Teatro, Chardonnay
wine.review: A fresh, unoaked, very tasty white wine, made in the style that makes us love Chardonnay from the southern hemisphere. This is not too high in alcohol (but not too low, either) with approachable, apple-y flavors.

wine.name: Casa Julia Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: A new offering from Chile. This is a gleaming, pale yellow wine with notes of green. It offers plenty of fruit, both tropical and citrus with herbs. In the mouth it has a young, lively citrus taste, plus other tropical fruit flavors. Great body and a long finish.

wine.name: Bizkaiko Txakolina, Doniene Gorrondona
wine.review: This wine is made from 150-year-old pre-phylloxera Hondarribi Beltza vines and is extremely unusual. Last vintage, it was quite peppery and herbal; this vintage it is ripe and rompy and truly reminiscent of a juicy, refreshing Loire valley wine.

wine.name: Dominus, Napa
wine.review: This is the proprietary blend of this estate in the heart of the Napa Valley. Created by Christian Moueix of Libourne, France, Dominus was created to show off the unique terroir of the Napanook vineyard. Layers of complexity, chewy tannins, and notes of dark chocolate and cassis make this a memorable wine.

wine.name: Folie à Deux, Ménage à Trois
wine.review: A Zinfandel-based blend that is plush, full of sweet fruit, and immensely popular.

wine.name: Coenobium "Rusticum"
wine.review: Advising oenologist Paolo Bea suggested that these Cistercian sisters try aging longer on the lees and this is the result. The wine is golden in the glass with notes of roasted fennel, mint, and pear skins on the nose. The palate is dense with sweet fruit and prominent preserved lemon acidity. The finish shows hints of skin tannin. A uniqe and beautiful wine.

wine.name: Greco, Ocone
wine.review: This is a mellow and crowd-pleasing Greco that provides a wonderful introduction to the grape. The nose offers stone fruits and is somewhat reminiscent of a Pinot Gris. On the palate, you'll get the tell-tale smoky flavor of Volcanic mineral along with some tangy citrus pith notes.

wine.name: Prosecco, Sorelle Bronca
wine.review: A sweet and perfume-y Prosecco with the faintest touch of sweetness, a style we call "tender." These easy bubbles make a delightful afternoon wine and also pair exceptionally well with sushi.

wine.name: Curious Cove Pinot Gris, Hawke's Bay
wine.review: Here's a dry and lively offering from the east coast of New Zealand, where the summers are especially long, dry, and conducive to grape growing. This wine is medium bodied with exotic notes of grapefruit and guava. A small portion sees time in new barrique so there's nice roundness on the palate.

wine.name: Lingenfelder Gewürztraminer
wine.review: Here's an extremely rosy Gewürztraminer at a great price. Though the nose gives classic Gewürz. notes, the wine is quite delicate and elegant. It's an off-dry style so expect a touch of sweetness to compliment the wine's floral profile.

wine.name: Beaujolais-Villages "Vieillevigne", Dom. des Terres Vivantes
wine.review: This is a relatively full-bodied and structured Beaujolais-Villages that drinks like a cru Beaujolais. The nose offers lots of grape-y Gamay fruit and the palate is full of dried leaves and granitic mineral notes.

wine.name: Blanc de Blancs Extra-Brut "Les Rachais", Boulard
wine.review: This is a rich and leesy Champagne without dosage and with less than 3 grams/liter of residual sugar. Made from 100% Chardonnay harvested in 2002, the wine is fermented in used oak. Grower bubbles at their best.

wine.name: Ca Dia Merlot, Veneto
wine.review: It's rare to find such a rich Merlot from Italy. This stands out from the pack because it is full of black plums, dark berries, and easy-drinking tannins.

wine.name: Vigna d'Oro Rosso, Sigillus Primus
wine.review: A hearty red blend from the Italian region of Puglia (the heel of the boot). This tastes of southern Italy, with spicy fruit flavors and aromas of dried cherries and sweet black plums. An excellent choice with anything from the grill.

wine.name: Salice Salentino Riserva, Sigillus Primus
wine.review: This Salice Salentino has all the tastes we love in a southern Italian wine. With mixed dark berries and dark fruit aromas on the palate, it's dry, delicious, juicy, and easy to get hooked on.

wine.name: Château Chalon, Berthet-Bondet
wine.review: The most extraordinary wine of the Jura. This Savagnin is aged for 6 to 7 years sous voile before release and can keep for up to 100 years.

wine.name: Château Chalon, Berthet-Bondet
wine.review: This is a legendary and noble wine based on the Savagnin grape that has great potential to age. The wine is oxidative so expect incredible complex nutty notes complimented by white fruits, spices, an curry. Château Chalon is also known to be extraordinarily food friendly.

wine.name: Müller-Thurgau, Schloss Mühlenhoff
wine.review: An aromatic and tropical expression of Müller-Thurgau that in made in a "feinherb" style meaning that there is a touch of approachable sweetness on the palate. Juicy, ripe, and thoroughly enjoyable.

wine.name: VdP de la Vallée du Paradis, "la démarrante", Magnon
wine.review: This wine from Corbières is crammed with sweet red berry fruits made interesting by a hint of funk. While deeply colored, the wine is light-handed with body and texture reminiscent of Beaujolais, which makes sense because the vigneron, a young man named Maxime Magnon, studied with Foillard, one of the great Morgon winemakers. Though the wine is from Corbières, it cannot be labeled as such because the grapes don't align with Corbières appellation laws.

wine.name: Moet Nectar Bucket of Bubbles
wine.review: Perfect for the beach or rooftop party.

wine.name: Pétillant Naturel, Thierry Puzelat
wine.review: Unlike many other Pétillant Naturel wines, this bottle is a) made from Menu Pineau, a rare, indigenous Loire grape, and b) without dosage, meaning that it truly is on the drier side but with amazingly ripe orchard fruits and pollen-like aromatics. Puzelat does it again!

wine.name: Verdicchio dei Castelli di Jesi "Podium", Garofoli
wine.review: This characterful Verdicchio sees between 10 and 12 months on the lees, giving it lovely texture on the palate. The nose is full of peaches and salty, maritime minerality.

wine.name: Morgon "Vieilles Vignes", Guy Breton
wine.review: Guy Breton, another of the Morgon Gang of Four, ages this Gamay in old barrels for 8 months before bottling with very minimal sulfur. The nose is full of berries, violets, and the perfume of naturally made wine. The palate is delicate and gives tart cherry and cranberry notes.

wine.name: Ch. Bellevue Lussac St. Émilion
wine.review: This is a traditionally styled Bordeaux that shows abundant high-toned dark fruits on the nose such as blackberries and plums. With 50% Merlot, the wine isn't as aggressively tannic as some but still packs an age-worthy punch on the finish. Elegant and with great cellar potential.

wine.name: Saint-Véran, Dom. la Source des Fées
wine.review: The Chardonnay that goes into this bottle is from a vineyard called "Innocence Sauvage." This is a very small production wine that is aged in Acacia and gives aromas of baked apples and butter. Some new wood is evident along with lots of ripe fruit on the mid-palate.

wine.name: Wahluke Slope "Oui Deux" Syrah, Bergevin Lane Vineyards
wine.review: This is a musky and aromatic Syrah with peppercorn notes on the nose and lots of rich, dark fruit on the palate.

wine.name: Troia "Canusio" Rosso, Domede
wine.review: This wine hails from the northern part of Apulia where the Nero di Troia grape is common. Aged in 100 liter oak cask, the wine is dark, chunky, deliciously ripe, and possessed of a firm mineral backbone.

wine.name: Merotto, Brut Rosé, Grani Rosa di Nero
wine.review: This Sparkling Rosé is made from 100% Pinot Nero and comes from the Valdobiaddene area in the Veneto. The wine is pale in the glass with lovely strawberry notes, gentle foam, and delicate minerality on the finish.

wine.name: Mukuzani Dry Red, Teliani Valley
wine.review: A dry, full-bodied red wine from the Kakheti region of Georgia. Made from the local Saperavi grape. Rich and full-bodied and reminiscent of a Zinfandel with a dose of tannins and mineral structure on the finish. The best of the region.

wine.name: Riesling Kabinett, Graff
wine.review: An aromatic, slightly sweet Riesling full of apple, white flower, and citrus aromas and flavors.

wine.name: Dashe Vin Gris
wine.review: To our knowledge, Michael Dashe is the only California vigneron to ferment his wines using entirely indigenous yeasts. He's a maverick, a special guy, and a great winemaker. This Vin Gris is made from Grenache, Petite Sirah, and Zinfandel. The nose and palate are full of dense, red fruit and the wine drinks like a red in that it has some tannin. Dashe says this tannic structure comes from the Petite Sirah in the blend. In many ways, with its full body, this is a serious rosé; it's also unique and deserving of a place at the table.

wine.name: Crozes-Hermitage, Dard and Ribo
wine.review: A unique style of Syrah that is soft, fruity, and peppery. Here is a smoky, zesty, intensely flavored wine with bright fruit, creamy texture, and a dark, brooding essence.

wine.name: Rueda "Spring in a bottle", Verderol
wine.review: White wines from Rueda are all about freshness. Nothing is more telling than drinking it from the latest vintage. This is fresh off the boat and showing amazing citrus fruit and vibrant floral aromas. A dry, everyday type of wine that's excellent before and during dinner, this pairs extremely well with seafood.

wine.name: El Bon Homme Siente, Valencia
wine.review: A beautiful red wine from Valencia, Spain that's made from old vines Montastrell and Cabernet Sauvignon. Medium-bodied with spice and dark berried aromas. A natural match with grilled meats.

wine.name: Bergerac Sec, Château le Payral
wine.review: Here's one of the best examples of Bergerac Sec we've seen in a long time. The nose has beautiful notes of lemon and lime that are complimented on the palate by ripe, tangy green apple fruit. Based on Sauvignon Blanc, the wine is crisp but far from austere.

wine.name: Comienzo, Ribera del Duero
wine.review: Ribera del Duero wines often undergo extensive oak and bottle aging. This one is quite different: it is made in an overtly fruity style that appeases those looking for something more approachable. An uncommon and delicious rendition of Ribera del Duero.

wine.name: Alsace Blanc, Kuentz-Bas
wine.review: This is the basic bottling from winery Kuentz-Bas and is everything you could want from a white Alsatian wine. It's aromatic, fruit driven, light and refreshing. Just the type of wine that you can drink by the case.

wine.name: Bourgogne Blanc "La Soeur Cadette", Dom. de la Cadette
wine.review: You can smell and taste the fossilized oyster shell in this Chardonnay. This is what we mean by "minerally" when we're speaking of white Burgundy. A delicious, dry white Burgundy that's citrus driven and full of fresh fruit character and, you got it, mineral.

wine.name: Terranoble Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: Everything you could want in a Chilean Sauvignon Blanc; grapefruit with a touch of fresh herbs. Light, easy and dry on the palate.

wine.name: Kaseler Nies'chen Riesling Kabinett, Erben von Beulwitz
wine.review: The Nies'chen vineyard is located in the village of Kasel in the Saar - a tributary off of the famed Mosel River in Germany. We'd like to say this is classic Kabinett but in fact it's a rarity. Wonderful fruit, citrus, stonefruit all enveloped in enoki mushroom and gorgeous flint minerals. Off dry with a delicious finish. Low alcohol (9%) means more glasses of deliciousness for you today.

wine.name: Rosso Piceno Superiore "Castellano" Pharus
wine.review: A red wine based on Montepulciano that comes from the little known region of the Marches. Spicy with thyme and oregano and dark fruits.

wine.name: Mâcon-Pierreclos, Thevenet
wine.review: Jean-Claude Thevenet, one of the finest producers in the Mâconnais, delivers a very crisp, clean style of white wine. There's lots of ripe apple and pear character in this elegant Chardonnay; the wine calls for shellfish, chicken, or a light meat dish.

wine.name: Hello Kitty, Rosé Sparkling Brut
wine.review: We never knew that Hello Kitty was into Pinot Noir. We never knew that Hello Kitty was into sparkling rosés either. You'll be pleasantly surprised that this is great wine. It's intensely fruited with warm spices and red berries and mineral. Rich and dry on the finish.

wine.name: Freisa d'Asti "Cento Filari", Lo Spaventapasseri
wine.review: The name of this estate means "little sparrow" in Italian. Freisa can sometimes be a touch pétillant, but not in this case: this red wine is completely without fizz. With classic notes of Piedmontese soil on the nose, dark fruits melding with purple flowers, and hints of tar, this is a light-bodied and lively wine.

wine.name: Crémant de Jura Blanc de Blancs, Bornard
wine.review: Made from 100% Chardonnay in the tiny village of Pupillin, this Pétillant Naturel style Crémant offers a minerally mid-palate and finish combined with a nose full of delicious orchard fruits. Philippe Bornard is from a new generation of Jura vignerons who have embraced natural winemaking. His wines contain very little sulfur and have the kind of juicy, funky quality that we have come to expect and love from wines made this way.

wine.name: VdP Chardonnay, Dom. de la Patience
wine.review: A juicy, round, and southerly style of French Chardonnay from the Coteaux de Pont du Gard. The nose is fresh, minty, and floral with white peach and green apple coming through on the palate.

wine.name: Furmint, Wenzel
wine.review: A dry white wine made from the Furmint grape. The aromas are fully floral and rosey and complement the beautiful texture and mineral of this luscious, full-bodied bold wine.

wine.name: Dom Perignon Rose
wine.review: Dom Perignon makes an unparalleled Rosé Champagne and the 1998 vintage is no exception. The house style of Dom P leaves its clear mark on the wine, resulting in a fine balance between the clean, orchard fruit of Chardonnay and the earthy, almost woodsy quality of Pinot Noir. On the nose, notice floral notes mingling with a sensation of dried red berries such as stawberries and cherries. On the palate, Dom P's Rosé is quite delicate in style, earthy, red fruits giving way to chalky minerality on the finish. A complex and lingering Rosé Champagne that deserves the praise it consistently garners.

wine.name: Grüner Veltliner Messwein, Stift Goettweig
wine.review: Maybe we'd all be sitting in the pews a little more often if we got to drink this delicious wine. This is literally "altar" wine used during mass at the Stift Goettweig monastery. A crisp white wine that's full of floral pollen and mossy minerals.

wine.name: Kalkstein Terrassen Riesling Trocken, A. Christmann
Cori "Capolemole," Marco Carpineti
wine.review: This round, slightly oxidative white wine from Lazio shows succulent notes of apple and pear skin. The wine is fermented in large, neutral Slovenian oak, giving the wine appealing roundness and weight on the palate.

wine.name: "Les Pinots d'Alsace", Dom. Bott Geyl
wine.review: This is a blend of Auxerrois, Pinot Blanc, Pinot Gris, and Pinot Noir (vinified as a white wine). The wine is golden in the glass, the nose, deep and earthy. Showing spice notes on the nose, richness on the palate, and firm minerality on the finish, it's truly a unique bottle.

wine.name: VdP de Pays d'Oc Chardonnay "Superbe"
wine.review: This is remarkable clean, fresh, vibrant Chardonnay. The nose offes an array of tasty orchard fruits and the palate is delightfully balanced. Here's a wines that will do well on its own on a warm afternoon.

wine.name: Mercurey 1er Cru "Clos des Barraults", L. Juillot
wine.review: This is a very traditional style of Burgundy that is drinking well right now. The nose is complex, slightly evolved, earthy, and possessed of a well integrated herbal note characteristic of the vintage.

wine.name: Marsannay Rouge, Dom. Collotte
wine.review: A meaty, firm Marsannay that comes from 40 year old vines planted on the Marsannay hills. There's a core of cherry fruits with mineral and tannins on the finish.

wine.name: Ch. du Seuil, Coteaux d'Aix-en-Provence
wine.review: A full-bodied red wine from the south of France. The mineral component of this red wine is piercing and adds a delicious complexity to the dark berries and licorice. Made from a blend based on Cabernet Sauvignon, Syrah and Grenache.

wine.name: Rosso Toscano, Casina di Cornia
wine.review: This 7-hectare estate in Sienna makes one of the most light-handed and feminine styles of Sangiovese that has touched our lips in a long time. The wine is on the light side of medium-bodied with beautiful, floral aromas of raspberry and sweet cherry. Well balanced with firm chalk and clay minerality showing itself on the finish, this will do wonders along side a pizza at your table tonight.

wine.name: Russian Jack Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: The regional differences in New Zealand Sauvignon Blancs is notable and in this case much more restrained than those from Marlborough. This comes from Martinborough, a viticultural area located on the southern part of the north island. Dry yet incredibly dense with floral fruit and clay minerals.

wine.name: Langhe Dolcetto, Az. Agr. Bricco del Cucu
wine.review: From a high elevation vineyard in the Langhe hills comes this fabulous Dolcetto. The family behind Bricco del Cucu have been making wine in this region since the 15th century and, according to our palates, they've got it figured out. This Dolcetto is aged in stainless steel so that the lovely dark fruit of the variety really stands out. The nose offers the clear, tar-y notes of Piedmontese soil, mingling with bright red and dark berry fruit. The tannins have definite presence here making this a wine for the table.

wine.name: Langhe Rosso "Superboum", Az. Agr. Bricco del Cucu
wine.review: This Langhe Rosso is a blend of Dolcetto and Merlot. The wine is fermented and aged in stainless steel to preserve the wine's enticing dark cherry aromas and flavors. On the label, you'll see a depiction of a local fresco. The name of the wine is a play on words, meaning both "pride" in Latin and "supercool" in contemporary Italian slang. This is a fabulous bottle, full of concentrated, sweet fruit but also structure and tannin, resulting in a superbly balanced finished product.

wine.name: Barbera d'Alba, De Forville
wine.review: A pulpy, plump Barbera wine that is vinified in steel and then aged in large oak barrels for nearly ten months. Dry and deliciously fruity, with bold flavors of dark berries and plums.

wine.name: Riesling Smaragd Vision, Högl
wine.review: A dry, dense Riesling with an incredibly elegant texture. The vines are planted in Loiben where the aromatic spectrum tends toward the tropical side of Riesling.

wine.name: Barbera d'Asti "Arbuc", Massimo Bo
wine.review: This wine comes from an area that is covered in Linden trees, a flavor that can be found in the wines. The nose here is mellow and complex with waxy, floral notes as well as hints of leather and plum. The palate is light-handed but densely fruited with no oak and less agressive tannins than are sometimes found in Barbera. Massimo Bo practices green-harvesting to keep yeilds low with the result that his wines are concentrated and of very high quality.

wine.name: Moscato d'Asti, Massimo Bo
wine.review: This treasure comes from 60-70 year old Moscato vines of an extremely uncommon local strain with small, intensely flavorful berries. The nose offers enticing notes of lychee and rosewater while the palate is sweet but balanced with a lovely citric edge.

wine.name: "Tai Rosso", Rezzadore
wine.review: This Grenache from the province of Vicenza in northeastern Italy drinks more like Gamay than Grenache. The wine is extremely light, fruity, and full of tart cherry and cranberry notes on the nose and palate. There's a hint of funk at the onset and the wine finishes with bright acidity and soft tannins. Serve chilled.

wine.name: Lambrusco "Rigoletto", Vinicola Negri
wine.review: An off-dry and refreshing Lambrusco with earthy, red fruit on the nose and zesty tannins on the finish.

wine.name: Arneis, Le Formiche
wine.review: This Arneis benefits from a long period of aging on the lees, giving it complexity on the nose and weight on the palate. The nose offers mellow notes of fresh melon and pear skin along with a delicate, green herbal note that carries through to the palate, which is nicely balanced with mineral hints.

wine.name: Nebbiolo d'Alba, Le Formiche
wine.review: This rich, ripe, dark-fruited Langhe Rosso is made from 100% Nebbiolo. On the nose you'll get earthy, tarry notes as well as blackberry and plum. The fruit flavors are quite ripe and sweet but with a spicy, tannic edge and a hint of espresso bean on the finish. Drink with hearty fall fare.

wine.name: Touraine Cabernet "La Gautrie", Venier
wine.review: This is a very special Cabernet Franc. It's quite pale, rusty red, and cloudy in the glass and offers a bouquet full of red berries, dried herbs, and delightful Loire Valley funk and muskiness. The palate is tangy and juicy with soft tannins. Serve with a light chill for best results.

wine.name: Verdicchio di Matelica "Vigneti del Cerro", Belisario
wine.review: A vibrant, dry white wine that's beautifully aromatic on the palate with white flowers and a dusting of powdery minerals. Unoaked and best enjoyed with a chill.

wine.name: Faugères, Dom. Leon Barral
wine.review: This wine is a gem. The Domaine is so fervent about biodynamism that 1/3 of the vineyard land is devoted to sheep raising so the animal's manure can nourish the vines. The wine is dark and nearly opaque in the glass with notes of garrigue and game. On the palate, the wine has a ripe, powerful, southerly feel. Leon Barral is a natural winemaking star in France- now, at the request of the importer, the Barral's have been convinced to add just a touch of sulfur before bottling. Aged in old foudres.

wine.name: Grüner, Franz Etz
wine.review: A lively, densely fruited white wine from the Kamptal region of Austria. Floral and fresh with minerals on the finish. Sometimes Grüner Veltliner makes more sense to buy in a liter size. More goodness for more friends.

wine.name: Petit Amour, VdP de Vaucluse
wine.review: This Vin de Pays is a blend of red grapes, with a friendly appeal that makes it a great "house red." If you're throwing a dinner party, this rustic red will go with just about any dish you're serving.

wine.name: Cotes du Rhone, Dom. du Grand Prieur
wine.review: A rich red Côtes du Rhône that is full of spicy dark berry flavors. Based on the Grenache grape, with Syrah and Mourvèdre to finish the blend. The tannins are accessible, and they make this a tasty match for grilled meats.

wine.name: Côtes-du-Rhône Villages Signargues, SVP
wine.review: This Villages Côtes-du-Rhône offers a significant step up in quality from a basic Côtes-du-Rhône. Signargues was just granted "named village" status in 2005. This red wine relies more heavily on the Syrah grape than many Côtes-du-Rhône wines, and offers pulpy mixed dark berries, spices, and lithe tannins on the finish.

wine.name: Pinot du Bugey, Peillot
wine.review: This Pinot is made from Pinot Fin, an ancient strain of the Pinot Noir variety that is hardly cultivated these days. The wine is extremely delicate in the glass offering red raspberry and cherry fruit on the nose and juicy acidity on the palate. Serve with a light chill.

wine.name: Rioja Tinto "Rayos Uva", Olivier Rivière
wine.review: This is a fruity, all-stainless-steel-raised Rioja from very old vines in Rioja Alta. The winemaker is a Frenchman who fell in love with Rioja. The wine is bursting with black fruit and spice that comes from Graciano (rather than new oak).

wine.name: Rioja Rosado "La Vida en Rosa", Olivier Rivière
wine.review: Depending on the individual, this wine could be viewed as a light red... or a full bodied Rosé. Either way, it's incredibly delicious with sweet cherry and floral, red fruit on the nose and exquisite balance on the palate. Best lightly chilled.

wine.name: Egly-Ouriet Brut Reserve
wine.review: This extremely dry Champagne (2 grams/liter of residual sugar) is stunningly intricate with honeyed apple and pear notes on the nose and lots of tangy ripeness on the palate. Evolved in the glass, the wine also shows an intriguing mushroom-y note. Only the best Champagne producers can make such dry Champagnes come alive with balance and complexity. Mostly Pinot Noir.

wine.name: Ferreira Vintage Port
wine.review: A Vintage Port that has great potential to age. The wine offers complex notes of violets and black fruits: blackberry, cassis, and plum, as well as hints of balsamic and cedar. Ferreira is a 250 year old estate that produces Ports of impeccable quality.

wine.name: Vino Nobile di Montepulciano, Corte alla Flora
wine.review: A full-bodied Tuscan wine that's based on the Prugnolo Gentile grape variety also known as the Sangiovese Grosso - the variety used for Brunello. This wine is rich, spicey, and boasts mineral and tannins on the finish. Evolves instantly in the glass and marries well with meat fare.

wine.name: Chablis, Fréderic Gueguen
wine.review: Fréderic Gueguen is a passionate winemaker who practices Biodynamics in his vineyards. This is a classic Chablis with steely minerals, good weight and ripe citrus and yellow orchard fruits on the palate.

wine.name: Willowglen Shiraz-Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: This juicy Australian red is full of raspberry candy on the nose and bright acidity on the palate. Plush, soft, and delightful on its own or with food.

wine.name: Pouilly-Fuissé "Les Creuzettes", Dom. des Maillettes
wine.review: Pouilly-Fuissé is a white wine made from Chardonnay. It is also the name of the village located just north of the Beaujolais region. A floral, dry white wine that's full of plums, apples and smoky limes.

wine.name: Pinot Gris Reserve Trimbach
wine.review: Deep, golden tropical fruit is the theme here. Full-bodied and sublimely flavorful, this wine is incredibly rich yet fully dry, showing great balancing acidity.

wine.name: Moscato d'Asti "Bricco Quaglia", La Spinetta
wine.review: A single vineyard Moscato from a very well respected producer in Piedmont, this wine will know your socks off with its delightful rose water and lychee notes and lightly sweet palate.

wine.name: Quincy "Beaucharme", Dom. Sylvaine Bailly
wine.review: Quincy, pronounced "can see", is a lesser-known region in the Loire Valley. This is undoubtedly Sauvignon Blanc on the palate. Full of fresh herbs, citrus fruit and a delicious ripe qualilty. The lighter, dry white wine that's approachable yet ideal with light fare.

wine.name: Chapuy, Brut Tradition
wine.review: These days a half bottle of Champagne is the way to go. This boasts toasty aromas with orchard fruit and citrus on the finish. Fresh, lighter in style and portable.

wine.name: Two Paddocks "Picnic" Pinot Noir
wine.review: The Central Otago region of New Zealand has long been appreciated for stellar Pinot Noir bottlings among other wines. This has to be one of the best values we've seen yet! Full of darker berried fruits, cherries and the like with a blood orange and floral complexity on the finish. Light to medium bodied and incredibly complex without any overt use of oak.

wine.name: Arbois Pupillin Pinot Noir "l'Aide Memoire", Bornard
wine.review: This is Pinot Noir like you've never seen it before. Redolent of dark, ripe cherries, plums, and irony minerality, this wine is muscular, savory, age-worthy, and characterized by a ripe and excellent vintage. If you aren't familiar with Philippe Bornard's wines, now is the time to try them. After only 5 years making wine in Pupillin, the wines are undeniably beautiful, lively, and unique.

wine.name: Yarraman Estate "Hay Burner" Chardonnay
wine.review: This unoaked Chardonnay is full of tangy apples on the nose and palate. The wine has plenty of sweet ripe fruit that is balance by bright acidity.

wine.name: Catapanus, Bombino Bianco, d'Alfonso del Sordo
wine.review: A fascinating wine made from the Bombino Bianco variety. This wine gives floral notes of earth and anise seed on the nose. The wine is rich and dry with a green note that runs through the nose and palate.

wine.name: Pinot Grigio, Muzic
wine.review: This is a rich style of Pinot Grigio that shows an earthy side of the grape. The wine offers stone fruit, floral, and herbal notes on the nose and palate. Not your average zippy Pinot Grigio, this wine has lots of fascinating, dense, waxy character.

wine.name: St. Magdalener Klassisch Sudtirol, Weingut Erbhof
wine.review: Normally a co-op wine, it's unusual to see an artisanal Schiava such as this one. The nose is full of red Apline berries mingling with fig and citrus notes. A great example of the style that is best served chilled with light fare.

wine.name: Montefalco Rosso "Le Mura Saracene", Goretti
wine.review: This is a pulpy and full-bodied wine that shows notes of blackberry and cassis. Mostly Sangiovese, the wine sees a year in wood but doesn't show too much overt oak. Plush and structured.

wine.name: Sagrantino di Montefalco "Le Mura Saracene", Goretti
wine.review: This is a very big and modern styled Sagrantino that offers some new oak notes that will dissipate with time. Full of dark fruit and appropriate for the cellar or a good decanting and a slab of meat.

wine.name: Abadia Retuerta, Cuvée Palomar
wine.review: If you're a fan of rich, oaky reds with lots of chocolate and coffe flavors than this wine is for you.

wine.name: Gentil d'Alsace, Meyer-Fonné
wine.review: This very aromatic and floral Alsatian wine from the village of Katzenthal is based on Pinot Gris blended with Gewürz, Riesling, and Muscat. The winemaker at Meyer-Fonné is a Zind-Humbrecht diciple, so there is some richness on the palate that is exquisitely balanced with acidity.

wine.name: Patrimonio Blanc, Domaine D'E Croce, Yves Leccia
wine.review: From the chalky soil of northern Corisca comes this incredibly succulent, round, and flavorful rendtition of Vermentino. Very old vines and low yeilds give this wine unparalleled aromatic complexity and minerality.

wine.name: Saint-Joseph, Dom. Faury
wine.review: This is a traditionally made Saint-Joseph that is very pure in its expression of Syrah fruit. The grapes that go into this wine come from a single parcel that is set apart from the rest of the appellation's vineyards. Faury uses only old wood- allowing the granite soil of the region to speak loudly and clearly. Very concentrated and full of leathery and peppery notes on the nose and palate.

wine.name: Touraine Sauvignon, Dom. de la Potine
wine.review: Here is an approachable Sauvignon that is full of fresh herb notes, pineapple, and chalky minerality. The wine has great balance and lots of bright acidity.

wine.name: Mâcon-Davayé, Dom. des Valanges
wine.review: This medium-bodied Chardonnay has all the orchard fruit one could want from a wine from the Mâconnais. The mid-palate is dense with the kind of sweet, ripe fruit notes that come from lees aging. A delicious example of unoaked Chardonnay.

wine.name: Clos Julien Chardonnay, Central Coast
wine.review: This lightly oaked Chardonnay is made from mostly Edna Valley fruit. The wine has ripe apple aromas, hints of vanilla, and lots of rich, sumptuous fruit.

wine.name: Santimedici, Castel di Salve
wine.review: This deeply fruity wine is made from the Negroamaro variety. On the nose, you'll get southerly notes of prune and plum that marry nicely with the wine's delicious, confected edge. This wine is raised in stainless steel and sees no oak.

wine.name: Unti Barbera, Dry Creek Valley
wine.review: The Unti estate was born in 1992 when George Unti bought vineyard land in Dry Creek. His son, Mick, now runs the winery. This is a plush, dark fruited Barbera that, in spite of its weight, has lovely balance. Meaty and showing just a touch of cedar from 11 months in mostly neutral oak.

wine.name: Unti Zinfandel
wine.review: The grapes that go into this Zinfandel come from very low yielding vines. The wine is dark, pulpy, and pure with no oak treatment at all.

wine.name: Unti Syrah, Dry Creek Valley
wine.review: Here is a rich and robust Syrah that sees 14 months in French oak, some of which is new. Mick Unti keeps yields extremely low in the vineyard to ensure that this wine is dense and packed with intense, dark fruit aromas and flavors. Pure, pulpy, and spicy.

wine.name: Ken Forrester, Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: A dry Sauvignon Blanc with flinty minerals mixed with tropical quince and honeyed stone fruits. Not your typical Sauvignon Blanc in that it's not just about the fresh herbs but rather more about ripe tropical fruits and mineral. Dry yet ripe and wonderful with a chill alone or with food.

wine.name: Meinert, Merlot
wine.review: A complex Merlot that's full of mint, black tea and plush dark berries. This comes from the Devon Crest vineyard - well known for its clay soils. Aged in lightly seasoned French oak barrels for 18 months.

wine.name: Vouvray Sec, Clos Naudin, Foreau
wine.review: Amazing concentration of crisp chalky Chenin Blanc. Try it with chèvre for a classic wine-food match. This wine will evolve nicely for 10+ years.

wine.name: Vouvray "Cuvée Tradition", Pinon
wine.review: A gentle sweetness in the attack brings on flavors of apple and quince, accented with spice, leading to a pleasant citrus finish with resonance and length.

wine.name: Corbières "l'Enclos", Dom. des Deux Ânes
wine.review: Another great endeavor from this husband-and-wife team in the Corbières area of Languedoc and now in large format. Aged both in tank and in old barrels, this structured red wine comes from a warm vintage, giving it powerful flavors of black fruit, nutmeg, and dried fig.

wine.name: Minervois, Le Clos du Canet
wine.review: This full-bodied Minervois is a red blend based on old Grenache vines. Aged in large, used wooden vats for a subtler oak influence, the wine tastes of blackberries, cherries, and chocolate, with clay minerals and tannins on the finish.

wine.name: Top 10 Under $10 October 2009
wine.review: Finding even one great wine under $10 is a challenge at most stores. Here at Astor, we haven’t yet had any problem finding you ten of them each month - and throwing in a couple of free bottles for good measure. The Top 10 Under $10 is a case of ten of the most delicious wine values we’ve come across each month, plus an extra bottle of each of the two wines marked (***) - in case you’re keeping track, that’s twelve wines for the price of ten. We’re able to offer this package because, with half a century of experience under our belts, we’ve learned a few tricks about finding quality wine at good prices. With an unprecedented amount of wine being produced in the world, there are countless great values to be discovered if you happen to know (as we do) a few open-minded, intrepid wine buyers with the noses to sniff them out. Just in case you’re curious about exactly why we fell in love with each bottle, we’ll include a list of the buyers’ notes with each case.

wine.name: Amala Chardonnay
wine.review: An easy-drinking white wine that's medium-bodied with aromas of orchard fruit and baked apples. Chill and enjoy.

wine.name: Amala Merlot
wine.review: A soft, approachable red wine that's all about plum flavors and blackberries.

wine.name: Amala Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: An unoaked Cabernet Sauvignon that boasts blackberries, cherries and spice on the palate. Excellent with burgers!

wine.name: Chinon "Cuvée Les Puys", Dom. Wilfred Rousse
wine.review: A delicious Cabernet Franc that's all about dense, dark fruits and warm spices on the palate. The finish is mineral driven and is balanced with the tannins. Wilfred Rousse started his wine adventure in 1987 with a mere hectare of vines. Today, he has 3 hectares of vines planted in Cab Franc.

wine.name: Substance "Re" Riesling
wine.review: An off-dry Riesling from the Columbia Valley of Washington State. Aromas of tangy peaches and minerals dominate the palate. Light to medium bodied with a vibrant finish.

wine.name: Gundlach Bundschu Merlot
wine.review: This Merlot is unique in that it boasts a great backbone of tannins and mineral. This alongside the berries, plum and spice make it a great red wine to sip alone or with any meat fare.

wine.name: Substance "Sy" Syrah
wine.review: A medium-bodied red wine with juicy dark berries and bright tannins. Robust and a great wine with grilled foods or hard, aged cheeses.

wine.name: Waters "Interlude"
wine.review: A Bordeaux blend that is full-bodied with aromas of cassis, powder and spice from the French oak aging. The texture is sophisticated and slick and a wine that will marry well with a roast.

wine.name: Del Rio, Viognier
wine.review: New World Viognier that's spot with classic aromas of peaches and apricots. Elegant, aromatic, dry and a great value from Oregon. Aged in wood - 15% of which was new to add more body.

wine.name: Rock Point, Pinot Grigio
wine.review: A vibrant, easy-drinking Pinot Grigio that is sippable and quite addictive with floral-citrus aromas and mineral on the finish. Great alone with a chill.

wine.name: Rock Point Red Blend
