wine.review: A juicy red blend that's based on Syrah and Cabernet Sauvignon. Aged in French oak for that added dose of spice. Great with anything from mushroom burgers to grilled sausages.

wine.name: Del Rio, Syrah
wine.review: A spicy Syrah that's full of dark cherry and blackberry fruits. Accessible tannins and a mildy oaked finish from barrique aging. Vibrant and full bodied.

wine.name: Chassagne-Montrachet Blanc, Carillon
wine.review: The Carillon Family have been making wine in Puligny Montrachet since the 16th century, using traditional methods to create wines that fully represent the terroir of the vineyards. The whites are barrel fermented and barrel aged and there is a small per cent of new oak used, but don't expect it to overwhelm.

wine.name: Puligny-Montrachet, Carillon
wine.review: With a long history of wine-making in Puligny Montrachet, the Carillon Family uses traditional methods to create wines that fully represent the terroir of the vineyards. This is a classic, clean and elegant white that can be enjoyed now or even benefit from a few years of age.

wine.name: Mckinley Spring Chenin Blanc, Horse Haven Hills
wine.review: The Horse Heaven Hills is bordered in the north by the Yakima hill, to the south by the Columbia River, and surrounded by the larger Columbia Valley appellation. The winds from the Columbia River protect against vine diseases and provide a cooling effect that concentrates fruit flavors, while the south facing slopes provide optimum growing conditions. This sustainable estate wine is an expressive 100% stainless steel Chenin with nice minerality and a pleasant hint of honey on the finish. With a slight chill it's easy to enjoy.

wine.name: Stuhlmuller Vineyards Estate Chardonnay
wine.review: Starting in 1998, Fritz Stuhlmuller gives us his Estate bottled, classic California-style oaked Chardonnay. Pair with chicken in a butter cream sauce.

wine.name: Montinore Pinot Noir, Willamette Valley
wine.review: A lovely old-world style Pinot Noir from Montinore Estate, while pale in color, the nose and palate burst with brambly raspberries and red cherries. Perfect paired with lighter fare or delicate meats.

wine.name: McKinley Springs Heaven’s Reward Late Harvest Chenin Blanc
wine.review: A delicious and refreshing dessert wine made from late harvested Chenin Blanc and sourced from one of their first vineyard blocks planted in 1981. The sweet nose is full of honeyed waffles and orange blossoms, with a hint of mandarin. Enjoy chilled with a fruit tart or crêpe

wine.name: Independent Producers "la Bourgeoisie" Merlot
wine.review: A great, lively Merlot from Washington State. Good structure, a nice nose of plums and a touch of thyme on the end. And yes, the label hooked us too.

wine.name: Taittinger Prestige Brut Rosé
wine.review: Perfect for any celebration with nice red berries and a softness on the end of the palate

wine.name: Brut Rosé, Le Colture
wine.review: A plump rosé sparkler made from primarily Merlot with lots of red berries and a nice solid finish; it's dry, but not bone dry.

wine.name: Cesca Vicent Priorat
wine.review: Cesca wines are small production wines from estate owned family vineyards that have been around since the 13th century. This is a nice, ripe modern approach with chalky appeal and a touch of chocolate.

wine.name: Mengoba Blanco
wine.review: The Bierzo region of Spain is best known for red wines but here is an excellent white Bierzo made from Godello and Doña Blanca. The delicate softly fruity grapes here are given extra depth and weight by leaving the wine on the lees for 7 months before bottling. Finely tuned and gently expressive, this top shelf white has immediate appeal as well as the potential to age well for several years

wine.name: Monasterio de Corias, Vino de la Tierra de Cangas
wine.appellation: Vino de la Tierra de Cangas
wine.review: Monasterio de Corias works exclusively with native grapes found on the mountain side region of Cangas located in northwest Spain. Made from a field blend of old vine Carrasquin, Verdejo Negro & Mencia, this light red was fermented with wild yeasts & bottled without filtration. The palate is packed with minerals & delicious bright fruit.

wine.name: Masia D Bielsa, Campo de Borja
wine.review: This cuvee is made at a small bodega whose average vine age is just over 30 years. Made from 100% Garnacha and fermented in stainless steel this wine has spicy raspberry & cherry on the nose, with subtle pepper & herbal notes adding complexity. Firm dark berry flavors are braced by zesty acidity and given grip by dusty tannins. Very easy to drink

wine.name: Clos de Noi, Montsant
wine.review: This small production wine by winemaker Carles Escolar is made from 50-60 year old 100% Samso (aka Carginan) and is a blend of 3 vineyard sites each representing the typical soils of the region – Chalk, Clay & Galets. This gripping wine has a nose of dark berries and graphite followed by an earthy & berried palate with a medium body.

wine.name: Primitivo Quiles "Raspay" Tinto
wine.review: Made from low-yielding 100% monastrell grapes grown in this exceptional winemaking region & produced in small batches using traditional techniques before being aged in old oak barrels and then, for a longer period, in bottle. A dark, intense wine in an oxidized style, so it's not for everyone - but an amazing experience, reminiscent of Chinato

wine.name: Primitivo Quiles "Fondillon" Gran Reserva
wine.review: Fermented by native yeast and never fortified. Aged in a solera that started in 1948 for decades. This small production wine shows an intriguing bouquet of cherry, strawberry preserves, maple, floral honey and smoked meat. Very complex in style, with powerful red berry flavors, a sappy texture, and vaguely oxidized, nutty qualities. Just when you think it's a sherry style, the exuberant red fruit snaps back hard. Intriguing, utterly singular wine; it ought to be fun to pair this with food, say, blue cheese.

wine.name: Montinore "Almost Dry" Riesling, Willamette Valley
wine.review: Another great wine from this biodynamic producer. This off-dry Riesling has a peachy nose with a zippy, fresh appeal.

wine.name: Yarraman Estate "Hell Raiser"
wine.review: "YARRAMAN" is an aboriginal word meaning "Wild Horse". Previously owned by Penfolds the Yarraman Estate Wybong vineyard has created this bold, yet easy drinking blend of Cabernet Sauvignon and Merlot. It’s a rich, plump & full flavored wine perfect for hearty meat dishes

wine.name: Stuhlmuller Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: This wine displays a dark ruby color with aromas of black cherry, blackberry, tealeaf, anise, currant and clove. The rich and soft mouthfeel echoes the bouquet with juicy layers of blackberry, dark cherry and currant, accented by spicy oak and fine-grained tannins. Easy drinking but not overwhelming

wine.name: Stuhlmuller Vineyards Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: This wine displays a dark ruby color with aromas of black cherry, blackberry, tealeaf, anise, currant and clove. The rich and soft mouthfeel echoes the bouquet with juicy layers of blackberry, dark cherry and currant, accented by spicy oak and fine-grained tannins. Easy drinking but not overwhelming

wine.name: Clendenen Family Vineyards Sauvignon Blanc, Stallion Vineyard
wine.review: A great example of Sauvignon Blanc from California with dried herbs and white pineapple on the nose, followed by a tangly lean expression on the palate. Delicious.

wine.name: Clendenen Family Vineyards "Le Bon Climat", Chardonnay
wine.review: A tangy and lean style Chardonnay with subtle vanilla notes. A lovely wine that everyone at the table will enjoy.

wine.name: Etoile Savagnin, Dom. de Montbourgeau
wine.review: A wildly complex white wine that's not for the faint at heart. Understand well that this delicious, dry wine is anything but ordinary. Tangy with roasted hazelnuts, citrus rind and mineral abound. Drink lightly chilled. Comes from the tiny Etoile sub-region of the Jura region of eastern France.

wine.name: Morgon, Domaine Chamonard
wine.review: With their winery in the center of the AOC & vineyards perfectly situated in the middle of the slopes with south and southwest exposures Dom. Chamonard gives us this brilliant Gamay full of dark cherries, meaty aromas, lots of classic, tangy granite minerals. 100% hand harvested, biodynamic old-vine vineyards lends to achieve an ideal ripeness of the grapes and lets the terroir shine through.

wine.name: “L’Insoumis du Village” , Reynald Héaulé
wine.review: The "black sheep" of the village, winemaker Reynald Héaulé is proud to be planting varietals that are uncommon for modern winegrowers in Orléans. This 100% Pinot Meunier gives leather & musk on the nose while the taste expresses a true raw, natural element to the wine. Quite intriguing!

wine.name: Auxey-Duresses Rouge 1er Cru, Dom. du Comte Armand
wine.review: Although best known for their Pommards, this 1er Cru bottling deserves a place in your cellar.

wine.name: Aloxe-Corton "Le Suchot", Dom. Simon Bize et Fils
wine.review: Domaine Simon Bize is one of the highly respected Burgundian addresses, a classic, or as the French are fond of saying, an ‘incontournable’ – ‘an absolute must’. Viticulture is all important here. The vines are Guyot trained; they are generally old, and yields are low, making wines from this producer quite special.

wine.name: Savigny-Les-Beaune Rouge "Les Bourgeots", Simon Bize et Fils
wine.review: One particularly appealing practice for this domaine is the sensible use of oak here, resulting in a wines of quality; this is without doubt one of Savigny's leading domaines.

wine.name: Clos de Vougeot Grand Cru Vieilles Vignes, Dominique Laurent
wine.review: An experienced practitioner of non-interventionist winemaking, Laurent labors intensively to preserve and feature the purity and freshness of the fruit and the character of the terroirs he works with.

wine.name: Auxey-Duresses Blanc, Maison Deux Montille Soeur et Frère
wine.winery: Maison Deux Montille Soeur et Frere
wine.review: Made by the small negociant firm run by Alix de Montille, and owned by Alix and her brother Etienne, who runs the famous Domaine de Montille in Volnay.

wine.name: Blaufränkisch, Rosi Schuster
wine.review: The estate was formed in 1979 where vines are planted in the most relevant parameters of microclimate, soil-type & growing season that best provide for each variety. This Blaufränkisch is an easy, light and ripe wine that was "built" in the vineyard & has little to do with the cellar work.

wine.name: Riesling "Rothenbart", Ludwig Neumayer
wine.review: Cultivated in limestone soil, this Riesling is dry, ripe and surprisingly evolved while maintaining a freshness on the nose. The palate has a delicacy that’s amazing, making this a must-try.

wine.name: Intrepid Wine Company, Ortrugo, Colli Piacentini
wine.review: The Ortrugo vareity is usually used in sparkling wine, but here we have a shining example of a fresh still white. With a hint of white pineapple, great minerality and a bright acidity this makes a perfect pair with sardines

wine.name: Intrepid Wine Company, Asprinio
wine.review: Coming from vines trellised 50 in the air, this 100% Asprinio offers a deep colored white with a nose of dried apples, dried pears and a touch of earth. A sweet oxidative ripeness shows on the palate while still remaining dry and fairly light. Best not to overchill.

wine.name: Cerasuolo di Vittoria, Gulfi
wine.review: A delightful red wine that's full of raspberry and currant fruit aromas. Delicate, dry, and incredibly fresh and playful.

wine.name: Colombaia Toscano IGT
wine.review: This biodynamic Tuscan white blend of 50% Trebbiano and 50% Malvasia offers delicate aromatics and a fresh, clean flavor. Enjoy with a light pasta dish.

wine.name: Chianti Colli Senesi, Colombaia
wine.review: With a lucious color and medium body this wine is lively and intense with dense mineral and blackberry fruit. Perfect for tomato based Tuscan dishes.

wine.name: Escoda Sanahuja "Les Paradetes", Conca de Barberá
wine.review: Biodynamic winemaker Joan-Ramon Escoda creates this lovely red blend in the Conca de Barbera appellation just south of Barcelona. The wine is lithe and elegant with a touch of mineral at the end.

wine.name: Escoda Sanahuja, "Coll del Sabater", Conca de Barberá
wine.review: Dark, medium bodied 100% Merlot with nice tannins on the end, lends itself to be a perfect wine with grilled meats.

wine.name: Del Rio, Chardonnay
wine.review: Del Rio Chard

wine.name: Aloxe-Corton, "Les Guerets" Camille Giroud
wine.review: The Giroud family makes classic Burgundy espousing old techniques that have proven their efficacy through the ages. This Pinot Noir is delicate, exuding minerals and red berries.

wine.name: Heitz "Trailside Vineyard" Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: In the early 1980s, the Heitz Family acquired the Trailside vineyard. Compared to Heitz's other single vineyards, this bottle is considered the most robust and powerful style with bold fruit and assertive but upfront use of new oak.

wine.name: Heitz Cellars "Martha's Vineyard" Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Martha's vineyard is 34 gently sloping acres on the western side of Napa Valley. In 1966, Martha's vineyard became the first vineyard-designated wine in Napa Valley. This is aged in mostly new casks adding a broad element of spice to the cassis fruit.

wine.name: Rosso di Montepulciano, Azienda Casale Daviddi
wine.review: An earthy Tuscan red wine with aromas of leather, red berries and spice. A great choice for tomato-based pastas or cured meats.

wine.name: Chinon "Canal des Grands Pièces", Domaine de L'R
wine.review: The first cuvée of Frédéric Sigonneau's first vintage, this Cab Franc truly gives a sense of place with hints of capsicum on the nose and lovely fruit on the palate.

wine.name: Mâcon-Cruzilles, Dom. Guillot Broux
wine.review: 100% Gamay with toasted cumin spice, pepperiness and a sanguin sweetness makes this a beautifully balanced wine; perfect for the dinner table.

wine.name: Château Tire Pé "Diem"
wine.review: A primarily Merlot blend that's tasty and easy drinking from 10 year old vines overlooking the Gironde River.

wine.name: Château Tire Pé
wine.review: Great, dark classic Bordeaux blend with a hint of tannins on the end, making this a great food wine.

wine.name: Dom. Les Clapas "Fesquier", VdP Coteaux de l'Ardèche
wine.review: Dom. les Clapas is a small, family run, organic vineyard with low yields making this a special find. 100% Grenache showing dark, ripe fruit and a richness on the palate. A fine example from this southern Rhône region.

wine.name: Chassagne-Montrachet, Ramonet
wine.review: This is a classic Burgundy Chardonnay with aromas of white flowers and apple fruits. Ramonet's village Chassagne-Montrachet is a wonderful example of classic Burgundy.

wine.name: Puligny-Montrachet "Enseigneres", Ramonet
wine.review: White Burgundy

wine.name: Meursault, Matrot
wine.review: Meursault

wine.name: Anjou Blanc "Effusion", Dom. Patrick Baudouin
wine.review: Winemaker Patrick Daudouin aims to do what Nicolas Joly achieves, but in a different terroir and this wine is proof. Great nose with powdery-schisty minerals and laden with baked floral fruit which all carries to palate.

wine.name: Amethyst Vinalia Napa Valley Red Table Wine
wine.review: An even blend of Nebbiolo and Sangiovese this fuller bodied red has seen some age and is now ready to drink, especially with a nicely prepared steak dinner.

wine.name: Chablis Vieilles Vignes, Defaix
wine.review: This Chablis is wonderfully concentrated with a lively, fresh attack followed by a sense of ripe fruit with hints of honey. The finish is incredibly long and quite mineral driven. This Chablis comes from 50 year old vines.

wine.name: Huia Brut, Marlborough
wine.review: Toasty rich nose with a quince tang on the palate. A fun and unique sparkler from New Zealand.

wine.name: Viña Aquitania Sol del Sol Chardonnay
wine.review: A "Chablis" style Chardonnay from the volcanic soil of the Malleco Valley, the southern most wine region on Chile. Expect ripe apple, vanilla and minerals on the nose and palate.

wine.name: Kuyen, Alto del Maipo Valley
wine.review: A dark blend of Syrah, Carmenère and Cabernet Sauvignon with soft oak on the end.

wine.name: Josep Foraster Crianza
wine.review: Powerful yet elegant aroma with currants, smokey notes, vanilla, chocolate and spice. The palate is meaty & complex with mature tannins. Perfect for hearty meat dishes, oily fish or cheese.

wine.name: Summers Charbono, Villa Andriana Vineyard
wine.review: With few Californian wineries growing Charbono; Summers Estate Wines produces the largest amount of this special wine annually. Dark briary fruit with vanilla and spice on the end. The volcanic soil lends a touch of mineral on the end.

wine.name: Beckmen Vineyards, Cuvee Le Bec
wine.review: A Rhône varietal blend, ever evolving with watermelon, spicy-sweet red and dark fruits and touch of black licorice. Biodynamic and 100% hand farmed.

wine.name: Beckmen Vineyards Syrah
wine.review: A product of the great 2007 growing season this deep dark Syrah shows rich fruit and melted chocolate followed by a spicy mid palate ripeness that makes this biodynamic Syrah a must have with duck mole!

wine.name: Heller Estate Cachagua, Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Heller Estate vineyards are dry-farmed, the roots of the vines descending deep in the loamy, sandy soil in search of the underground "Cachagua" (hidden) springs, producing this ripe Cabernet with blackberry and cassis aromas with a touch of mocha and vanilla.

wine.name: Terra Valentine, Cabernet Sauvignon
wine.review: Under new ownership since 1999 Angus and Margaret Wurtele are working to reinvigorate the quality and production of these wines. This full bodied Cabernet is a great example showing nice cassis fruit with red berries and a spicy sweet cedar on finish.

wine.name: Stadlmann Zierfandler Classic
wine.review: Difficult to pronounce yet so easy to drink, Zierfandler is a varietal that is planted to less than 200 hectares in the world, native to Austria and a fabulous food wine. This wine has lots of round, ripe fruit, chalky spritzy citrus, white peppercorn and a touch of floral notes.

wine.name: Crémant "Ludwig Hahn", Guy Bossard
wine.review: This crisp, mineral-driven sparkling wine hails from Nantes in the Loire Valley. One of the driest sparkling wines in the store, it makes an excellent apéritif. Producer Guy Bossard makes the wine from organically grown grapes.

wine.name: Maury Vin Doux Natural, La Coume du Roy
wine.review: Maury can be kept for decades and La Coume du Roy has been producing these unique dessert wines for over 5 generations and is the oldest in the AOC. The 1977 is more cognac-reddish in color and finishes slightly dryer with an almost mineral aspect; absolutely unique.

wine.name: Maury Vin Doux Natural, La Coume du Roy
wine.review: From the oldest producer in the AOC these Maury wines can age for decades. The 1965 shows a similarity to Madeira with a hint of sweetened iron minerals. A very interesting and special bottle.

wine.name: Vieux Muscat, La Coume du Roy
wine.review: From the oldest producer in the Maury AOC this vin doux naturel shows meyer lemon zestiness on the front palate with a sweetness that is not over top followed by a refreshing acid at the end. Delicious!

wine.name: Byrd-Cooper Zinfandel
wine.review: From the St. Helena region of Napa this medium bodied Zin has spicy brambly fruit and dark berries making it a very easy drink.

wine.name: Terrace Heights Estate, Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: A clean, lean style of Sauvignon Blanc with elegant quince and gooseberry fruit that keeps you coming back for more.

wine.name: Gevrey-Chambertin 1er Cru "La Perrière", Harmand-Geoffroy
wine.review: Clearly from a 1er Cru site the complexity includes raspberry, earth, mocha and black plum with nice tannic structure.

wine.name: Montepulciano d’Abruzzo "Ancilla", Ciavolich
wine.review: In ancient Rome traditionally young girls would serve wine to the nobility. Nowadays with its dark fruit and nice tannins this wine is worthy of a royal meal. Serve with a slight chill.

wine.name: Rosso di Montepulciano, Le Bertille
wine.review: Dark fruit, black cherries, nice tannins with a hint of graphite on the end. Complex and delicious

wine.name: Barolo, Camerano
wine.review: Very traditional style producer making very profound wines. This is rich and tannic with a hint of eucalyptus on the end. Fine now but a few years of age would be great.

wine.name: Morey-St.-Denis, Remi Jeanniard
wine.review: Beautiful ruby red color with a feminine nose full of red fruits & peppercorn; the palate is more firm without loosing acidity, or complexity.

wine.name: Cheverny Rouge "Le Clos des Carteries", Venier
wine.review: Christian Venier works biodynamicly and the natural approach really shines through this blend. Delicious and ripe with the classic hint of musk and bitter cherry. A wine not to be missed.

wine.name: Weinhof Sankt Anna, Mosel 2007 Kinheimer Rosenberg Riesling Kabinett
wine.review: Husband and wife team working in the classic style this wine displays a petrol evolution on the nose with nice plump fruit and a kiss of sweetness, all held together by bright acidity.

wine.name: Weinhof Scheu, Grauer Burgunder Kabinett
wine.review: Just at the boarder near Alsace and established in the mid Sixties, the Father and Son team are creating wines ranging from dry, off-dry and sweet dessert. This Pinot Gris is done in a true off-dry style with fresh peaches on the nose and packs nice minerality and crisp acidity.

wine.name: Weingut Heinz Nikola, Erbacher Honigberg Riesling Feinherb
wine.review: With a great community of support, this father and son team is producing lovely wines; even in tough vintages. This off-dry Riesling has a nice medium body with plump peaches on the nose and palate.

wine.name: Finnegan's Lake "FIN." Pinot Noir
wine.review: Grapes sourced from Caneros and Arroyo Grande, this light bodied Pinot has red fruits, cherry and spice making it ideal for year round drinking.

wine.name: Charles Ellner, Rosé Brut
wine.review: Blend of Pinot Noir and Chardonnay with a sweet watermelon aspect on the nose, the palate has delicate dried fruit/floral notes and a tangy end. Very pleasing mousse.

wine.name: Vin Santo "Dolce Ariana", Fattoria Viticcio
wine.review: Founded in 1960 the estate stands above the town of Greve in the heart of the Chianti Classico region. A beautiful dessert wine with dried sultanas and nuttiness on the nose, the palate is clean and not overly sweet.

wine.name: B.V. Noe, Rioja
wine.review: Located near the town of Alcanadre on the Ebro River which creates a micro climate within the arid region. Nice dark fruit with a plush mouth-feel, a blend of Tempranillo and Garnacha. Great for everyday drinking.

wine.name: Chiroubles, Damien Coquelet
wine.review: Damien Coquolet, stepson of George Descombe, has produced a standout in the world of Beaujolais. Crisp red fruit, light cranberry and minerals are followed by focused acidity.

wine.name: Touraine "Côt à Côt", Noella Morantin
wine.review: Young winemaker, Noella Morantin's first vintage of purchased vines formerly of the Clos Roche Blanche vineyards. A great wine with a pure nose of brambly fruit, a touch of cassis and dill that follow through the palate. Yummy!

wine.name: Valpolicella Classico Superiore, Monte dall’Ora
wine.review: Complex nose of earth, spice, tomato leaf and florals with a touch of minerals and tannins on the end. Non ripasso.

wine.name: Les Coccigrues Rouge, Yannick Pelletier
wine.review: A red blend that truly shows the minerals from the schist solid of the St. Chinian region while balancing with ripe red fruit. A very elegant wine.

wine.name: Umbria Bianco "Arboreus", Paolo Bea
wine.review: This brilliant white from the legendary Paolo Bea estate is made from a regional version of Trebbiano called "Spoletino." The wine spends four years on the lees, giving it a golden hue and fleshy complexity. Dry, full-bodied, and with striking minerality. Here the vines are trained high off the ground, a technique that was meant to leave room to plant other crops underneath. The wine takes his name from the Italian work for tree, "albero."

wine.name: Rosso de Veo, Paolo Bea
wine.review: From the youngest vineyards or vines Bea doesn't consider for his top labels, this is a medium bodied blend that spends only 1 year in cask. Blueberries, black berries, wild herbs and flowers with a touch of earth. Very accessible and drinking nicely today.

wine.name: Chassagne-Montrachet 1er Cru "En Remilly", Bruno Colin
wine.review: The most northerly of the Premiers Crus vineyards abutting Puligny Montrachet, here fourth generation winemaker Bruno Colin employs "la lutte raisonnée" in tending his vines and thus produces this classic style white.

wine.name: St. Laurent "Zagersdorf", Hannes Schuster
wine.review: From the limestony end of things, a rich, opulent and splendid expression of St Laurent: not only iron minerals, blackberries and plums, but also a hint of cherry from forty-year old vines.

wine.name: Riesling "Silberbichl", Stift Göttweig
wine.review: Mica-slate can be found in huge chunks on this “silver hill” where these Riesling vines grow in ideal soil. Aromas of pears, peach and marzipan with a fresh and fruity acidity that lasts long on the palate. Delicate and delicious.

wine.name: Riesling “Steinbuhel”, Malat
wine.review: From father/son team of Gerald & Michael Malat this Riesling opens with ripe stonefruit aromas and with a lively light spritz, nice notes of slate minerals on the palate.

wine.name: Wenzel SAZ Ruster Ausbruch
wine.review: At Winery Wenzel (“Family run since 1647”) history and tradition run very deep & results in some of the most exquisite noble sweet wines in the world. This is a blend of Muscat and Furmint showing botrytis on the nose with tones of apricot and finishing with a great acidity. The perfect partner for foie gras with date purée.

wine.name: Zweigelt, Feiler-Artinger
wine.review: The Feiler-Artinger winery was established in Rust in the early 1900 and 3rd generation winemaker Kurt Feiler gives us a classic Zweigelt that shows fruit, Floral and blueberry on the nose, spice, elegance and a softness of tannins that makes it a perfect food-pairing red.

wine.name: Banyuls Clos de Paulilles
wine.review: A fortified dessert wine from France showing aromas of hazelnuts, yellow plums, prune, and spice. This is very nice as an apéritif wine; enjoy it with a slight chill.

wine.name: Beaujolais Chardonnay, Terres Dorées, Brun
wine.review: Fruit, fat, and finesse, not to mention a solid mineral structure, have garnered rave reviews for this versatile white wine. For great value in a Chardonnay, it's tough to beat.

wine.name: Jurançon Sec Ch. Jolys
wine.review: This light, dry white comes from Jurançon, 30 miles from the Spanish border. With notes of ripe melon, a slight nuttiness, and great acidity, this is the perfect choice with rich shellfish dishes.

wine.name: Dom. Ott, Clair de Noir Rosé
wine.review: This is a classic and classy Provençal rosé: dry with light berry fruit and a clean, fresh finish. Perfectly elegant alone, but it fits seamlessly into a light meal of salad and white fish.

wine.name: Ch. de Roquefort, "Les Mûres"
wine.review: This very rich Provençale red has intriguing flavors of blackberry, black pepper, aromatic herbs and leather. Enjoy with intensely flavored meats, grilled and the like.

wine.name: Côte-Rôtie "Bassenon", Cuilleron
wine.review: A superstar of the Northern Rhône, this is a well made Côte-Rôtie (always Syrah with up to 20% Viognier permitted) which needs some time or decanting. Full bodied, peppery with dark, dark berried fruit and woodsy finish.

wine.name: St. Joseph "Serines" Cuilleron
wine.review: Drinking well now & within the next few years this is a full bodied Syrah with notes of tar and smoke, blackberry fruit and silky textured tannins.

wine.name: Sancerre "Apud Sariacum", Raimbault
wine.review: Like all great examples of Sancerre, this wine is characterized by a perfect marriage of place and grape variety. It shows perfectly ripened fruit and a fine-toned, racy minerality of white limestone.

wine.name: Pouilly-Fumé Buisson Renard, D. Dagueneau
wine.review: From the last vintage of winemaking genius, Didier Dagueneau, comes this stunningly creamy, age-worthy Sauvignon Blanc. Full of flinty mineral, voluptuous texture, and nervy acidity.

wine.name: Muscadet "Briords", Marc Ollivier
wine.review: Delicate aromas of granite and schist, white floral notes, sea shells and stones. This wine has depth, richness and complexity unparalleled in Muscadet.

wine.name: Nuits-St.-Georges, Gouges
wine.review: If you haven't had a chance to try the wines of Henri Gouges, start with this village Nuits and take a peek at how marvelously they handle Pinot Noir.

wine.name: Touraine Cabernet, Clos Roche Blanche
wine.review: Unassuming, unpretentious, but delicious in a red-fruity way, with enough tannic structure to keep it upright. It comes from one of our favorite producers, and offers one of the very best values in a red wine. It's organic too.

wine.name: Provignage Romorantin, Charmoise
wine.review: An amazing bottle of white wine made from pre-phylloxera vines that are over 120 years in age. Made from the delightful, indigenous variety, Romorantin. On the palate, incredible concentration and ripeness with yellow fruit - quince, yellow plums, honey and melon - and ripe minerals on the finish. What's not to love in a wine whose vines have outlived many of us.

wine.name: Ch. Pimpine, Côtes de Francs
wine.review: A small, organic estate from the Côtes de Francs. Merlot based with a touch of Cab Sauv. Lush cherry fruit aromas, bright acid & a hint of sage. Excellent wine from a less known Bordeaux area.

wine.name: "Racines" Les Cailloux du Paradis, Courtois
wine.review: B/N. A red blend made from Côt (Malbec) and Cabernet Franc. This wine is feral, mineral-driven, and packed with dark, earthy black fruits; it will change before your eyes. A food wine that will pair very well with rich, rustic meals.

wine.name: St.-Chinian "Travers de Marceau", Rimbert
wine.review: A tasty organic red made from Mourvèdre, Carignan, and Grenache. Notes of cedar and blackberry on the nose are sustained through the palate, along with black cherry and jam flavors. The tannins are present but smooth.

wine.name: Cahors, Clos Siguier
wine.review: A Malbec from the Cahors region of southwest France. It's fruit-driven but never guilty of excessive extraction, showing surprising aromas of blackcurrant fruit.

wine.name: Le Joyau du Château Le Queyroux
wine.review: Château Le Queyroux is an amazing estate in Bordeaux. This full-bodied red is made entirely from free-run juice from old vines of Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon and pre-phylloxera vines of Petit Verdot. Full of dark fruits with unbelievable concentration and smoky tannins.

wine.name: Arbois Chardonnay, Puffeney
wine.review: Jacques Puffeney is hailed as the master of the Arbois. We couldn't agree more that he's one of the top producers of these idiosyncratic wines, which many have yet to experience. His Chardonnay is the first grape he harvests each year. It's fermented in stainless steel and then aged in old casks for months before release. What's so distinctive about his wines is the mineral character and leesy, near fresh milk fruit on the palate. Gorgeous yellow stone fruit on the palate with raw honey and pollen on the finish.

wine.name: Petit Chablis, Dom. Ste. Claire, Brocard
wine.review: Petit Chablis is one of the 4 official ranks that all French Chablis fall into categorically. Consider this the beginner's Chardonnay but from such a solid producer that you’ll be amazed at the quality. This is an unoaked Petit Chablis that’s full of yellow plums, citrus fruit and even honey.

wine.name: Viognier VdP, Cuilleron
wine.review: Born in the hills of the northern Rhône, this Viognier is rich with notes of peaches and spice. Winemaker Yves Cuilleron is a fourth-generation vigneron who strives to revitalize Seyssuel's vineyard, which was popular in Roman times.

wine.name: Buzet, Baron d'Ardeuil
wine.review: This is primarily Merlot, blended with Cabernet Sauvignon and Cabernet Franc. A wine for Bordeaux fans and quite an impressive one at that, this is an excellent value.

wine.name: Cairanne, Richaud
wine.review: The wine is deep and dark, powerful and elegant, superbly balanced, a great Côtes du Rhône from one of the superstars of the appellation.

wine.name: Côtes du Rhône Brézème, Eric Texier
wine.review: Classic example of cool-climate Syrah from the northern Rhône. It shows fat smoky tar and game over huckleberry and black currant fruit; has great acidity and staying power so give it lots of air.

wine.name: Saumur Blanc, Vignerons de Saumur
wine.review: Dry, fresh and wonderfully aromatic of white flowers, honey and citrus. This is a fruity style of wine made from 100% Chenin Blanc, in the Saumur region of the Loire Valley.

wine.name: Châteauneuf-du-Pape, Ch. La Nerthe
wine.review: Full of ripe, earthy fruit along with a good tannic backbone. This wine has a nice, slightly chalky character to it that addd complexity. Drinking well today but could still be cellared for a few years to come.

wine.name: Pouilly-Fuissé, "Vernays", Ferret
wine.review: Madame Ferret makes Pouilly-Fuissé that so far exceeds the quality of most of her neighbors' wines that they are better compared with best of Puligny or Chassagne. A great example of top white Burgundy.

wine.name: Crozes-Hermitage, "Les Jalets," Jaboulet
wine.review: Soft and rich with spicy blackcurrant flavor, this value-driven Rhône red is made by noted producer Paul Jaboulet-Aîné. Some of the Syrah is sourced from younger vines that are grown in the same soil as the superb Thalabert Crozes-Hermitage.

wine.name: Mâcon-Villages, Verget
wine.review: One of the star producers of white Burgundy. This Chardonnay, has just a hint of buttery oak and elegance that lasts right through its long finish.

wine.name: Pinot Blanc "Herrenweg", Baur
wine.review: Aromas of white peach and pear greet the nose; this is a soft, easy-drinking white wine with a full, aromatic bouquet.

wine.name: Savennières "Clos Papillon", Closel
wine.review: Clos du Papillon is one of the two or three best vineyards in Savennières, always giving a wine of richness and powerful minerality. This is an excellent vintage, especially notable for harmony.

wine.name: Touraine Pinot Noir, Puzelat
wine.review: This Loire Valley Pinot Noir is made from the reputable Thierry Puzelat. Pure Pinot Noir character on the palate with lusty red raspberries, thyme and cherries. Tastes like freshly crushed berries that will make you coming back for more.

wine.name: Côtes du Rhône "Grandes Vignes," D'Estezargues
wine.review: This great wine from a Natural winemaker is full of dark fruit, with tiny suggestions of smoke and game. Great now in the flush of youth but also shows interesting medium-term aging potential.

wine.name: Minervois, Ch. d'Oupia
wine.review: An aromatic and densely colored red wine, full-bodied with generous blackberry and raspberry flavors. Fine tannins, along with accents of pepper and spice, make this an elegant and well-balanced wine.

wine.name: Gaillac, Ch. Lastours
wine.review: From the Gaillac area in southwest France, this red blend is soft and easy to drink, with aromas of green peppers, spices and black cherries. It's great with game dishes.

wine.name: Sancerre "Croix de Roy", Lucien Crochet
wine.review: Outstanding, textbook Sancerre. Lucien Crochet is renowned for his excellent Loire wines, and "La Croix Du Roy" is one of them. With bright citrus fruit with delightful earthy and herbal tones, this is exactly what a great Sancerre should be.

wine.name: Sancerre Rouge Croix du Roy, Crochet
wine.review: The soil composition of Crochet's vineyards yields wines that are highly aromatic with excellent balance of pure and delicate fruit with fine minerality. This cuvee comes fron 35 yr old vines.

wine.name: Cahors, Ch. de Haute-Serre
wine.review: Of France's "country wines" no appellation produces a more robust and age-worthy red than the Southwest's Cahors. This velvety beauty is just now blossoming with black fruit, herbal and mineral flavors blending in a long, toasty finish.

wine.name: Bienvenues Bâtard-Montrachet Grand Cru Blanc, Paul Pernot
wine.review: Grand Cru white Burgundy that you shouldn't but could drink for breakfast. Racy, with aromas of honeysuckle, poached pears and minerals. A wine to age but perfect for the impatient types who like their Burgundy young.

wine.name: Roussette du Bugey, Montagnieu "Altesse", Peillot
wine.review: This is a very ripe style of wine with aromas of honey and apple on the palate. Give it just a light chill and enjoy alongside anything from chicken to rich seafood dishes.

wine.name: Dr. Loosen Riesling
wine.review: An off-dry Riesling with all that peach fruit character you've grown to love. Reach for this entry-level Riesling any time you're in the mood for a fresh, fruity white with a touch of sweetness.

wine.name: Pouilly-Fumé, "Silex", D. Dagueneau
wine.review: Simply the best Pouilly-Fumé produced. This is the top cuvée from legendary grower, Didier Dagueneau. Fantastic concentration and complexity due to Dagueneau's meticulous sorting of grapes for ultimate ripeness. The wine is known for its unique ability to express the inherent smokiness of the flint or "Silex" soil of Pouilly-Fumé. Dagueneau is a rebel who is renowned for his desire to adhere to the traditional methods of the region and to make his wines as expressive as they can be or terroir. He is from a family of vignerons; he began making wine in 1982 but his wines are thought to have come into their own a few years later when he began aging in old oak barrels. He is opposed to malolactic fermentation in all vintages.

wine.name: Riesling, Trimbach
wine.review: A family-run winery since 1626 with some of the best Grand Cru vineyards in Alsace. This, the basic Riesling, is delicate yet firm, fresh, dry and finely mineral.

wine.name: Gewürztraminer, Trimbach
wine.review: Classic Alsatian Gewürztraminer: dry, elegant, and mineral, with fine floral aromas. A very nice bottle, and an excellent introduction to one of the most delicious and distinctive grape varieties there is.

wine.name: Riesling, Hugel
wine.review: Sometimes we think Alsace is the best-kept secret in the wine world. This value bottling is a perfect example. It's a perfectly balanced dry Riesling with ripe peach and apricot aromas.

wine.name: Sancerre, Lucien Crochet
wine.review: This is a pure, unoaked Sauvignon Blanc from the region of Sancerre. Incredibly fresh, full of minerals and smoky subtle fruits. Excellent with seafood.

wine.name: Fleurie, Clos de la Roilette
wine.review: Complex, structured, broad-shouldered cru Beaujolais with pure berry fruit, floral notes, and herbal accents. Excellent now - and even better in five years.

wine.name: Pouilly-Fumé, "Pur Sang", D. Dagueneau
wine.review: The wines of Dider Dagueneau are unrivalled in the world of Sauvignon Blanc. Due to his choice to age in old oak, Dagueneau's wines take on a creaminess as well as an ability to age that is unusual for the region. The "Pur Sang" is as beautiful as the "Silex" but with less emphasis on smoky minerality.

wine.name: Côtes du Rhône, Rouge, Dom. Pelaquié
wine.review: From the quaint village of Laudun on the Rhône's western bank comes this spicy, rustic Côtes du Rhône. It's 60% Grenache blended with Syrah, Mourvèdre, Cinsault and Counoise. Try with grilled sausages or chili.

wine.name: Chablis, "Côte de Lechet", Defaix
wine.review: This Chablis offers a great sense of terroir with notes of orange, honey and apricot flavors. This winery produces Chablis with a rare combination of finesse and complexity. Always a favorite in our books.

wine.name: Mouton Cadet Rouge
wine.review: The Mouton Cadet wine has always been a standby when you're looking for affordable Bordeaux.

wine.name: Ch. Fourcas-Hosten, Listrac
wine.review: A densely colored, full-bodied wine. This wine has firm tannins and a dry, earthy flavor. This wine should be allowed to breathe and served with red meat. This wine comes from the small Listrac region of Bordeaux on some of the highest elevations of the Médoc.

wine.name: Ch. Tour de Goupin Rouge, Organic
wine.review: Organically grown Merlot, Cabernet Sauvignon, and Cabernet Franc are the ingredients in this straightforward, easy-drinking Bordeaux red. It's light, dry, attractive, and from the vintage of a lifetime.

wine.name: Ch. Tour de Goupin Blanc, Organic
wine.review: This bright white Bordeaux, a blend of organically grown Sauvignon Blanc, Sémillon, and Muscadelle, has zingy citrus notes and a crisp mouthfeel. Drink this with seafood or white meats for a great pairing.

wine.name: Ch. Graville-Lacoste, Graves
wine.review: Château Graville-Lacoste delivers a crisp and dry, medium-bodied Graves full of rich, fruity, herbal character. The classic white Bordeaux blend of Sauvignon Blanc and Semillon, it has a fresh, lingering finish. Remarkable personality for the price.

wine.name: Ch. Picau Perna, St.-Émilion
wine.review: This Merlot-based red offers all the elegance and plummy fruit that you want in a Bordeaux. You'll also find a touch of fresh herbs, soft tannins, and an elegant finish. This is a fantastic find from St.-Émilion at an unbelievable price.

wine.name: Ch. Roc de Boissac, St.-Émilion, Kosher
wine.review: Unique blend of spice notes with dark plum, cassis and hints of leather and cigar box. Tight and deep tannins require decanting before serving.

wine.name: Ch. Léoville-las-Cases, St. Julien
wine.review: Concentrated and powerful, yet elegantly refined, Léoville-Las-Cases is classic. The superb 1986 from this estate (located next to Pauillac's Latour), is rich, full-flavored with intense aromas of cassis, spices and vanilla.

wine.name: Ch. La Conseillante, Pomerol
wine.review: In blind tastings, Ch. La Conseillante frequently comes ahead of the top estates. This bottle is no different in our opinion.

wine.name: Ch. Léoville-Las-Cases, St.-Julien
wine.review: A dark, intense and concentrated Bordeaux from Château Léoville-Las Cases. The tannic structure is just beginning to dissolve. From the renown 1982 vintage. Drinking well today but still has years of life.

wine.name: Rouge Côt, Clos Roche Blanche
wine.review: This is Côt from vines over 100 years old. Côt is synonym for Malbec. It is always intensely tannic and deeply ripened dark berried fruit.

wine.name: Ch. La Mondotte, St.-Émilion
wine.review: La Mondotte is a gigantic example of garagiste Bordeaux made from Merlot and Cabernet Franc. Fermented and aged in barrrel as well as aged on the lees for some time, the wine is opaque, plush, and full or espresso, dark chocolate, and vanilla notes. RP of The Wine Advocate believes it will age through 2035.

wine.name: Ch. Haut Surget, Lalande-de-Pomerol
wine.review: The Merlot-based Château Haut Surget is a perennial Astor favorite. Vintage to vintage, this red Bordeaux consistently shows exceptional concentration and dense black fruit.

wine.name: Ch. d'Arcins, Haut-Médoc
wine.review: Château d'Arcins offers a great bottle of red wine with all the cassis and plum aromas we desire in a Bordeaux. Enjoy today with any rich meat dishes.

wine.name: Ch. Valandraud, St.-Émilion
wine.review: Old school fans of Valandraud should be cautioned that this is a more elegant vintage for the Château than some. It is medium bodied and displayed a certain youthful roughness that suggests superior aging potential. The tannins are just now beginning to mellow. Think tobacco, cedar, and chocolate/mocha notes.

wine.name: Ch. Greysac, Médoc
wine.review: From a classic Cabernet vintage, this quintessential Médoc Bordeaux is deeply colored, with pleasant aromas of plummy fruit, chocolate and earth. The tannins are firm, but balanced nicely by the wine's fleshy ripeness. This wine will age nicely for 5 to 7 years, but is drinking nicely now with a good decanting. A fine match for roast leg of lamb.

wine.name: Ch. Léoville-Las-Cases, St.-Julien
wine.review: This is drinking wonderfully today with elegant, lithe, dark berry fruit on the palate. There's a soft backbone of tannin and beautiful balance.

wine.name: Ch. Ducru Beaucaillou, St.-Julien
wine.review: The exceptional conditions of this vintage are no doubt marked in this bottle by more agressive tannins. You'll also find gravel minerals and a distinct fresh tobacco aroma that's mesmerizing. One of the 14 classified Second Growths from the 1855 Classification.

wine.name: Ch. La Grange Clinet, 1er Côtes de Bordeaux
wine.review: Intense black berry and blueberry fruit with hints of cedar and full, ripe tannins. Excellent with game birds (goose, duck) or Steak au Poivre.

wine.name: Ch. Lamothe Blanc, Bordeaux
wine.review: A classic Bordeaux Blanc offering a pretty nose of citrus and peach in harmony with refreshing acidity. This delicate wine is a perfect apéritif or enjoy with light fish dishes.

wine.name: Ch. La Rame, Ste.-Croix-du-Mont
wine.review: The Ste.-Croix-de-Mont appellation is considered the finest of the trio of sweet wines (with Loupiac and Cadillac) across the Garonne River from Sauternes. This wine is botrytis-affected in a somewhat lighter style than traditional Sauternes.

wine.name: Ch. Haut Segottes, St.-Emilion
wine.review: Danielle Andre took over her father's estate in 1972, and tradition still reigns at Haut Segottes. Harvest is performed manually. Fermentation takes place in cuve. Wines are rotated into barrel for an "élevage" of approximately 18 months; 20% of the barrels are new. The wine is mostly Cabernet Franc, with the remainder made of Merlot. The result of all this meticulous, traditional winemaking is a spectacular yet elegant red Bordeaux.

wine.name: Ch. La Peyre, St.-Estèphe
wine.review: A hearty red that's based on Cabernet Sauvignon (from gravel-based soils) and Merlot (coming from clay-based soils - ideal for Merlot). This estate only has 15 hectares of vines. Harvest is done manually and the new oak regimen is limited to 40% new oak maximum.

wine.name: Dom. de Jaugaret, St-Julien
wine.review: This domain has a mere 1.3 hectares of vineyards planted with old vines, made up almost exclusively of Cabernet Sauvignon (80%) with some Petit Verdot and Malbec to supplement this classic Medoc structure. Beautiful concentration. This is wine that will last for decades.

wine.name: Ch. Bonnet, Entre-Deux-Mers
wine.review: A delightful and refreshing blend, and a perfect introduction to white Bordeaux. With aromatic peach and melon scents and a crisp, dry finish, it's a treat on its own, or before dinner with delicately flavored snacks.

wine.name: Albariño, Fefinanes
wine.review: One of our drier Albariños, this one has a mineral edge and floral peach aromas. This was absolutely made for shellfish and other light seafood dishes.

wine.name: Berg Roseneck Riesling TBA, Leitz
wine.review: If there ever be a recent vintage of Trockenbeerenauslese you should buy, it's this bottle. All wines from the Leitz estate turned out marvelously this year. You can hold this dessert wine for years to come.

wine.name: Nebbiolo d'Alba "Valmaggione", Brovia
wine.review: A great value in Nebbiolo for those of you who crave Barolo but are saving that bottle for the right occasion. This is drinking very well right now: berries, plums, and almonds shine through on the palate, and the finish is firm and tannic.

wine.name: Kied Gräf Riesling Auslese, Weil
wine.review: From the slatey slopes of the Rheingau comes this fine dessert wine. It has exquisite aromas of peach, apricot and honeysuckle backed up by firm acidity.

wine.name: Sagrantino "Pagliaro", Paolo Bea
wine.review: Dark fruit aromas: black cherries, blackberries, currants. Dry, full-bodied and structured with exquisitely ripened character. Paolo's wines speak for themselves, honest, made to live through the ages.

wine.name: Ghemme, Cantalupo
wine.review: Ghemme is an appellation in Piedmont known for its lighter, more approachable Nebbiolo. Violets, rose petals, earthy cherries, and fine rustic acidity shine through in this distinctively northern Italian red wine.

wine.name: Sagrantino Passito, Paolo Bea
wine.review: In addition to their Sagrantino-based wines, this tiny estate grow olives, fruits and veggies and is as self sufficient in these modern times as you can find. This dessert wine is rich with notes of sweet prunes and figs. Tannic yet elegant. Amazing.

wine.name: Riesling "Privat," Nigl
wine.review: A multi-faceted jewel of a wine, with an endless procession of flavor nuances, all silken, soft, and approachable. Notes of white pepper and celery seed come forth on the finish, along with a lasting minerality.

wine.name: Le Muraglie Rosso, Ezio Voyat
wine.review: Ezio Voyat, a legend in the world of obsure bottles, was not a winemaker by trade but spent his days as the croupier in his home town of Chambave. Discover the mystery and romance that shrowd his wines with the "Muraglie," a profound and delicate blend of Dolcetto, Petit Rouge, and Gros Vien. The wine is brambly and red fruited on the nose with pretty aromas of raspberry and raspberry seed, red currant, and cranberry. The palate is simultaneously mellow and intense , finishing with soft tannins.

wine.name: La Gazzella, Ezio Voyat
wine.review: This dry Moscato was a favorite of Ezio Voyat's. The wine is remarkably subtle on the nose for muscat, giving understated floral aromas and an array of minty and herbal notes. The palate has intriguing texture and weight that seem to further explain the pride Voyat took in creation.

wine.name: Il Santo, Zari Dino
wine.review: Just like a Vin Santo except it's not aged as long as Vin Santo and therefore cannot have "Vin Santo" on the label. A dessert wine where the grapes are left to dry through the winter after harvest before pressing. Sweet on the palate with, naturally, a dried fruit characteristic - dried sultanas, prunes and spice. Drink with a light chill and enjoy with biscotti as is done in Italy.

wine.name: Le Muraglie Ambrato, Ezio Voyat
wine.review: Here is a masterfully made passito with intriguing tea and dried fruit notes on the nose. Though there is no shortage of residual sugar in this bottle, the wine seems balanced due to its mouth watering acidity. The texture is extremely luscious, the finish full of sultana and dried apricot flavors.

wine.name: Norheimer Dellchen Riesling Auslese, Dönnhoff
wine.review: The Dönnhoff estate offers some of the most incredibly elegant Rieslings around.

wine.name: Barbaresco, Produttori del Barbaresco
wine.review: This comes from a "Cantine Sociale", also known as a cooperative of growers known as Produttori del Barbaresco. This is in fact the most important wine of their lineup since it comprises the bulk of their production. Youthful upon opening with dark berries and chalk-driven tannins.

wine.name: Falanghina "Campi Flegrei", Cantine Farro
wine.review: Falanghina thrives on the volcanic soil of Campania. On the palate, you'll taste notes of quince, pear skin and white flowers. The texture is silken and the finish is lightly mineraled. This is a dry white wine that can certainly be enjoyed alone but, as always, does even better with food. Seafood or light meats would be the natural choice.

wine.name: Il Frappato, Valle dell'Acate
wine.review: A dry red made from Frappato, a very Sicilian grape variety. Pretty from the start, this scrumptious wine is ruby red in color, with firm raspberry fruit and lively acidity. It is the perfect easy-drinking wine to enjoy every day with Italian red sauce dishes.

wine.name: Fiano "Kratos", Maffini
wine.review: Grown in Campania, this Fiano is an unusually full white with crisp fruit characteristics and a beautiful dry finish. Herbs and flowers appear on the nose and are accompanied by apples and melons on the palate.

wine.name: Bernkastel Kurfurstlay Riesling, J&H Selbach
wine.review: When one can drink such a delightfully lively and fruity white for this price, it's a wonder that anyone pays more for mediocre Chardonnay. Those in the know, however, will reap the benefits both at the table and the cash register.

wine.name: Chianti Classico "Berardenga", Fèlsina
wine.review: Delicious Chianti Classico from one of Tuscany's top estates. Packed with ripe red berry fruit and displaying Felsina's typical finesse, this is a truly memorable bottle.

wine.name: Chianti Colli Senesi, Villa Sant'Anna
wine.review: Traditional blend of Sangiovese and Canaiolo. Red and black cherry laced with leather and licorice. Smooth texture, excellent balance.

wine.name: Moscato d'Asti "Sourgal", Perrone
wine.review: Lightly sparkling, lightly sweet, and light in alcohol - but heavy on the joyous tropical fruit flavors.

wine.name: Bigaro, Elio Perrone
wine.review: What's this you ask? A lightly sparkling, lightly sweet rosato wine from Piedmont made from the red Brachetto grape and the ever-aromatic white Moscato grape. Not only is this pretty to gaze at, it also has remarkable raspberry and lychee aromas.

wine.name: Cirò Rosso, Librandi
wine.review: Cirò is produced from Gaglioppo, the most important grape variety in Calabria. This red has spicy fruit on the nose, with an elegant texture supported by firm, ripe tannins.

wine.name: Santacroce, Castell'in Villa
wine.review: This is a fantastic, full-bodied red wine that's just beginning to show some evolution in the bottle. It's packed with black fruits - berries, plums, and cassis especially - and is rounded off with brilliant minerals and tobacco on the finish. This wine is a delight.

wine.name: Terre di Tufi, Teruzzi & Puthod
wine.review: This blend of Vernaccia, Chardonnay, Malvasia, and Vermentino is barrel-fermented, yielding a wine full of bright and vivid fruits ranging from pineapple to peach. Made in a lush, medium-bodied style, the barrel ageing adds an undercurrent of vanilla and lovely toasty nuances than permeate the wine. A great match for baked sea fish.

wine.name: Vermentino, "La Cala", Sella & Mosca
wine.review: Sella & Mosca, founded in 1899 by Piedmontese Emilio Sella and Edgardo Mosca, is Sardinia's top winery. This Vermentino is made at its huge estate on the north side of the island. Delicate and floral, this may be enjoyed as an apéritif or with light fare.

wine.name: Isola di Nuraghi "Perdera", Argiolas
wine.review: Monica di Sardegna, a grape of Spanish origin, produces a dry, ruby-red table wine on the Mediterranean island of Sardinia. This soft, easy-drinking bottle hails from Antonio Argiolas's winery, located outside of Caligari, the capital city.

wine.name: Gattinara, Antoniolo
wine.review: Gattinara is the little brother to Barbaresco and Barolo. Also made from 100% Nebbiolo, the wine is powerful with the classic regional flavors of tar and roses.

wine.name: Santa Cristina, Antinori
wine.review: This blend of Sangiovese and Merlot is a brilliant ruby red color, with intense fresh fruit aromas and pleasant floral notes. The finish sweet tannins and pleasant, lingering fruit.

wine.name: Rosso Ibleo, Gulfi
wine.review: The Gulfi winery's entry-level Nero d'Avola, a radiant red that offers juicy raspberry fruit, lively acidity and a touch of spice. This is a wine that benefits from air: try it before and after decanting and you'll easily taste the difference.

wine.name: Nero Màccari, Gulfi
wine.review: Nero d'Avola sourced from the Màccari vineyard, where it develops high acidity in the sunny Sicilian climes. This rich red wine has notes of blackberries, blueberries, eucalyptus, and tobacco.

wine.name: Gavi, La Zerba
wine.review: An elegant Gavi with honeydew, green apple aromas and vibrant minerals on the finish. Livio Lorenzi comes from a 200-year family tradition of northern Italian farmers. He moved to Tassarolo in the 1970s and purchased the 12 hectare estate of La Zerba.

wine.name: Chianti Classico, Cennatoio
wine.review: Just as the name implies, this is a classic Chianti, based on the Sangiovese grape with a touch of the (literally) colorful Colorino grape. This is a medium-bodied red wine with a lot of black berried fruit aromas. The tannins are mineral-based. This is a must with rich foods.

wine.name: Roero Arneis, Brovia
wine.review: The Brovia estate of Piedmont is a favorite among our Barolo collectors. This gorgeous dry wine, made from the Arneis grape, is their only white. This has aromas of pears, apples, acacia honey, and almonds. A silken texture makes it very satisfying alone, and it's stunning with white meat and seafood.

wine.name: La Segreta Rosso, Planeta
wine.review: A blend of mostly Nero D’avola with dollops of Merlot and Syrah. This is a big, easy-drinking introduction to the pleasures of Italian wine. Distinctly and unapologetically fruit-forward yet not simple. The fruit is draped over sufficient structure to keep it all interesting and the plum and cherry fruits benefit greatly from the distinct spicy notes that Syrah brings to the blend. Great with burgers.

wine.name: Dolcetto d' Alba, Roagna
wine.review: We fell in love with this wine over eggplant parmigiana! With its lush raspberry and red cherry fruit paired with refreshing acidity, this wine's style makes it perfect for year-round enjoyment.

wine.name: La Segreta Bianco, Planeta
wine.review: This unusual blend combines Grecanico, Chardonnay, Viognier, and Fiano into one exciting package. The nose has lovely notes of honeysuckle and lilac in addition to the prominent, crisp citrus and tropical fruits. In the mouth it is unexpectedly rich, oozing orchard fruit flavors with a nice refreshing note of minerality keeping everything taut and lively. This is a great apéritif wine and a lovely choice for simple fish dishes.

wine.name: Carema White Label, Ferrando
wine.review: Nebbiolo from the tiny district of Carema expresses itself in a much more reserved fashion. Here we offer you an excellent bottle for an unbelievable price. This is a lighter version with telltale nebbiolo aromas of violets, tar and white pepper.

wine.name: Brachetto, Gatti
wine.review: A lightly sparkling red dessert wine with raspberry and strawberry aromas. A lightly sweet, festive wine to please the palate.

wine.name: Monte Antico Rosso
wine.review: From the hills of southern Tuscany comes this Sangiovese based red. Easy drinking for every day meals.

wine.name: Teroldego Rotaliano, Foradori
wine.review: Okay, so some grapes were obviously not named by Madison Avenue. But whenever we find a wine as delightful and distinctive as this ripe, blackberry-flavored red, we happily take on any pronunciation-related challenges that may be involved in offering it to our customers.

wine.name: Sangue di Giuda Paradiso, Verdi
wine.review: A slightly sweet, slightly frizzante red wine from Oltrepò Pavese. Enjoy this uniquely styled wine with a light chill alongside prosciutto and other cured meats.

wine.name: Pierre Brigandat Brut
wine.review: Brigandat is a small organic grower. This is made entirely from Pinot Noir. Dry on the palate with aromas of strawberries and a touch of brioche.

wine.name: Lagrein, Muri Gries
wine.review: This is a red wine made by monks in an 11th-century monastery just south of the Bremmer Pass. Lagrein, a variety that yields wines of surprising depth and elegance, is a cool-climate cousin of Syrah that is indigenous to the Alto Adige. Complex and lithe, this wine is great with a variety of foods from salmon to butternut squash ravioli.

wine.name: Pinot Grigio, Santi
wine.review: The type of white wine you wanna drink on a warm day. Easy with water-like freshness that makes it all the more approachable and easy to drink alone.

wine.name: Etrusco - Etrurian, Cennatoio
wine.review: Concentrated, elegant, and rich, this 100% Sangiovese Grosso has exquisite blackberry aromas, with notes of smoke, leather and anise. It drinks well today with decanting, but will certainly evolve and improve with age. This is aged in 50% new barrique, but the oak is unobtrusive on the palate.

wine.name: Duca San Felice Riserva, Librandi
wine.review: A nice spicy red, made from the Gaglioppo grape variety in Southern Italy's Calabria region. This vintage brought out more dark fruit than most, but the wine maintains its trademark dark spice aromas.

wine.name: Counoise VdP, Ramière, Monpertuis
wine.review: A very pretty Vin de Pays from the southern Rhône. It's on the lighter side, a little bit rustic, fairly distinctive, and very charming and delicious.

wine.name: Brunello di Montalcino, Poggio di Sotto
wine.review: Poggio di Sotto is driven to show the beauty of the Sangiovese grape. This is a traditional estate and in a vintage such as 1999 you'll find that this regal grape, when in the right hands, ages marvelously. The ultimate representation of classical Brunello producers.

wine.name: Barbera d'Alba "Sori del Drago", Brovia
wine.review: Medium-bodied with voluptuous plum fruit. As is so typical of Barbera, this is dangerously easy-drinking. A bottle for those who crave a red with substance without a highly tannic backbone.

wine.name: Antinori Villa Red IGT
wine.review: Red berries and light oaky aromas on this red. Unobtrusive tannins make it go well with a huge range of meat dishes.

wine.name: Barolo "Ciabot Mentin Ginestra", Clerico
wine.review: A rich, modern style of Barolo with lots of intensity on the nose and palate. Flavors of licorice, spice, and forward dark fruit abound here. A Barolo that will benefit from a few years in the cellar but can also be drunk young.

wine.name: Chianti Classico Riserva "Oro", Ruffino Gold Label
Montepulciano d'Abruzzo Riserva, Zaccagnini
wine.review: A terroir-driven wine that even comes with its own piece of grapevine on the bottle. Loaded with floral aromas, dates, and red berries, this medium-bodied red is great with pizza and red-sauce dishes.

wine.name: Est! Est! Est!, Falesco
wine.review: Light and simple, Est! Est! Est! is made from the Trebbiano and Malvasia Bianca grapes in the town of Montefiascone, north of Rome in Latium. This crisp, dry, refreshingly fruity white wine works with just about any dish you can think of.

wine.name: Primitivo, Cantele
wine.review: A chunky, plummy red from Apulia in Southern Italy. Great for everyday drinking.

wine.name: Amarone, Le Ragose
wine.review: Classic Amarone, the finest we stock. Vivid red berries, exquisite ripe acidity and balance give this wine longevity. Elegance in Amarone is hard to find. This is exemplary.

wine.name: Refosco, Il Roncal
wine.review: A dry, full-bodied red wine from the Friuli region of northern Italy. Full of dark, spicy, musky dark berries with great, mineral-driven tannins. Made from the Refosco grape variety and a natural match for cured meats and cheeses.

wine.name: Sassicaia
wine.review: The first vintage of Sassicaia was made in 1968; thus the "Super Tuscan" was born. The wine is mostly Cabernet with a touch of Cabernet Franc. It is made in the image of a great Bordeaux and, like great Bordeaux, will age for a very long time in your cellar.

wine.name: Vernaccia, Montenidoli Fiore
wine.review: This Vernaccia from the hilltop town of San Gimignano has notes of ripe lemons and melon, while remaining dry on the finish. This wine is very fresh and is great as an apéritif or with lighter fare.

wine.name: Côte-Rôtie "Chavaroche", Levet
wine.review: From the Côte Brune, this wine always has good structure and benefits from extended aging. This is more approachable than usual, with rich, sweet fruit surrounded by fat and smoke.

wine.name: Vega Sindoa Cabernet-Tempranillo
wine.review: A delightful combination, this Cabernet-Tempranillo from Spain's northern Navarra region is full of juicy berry fruit. Soft and smooth with dark fruits and an international, fruit-forward approach.

wine.name: Remelluri, Rioja
wine.review: A very unusual single vineyard production from Rioja. Massive texture reminiscent of classic Bordeaux. Full-bodied and dry.

wine.name: Rüdesheimer Klosterlay Riesling Kabinett, Leitz
wine.review: This Riesling is chiseled just right with minerals, mint leaf, and peaches on the palate. Tangy and just delightfully fresh.

wine.name: "Il Mimo" Nebbiolo Rosato, Cantalupo
wine.review: A pink Nebbiolo that's dry, full-bodied, and lush, with gorgeous cherry fruit. This wine is more than ready to convert anyone still harboring rosé reservations.

wine.name: "G" Dehesa Gago
wine.review: This wine is made entirely from the Tinto de Toro grape, better known as Tempranillo. The “G” is fermented in stainless steel, allowing its pristine aromas of black plum, cherry and spice to be perfectly preserved.

wine.name: Barbera d'Asti, Chiarlo
wine.review: A simple, quaffing red wine that you don't have to think about. Plum and blackberry fruit, a hint of spice and tangy acids make this a good match for lively tomato-based dishes.

wine.name: Muga, Reserva
wine.review: Rich, black currant-cherry aromas & flavors. A top-value reserve bottling, unfiltered with a smoky, spicy edge.

wine.name: Marqués de Murrieta "Castillo Ygay" Gran Reserva Especial
wine.review: Only made in stellar vintages and a wine that's equally complex as it is unique. Full of cherries, leather, chestnuts and spice. A wine with incredible character that's drinking well but can still be stored for years.

wine.name: Marqués de Riscal Red
wine.review: Marqués de Riscal is Spain's oldest Bodega. The earthy nose gives way to a palate of cherries, strawberries and vanilla. The finish is long and luxurious. Try with stew, lamb or poultry.

wine.name: Montecillo Reserva
wine.review: Silky smooth with elegant fruit, fine dusty tannins and very pleasing complexity, this wine offers a classic expression of Rioja.

wine.name: Marqués de Murrieta Reserva, Rioja
wine.review: Marqués de Murrieta is traditional producer from the Rioja region of Spain, making wines of a classic style that are age-worthy. This Reserva, made from Tempranillo, Graciano, and Mazuelo, exhibits cedar, cigar box, and bright red fruit flavors, with lively, sweet tannins on the finish.

wine.name: Fiano di Avellino, Feudi San Gregorio
wine.review: Wines made from the Fiano variety have a gorgeous waxy texture and intriguing aromas of pine nuts, a specialty of Campania. Serve this with homemade pesto.

wine.name: Heitz Cabernet Sauvignon, Napa
wine.review: Heitz is a family-run winery that has been operating since the early 1960s, making classically styled wines that are at once both subtle in flavors and layered in complexity. This wine showcases the long growing season with dense dark cherry and currant fruit and a core of bright acidity. Vanilla and spice notes frame the wine, with well-integrated, fine-grained tannins to knit it all together. Drinking well already, and sure to offer pleasure for many, many years to come.

wine.name: Alamos Chardonnay
wine.review: Made at Catena Bodega Zapata, this Chardonnay exudes notes of tropical fruit, stone fruits and citrus with vanilla and spice on the creamy finish.

wine.name: Catena Chardonnay
wine.review: Argentina's great international success, Catena sets high standards for their wines. In fact, they've repeatedly skipped vintages when they felt the wines have been anything short of excellent. 2006 is a vintage that made the cut: this Chardonnay is loaded with toasty apples and great acidity.

wine.name: Muga Blanco Rioja
wine.review: Isaac Muga is one of Rioja's great characters and his wines share his exuberant personality. His white balances spicy oak and floral quince flavors. Medium-bodied and quite flavorful; enjoy this with zesty shrimp or chicken dishes.

wine.name: Warre's Warrior Special Reserve Port
wine.review: This port shows fragrant aromas of fruits and a rich palate dominated by sweet black fruits with a nice mineral finish. Enjoy this great-value ruby port any time. It goes well with aged cheddar and other dried fruits.

wine.name: Firestone Sauvignon Blanc
wine.review: Delightful Sauvignon Blanc from Santa Barbara, where a slightly cooler climate yields wines with ripe melon and citrus fruit. Blending barrel- and tank-fermented juice gives the final product richness as it retains its bright fruit. Very food-friendly.

wine.name: Brampton Chardonnay, South Africa
wine.review: A golden Chardonnay that mingles delicious floral aromas with a soft herbal note. The finish consists of pleasantly lingering vanilla.

wine.name: Steingrube Albalonga TBA, Wittmann
wine.review: Albalonga is a rather obscure, white grape variety that performs incredibly well in the Rheinhessen region of Germany. This is a dessert wine that's been made from naturally, vine-dried grapes.

wine.name: Viña Real Crianza CVNE
wine.review: Rich and smooth, this Rioja Crianza comes from a very traditional producer in Spain. CVNE was established in the late 1800s as a company that believed in maintaining tradition while using innovative techniques. Bright cherry flavors, balanced acidity, and notes of vanilla on the finish characterize this true Rioja.

wine.name: Thalassitis Santorini, Gai'a
wine.review: Coming from the Greek island of Santorini and made entirely from the indigenous Assyrtiko grape, this smoky white wine is simply a delight. Bright notes of honeysuckle and citrus play against a focused minerality.

wine.name: Montecillo Crianza, Viña Cumbrero
wine.review: An Astor favorite for years. Soft and smooth, with ripe cherry and mellow oak flavors that are great with a broad range of simply flavored meat and vegetable dishes.

wine.name: Marqués de Cáceres Red
wine.review: Lusciously fresh and fruity on the palate with strawberries and raspberries. A perfect accompaniment to paella, chorizo or ham.

wine.name: Marqués de Cáceres, Blanco
wine.review: An ideal wine to relax with as a delicious apéritif or to accompany seafood, grilled fish and shellfish. Also a great, dry white wine that works with sushi and sashimi dishes. Drink chilled.

wine.name: Tondonia Blanco Reserva, Lopez de Heredia
wine.review: A baby of a wine has intensely concentrated flavors of baked fruit and nuts that are reminiscent of white wines from the Jura. Tangy, leesy and complex. Superb balance and a long finish. Aged in wood for 10 years before bottle aging. Drink now or age for 30 more years.

wine.name: Marqués de Riscal Blanco
wine.review: Made from 85% Verdejo and 15% Viura grapes, this white is crisp and fruity with a floral bouquet. No oak is used, so the ripe fruit flavors come through beautifully.

wine.name: Quinta do Infantado Tawny Port
wine.review: Tawny port just doesn't get better than this one from Quinta do Infantado. Excellent body, rich with notes of roasted hazelnuts and sultanas followed by just a hint of sweetness. Simply delicious.

wine.name: Torres Sangre de Toro
wine.review: Abundantly fruity aroma suggestive of wild raspberries, with an earthy hint of spiciness. Generous and smooth on the palate.

wine.name: Torres Sangre de Toro
wine.review: Abundantly fruity aroma suggestive of wild raspberries, with an earthy hint of spiciness. Generous and smooth on the palate.

wine.name: Torres Coronas
wine.review: Rich fruit aroma, with a hint of vanilla from the oak aging. Torres' distinctive winemaking have earned them a sterling reputation and following.

wine.name: La Rioja Alta, Viña Ardanza Reserva
wine.review: The La Rioja Alta family was founded in 1890 by a group of families. Today, the descendents of these families are still involved with the winemaking. The Viña Ardanza is a blend of 80% Tempranillo and 20% Grenache. This wine is intense and spicy, with notes of red fruit, tobacco, and a toasty vanilla on the finish.

wine.name: Conde de Valdemar, Crianza
wine.review: One of Spain's most modern wineries, Valdemar is noted for their silky-smooth Riojas that balance ripe Tempranillo fruit with nicely toasty oak. Their Crianza is the pinnacle of their house style.

wine.name: Albariño, Martín Códax
wine.review: Spain's aromatic white Albariño grape flourishes in the northwestern province of Galicia, and nowhere are the results as impressive as in the Rías Baixas region. Delightfully crisp, vibrant, and floral, this seafood-friendly wine has lively fruit character with a flinty, minerally edge.

wine.name: Albariño, Burgans
wine.review: Soft and round, with bright tropical fruit and a nutty minerality. 100% Albariño from Galicia's Rías Baixas zone, this aromatic white wine is named for a hill called Burgans, which overlooks the Atlantic.

wine.name: Dorado Alvarinho
wine.review: A stunning example of Alvarinho with rich golden fruit, lean, fresh minerals, and a sense that the sea is somewhere nearby.

wine.name: Conde de Valdemar, Reserva
wine.review: Astonishing complexity and elegance for a wine at this price. This is a medium-bodied, dry red wine with subtle hints of cranberry, earth, and spice.

wine.name: Quinta dos Aciprestes, Douro
wine.review: From the steep hillsides of the Douro River valley, where the great fortified Ports are born, comes this lush, silky, dry red wine. Made up of a blend of deeply colored Port grapes, its rich plum flavors and black pepper notes are ideal with beef or lamb.

wine.name: La Rioja Alta Gran Reserva 904
wine.review: Made from Tempranillo and Graciano, this is La Rioja Alta's luxury cuvée. This bottling was created to commemorate the company's acquisition of the Viña Ardanza estate. Pristine notes of rose petal, red cherry, and earth.

wine.name: Krimskoye Sparkling Muscat
wine.review: Sparkling and nicely sweet.

wine.name: Viña Tondonia Reserva, Lopez de Heredia
wine.review: Wonderful velvety texture, great depth of fruit, finely balanced, in the flush of youth but with a great future ahead, should you choose to age this wine.

wine.name: Periquita, Fonseca
wine.review: Periquita (meaning "parakeet") is a flavorful red wine bearing the name of the most widely grown grape in the vast Terras do Sado region. A formidable structure makes this wine great with grilled meats or aged cheeses.

wine.name: Erdener Prälat Riesling Auslese, Mönchhof
wine.review: The success of a great Auslese, especially a great Mosel Auslese relies on a harmonious marriage of ripeness, acidity, and minerality. Experience them all here in this bottle from the Mönchhof family, whose history in the Mosel dates back to the 12th Century.

wine.name: Vinho Verde, Casal Garcia
wine.review: Trying to find a perfect summer white? Casal Garcia produces a nice light, fruity white Vinho Verde. Slightly effervescent with citrus notes. Perfect with seafood on a hot summer's day.

wine.name: Newton Claret
wine.review: A brilliant Bordeaux blend that's as dark in the mouth as it is in the glass. Blackcurrant, plums, and dark berries are the most prominent flavors, and smooth tannins linger on the finish of this great Napa Valley red.

wine.name: Cape Mentelle Sem-Sauv Blanc
wine.review: A fresh and flavorful wine with the honey lemon-limey aromas of Semillon married to the grassy and gooseberry flavors of sauvignon. One of the standout wines of Western Australia's Margaret River wine region.

wine.name: Warre's Otima, 10 Yr. Tawny Port
wine.review: Although much lighter than most ports, the aroma has dense caramel and walnut notes with a palate that has fresh, concentrated fruit.

wine.name: Rosemount Grenache-Shiraz
wine.review: Smooth yet spicy, sophisticated but earthy, this bright new wine has all the characteristics you'd expect from Rosemount--and at a great price too! Enjoy it with simple, flavorful meat, chicken or pasta dishes.

wine.name: d'Arenberg Shiraz, Footbolt
wine.review: Rich, full-flavored Shiraz sourced from late-19th-century vines in the heart of South Australia's McLaren Vale. Marvelous texture with plum, blackcurrant, and blueberry flavors paving the way to a long, rewarding finish.

wine.name: Cloudy Bay Sauvignon Blanc, New Zealand
Penfold's Cabernet "Bin 407," Australia
wine.review: Penfold's dark, chewy Cab displays extraordinary ripe fruit with a hint of the grape's firm tannins.

wine.name: Yalumba, Museum Muscat
wine.review: Long-established Yalumba winery, based in South Australia's Barossa Valley, produces a wide range of wines, including excellent stickies - or dessert wines.

wine.name: Selaks Ice Wine, New Zealand
wine.review: Selaks, a long-established family estate on New Zealand's north island, now has a second winery in Marlborough, where this luscious dessert wine is produced. A blend of Riesling and Gewürz, the wine's honeyed sweetness is balanced by fine acidity.

wine.name: Yering Station Pinot Noir
wine.review: With aromas of herbs, cherries, raspberries, and warm spices on the palate, this medium-bodied wine is quite stunning. Open a bottle tonight and you’ll immediately understand why Yering Station has received tremendous accolades in Australia this past year.

wine.name: Penfold's Shiraz-Cab. Sauvignon Koonunga Hill
wine.review: Launched in '76, this blend of Shiraz and Cabernet represents the value-driven introduction to Penfold's stellar line of Australian reds. Consistent high-quality has been achieved in a firm, fruity wine that also has great aging potential.

wine.name: Rosemount Shiraz
wine.review: Rosemount's "Diamond Label" Shiraz is one of Australia's most successful exports - and with good reason. Year after year, winemaker Philip Shaw delivers a smooth, silky wine with delicious fruit and spice flavors.

wine.name: Moscatel de Setúbal, Bacalhoa
wine.review: A rich and aromatic, sweet, fortified wine. Nicely balanced, offering fresh raisin-orange-citrus notes with hints of cinnamon. Drink chilled.

wine.name: Penfold's Bin 389 Cabernet-Shiraz
wine.review: Delightfully rich, fully ripe fruit onslaught and a lush, soft and supple smoothness in the finish. Fantastic winemaking!

wine.name: Penfold's Bin 707 Cabernet
wine.review: Penfold's' top-of-the-line Cabernet - remarkably dense and concentrated. Beautifully balanced with opulent fruit and toasty oak, Bin 707 has firm tannic structure. Grapes sourced from Coonawarra, the Barossa and Eden Valleys.

wine.name: Txakoli, Txomin Etxaniz
wine.review: In the Basque fishing village of Guetaria, the native Hondarribi vines grow on terraced slopes overlooking the Cantabrian Sea. They produce this fresh, slightly sparkling, very tart white that is ideal with fresh fish and shellfish.

wine.name: Viña Borgia, Campo de Borja
wine.review: One of the world's great wine bargains, this lush, smooth 100% Grenache from northeast Spain is perfect for parties. Enjoy with barbecue, grilled pork or chicken and zesty pasta dishes.

wine.name: St. John Commandaria Cyprus, Keo
wine.review: This traditional dessert wine is considered to be the oldest named wine still in production. Grapes that are indigenous to the island of Cyprus are picked late and dried on mats, in order to obtain maximum concentration and sweetness. Produced by the Solera system, this is a nutty wine with aromas of cocoa and baking spices.

wine.name: Leeuwin Riesling, Margaret River
wine.review: Riesling from Western Australia at its finest. Ripe peach aromas, medium-bodied and dry.

wine.name: Concha y Toro, Casillero del Diablo, Cab. Sauvignon
wine.review: This wine starts off with a good amount of wood, but then rounds out into a nicely ripe, well-balanced, fruity finish that is uncommon in any Cabernet Sauvignon at this price.

wine.name: Cousiño Macul Chardonnay
